It accomplishes this through activation of inhibitory neurones in the ventrolateral pre-optic area (vlPOA) which descend to the lateral hypothalamus and inhibit orexigenic neurones firing, causing the flip-flop to switch to sleep state to begin repaying the sleep debt. 

 

Source - Recommended reading; Carlson, Foundations of behavioural neuroscience.

Question:
You are a year 4 medical student on psychiatry placement. A patient presents to you for the second time, after having an episode of mania last year. The patient informs you that they have been well since recovering from their manic episode, however over the last week the patient has been feeling extremely low, finds that they have a lack of energy and have lost interest in the things they enjoy. 

 

After the consultation the doctor you are shadowing informs you that the patient will be diagnosed with Bipolar Affective Disorder (BPAD), and asks you to write down the nomenclature of the diagnosis. Which of the following correctly describes this patients diagnosis?
OptionE: BPAD type 2, current episode mixed affective state.
Explanation:
BPAD diagnosis requires at LEAST 2 episodes of mood disorder, with recovery usually occurring in between episodes. The nomenclature for BPAD diagnosis is; BPAD type X, current episode X. 

 

BPAD 1 - One episode MUST be mania. Plus episodes of; depression, hypomania or affective state.

BPAD 2 - One episode MUST be HYPOmania. Plus episodes of depression / hypomania. BPAD 2 can NOT include episodes of mania or mixed affective states. 

 

A - Incorrect ( patient is obviously suffering a depressive episode, so although BPAD 1 is correct, current episode is incorrect) 

B - Incorrect ( patient has had PREVIOUS episode of MANIA, therefore cannot be BPAD 2)

C - Incorrect ( again, previous episode of mania excludes BPAD 2 and current episode is not mania.)

D - CORRECT ( Patients previous episode or mania indicates type 1 BPAD, whilst their symptoms are the 3 core symptoms of depression.)

E - Incorrect ( BPAD 2 DOES NOT include episodes of mania or mixed affective state and therefore this is obviously incorrect.)

Question:
A 17 year old male attends the hospital presenting with lower back pain. The pain usually spreads across the lower back, and feels like a muscle strain. The pain is worse with vigorous exercise or activity. After an X-Ray the patient is found to have a fracture in the L5 vertebrae. The fracture is in the region pointed to by the arrow. He has no neurological symptoms.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Spondylolisthesis: The forward displacement of a vertebra, especially the fifth lumbar vertebra, most commonly occurring after a break or fracture. Backward displacement is referred to as retrolisthesis.

 

Spondylolysis: A defect in the pars interarticularis vertebra (Shown by the arrow). Most commonly occurs in the L5 vertebrae but can occur in both the lumbar and thoracic vertebrae. Although it commonly occurs in after repetitive trauma during strenuous sport, studies have shown a strong genetic link.

 

Spondylolytic Spondylolisthesis: Spondylolysis which results in spondylolisthesis

 

Spondylosis: Pain caused by degenerative changes in the spine

 

Spondylitis: Inflammation of the spine

 

The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Spondylolysis. If neurological symptoms had been present a complication of spondylolysis could have occurred called Spondylolytic Spondylolisthesis.
Tags: Anatomy, Birth Defects, Neurology, Genetics, Case 14

Question:
Mr Moody, a 19 year old medical student presents to his GP. He tells his GP that over the last few weeks (3-4weeks) he has not been feeling himself. He explains how he feels down all the time, and has lost interest in his hobbies such as playing rugby and going to the Lash (aka YOLO).

 

When further questioned he describes how he has a sudden loss of concentration and attention throughout all aspects of his day. He also informs his GP that he has stopped eating due to a lack of appetite and is not sleeping at all. 

 

His GP tells Mr Moody that he is experiencing a depressive episode however which type of episode is he experiencing?
Explanation:
Mr Moody is experiencing an episode of MODERATE depression, showing 2 core symptoms (anhedonia and persistent low mood) and 3 associated symptoms (loss of appetite, insomnia, loss of attention/concentration). The ICD-10 states that for an episode to be classed as depression the symptoms need to be present for 2 weeks or more.

 

Mild - 2 core + 2 associated

Moderate - 2 core + 3 associated

Severe - 3 core + 4 associated.

Severe with psychosis - Severe + mood congruent delusions/pyschomotor change/ perceptual abnormalities.

Dysthmia - Milder form of depression, with long-term low moods - present for 2 years or more (ICD10)

Question: The above karyogram illustrates the light and dark banding of the chromosomes in Giemsa staining, what differences in the chromatin account for this visual distinction?
Explanation:
Taken from Dr Andrew Fry's lecture in case 7 plenaries.

The dark bands show dense, condensed chromatin which is for his reason not transcriptionally active, these darks bands are AT (adenine thymine) rich which is why they appear dark as the giemsa stain has an affinity for regions of DNA with high AT bonding

 

Dark bands show areas of heterochromatin while light bands show areas of euchromatin

Question:
Mrs Scott is brought into the mental health ward by the police after being found wandering the streets of Cardiff claiming that she is being followed by an assassin. You review Mrs Scott and find; 

  • Auditory hallucinations (3rd person - running commentary)
  • Delusions of persecution
  • Thought insertion (the assassin is trying to make her kill her mother)

You note that she is exhibiting 3 of the core symptoms of schizophrenia and apart from this, note that there is no affective flattening, no catatonic symptoms and her speech is coherent. It is clear that the delusions and hallucinations are prominent. On consulting the oncall consultant they question your diagnosis of schizophrenia and ask which subtypes of schizophrenia Mrs Scott is exhibiting?
Explanation:
C - Correct. 

 

Paranoid schizophrenia --> exhibit symptoms for schizophrenia diagnosis. Hallucinations and delusions of grandiose or persecution are prominent. Affective flattening, incoherent speech and catatonia are not usually part of clinical picture and if present and very subtle. Paranoid schizophrenia is most common subtype in UK.

 

Catatonic schizophrenia --> Motion/movement symptoms are most prominent. Can include waxy flexibility (where you move patient limb into position and they maintain this position), command automatism (where say command and they perform command) and negativism (where they appear motionless but ignore commands and resist any movement from their current position).

 

Hebephrenic Schizophrenia --> Hallucinations/delusions are NOT part of main presentation. Symptoms indicative of hebephrenic schizophrenia include behaviour being disorganized and without purpose, thoughts disorganized and patients often play pranks, giggle a lot and have numerous health complaints.

 

Undifferentiated schizophrenia --> When a patient exhibits signs from more than one of the above classification and therefore does not fit into any of these classes.

 

Residual schizophrenia --> patient would have met criteria for schizophrenia diagnosis however they currently DO NOT meet this criteria. Negative symptoms of schizophrenia are prominent in these patients. (Anhedonia/Apathy(Avoltion)/ Alogia/ Attention deficit/ Affective flattening)

Question: A 35 year old G2 P2 has two children both of whom have Down syndrome. Karyotyping of the father reveals a no abnormalities and of the mother reveals a Robersonian translocation between 21:21 what is the likelihood of any subsequent children having Down syndrome?
OptionB: ~1% or maternal age risk if greater
OptionC: ~10% or maternal age risk if higher
Explanation:
In Robersonain translocation of 21:21 all children will either inherit no maternal copies of chromosome 21 which will result in monosomy 21 a non viable outcome or will inherit the two fused maternal copies of 21 and another copy from the father resulting in trisomy 21 and Down syndrome. 

The most common translocation resulting in Down syndrome is that between 14 and 21 and can have a number of outcomes for future offsrping if assuin the other parent is normal:

  1. viable:
  • normal 14,14,21,21
  • normal carrier 14,14/21,21
  • Down syndrome 14,14/21,21,21
  1. non viable
  • monosmy 21
  • monosmy 14
  • trisomy 14

               The risk of recurrence

  • non disjunction-1% or age related risk if higher, 10% after 2 T21 pregnancies
  • translocation-10-15% dependent on translocation, low if the transloaction occurs in he male possibly as it is selectively disadvantageous, 100% if 21:21 as the offspring can only inherit either monosomy 21 therefore non viable or trisomy 21 therefore Down syndrome
  • mosaicism-1-2% or are related risk if higher

All information taken from Dr Andrew Fry's plenary in case 7 plenaries
Tags: Screening, Development, Birth Defects, Embryology, Genetics

Question: What cytokine, produced by sentinel cells (macrophages and dendritic cells) is most likely to activate Natural Killer cells of the innate immune response to a virus
Explanation: Taken from case 9, immunology lecture 1, James Matthews

Question:
Connie is a 26 year old woman of Caribbean descent who is pregnant with her first child. She has gone to see her community midwife for her booking appointment.

 

The midwife takes some blood from Connie for testing; what is being looked for in these blood tests?
OptionA: The tests are to determine Connie's blood group and her Rhesus group.
OptionB: The tests are to determine Connie's blood group, Rhesus group and to see whether her baby is at risk of any congenital infections.
OptionC: The tests are to determine Connie's blood group, her Rhesus group, to see if she carries a sickle cell gene, and to see if her baby is at risk of congenital infections.
OptionD: The tests are to determine whether Connie's baby is at risk of congenital infections.
Explanation: -Booking blood tests normally test for a FBC, blood group, Rhesus group and for any infections that could be passed on congenitally, such as HIV or syphilis. Because Connie is of Caribbean descent, there's more of a chance that she might be a carrier of a sickle cell gene, this would be picked up by a screening questionnaire and she would be offered the test for sickle cell. The ideal time for the sickle cell test is before 10 weeks of pregnancy.

Question: Marigold Border is a 9 month old child, who is thought to be developing typically. Which of the following is a typical combination of developmental milestones you would expect Marigold to exhibit?
OptionA:
Vision - interested in objects, able to recognise hidden objects, develops a fear of strange faces

 

Speech and Language - able to pretend play, has an increasing understanding of everyday words

 

Social - able to help with being dressed
OptionB:
Motor - can roll supine to prone, crawls

 

Vision - interested in objects, able to recognise hidden objects, develops a fear of strange faces

 

Social - can put out arms to be held
OptionC:
Vision - can recognise faces in a photo and is able to "read" the pictures in storybooks

 

Speech and Language - can respond to own name and basic commands such as "no", waves and claps

 

Social - can put out arms to be held
OptionD:
Vision - interested in objects, able to recognise hidden objects, develops a fear of strange faces

 

Speech and Language - can respond to own name and basic commands such as "no", waves and claps

 

Motor - can roll prone to supine but not supine to prone, cannot crawl
OptionE:
Speech and Language - can respond to own name and basic commands such as "no", waves and claps

 

Motor - can roll supine to prone, crawls

 

Vision - can recognise faces in a photo and is able to "read" the pictures in storybooks
Explanation:
*Every child will develop differently and at different paces.The Developmental Milestones are what most children should be doing by that age, but if a child is not exhibiting a milestone it's not a huge concern. If a child is massively behind in development or has not reached milestones in several areas, that is more of a worry and should be investigated.*

 

A = Both the Vision and Speech and Language are typical of a 9 month old, but the Social milestone is something that is much more likely from a 2 year old. 

B = the correct answer, all 3 are typical of 9 month olds.

C = Vision - unlikely a 9 month old would be able to do this, more likely from a 2 year old. The Speech and Language and Social are expected for a 9 month old. 

D = Vision and Speech and Language typical of 9 month old. Motor is more likely of a 3 month old as most 9 month olds can crawl

E = Speech and Language and Motor typical of 9 month old, Vision more likely of a 2 year old

 

Source - Child Development lecture from Case 9 (lists all the Milestones at different ages)

Question: In an excitable cell, what is the equilibrium potential (mV) of Sodium at rest?
Explanation:
Equilibrium potentials can be derived from the Nernst equation

 

Sodium has a positive resting equilibrium potential which depending on sources is around 40-55 mV

Potassium has a negative resting potential which is around -90mV and is closest to the resting potential value as the membrane is much more permeable to potassium

Chloride ions have a negative resting potential which is around -70mV

Question: In an action potential in an excitable cell, what causes hyperpolarisation?
OptionE: A combination of all of the above
Explanation: The delayed rectifier potassium channels which are activated during an action potential, increase the permeability of potassium such that potassium rushes into the cell, restoring the resting potential. However these can be slow to deactivate meaning it "overshoots" the resting potential causing hyperpolarisation.

Question: In the Simpsons episode "One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish" Homer consumes incorrectly prepared Fugu pufferfish which contained Tetrodotoxin, a neurotoxin. What is its mechanism of action?
Explanation: Tetrodotoxin was mentioned along with TEA+ (another neurotoxin) in one of the PCS lectures on Nerves and APs

Question: Which of the following hormones is most likely to bind to an intracellular receptor?
Explanation: Intracellular receptors require the hormone to be able to permeate through the cell membrane. As oestrogen is a steroid hormone which is a family of hormones with a lipid basis. The rest of the hormones are peptide based so you would not expect them to have intracellular receptors. Steroid receptors, along with Thyroid hormone receptors form most of the intracellular hormone receptor group.

Question: Which of the following activates adenylyl cyclase?
Which class in the Baltimore Scheme does the Influenza virus belong to?
Explanation: Influenza is a negative single stranded RNA virus. This means that its genetic code contains an "antisense" strand of RNA which is complementary to the base sequence necessary for it to function. For this reason it carries it's own RNA dependent RNA polymerase enzyme which synthesises the complementary strand of RNA needed. The virus is then able to replicate.

Question: You are on the Megabus to Cardiff when a woman screams that she is in labour. As a 2nd year medical student, you rush to her aid only to find that the woman's husband is in control of the situation. However, you realise that this poses an excellent opportunity to think about the stages of labour. The husband says that he can "see the head". What is the next fetal movement that will take place as the fetus navigates the birth canal?
Explanation:
In a normal, cephalic presentation at labour the movements of the fetus to navigate the birth canal can be remembered using the mnemonic - Do Frogs in Cardiff Ever Ride in APink Limo?

 

D - Descent

F - Flexion

I - Internal Rotation

C - Crowning

E - Extension

R - Restitution

I - Internal Rotation

A - Anterior shoulder delivered

P - Posterior shoulder delivered

L - Lateral Flexion

 

The husband is describing crowning as the baby's head exits the birth canal. The next stage is therefore extension.

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=duPxBXN4qMg

Question: You are still on the Megabus to Cardiff. The baby has been safely delivered and the mother is well. However you are aware that labour is not over yet and the placenta and membranes still need to be delivered. Which of the following is not a sign that this stage of labour has begun?
OptionC: Change in uterine shape from discoid to globular.
OptionD: Increased frequency and strength of uterine contractions.
Explanation:
The final stage of labour concerns the delivery of the placenta and its membranes. This may be shown by a gush of blood, cord lengthening and a change in uterine shape from discoid to globular.

 

Increasing frequency and strength of uterine contractions occurs during the first stage of labour.

Question: You are a GP working in the afternoon immunisation clinic and are administering routine flu vaccines. Which of the following patients is the flu vaccine not indicated in ?
OptionC: 55 year old male who is receiving weekly dialysis.
OptionE: 28 year old female primary school teacher
Explanation:
The flu vaccine is indicated in the following circumstances:

 

Clinical Risk Groups: Chronic respiratory (including asthma), cardiovascular, hepatic, neurological or renal disease. Diabetes or immunosuppressed patients.

Age 65 or over

Pregnant Women

Carers of the elderly or disabled.

People in long term care

People involved in direct patient care.

 

Children are often vaccinated with the flu vaccine since they are the most transmissible vectors of the virus. Therefore, the primary school teacher is at low risk anyway of contracting the flu and is not indicated in the above guidelines to receive the vaccine.

 

Immunisation Lecture

Question: As a 2nd year medical student which vaccinations should you have received from occupational health?
Explanation:
As a medical student and future healthcare professional you should have received your BCG, MMR, HBV and Influenza vaccines. Varicella is the vaccine for chicken pox. Most people will have experienced this first hand as children so are not all necessarily vaccinated but this will be noted in your immunisation record. If you have not received it, or any of the other correct vaccines contact occy health!

 

Immunisation lecture.

Question: A 22 year old lady is admitted to hospital following failure to correctly manage her insulin regime resulting in her developing DKA. Blood tests reveal a blood pH of 7.00, bicarbonate of 10mmol/l and the presence of ketones. What is the normal physiological range of blood pH?
Explanation:
The normal blood pH lies between 7.35 and 7.45, anything lower can be classed as an acidosis and anything higher an alkalosis. 

Typically:

  1. In metabolic acidosis the pH is decreased, CO2 remains around the same and bicarbonate is decreased
  2. In respiratory acidosis the pH is decreased, CO2 is raised and bicarbonate remains around the same
  3. IN metabolic alkalosis the pH is increased, CO2 remains around the same and bicarbonate is raised
  4. In respiratory alkalosis the pH is increased, CO2 is decreased and bicarbonate remains around the same

Question: Phosphodiesterase inhibitors have a number of therapeutic benefits. Which of the following is a function of phosphodiesterase?
Explanation: Phosphodiesterases are a group of enzymes which degrade the phosphodiester bond in cAMP and cGMP. The enzymes are therefore important in regulating these secondary messengers. Phosphodiesterase inhibitors will lead to potentiated effects of cAMP and cGMP.

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding deflections occurring in depolarization and repolarization on the ecg
OptionA:
Depolarization towards lead=+ve deflection

Depolarization away from lead=-ve deflection

Repolarization towards lead=-ve deflection

Repolarization away from lead=+ve deflection
OptionB:
Depolarization towards lead=-ve deflection
Depolarization away from lead=+ve deflection
Repolarization towards lead=n+ve deflection
Repolarization away from lead=-ve deflection
OptionC:
Depolarization towards lead=+ve deflection
Depolarization away from lead=+ve deflection
Repolarization towards lead=-ve deflection
Repolarization away from lead=-ve deflection
OptionD:
Depolarization towards lead=-ve deflection
Depolarization away from lead=-ve deflection
Repolarization towards lead=+ve deflection
Repolarization away from lead=+ve deflection
OptionE: ECG's make no sense at all to me
Explanation:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MJPt8hUdnt0

 

From the recommended reading for case 13, nice clear explanation of the basics of ecg formation found it really helpful. Knowing this and the position of the leads relative to the heart can help us predict the the form of readout the lead will record.

The greater the muscle mass (muscle mass is greater in the left ventricle than the right) the greater the influence on deflections seen in the leads. In this way although the wave of repolarization in the right ventricle is spreading away from V1, the greater muscle mass of the left ventricle means that the repolarization wave is larger and therefore exerts it's influence (replarization away from V6 and towrds V1) on V1 as seen by the negative deflection in this lead as oposed to the positive deflection you would expect to see with repolarization moving away from the lead. The same principle applies in all cases the bigger the muscle mass the greater the influence!
Tags: The ECG, Thorax, Case 13, Heart, Year 1 Revision

Question: An increase secretion of renin would be expected to have what effect on sodium excretion and potassium excretion in urine?
OptionA: increase in Na+ excretion and increase K+ excretion
OptionB: increase in Na+ excretion and decrease K+ excretion
OptionC: decrease in Na+ excretion and increase K+ excretion
OptionD: decrease in Na+ excretion and decrease K+ excretion
OptionE: decrease in Na+ excretion but no effect on K+ excretion
Explanation: The answer is C. By increasing renin there will eventually be a rise in aldosterone, which increases Na-K pumping (antiport) in the renal distal tubule and collecting duct. Thus, Na reabsorption will increase (reduce excretion) and K secretion will increase (increase excretion).

Question: How much CSF, on average, is produced daily?
Explanation: C - figures vary from 450-500mL for an average person.

Question: How does CSF flow from the lateral ventricles (first and second ventricles) into the third ventricle?
Explanation:
A - foramina of Monro allows access between the lateral ventricles and the third ventricle. 

B -  cerebral aquaduct allows third ventricle to communicate with the fourth ventricle

C - is part of the middle cranial fossa, and is associated with the hypophysial fossa (in which the pituitary gland resides)

D - Cavernous sinuses are part of the venous system of the brain

E - Who doesn't like Alanddin references?

Question: You're an SHO in A&E and receive a patient who has had a nasty whack over the head when being mugged; you're especially worried because the impact site is on the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery path. Where is the impact site?
Explanation:
A - the glabella is the surface of the frontal bone immediately superior to the nasal bone,

B - correct, it is the site where several bones connect (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid) and behind it the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery passes. 

C - is of the occipital bone, and is a site of origin of the trapezius, 

D - of temporal bone, 

E - part of the zygomatic part of temporal bone and the zygomatic bone.

Question: You're absolutely shattered after a long night... studying, and arrive on placement to find an equally grumpy surgical consultant. Seeing you he barks, "You, the sleepy looking one; what's a comminuted fracture?" Your reaction is?
OptionA: A fracture where the bone is shattered into multiple fragments
OptionD: a fracture of the contralateral side of the cranium to the impact site
OptionE: Give up, with a whimper and go back to a lovely warm bed
Explanation:
A - http://radiologymasterclass.co.uk/tutorials/musculoskeletal/trauma/trauma_x-ray_page2.html 

 

C - made up the bones, 

D - is a linear calvarial fracture

E - the second best answer

Question: What is unusual about the sympathetic innervation of the adrenal gland?
OptionC: There is no sympathetic innervation of the adrenal gland
OptionD: The ganglion is very close to the adrenal gland making a very short post-ganglionic fibre
Explanation: Typically preganglionic fibres synapse onto their ganglia, before a postganglionic fibre continues to the effector.

Question: How do benzodiazepines work?
OptionB: Agonists of GABA A and B receptors
Explanation: They are not agonists, per se, instead they act as positive modulators, whereby they increase the activity but by action in accessory sites. AMPA receptors are a type of glutamate receptor.

Question: What does the falx cerebri divide?
OptionE: divides the frontal and parietal lobes, from the temporal lobes
Explanation:
C - falx cerebelli 

D - there is no pituitary lobe

E - Sylvian fissure

Question: The 5 in 1 vaccine given to children first at 3 months provides protection against which childhood diseases/viruses?
OptionA: Diptheria, Tetanus, Polio, Pneumococcal Disease, Haemophilus Influenzae B
OptionB: Diptheria, Tetanus, Whooping Cough, Polio, Haemophilus Influenzae B
Explanation:
At 3 months an infant should receive their first set of vaccinations as part of the UK routine immunisation schedule. This consists of 3 separate vaccines: the 5 in 1 vaccine, PCV (Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine) and Rotarix (Rotavirus vaccine). The 5 in 1 vaccine consists of:

 

dTap, IPV and Hib - Diptheria, Tetanus, Acellular Pertussis (Whooping cough), Inactivated Polio virus and Haemophilus Influenzae B (Can cause meningitis and pneumonia).

Question: Which of the following is true about vaccination?
OptionA: Giving too many vaccines at once can harm the immune system.
OptionB: Homeopathy is an effective alternative method to vaccination.
OptionC: Vaccines should not be given if a child has a fever on the day of vaccination.
OptionD: The MMR should not be given if a child has a minor egg allergy.
OptionE: Anaphylaxis is a real and common side effect of vaccination.
Explanation:
A - There is no evidence to suggest that giving multiple vaccines at once can harm the immune system and there is no proven evidence to suggest that giving single vaccines is advantageous. If anything, giving single vaccines means that more appointments need to be made which can be missed meaning that a child may not receive all of their required vaccinations.

 

B - Homeopathy works on the principle that "like cures like" and if a substance that causes disease is given in a tiny quantity as a serial dilution it can also cure disease. The practice often uses herbal remedies as a means of treating disease. Although many people use this practice there is no evidence to suggest it works or can provide any protection from disease. It is not a proven safe or effective alternative to vaccination.

 

C - CORRECT. Vaccines should not be given to children who have any illness accompanied by a fever on the day of vaccination. Vaccines can be given when a child has a cough/cold but no fever. If a fever is present, the vaccination should be rescheduled.

 

D -  The MMR vaccine is cultured in chick embryos. It can be given if the child has a minor egg allergy and is only contraindicated if there is evidence of a previous serious anaphylactic reaction to egg. If there is still concern it should be administered in a setting where there are resources to handle anaphylaxis if it occurs.

 

E - Anaphylactic reaction is a possible side effect of vaccination but is extremely rare.

Question: What is the most commonly reported side effect of ACE inhibitors?
Explanation: Whilst GI upsets are fairly common potential side effects of many drugs, patients on ACE inhibitors regularly complain of a dry cough.

Question: You are performing a spinal examination and you note that your patient has lost sensation over their regimental badge area. Which nerve root is likely to be affected?
Explanation: The sensation of the regimental badge is provided by C5.

Question: Pregnant women of what age group should be automatically offered screening for Down syndrome?
OptionE: Should be offered regardless of maternal age
Explanation: Screening for Down syndrome should be offered regardless of maternal age!Taken from case 7 lecture on foetal anomaly screening.

Question: A 22 year old man is rushed into A&E after a motorcycle crash with a suspected cervical spine injury. Which of these is NOT part of the 'TAVOS' mnemonic for assessing cervical spine trauma?
Explanation:
The 'O' in 'TAVOS' is Odontoid Peg

 

The mnemonic details all the things that you should be able to see and test for to assess whether the image is normal.

 

C6/C7 is the most common site for trauma fractures.

 

The hypothetical motorcyclist was discharged with no evidence of C-spine trauma. It was determined that his sore neck was from an overindulgence in Sian Williams' eTutorials.

Question: A parent presents to you with their 4 year old child. The child has a fever, lethargy and anorexia. You suspect the child has a virus. What advice does NICE suggest you give the parent regarding treating their child's fever with antipyretics (e.g. paracetamol and ibuprofen)?
OptionA: Antipyretics should always be used to reduce fever in children.
OptionB: Antipyretics should never be used to reduce fever in children.
OptionC: Antipyretics can be used, but should only be used if the child is distressed.
OptionD: Antipyretics should be used if the child's temperature exceeds 38C.
OptionE: Antipyretics should only be used under medical supervision.
Explanation:
Fever enhances cellular and biochemical process involved in the immune response. It enhances bactericidal activity of neutrophils, enhances the antiviral effects of interferon, enhances the proliferative response of lymphocytes and enhances antibody production. Fever is therefore improving the immune response to infection. Fevers can cause discomfort though and can be associated with shivering, sweating, headaches, myalgia, anorexia, dehydration, malaise and lethargy. Very high temperatures (above 39.4C) can cause hallucinations, confusion, irritability, convulsions and dehydration and fevers above 41C can be life threatening. 

 

NICE recommends that antipyretics should be considered for use if the child appears to be distressed but shouldn't be used for the sole aim of reducing fever. Antipyretics do not prevent febrile convulsions and shouldn't be used preventively for this. If using anti-pyretics to reduce discomfort they should only be used for the length of time that the child is distressed and then should be stopped.

Question: A 78 year grandmother attends your GP surgery with her 4 month old grandchild. Both grandmother and grandchild are here to receive their pneumococcal vaccine. Which of the following best describes how you would deal with this?
OptionA: Give both grandmother and grandchild the pneumococcal conjugated vaccine.
OptionB: Give both the grandchild and grandmother the polysaccharide pneumococcal vaccine.
OptionC: Give the grandmother the conjugated pneumococcal vaccine and the grandchild the polysaccharide pneumococcal vaccine.
OptionD: Give the grandmother the polysaccharide pneumococcal vaccine and the grandchild the conjugated pneumococcal vaccine.
OptionE: Give grandmother and grandchild either, it doesn't matter which they receive.
Explanation:
Pneumococcus (aka Strep. Pneumoniae) is a bacterium known to cause pneumonia and meningitis in some. The polysaccharide pneumococcal vaccine is given to adults. The conjugated pneumococcal vaccine is given to children.

 

Polysaccharide antigens (like in the polysaccharide pneumococcal vaccine) illicit a T cell independent immune response. T cells can only respond to peptides presented to them on MHC. If there is no peptide element to the vaccine T cells will therefore not be involved. B cells can still produce an antibody response without T cell help but in children under the age of two the immune response to polysaccharide, this T cell independent process, is poor and does not lead to adequate immunity, hence why the polysaccharide vaccine is not used on children.

 

The conjugated vaccine contains the polysaccharide conjugated to a protein. The protein allows T cells to become involved and allows a T cell dependent immune response to take place. This allows the children to generate an adequate immune response to the vaccine.

Question: What are the three cardinal signs of high left arterial pressure?
OptionC: Breathlessness, fatigue and rapid or irregular heart beat
OptionE: Breathlessness, oedema and persistent cough or wheezing with white or pink blood-tinged phlegm
Explanation: Taken from Case 15 Plen 2 (Alan Fraser) - diagnosing heart failure.

Question: A 74-year-old male presents with gout. His blood tests show hyponatraemia and hypokalaemia. Two months previously he had been started on a new medication for heart failure and underlying ischaemic heart disease. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his gout?
Explanation: The answer is B - the loop diuretic furosemide. It blocks the NaKCl channel in the thick ascending loop which means that the ions stay in the urine --> water moves from blood to urine --> rapid high volume diuresis which can result in hyponatraemia and hypokalaemia as this guy is passing these ions out in his urine. kumar and clarke and dr coffeys lecture.

Question: A 22-year-old woman is heard to have splitting of the second heart sound on a routine insurance medical check. What may it be associated with?
Explanation: Second heart sound (S2) is due to aortic and pulmonary valve closure. Physiological splitting of S2 occurs during inspiration in children and young adults. - Kumar and Clark

Question: You've just had a eureka moment when you realise that there are three leads in the 12 lead ECG that are perpendicular to one another and are called the orthogonal leads as shown in the diagram below. Which leads are they?
Explanation: The answer is D - V2 is on the horizontal plane and gives a septal view of the heart, lead I is on the frontal plane and gives a lateral view of the heart and aVF is also along the frontal plane and gives an inferior view of the heart. Hopefully this puts things into perspective/helps with spatial understanding of the ECG.

Question:
A mother brings her child in to see you to have its development assessed. The child is able to roll supine to prone and is able to crawl. You see that the child is able to cast objects away and responds to his own name. The mother reports that the child can feed himself with his hands although not with a spoon and that he points to things that he wants. You confirm that the child's development is normal for a child his age. 

 

Which of the following is the best estimation of the child's age?
Explanation:
Other things that you would expect of a 9 month old include:

  • Pulling to stand with support
  • Transferring objects hand to hand
  • Interested in pictures
  • Recognising hidden objects
  • Puts arms out to be held
  • Stranger anxiety
  • Interested in watching other children

Question: A 65 year old man attends your GP surgery. He says his wife has sent him as she believes he needs vaccinations because of his age. You confirm that he is entitled to vaccines because of his age. Which of the following are the vaccinations that you recommend he has?
Explanation: Shingles vaccine is only offered to people aged over 70. People can either have the vaccine when they are 70 or if they have not had it age 70 they can have it aged 78 or 79 as a catch up.

Question:
Which of these phases of the viral life cycle is the most common therapeutic target?

 

CLUE: Aciclovir is a well known example of a drug that targets this phase
Explanation:
C is correct! - Aciclovir is an example of a viral replication inhibitor

 

There are 6 phases of the viral life cycle (5 shown here):

 

1. Viral entry - often receptor mediated (via endocytosis)

 

2. Uncoating - unpacking of the genome

 

3. Genome replication

 

4. Protein synthesis

 

5. Assembly

 

6. Virus-egress - via budding or lysis

 

 

Content reference: Dr Rugert's 1st lecture on virology

 

Image reference: http://img.medscape.com/article/746/132/746132-fig1.jpg

Question:
Viruses are second only to smoking as a risk factor for cancer. Various viruses are associated with the development of cancer.

 

Which of the following is most likely associated with the development of cancer?
Explanation:
Most cancer causing viruses are DNA viruses or produce DNA during replication (e.g the retroviruses). Hepatitis C virus is an exception in that it is an RNA virus that does not produce DNA during replication but is associated with malignancy, however it is thought that it does this indirectly through it's damage to hepatocytes leading to inflammation, hyperplasia and cirrhosis. 

 

HIV is unique as a retrovirus in that it does not induce malignancy. Obviously its effects on the immune system will leave the patient with an increased risk of cancer as their immune system is weakened but the HIV virus itself isn't inducing malignancy.

 

Viruses associated with cancer include:

Hep B virus

Hep C virus

Papilloma viruses (e.g HPV and cervical cancer)

Retroviruses (not HIV)

Epstein Barr virus (associated with lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma)

Question: Which of the following is least likely to be observed in a left ventricle diagnosed with combined systolic and diastolic dysfunction?
Explanation:
It is not uncommon in chronic heart failure to have a combination of both systolic and diastolic dysfunction. Therefore, the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR) is decreased and the slope of the passive filling curve (reciprocal of compliance) is increased in the ventricular pressure-volume loop shown to the right. When this occurs, there is a dramatic reduction in stroke volume because end-systolic volume is increased and end-diastolic volume are decreased. Both ejection fraction and stroke work are also decreased.
This combination of systolic and diastolic dysfunction, coupled with compensatory volume expansion, can lead to very high end-diastolic pressures that can cause pulmonary congestion and edema, as well as systemic edema and ascites (particularly when the right ventricle is in failure). Therefore, diuretic drugs are commonly used in these patients.

 

 

http://www.cvphysiology.com/Heart%20Failure/HF007%20PV%20loop%20diastolic-systolic%20failure.gif

Question: Which of the following statements is true of the histology of the fallopian tube, when travelling from the infundibulum towards the interstitium (inwards towards the uterus)?
OptionB: Ciliated cells are replaced by peg cells
OptionD: The muscularis layer becomes thinner and less pronounced
OptionE: The height of the epithelial cells increases
Explanation:
A - The lumen becomes narrower travelling inwards from the infundibulum. 

B - This is correct. Ciliated cells waft the ovum through the fallopian tube into the ampulla for fertilisation, and into the uterus for implantation. Closer to the uterus, the muscularis layer of the fallopian tube wall is thicker and takes over this role so fewer ciliated cells are required. Peg cells secrete a fluid that sustains spermatozoa, oocytes and zygotes and promotes capacitation. Therefore more of these are needed closer to the uterus, as if conception has occurred it is essential that the zygote is sustained before it enters the uterus.

C - The plicae (the folds of the lumen) become less complex heading towards the uterus.

D - As already mentioned, the muscularis layer (which comprises an inner layer of circular muscle and an outer layer of longitudinal muscle) becomes thicker and more pronounced as the fallopian tube heads towards the interstitium. 

E - The height of the epithelial cells (as well as the position of the nuclei of the peg cells) alters with the menstrual cycle, but does not change according to position within the fallopian tube.

 

Sources: Leeds Histology and 'Pathology of the Female Reproductive Tract'

Question: In which area of the fallopian tube does fertilisation most commonly occur?
Explanation: F is the ovary.

Question: Which of the following is a cause of Prader-Willi syndrome?
OptionA: Lack of expression of the maternal allele of UBE3A
Explanation:
The UBE3A gene is an imprinted gene present on chromosome 15. This means that there is difference in the dominance of maternal and paternal alleles of this gene in different organs. The paternal allele is silenced in the brain and the maternal allele is silenced elsewhere in the body.

 

Lack of expression of the maternal allele due to a deletion or mutation of part or whole of chromosome 15, paternal uniparental disomy and imprinting defects are all causes of Angelman syndrome. This is because if there is something wrong with the maternal allele then there will be no UBE3A allele acting within the brain (as the paternal allele is silenced here). 

 

Lack of expression of the paternal allele due to a deletion or mutation of part or whole of chromosome 15, maternal uniparental disomy and imprinting defects are all causes of Prader-Willi syndrome. This is because if there is something wrong with the paternal allele then there will be no UBE3A allele acting within organs throughout the body (as the maternal allele is silenced here). 

 

Trisomy 15 is a condition that is compatible with life, but neither Angelman syndrome nor Prader-Willi syndrome result because there is an excess of UBE3A rather than a lack of the gene.

 

Uniparental disomy is the phenomenon by which both copies of a chromosome are inherited by one parent.

 

The typical symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome are feeding problems in infancy, excessive weight gain from age 1 - 6 years, narrow shaped face and almond shaped eyes, global development delay and mild to moderate learning difficulties.

 

 

Sources: 'Genetics and Conditional Probability' and 'Congenital Malformations and Teratology' lectures from Case 7

Question:
A medical student revises the contents of semen.

That evening, he writes this question in the hope of remembering it better.

 

Which of these does not contribute to the composition of semen?
Explanation:
Bulbourethral glands - %1 contribution - Mucus to increase sperm mobility

 

Prostate - 25-30% - Citric acid, acid phosphatase, prostate specific enzyme, zinc (stabilises chromatin which contains DNA), proteolytic enzymes

 

Seminal vesicle - 65-75% - Citrate, amino acids, flavins, fructose (energy source), Prostaglandins, Vitamin C

 

Testes - 2-5% - 200-500 million spermatazoa per ejaculation

 

The epididymis only stores sperm

Question: Which of these neurotransmitters may be a ligand for ionotropic receptors within the CNS?
Explanation:
All of these neurotransmitters are only neuromodulators within the CNS, with the exception of GABA.  This means they do not directly cause a change in the postsynaptic potential when they are released, by causing opening of ion channels - neuromodulators bind to metabotropic receptors, which are often G-protein coupled, resulting in intracellular second signalling cascades.

 

GABA is the ligand for two major subtypes of receptor: GABA-a and GABA-b receptors.  GABA-a receptors are ionotropic, causing hyperpolarisation in the postsynaptic membrane due to ion channel opening, while GABA-b receptors are metabotropic, coupled to a Gi protein.

 

Sources: Dr Lisa Wallace's Neuropharmacology lecture, Rang and Dale's Pharmacology.

Question: A 25 year old is prescribed Trimethoprim following a diagnosis of a urinary tract infection. What is the mechanism of this antibiotic?
Explanation:
A- Mechanism of Fluoroquinolones e.g Ciprofloxacin, Metrozindazole 

B- Mechanism of B lactam antibiotics e.g Penicillin 

C- Correct- type of Co-trimoxazole 

D- Mechanism of Isoniazid

E- Mechanism of Macrolides, Aminoglycosides, Tetracyclins, Chloramphenicol

Question: What is the anterior surface of the heart composed of?
OptionA: Right ventricle, right atrium, left ventricle and some of left auricle.
OptionB: Left ventricle, left atrium and right ventricle.

Question: What type of cardiomyopathy is most likely associated with diastolic dysfunction?
Explanation:
A- ARVC- characterised by fibro-fatty infiltration, ventricular dilatation and hyper-trabeculation 

B- characterised by cardiac enlargement with reduced systolic function 

C- Correct! Ventricular hypertrophy > chamber stiffness: diastolic dysfunction 

D- characterised by normal cardiac size, reduced systolic dysfunction and bi-atrial dilatation 

E- All other types not classified! - other types unclassified could cause diastolic dysfunction, but main classified is HCM

 

Case 15 lecture- non-ischaemic cardiomyopathies

Question: Bob has just returned from his travels exploring the world and has come back with more than just happy memories. The doctor explains that the nature of the cause of his diarrhoea is protozoal, given this information what is the most likely causative agent?
Explanation: According to the week 11 lecture Giarda is the biggest single cause of protozoal diarrhoeal infection and is found worldwide. The others are not protozoa!

Question: A 21 year old female attends your GP surgery. Over the past 2 weeks she has been complaining of feeling increasingly tired and has also found herself having to pass water much more frequently. This has made her incredibly thirsty. She has also admitted to some weight loss. You suspect a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes and decide to take some bloods. Which blood results would confirm a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes ?
Explanation: A clinical diagnosis of type 1 diabetes can be made where the 3 cardinal symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia and weight loss co-exist with a random blood glucose level > 11mmoll-1 and a fasting blood glucose level > 7mmoll-1. Other symptoms may include fatigue, thrush infections and general malaise. A HbA1c may also be a useful diagnostic test and is indicative of type 1 diabetes if >7.5%.

Question:
A patient has angular stomatitis, koilonychia (spoon shaped nails) and glossitis with black spots on the tongue.

 

Which vitamin or mineral are they most likely deficient in?
Explanation:
Deficiency of most of the B vitamins can cause angular stomatitis and glossitis but glossitis with black spots and koilonychia are indicative of Fe deficiency.

Vitamin C deficiency will lead to scurvy with bleeding, swollen gums, joint and muscle pain and general weakness and tiredness.

Question: Upon sensing a virus, macrophages produce a range of cytokines. Which cytokine is responsible for activating natural killer cells?
Explanation:
IL-6, TNF-a and IL-1B are all pyrogenic cytokines which act on hypothalamus to increased body temperature (virus replication is sensitive to temperature) 

CXCL8/ IL-8 induces chemotaxis in target cells, causing them to migrate to the site of infection. IL-8 also induces phagocytosis once they have arrived. 

IL-12 activates NK cells

 

Innate immune responses to virus Case 9

Question:
Katie a 38 year old woman is 16 weeks pregnant and has just received the results of her quadruple blood test. The results show:

 

  • low AFP (alpha fetaprotein)
  • significantly elevated hCG
  • elevated inhibin A 
  • low unconjugated estriol levels. 

 

What congenital abnormality (if any) is most likely to affect Katie's child?
OptionC: No congenital abnormality but results indicative of twin pregnancy
Explanation:
These results describe those expected from the quadruple blood test of a mother carrying a child with Down's syndrome (trisomy 21). 
AFP is made by the foetal liver and excreted in the foetal urine into the amniotic fluid, this will be decreased in Down's syndrome but elevated in spina biffida or anancephaly (which will have similar results to spina biffida)

3 beta hCG is significantly elevated if carrying a foetus with trisomy 21, not significantly altered in other trisomies 

Trisomy 18 / Edward's syndrome would have lower than average levels of all three markers used in the triple test (AFP, hCG and unconjugated estriol) as well as low for all in quadruple test (inhibin A)
Tags: Reproduction, Screening, Birth Defects, Embryology, Haematology

Question: Trisomy 21 (Down's syndrome) can predispose individuals to a number of health conditions. Which of these statements is false?
OptionA: Down's syndrome increases the likelihood of being born with a congenital heart defect.
OptionB: Down's syndrome increases the likelihood of developing Alzheimer's disease
OptionC: Down's syndrome increases the likelihood of developing celiac disease
OptionD: Down's syndrome increases the likelihood of developing gastroesophageal reflux
OptionE: Down's syndrome increases the likelihood of developing hyperthyroidism
Explanation:
The top four answers are true. 
Down's syndrome increases the risk of developing hypothyriodism (15% of people with Down's syndrome)

About half are born with a congenital heart defect
Tags: Risk Factors, Birth Defects, Genetics, Case 7, Chromosomal Abnormalities

Question: Tiny Tim has had a rather rough time of late, and to make it even worse the SHO thinks he has appendicitis. What is the most common orientation of the appendix?
Explanation: All the options are possible orientations/ positions of the appendix, but A (retrocaecal) is the most common.

Question: Mr Jones is a 65 year old man who has previously been diagnosed with AF. He is currently taking Amiodarone which works by:
OptionE: Inhibiting acfion of adenylyl cyclase decreasing cAMP
Explanation:
Volatge gated Na+ channel blockers e.g. FLECANIDE (used to treat SVT, AVNRT, WPW)

B1 adrenoreceptor antagoists e.g. BISOPROLOL (used to treat SVT)

Voltage gated K+ channel blockers e.g. AMIODARONE (used to treat VT, AF, WPW, atrial flutter) 

Voltage gated Ca2+ channel blockers e.g. DILTAZEM (usec to treat SVT and decrease ventruicular rate in AF)

Question: On examination of the pregnant abdomen at 16 weeks, roughly where/how would you expect to feel the uterus if this were a single, uncomplicated pregnancy?
OptionA: Uterus only just enlarged on deep palpation
OptionB: Clearly palpable enlarged uterus low in the abdomen
OptionC: Fundus of the uterus half way between pubic symphasis and umbilicus
OptionD: Fundus of the uterus at the level of the umbilicus
OptionE: Fundus of the uterus above the level of the umbilicus
Explanation:
A = 8 weeks 

B = 12 weeks (when pregnant uterus may just begin to be felt/show)

C = 16 weeks

D = 20-24 weeks

 

Can measure the symphasis-fundal height and would expect this length to be roughly 2cm less than the number of weeks into the pregnancy the woman is.

Question: The arteria pancreatica magna is a branch of which artery?
Explanation: It arises from the splenic artery to supply a large part of the pancreas.

Question: Up to how many hours after ovulation can an oocyte normally be fertilised?
Explanation: Can be fertilised for about 24 hours after ovulation. Sperm remain viable for up to 48 hours within the female reproductive tract due to uterine milk nourishment

Question: Where is the most common site for fertilisation to occur?
Explanation: Most common site is the ampulla of the uterine tube about 18-24 hours after ovulation

Question: At what vertebral level is the aortic bifurcation?
What term best describes this structure?
Explanation:
Zygote is the fused sperm and ovum. 

The cells of the zygote are blastomeres.

The zygote divides into 2 cell stage (2 blastomeres), 4 cell stage etc

The morula is the stage when the zygote has divided enough to resemble a mulberry (like a blackberry), consisting of roughly 12 blastomeres

Morula becomes compacted, with cells communicating with each other and forming tight junctions

There is rapid cleavage by mitotic divisions increasing cells number but not cells size (absence of G1/G2 phases)

The central blastomeres will form the embryoblast/ inner cell mass, the cells that will directly form the embryo

The out morula cells will form the trophoblast / outer cell mass that will form some of the supporting structures of the embryo e.g. placenta

As the morula passes into the uterus around 4 days after fertilisation, the trophoblast cells pull in luminal fluid from the uterine cavity forming a fluid filled space in the centre of the morula called the blastocoel 

Cells of inner cell mass are pushed to one end of the cavity to become the embryonic pole. The formation of this inner cavity is what define this structure to now be a blastocyst

 

To remember this, think of a cyst on the body, this would be full of fluid just like the blastocyst.

Question: There are four steps involved in the implantation of the blastocyst into the uterine wall. Which of these is the correct order of events?
Explanation:
1st - the blastocyst must 'hatch' from the zona pellucida (hardened by cortical reaction) before it can interact with uterine epithelium = hatching

2nd - the trophoblast comes into contact with the decidua of the endometirum but if the embryonic pole is not closest to the area of contact, the inner cell mass must rotate to become aligned with the decidua = apposition

3rd - the blastocyst then attaches to endometrial endothelium triggering changes to trophoblast and endometrium in preparation for implantation into uterine wall. Molecular communications between blastocyst and endometrial cells are vastly increased = adhesion 

4th - final stage is invasion of endometrium by the trophoblast = invasion

Question: What is the lymph drainage of the testes?
In which part of the subclavian artery does the dorsal scapular artery arise?
Explanation: There are only three parts of the subclavian artery, dictated by their relation to scalene anterior

Question: What structure passes through the Foramen spinosum?
Explanation: Essential Clinical Anatomy - Head

Question: At what vertebral level does the common carotid artery bifurcate?

A 25 year old patient presents to A&E with palpitations and dizziness, reporting that his heart is 'racing'.  Upon taking his pulse, his heart rate is 160bpm. He tells you that his mother died in her late 20s of a 'heart attack', though he was too young to actually remember the event.  When an ECG is taken, the consultant refers to it as 'Torsade de Pointes', and tells you that she suspects an inherited heart condition.

 

Which of the following heart abnormalities is most likely?
Explanation:
Long QT syndrome is associated with the setup of Torsade de Pointes - a Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia which can lead to Ventricular Fibrillation and Sudden Cardiac Death.

 

Answers A, B, C and E could all potentially present similarly with a tachycardia.  D: Lown-Ganong-Levine syndrome involves the patient having faster than normal conduction through the AV node, but their risk of developing uncontrolled tachycardia is no different to the rest of the population.  

 

Source: Case 14 ECG tutorial, Mechanisms of arrhythmias lecture

Question:
Steven Gerrard, a 34 year old football player, slips and cuts his leg in a crucial game.

 

11 months later the wound healing is in the scar remodeling phase. Which of the following statements best describes the cellular basis of what's occurring?
OptionB: Collagen I is replaced by collagen II
OptionC: Collagen III is replaced by collagen I
Explanation:
Scar remodeling is the last phase of wound healing (3-12 months).

 

D: Re-epithelialisation

E: Wound Contracture

 

NB: The emotional scars may never heal #sociology

Question: What group of embryonic cells give rise to melanocytes?
Explanation:
Epiblast cells will form ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm cells

Ectoderm cells will form neural plate cells/neuroectoderm and non-neuroectoderm cells

After gastrulation, neural crest cells are at the border of the neural plate and the non-neural ectoderm

From the neural plate the neural tube will be formed as the borders of the neural plate, also known as the neural folds, converge.

At this point the non-neuroectoderm will separate again from the neural tube becoming either neural crest cells or epidermis (with the other part of the ectoderm forming the neuro-ectoderm/neural tube) = primary neurulation 

Neural crest cells will leave the neural tube and migrate to other parts of the embryo, becoming mesenchymal cells, forming a wide range of structures including peripheral nervous system, skeletal parts of face, melanocytes (pigment cells) in the skin 

Those neural crest cells that form melanocytes are specifically from the trunk neural crest cells (other groups include cranial, vagal/sacral, cardiac)

Question: Which of these hormones in pregnancy will peak around 8-11 weeks gestation and only be produced by the placenta?
Explanation:
hCG is a gonadotropin that is naturally it is produced in the human placenta by the syncytiotrophoblast, first detectable around around 14 days after conception. hCG can also be made exogenously and used in fertility treatment or occasionally by pituitary but this is not usually the case.

Progesterone produced in high amounts in the ovaries (by the corpus luteum) from the onset of puberty to menopause, and is also produced in smaller amounts by the adrenal glands after the onset of adrenarche in both males and females. In pregnancy progesterone is produced in increasingly high amounts by the ovaries and placenta. At first by the corpus luteum maintained by the presence of hCG. However, after 8th week, production of progesterone shifts to placenta.

Prolactin is produced at least in the pituitary, decidua, myometrium, breast, lymphocytes, leukocytes and prostate

Oxytocin is produced by the hypothalamus and stored and secreted by the posterior pituitary gland

Oestrogen is also made by the placenta during pregnancy but it's level will continue to rise after this time, peaking at delivery.

Question: Which of the following pre-natal screening tests is a diagnostic test for chromosomal abnormalities?
Explanation:
Amniocentesis is the only one of these methods that is fully diagnostic. The others will imply risks or possible pathologies but will not offer definitive diagnoses. These results of the other tests can be combined to calculate a risk profile (or %) but these are not strictly diagnostic tests. 

Nuchal translucency measures the depth of the area at the back of the foetal head on ultrasound (between 11-13 and 6days) NT >3.5mm is suggestive of Donw's syndrome, these results can the be combined with triple or quadruple blood test results.

Question: Freshly ejaculated sperms are not capable of fertilizing the oocyte because there are:
Explanation:
This is one of the questions from the anatomy prac.

 

The answer is D because the sperm need to undergo the 7 hour journey to the site of fertilisation after ejaculation to remove part of the cap of the episomal region to expose the enzymes to allow penetration of the egg. Because of this, in IVF treatment intra-cytoplasmic sperm intraduction is used, injecting sperm directly into the egg to overcome this.

Question: What is the optimal gestational age for measurement of foetal nuchal translucency?
Explanation:
See foetal anomaly screening lecture or anatomy prac. 

The actual specified time is 11th week to 13 weeks and 6 days

Question:
If the base excess value is more than +2, what does this suggest?

 

Note: normal base excess range = -2 to +2
Explanation:
Answer: metabolic alkalosis

 

Why?

If base excess is high, excess base will increase ph. Blood becomes more alkali = alkalosis

Base excess is a metabolic component not respiratory.

Question: Which cranial nerves are  most commonly affected in Mononeuritis multiplex?
Explanation: Mononeuritis multiplex - This neuropathy typically only affects one nerve in the body at a time. Whilst any nerve can be affected, the most common sites for lesions are the third and sixth cranial nerves supplying the external eye muscles.

Question: Between which weeks of pregnancy do teratogens cause major heart defects?
Explanation: Case 8, Cardiovascular system develoment lecture.

Question: Above is a karyotype showing chromosome pairs using giemsa staining. Which of the following statements relating to this is true?
OptionA: Condensed chromatin takes up less stain, appears as the light bands and will be transcriptionally active
OptionB: Condensed chromatin takes up more stain, appears as the dark bands and will be transcriptionally active
OptionC: Condensed chromatin takes up more stain, appears as the dark bands and will be not transcriptionally active
OptionD: Less condensed chromatin takes up more stain, appear as the dark bands and will be transcriptionally active
OptionE: Less condensed chromatin takes up less stain, appear as the light bands, both light and dark bands are transcriptionally active.
Explanation:
This diagram shows the G-banding on the chromosomes produced by the giemsa stain. 

Dark bands are the more condensed chromatin which will take up more stain as have more genes which are not transcriptionally active and contain more AT pairings (made up of heterochromatin) Heterochromatin is a tightly packed form of DNA, which comes in different varieties.

Light bands are less condense chromatin, so take up less stain, the genes are transcriptionally active and are GC rich. (made up of euchromatin)

Euchromatin is a lightly packed form of chromatin (DNA, RNA and protein) that is rich in gene concentration, and is often (but not always) under active transcription. Euchromatin comprises the most active portion of the genome within the cell nucleus. 92% of the human genome is euchromatic.The remainder is called heterochromatin.

Question: During which phase of cell replication are telomeres added to the ends of chromosomes to promote stability?
Explanation: Telomeres are repetitive sequences of DNA added to the ends of chromosomes during metaphase to promote stability, ensure DNA replication to the tip of the chromosome and tethers to the nuclear membrane
Tags: Year 1 Revision, Case 7, Chromosomal Abnormalities, Cell replication

Question: Which of these genetic disease would not be picked up by karyotyping and is caused by abnormalities of the c7 gene?
Explanation:
Karyotype analysis determines the number of chromosomes in the cells and whether there are any pieces of chromosomal material that are missing, extra, or rearranged. Any variation from the normal chromosome number and arrangement can have implications for a person's fertility and the risk for having a baby with birth defects. The following chromosomal conditions can be detected by karyotype analysis:

 

Klinefelter Syndrome (XXY) - the most common male chromosomal disease, otherwise known as 47, XXY is caused by an extra X chromosome

Turner Syndrome (X) - results from a single X chromosome (45, X or 45, X0).

Cri-du-Chat Syndrome ( deletion on Chromosome 5) -(cry of the cat), from a truncated short arm on chromosome 5. The name comes from the babies' distinctive cry, caused by abnormal formation of the larynx.

Angelman syndrome – 50% of cases have a segment of the long arm of chromosome 15 missing; a deletion of the maternal genes, example of imprinting disorder.

 

There are many genetic conditions that are the result of single gene mutations. Additionally, there are many genetic conditions that are caused by multiple genes interacting. These conditions cannot be detected by chromosome analysis. 

Including:

Huntington's - on c4 gene

Cystic fibrosis - on c7 gene

sickle cell - on c11 gene

Question: Which enzyme initiates glycogenolysis?
Explanation: Glycogen phosphorylase cleaves glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate. Glycogen kinase is a cheeky answer, but Medical Biochem refers to the enzyme as glycogen phosphorylase

Question: What is "C-peptide"?
OptionA: A component of the complement system (innate response)
Explanation: Preproinsulin is cleaved to proinsulin and then, by endopeptidases, onto insulin and C-peptide. (N.B. it is not the same as Protein-C, which is involved in the negative feedback of coagulation)

Question: What is the best antidepressant to prescribe to a depressed and suicidal adolescent?
Explanation:
The answer is B Fluoxetine http://www.patient.co.uk/doctor/depression-in-children-and-adolescents

 

The best answer cannot be Mirtazapine or Amitriptyline as TCAs have a high level of toxicity great caution must be taken when prescribing them.

Question: Which of the following is NOT characteristic of a DKA presentation
Explanation:
The patient would be HYPOkalaemic on admission with a K+ concentration of less than 3.5 on admission

 

Typical DKA presentation 

1) low pH ( acidotic)

2) Low bicarbonate

3) Low K+

4) Low bp

5) GCS less than 12 

6) ketones

7) Low O2 states

Question: Which two layers constitute the placenta?
Explanation:
The mature placenta is composed of the maternal aspect (decidua basalis) and foetal aspect (chorion frondosum). 

The decidua basalis is found at the embryonic pole whereas the decidua capsularis is found at the abembryonic pole. The decidua parietalis surrounds the remaining uterine wall. 

The chorion initially is completely covered by villous structures however as development occurs the villous atrophy at the abembryonic pole to form the chorion laeve (smooth). The embryonic pole maintains its villous structure to become the chorion frondosum. 

As the foetus grows the decidua capsularis stretches and degenerates, leaving the chorion leave and decidua parietalis to fuse, eventually eradicating the uterine cavity.

Question: What is the "diploë"?
OptionA: Layer of cacellous bone containing red bone marrow in the skull
Explanation: It is has two layers of compact bone surrounding it and is found in the skull

Question: Which of these statements about changes to mother's physiology during pregnancy is correct for majority of normal pregnancies?
OptionA: Decrease in cardiac output for most of the pregnancy
OptionB: Decrease in total body water, ECF and plasma volume
OptionC: Increase in gut motility leading to diarrhoea
OptionD: Increase in platelet count leading to hypercoaguable state
OptionE: Vital capacity, respiratory rate, inspiratory reserve volume and partial pressure of oxygen mostly unchanged
Explanation:
CV changes

CO increases to meet demands of placenta and uterus and ensure waste removal. CO increases due to increasing heart rate and stroke volume between 6-28 weeks and in labour but may be slight decrease towards end of pregnancy (due to obstruction IVC by uterus) and returned to normal rapidly after birth. 

Fluid volume changes

Total body water increases by 6-8L, contributing largely to weight gain, ECF increases by about 3L (half into plasma, rest in interstitium). This can cause oedema. Not counteracted by falling ADH as osmoreceptors are set to lower threshold in pregnancy. Increased renin due to oestrogen from the placenta will increase ANGII which increases aldosterone secretion thus leading to conserving salt and water (so increased GFR). Progesterone also contributes to this by increasing potassium and sodium retention. Also pregnant women may experience increased thirst (due to ANGII) so increased fluid intake.

GI changes

Nausea and vomiting usually in first 12-14 weeks, can be severe and persisting (hyperemesis gravidarum) in 1 in 200 which can lead to dehydration and acid base imbalance. Constipation is common at any stage particularly later in pregnancy. This is due to enlarging uterus pressing on rectum and lower colon, relaxation of smooth muscle due to placental progesterone, decreased water content of stool due to increased water absorption (by increased ANGII and aldosterone), generally slowing of GI functions, slowed gastric emptying, decreased gut motility. Also relaxation of lower oesophageal sphincter leading to heartburn. Slowed bile flow increasing risk of gallstones. 

Haematological changes

RBC mass increases increases but not in proportion with Hb so mild dilution anaemia is normal. Small increase in WBC count and decrease in platelet count but within normal limits however pregnancy is a hypercoaguable state not because of platelet count but due to increased levels of fibrinogen and clotting factors increasing DVT risk

Respiratory changes

Vital capacity, respiratory rate, inspiratory reserve volume and partial pressure of oxygen mostly unchanged. Some minor reductions in lung volumes towards end of pregnancy due to uterus obstruction/ pushing against diaphragm (e.g. functional residual capacity, expiratory reserve volume, residual volume, total lung capacity). Resting tidal volume may increase by up to 40% by end of pregnancy and slight increase in thoracic circumference.
Tags: Respiratory, Gastrointestinal System, Physiology, Case 8, Pregnancy

Question: 'Howship's Lacuna' is a transient structure associated with which physiological process?
Explanation:
Howship's lacuna is the transient structure which is composed of osteoclasts at the front, reabsorbing bone, with osteoblasts lagging behind, reforming new bone.  

 

Source: 'Normal Bone Health and Bone Disease' lecture (Dr Beynon) - Case 14.

Question: Which of these statements is correct for define terms of parity?
OptionA:
A nullparous woman has never given birth or has only delivered stillbirths

A primiparous woman has given birth once. 

A grand multiparous woman has delivered five or more infants (not including any stillbirths)
OptionB:
A nullparous woman has never given birth or has only delivered stillbirths
A primiparous woman has given birth once.
A grand multiparous woman has delivered five or more infants regardless of the outcome
OptionC:
A nullparous woman has never given birth regardless of the outcome
A primiparous woman has given birth once.
A grand multiparous woman has delivered five or more infants (not including any stillbirths)
OptionD:
A nullparous woman has never given birth regardless of the outcome
A primiparous woman has been pregnant once.
A grand multiparous woman has delivered five or more infants (not including any stillbirths)
OptionE:
A nullparous woman has never given birth regardless of the outcome
A primiparous woman has given birth once.
A grand multiparous woman has delivered five or more infants regardless of their outcome
Explanation:
Note: A miscarriage is not considered as a delivery, after an infant reaches 24 weeks of gestation or more it will need to be delivered whether this is successful or a stillbirth therefore will be counted as a delivery using this system. 

 

A nullparous woman has never given birth regardless of the outcome, could have delivered a still birth/ child could have later died. 
A primiparous woman has given birth once. This term is sometimes incorrectly interchanged with primigravida (the term for a woman in her first pregnancy), but they will not become a primiparous until they have delivered the baby.

A multiparous woman has given birth more than once, a mutligravida has been pregnant more than once.
A grand multiparous woman has delivered five or more infants who have achieved a gestational age of 24 weeks or more, regardless of the outcome.

A great grand multiparous woman has delivered seven or more infants beyond 24 weeks of gestation regardless of the outcome

Question: After what gestational milestone is a miscarriage subsequently considered as a stillbirth?
Explanation:
A stillbirth is a baby born dead after 24 completed weeks of pregnancy.
If the baby dies before 24 completed weeks, it's known as a miscarriage or late foetal loss.

 

The first major milestone is 24 weeks: the threshold of viability. Babies born this early will likely spend at least three months in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), and a third of them will survive with no long-term problems

The second milestone is 28 weeks, at the start of the third trimester, when viability skyrockets. Ninety percent of babies who make it to this stage of gestation survive. Long-term complications — including cerebral palsy, vision and breathing problems — are still a possibility, however.
The next milestone is 32 weeks to 34 weeks. Babies born now generally have an excellent chance of survival, without any major long-term complications, though they might not have full lung maturity and will need to spend time in the NICU.

he following milestone is 37 weeks, when your babies will have full lung maturity and should be able to leave the hospital within a few days of delivery.
The final milestone is 39 weeks, when your babies will be considered full-term at delivery.

Question: Anti-D antibodies are what type of immunoglobulin?
Explanation: Hence they can cross the placenta (Lec. "Blood groups in Man")

Question: You are sat in the GP's wating room and notice one of the children 'throwing' objects it is given. At what age would you most likely expect this child to be?
Explanation: Case 9 development lectures

Question: Doris is in the first stage of labour with her second child. She is complaining of pain. The consultant asks you what is causing the pain and from which spinal nerves it originates. What do you answer?
OptionD: Distention of pelvic floor, perineum and vagina - S2-S4
OptionE: Distention of pelvic floor, perineun and vagina - T10-L1
Explanation:
The correct answer is B, the pain in the first stage of labour originates from the uterine contractions of the myometrium and the cervical effacement and dilation which are characteristic of the first stage. The pain from the uterus travel in visceral afferents (sympathetic) which enter the spinal cord through the posterior segments of the thoracic spinal nerves, T10 - L1.

Answer A is technically correct HOWEVER since this is an SBA, the best answer is B as it encompasses both causes of the pain. 

C is incorrect as the spinal nerves are those which carry pain in the second stage of labour. They are the routes of the pudendal nerve.

D is the cause of pain in the SECOND stage of labour and the correct spinal nerves which carry this pain. 

E is a mixture of the cause of pain from the second stage of labour and the spinal nerve which carry pain sensation in the first stage of labour.

Question: A 48 year old injecting drug user presents to a GUM clinic following concerns he may be HIV positive resulting from sharing drug paraphernalia. He is worried as two of his close friends have recently been diagnosed as HIV positive and believes he too may have been exposed. His rapid test results come back as 'reactive' but confirmatory blood tests some back as negative, it is explained that tests carried out before 3 months post infection are not reliable and he should come back in to be retested to confim at a later date. How would HIV be classified on the baltimore scheme?
OptionA:
I

double stranded DNA
OptionB:
III

double stranded RNA
OptionC:
IV 

+ single stranded RNA
OptionD:
V

- single stranded RNA
Explanation:
HIV is an enveloped reverse RNA virus (case 9 lectures) that can be calssified as class VI on the baltimore scheme. 

Class I includes:

  • herpes virus
  • pox virus
  • adenovirus
  • papilomavirus

Class III includes

  • reoviridae (includes rotavirus)

Class IV includes:

  • polio virus
  • hep a 
  • hep c
  • foot and mouth

Class V includes:

  • influenza virus

Question: Which of these is the correct management for pre-eclampsia
OptionA: Copper sulphate, aspirin and induce delivery at 34-37weeks
OptionB: Copper sulphate, aspirin and emergency caesarean section upon diagnosis
OptionC: Magnesium sulphate, aspirin and allow natural onset of labour but with specialist on hand in a hospital
OptionD: Magnesium sulphate, aspirin and emergency caesarean section upon diagnosis
OptionE: Magnesium sulphate, aspirin and induce delivery at 34-37weeks
Explanation:
Magnesium sulphate to prevent seizures, aspirin and induction of labour (37 weeks if mild, 34 if severe)

Patients may have undergo a caesarean section but this is not always the case, whereas labour would is always induced and a caesarean wouldn't be immediately upon diagnosis.

Question:
Oh, the grand old Duke of York,
He had ten thousand men;
He marched them up to the top of the hill,
And he marched them down again.
And when they were up, their PO2 went down

Which receptor detected this change?
Explanation:
Peripheral chemoreceptors detect decreased PO2, increased PCO2 and decreased pH of blood 

  • Carotid body -CNIX
  • Aortic body -CNX

 

Central chemoreceptors detect changes in PCO2 and pH of brain interstitial fluid (influenced by arterial PCO2)
