Part of the immediate treatment is fluid management via IV 0.9% NaCl

Kussmaul breathing is deep, laboured breathing which in DKA is due to the body trying to remove CO2 to reduce the acidosis (respiratory compensation)


Bicarbonate levels will likely be reduced as they act as a buffer to the ketones in the blood. 

Non-compliance with insulin will result in elevated blood sugar levels that can induce DKA. Thought to account for almost half of DKA cases.

Question: The below histological specimen is from which organ?
Explanation:
Indications that this from a pancreas are:

 

- The lighter coloured areas of cells which are Islets of Langerhans

- The small but disordered arrangement of groups of cells which are the acini

- The dense arrangement which suggests it is glandular without many luminal structures

 

 

The liver has a slightly more organised structure and the arrangement is centred on a central vein with portal triads around outside

Kidney would have many tubular structures within in it which are the nephrons.  Distinctive shaped glomeruli may also be visible.

The lungs would have much thinner tissue structure and large pockets of air

The testes have a distinctive tubular arrangement with many adjacent tubules containing germinal tissues.

Question: The ECG trace shown below exhibits which abnormality?
Explanation:
The fact that there is a QRS complex following most of the P waves means there is not complete block in the AV node (complete/third degree heart block). Long QT syndrome is simply an elongated QTc interval and would not cause the dropped beats shown in the ECG. 

 

Mobitz type I second degree heart block would appear similar to this only with a PR interval which becomes prolonged before the dropped beat. This trace has a constant PR interval before the dropped beat so is Mobitz type II.

 

Note; ECG may have other abnormalities present but they are not listed in the above answers

Question: Which of these physiological changes would you NOT expect to see in a pregnant woman.
Explanation: The ADH threshold, along with the third threshold, is reduced so that less fluids are lost in urine, maintaining blood volume.

Question: You are on placement when a known type 1 diabetic - John Collins- enters the GP room. The GP looks in John's eyes with a funduscope. The GP tells you that he believes that John has now progressed from a R1.1 to a R1.2. What does the GP mean by R1.2?
OptionA:
Pre-proliferative diabetic retinopathy -

 

Multiple blot haemorrhages greater than 1DD from fovea 

More than 8 blot haemorrhages per eye 

Venous irregularities 

Beading 

With or without cotton wool spots.
OptionC:
Background diabetic retinopathy 

 

More than 5 micro aneurysms >1DD away from fovea

More than 4 but less than 8 dot/blot haemorrhages

Less than 3 micro aneurysm less than 1DD away from fovea with 6/12 vision 

More than 3 MA less than 1 DD away from fovea.
Explanation: Taken from the diabetic retinopathy screening service Wales Grading Criteria - given as a hand out in the Case 10 eye practical.

Question: Which of the following muscles is not innervated by the median nerve?
Explanation:
Median nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment of the forearm other than flexor carpi ulnaris and the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus.

In the hand it innervates LOAF:

 

L - Lateral two lumbricals so 1st and 2nd lumbricals

O - Opponens pollicis 

A - Abductor pollicis brevis

F - Flexor pollicis brevis
Tags: Anatomy, Upper Limb innervation, Year 1 Revision

Question: Which terminal branch of the brachial plexus is formed from union of the lateral and medial cords?
What part of the GI tract is indicated below?
Explanation:
Learning outcome: General understanding of the histology of the lower gastrointestinal tract, including jejunum, ileum, colon, rectum and anus, and the changes seen with disease processes such as inflammatory bowel disease and gastroenteritis.

 

Villi are fairly broad and Brunner's glands can be seen- secrete mucus

Question: What junction is indicated in the image below?
Explanation: In the image, there is a thick muscle layer - this is circular muscle layer which forms the internal anal sphincter

Question: Which type of cell in the anterior pituitary gland is ACTH secreted from?
Explanation:
ACTH is secreted by corticotroph cells (make up 15-20% of the pituitary).

Gonadotroph cells secrete LH & FSH

Lactotroph cells secrete prolactin

Somatotroph cells secrete growth hormone

Thyrotroph cells secrete TSH.

Question:
Sally is a 37 year old female who comes into your surgery complaining of fatigue and weight gain. On questioning you discover she has recently has been developing menstrual irregularities, which she has put down to, in her words "the change". She is also struggling to pass stools.

On examination you find her skin to be cool, rough and dry, she has non-pitting oedema on her feet and has a hear rate of 42bpm. 

Which hormonal imbalance do you suspect?
Explanation: Sally is likely to have hypothyroidism. This could be confirmed by blood tests which would show low FT4 and high TSH (primary) or low FT4 and normal TSH (secondary). The tests may also show hyponatremia and elevated bilirubin.

Question: Which structure is most likely to eroded in osteoarthritis?
Explanation: OA is characterised by localised loss of cartilage, remodelling of adjacent bone and associated inflammation.

Question: What structure is indicated by 4?
Which of the following is a function of ANP?
Explanation: All the others are actions of aldosterone. ANP opposes aldosterone.

Question: Which of these is the word used to describe a mechanical factor which moulds part of the fetus over prolonged period?
Explanation:
A) Correct. E.g. Clubfoot.

B) A disruption is a destructive process which alters a pre-existing structure. E.g. Amniotic band syndrome.

C) A malformation occurs during the formation of structures.

D) A syndrome is a pattern of malformations occurring together, considered to have a common cause. E.g. Fetal Alcohol Syndrome.

E) Teratology is the study of abnormal development.

Question: Nancy is a 32 year old primigravida, 16/40. She injures her foot and is unable to bear any weight on it for several weeks. It is very painful. The doctor recommends her a painkiller however she is worried how it might affect her unborn child. The doctor reassures her that this painkiller is unlikely to cause any harm to her baby. Which painkiller has the doctor prescribed?
Explanation:
A) Aspirin can cause Reye's disease and should not be given to pregnant women or children <16 years.

B) Just because something is a natural remedy does not mean it is safe to take during pregnancy.

C) No recommended.

D) Should not be prescirbed during pregnancy - use during the second half of pregnancy can lead to the infant going through withdrawal when they are born. 

E) One of the only drugs which is recommended during pregnancy, however it is recommended no drugs are taken during the first trimester (Nancy is in her second trimester).

Question: Osmotic diuretics are used in increased intracranial pressure. Mannitol is an example of this. What is its mechanism of action?
OptionA: It is freely filtered at the glomerulus and not fully reabsorbed. Its presence in the tubular fluid reduces water reabsorption.
OptionB: Inhibits Na+/K+/2Cl- co-transporter in the luminal membrane, increasing the quantity of Na+ reaching the collecting duct. This increases  H+ and K+ secretion, water is drawn towards the high concentration of ions in the tubular fluid.
OptionC: Inhibits Na+/Cl- cotransporter in luminal membrane and increases the secretion of K+ and H+ into the collecting ducts. Water is drawn towards the high concentration of ions.
OptionD: Aldosterone antagonist decreases Na+ reabsorption, which decreases K+ and H+ secretion.
OptionE: Block Na+ reabsorption by P cells, which decreases the potential difference across the cell and reduces K+ and H+ secretion
Explanation:
A = Correct = Osmotic diuretic 

B = Loop diuretics 

C = Thiazides 

D and E = K+ sparing diuretics

 

Source: Crash Course Pharmacology

Question: Neutralizing antibodies are most often...
Explanation: Because many infections start at mucosal surfaces neutralizing antibodies are often dimeric IgA.

Question: In Scrubs Season 5 Episode 20 "My Lunch" Dr Cox and JD tragically lose three patients following transplantations of infected organs. This episode culminates in Dr Cox's emotional departure from the hospital to "How to Save a Life" by the fray, providing undoubtedly one of the most powerful endings to a TV episode ever. The infectious organism responsible has a SS -ve RNA genome and migrates retro-axonally through the PNS to the CNS where it causes fatal CNS infections if left untreated. Which of the following best matches this description?
Explanation:
A- Bacteria usually affects meningies 

B- CMV usually asymptomatic infections, can cause pneumonia 

C- Can cause CNS infections leading to paralysis but not usually fatal and migrates to CNS via blood

D- yup. most commonly spread by animal bites

E- Parasitic worms 

Source: Case 16 infections lecture & Scrubs S5e20 (wasn't on the reading list but definitely worth watching)

Question: Which of the following statements regarding blood glucose control is incorrect?
OptionC: Glucagon is is produced by alpha cells in the pancreas
OptionD: A blood glucose of 9mmol/L is acceptable in a diabetic after a meal
OptionE: 50g oral glucose will cause a greater insulin response than an equivalent IV glucose infusion
Explanation:
Glycaemic index is a representation of how much a substance increases blood sugar. Glucose will cause the greatest rise so is given the value of 100. 

Glucagon-like peptide 1 is an incretin which are substances released from the GI tract following eating which increase beta cell sensitivity to glucose and as such increases insulin secretion following a meal. It also suppresses glucagon secretion, hence B is incorrect.

Glucagon is produced by alpha cells which form part of the Islets of Langerhans. Beta cells in the Islets secrete Insulin whilst delta cells secrete somatostatin. In an adult the target range after a meal is 9mmol/L and a child is 10mmol/L so 9 is probably acceptable.

Due to the effects of incretins (GLP-1 etc) there is a greater insulin response if glucose is consumed via the GI tract i.e. orally, as opposed to IV delivery. This is discussed in the "Insulin therapy in type 1 diabetes" lecture in Case 10.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the PFK2/FPBase2 enzyme is incorrect?
OptionA: Increased PKA will inactivate the FBPase2 domain and activate the PFK2 domain
OptionB: Glucagon will cause phosphorylation of the enzyme complex
OptionC: Upregulation of the PFK2 domain will increase glycolysis
OptionD: FBPase2 will decrease the level of fructose 2,6-bisphosphate
OptionE: PFK1 is indirectly stimulated by PFK 2 activity
Explanation:
The PFK2/FPBase2 enzyme is found in the liver and is an important regulator of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. Increased insulin levels will lead to dephosphorylation of the complex which leads to PFK2 activation. Glucagon however, causes PKA to phosphorylate the enzyme leading to FBPase2 activity. Therefore B is correct and A is incorrect.  

 

C is correct as upregulation of PFK2 will increase formation of Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate from Fructose 6-phosphate.
Fructose 2,6-biphosphate will then stimulate PFK1 which is an important regulatory enzyme of glycolysis. This is one of the main ways insulin upregulates glycolysis. 

This also shows E is correct as PFK2 is indirectly causing an increase in PFK1 activity. 

 

D is incorrect as FBPase2 is Fructose 2,6-phosphophatase so removes a phosphate group from Fructose 2,6-phosphate, decreasing its levels.

Question: Which of the following ions is not included when calculating the anion gap?
Explanation:
Anion gap = {[Na+ ] + [K+ ]} − {[HCO3− ] + [Cl− ]}
There are more anions which are not included in this equation such as albumin, so there is less measured anions compared to cations giving the gap.

Question: As the neural folds elevate and fuse, neural crest cells undergo active migration, moving from the  ________ layer to the _________ layer. Fill in the blanks…
Explanation:
Learning outcome: describe the formation, migration and contribution to tissue/ organs of neural crest cells. 

 

Cells at the lateral border of the neuroectoderm begin to dissociate- this cell population undergoes epithelial to mesenchymal transformation. Neural crest cells leave the neuroectoderm by active migration and displacement to enter the underlying mesoderm. Crest cells from the trunk region leave neuroectoderm after the closure of neural tube.

Question: How do the symptoms of infection with Campylobacter and infection with Salmonella differ, in the case where both cause intestinal disease?
OptionA: Campylobacter causes nausea but Salmonella does not
OptionB: Salmonella causes nausea but Campylobacter does not
OptionC: Campylobacter causes bloody diarrhoea but Salmonella does not
OptionD: Salmonella causes bloody diarrhoea but Campylobacter does not
OptionE: There is no difference in symptoms - the only way to differentiate between the two is by stool culture
Explanation:
The main difference between the symptoms of Campylobacter and Salmonella infections is the presence of bloody diarrhoea in Salmonella. Both bacteria are known to cause nausea.

 

Answer E is not the correct answer as, even though stool culture is the only reliable method to distinguish between the two diseases, the question addresses differences in symptoms, so as an SBA question, answer D is the most correct.

 

I imagine that not all cases of Salmonella present with bloody diarrhoea and that occasionally Campylobacter does present with bloody diarrhoea (such as with ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease), but in the Infectious Diarrhoea lecture it was mentioned that bloody diarrhoea is the symptom that is most useful at differentiating between these two causative organisms. 

 

 

Source: 'Infectious Diarrhoea' plenary in Case 11
Tags: Infectious Intestinal Disease, Case 11, Gastrointestinal System

Question: A patient's arterial blood gas reveals blood pH of 7.55. Which condition can you reliably exclude with this information?
Explanation:
A blood pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis (alkalaemia). 

 

Conn's syndrome is also known as primary aldosteronism and is often due to adrenal gland hyperplasia. It causes increased aldosterone resulting in increased potassium and hydrogen ion excretion and relative bicarbonate retention causing alkalosis.

Heroin is an opiate and so overdose causes respiratory depression. Respiratory depression will cause hypoventilation and CO2 retention which will cause acidosis.

Panic attacks classically cause hyperventilation which will cause increased CO2 expulsion which results in respiratory alkalosis 

 

Hyperemesis gravidarum is severe morning sickness which causes frequent vomiting. This vomiting will lead to loss of chloride ions from gastric secretions. Whilst this may not result in alkalosis in all cases it can not be excluded. 

 

Furosemide is a loop diuretic which can cause hypokalaemia and if taken in excess will cause hypovolaemia and alkalosis. Again may not cause raised pH but can not be excluded at this stage.

Question: A patient has just received the results of her quadruple test at 19 weeks (she did not present until week 15), and they indicate that there is a relatively high risk of the foetus having Down Syndrome, meaning she is being offered diagnostic testing.  What are her tests likely to have shown?
OptionA:
free beta-hCG: Raised

PAPP-A: Low

Nuchal translucency: Raised

MSAFP: Raised
Explanation:
The Quadruple Test was formerly used for all pregnancies, however it has now been generally replaced by the Combined Test, except for those women that present too late for its timescale (11-13 weeks).

 

Quad test:

  • hCG (all types): raised with Down's
  • Inhibin-A: raised with Down's
  • MSAFP: low with Down's, raised with NTDs
  • mu-Oestriol: low with Down's

75% sensitivity for Down's

Combined test:

  • free beta-hCG: raised with Down's
  • PAPP-A: low with Down's
  • Nuchal translucency: raised with Down's and NTDs

95% sensitivity for Down's

 

Source: Foetal Anomaly Screening Lecture - Dr Claire Francis (Case 7).

Question: A 45 year old man comes into the GP surgery for his yearly check up. 6 months ago he had an inferior MI, but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following drugs would you not expect him to be taking?
Explanation:
Secondary prevention of MIs, according to NICE guidelines, involves pharmacological treatment with the following:

 

- ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) inhibitor

- Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus a second antiplatelet agent)

- Beta-blocker

- Statin 

 

Therefore, given the patient is otherwise healthy, you would not expect a diuretic such as spironolactone to be prescribed.

Question: During an eye examination you ask a patient to look further ahead at a point and then look at your finger which you are holding in front of their nose. Their eyes accommodate to focus on your finger. What best describes this action?
Explanation:
A & E - when viewing objects in the distance the lens is pulled thin

B - correct, when viewing objects 

C - this dilates the pupil

D - this constricts the pupil

 

 

PCS - practical pharmacology drugs in eye lecture

Question: Antibiotics are often effective treatments for infectious intestinal diseases (IIDs), but they should not be given with every pathogen. In which of the following scenarios would treatment with antibiotics be indicated, assuming the patient is immunocompetent?
OptionA: Haemolytic Uraemic Syndrome (HUS) caused by toxigenic E. coli
Explanation:
A - antibiotics should not be given to treat HUS caused by E. coli as they are thought to increase toxin production, thereby worsening the condition. 

B - antibiotics should only be given to treat VTEC E. coli infections when the condition is caught in the early stages, as when the antibiotics kill the bacterium, this causes release of toxins into the bowel that can be more dangerous than the infection itself.

C - the antibiotics vancomycin and metronidazole are normally good treatments for C. difficile, so this is the correct answer. These are not perfect, however, as they can sometimes also clear out the good bacteria in the bowels.

D - Salmonella infections do not normally require antibiotic therapy, but if the disease becomes severe then fluoroquinolone can be given.

E - Norovirus infection is caused by a non-enveloped SRS virus, and therefore would not respond to antibiotics.

 

Source: 'Infectious Diarrhoea' lecture in Case 11

Question: Which pathogen is the most common cause of travellers' diarrhoea?
Explanation:
A - cholera outbreaks are most commonly observed after natural disasters in South East Asia

B - correct answer

C - this is the most common protozoan cause of IID in returning travellers, but not the most common cause overall

D - norovirus is famous for causing outbreaks on cruise ships

E - VTEC E. coli is a less common cause of travellers' diarrhoea than ETEC E. coli 

 

Source: 'Infectious Diarrhoea' lecture from Case 11

Question: Mrs Jones has fallen ill with an infectious intestinal disease (IID) whilst she is in hospital being treated for an acute COPD exacerbation. The registrar performs some tests and finds that the causative pathogen is not bacterial. What is the most likely pathogen causing Mrs Jones' IID?
Explanation:
As well as being associated with IID outbreaks on cruise ships, norovirus is the causative pathogen of more than 90% of non-bacterial cases of IID in healthcare settings. 

 

Source: 'Infectious Diarrhoea' lecture from Case 11

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the placenta is incorrect?
OptionA: There are two umbilical arteries connecting placenta to foetus
OptionE: The placenta should not form near the internal os
Explanation:
A - There are two umbilical arteries and only one umbilical vein

B - Chorion (or chorion frondosum) forms the foetal aspect of the placenta which combines with the maternal aspect, the decidua basalis

C - The placenta has open spaces of maternal blood between villi, however foetal blood is contained in the villi

D - Primary villi form first after the syncytiotrophoblast invasion, and are just formed of trophoblastic tissue. It is only in secondary and then fully developed tertiary villi that mesoderm and blood vessels "core out" the villi. 

E - The placenta should not implant near the internal os, if this occurs then known as placenta previa and is a leading cause of bleeding during pregnancy.
Placenta accreta is where placenta invades all the way to the myometrium and so does not form correctly

Question: You perform an eye examination and note that there is no direct pupillary reflex in the left eye, though there is a consensual one.  The right eye has a normal direct reflex but no consensual one.  Which cranial nerve is most likely affected?
Explanation:
For this question you need to know which cranial nerves carry the Afferent signal and which carry the Efferent one.  For the pupillary light reflex, the Optic Nerve must be functional to carry the afferent signal for there to be any resulting pupillary constriction.  In this case, there is a left optic nerve lesion causing there to be no direct reflex in the left eye and no consensual one in the right - because the signal from the light is not reaching the brain from the left eye.  The Oculomotor nerves carry the parasympathetic efferent for the pupillary response, and since it has been demonstrated that both pupils are capable of constriction, we can say that there is no problem in either of the oculomotor nerves.

 

The Trigeminal nerve carries general sensation from the face, so its function is vital in the Corneal reflex, but has no function in the pupillary one.

Question:
A 26-year old woman who is 12 weeks pregnant attends her booking visit and is screened for Down's, Edwards' and Patau's syndrome.

 

The clinician calculates the risk of the foetus having the named abnormalities. How is the risk presented to the patient?
OptionA: A combined risk for all three syndromes e.g one risk
OptionB: A combined risk for Down's and Edwards'; one risk for Patau's
OptionC: A combined risk for Edwards' and Patau's; one risk for Down's
OptionD: A combined risk for Patau's and Down's; one risk for Edwards'
OptionE: Risks of each syndrome independently i.e three risks
Explanation:
Low risk- less than 1/150

High risk- greater than 1/150

Question: For whom is the Quadruple Test NOT recommended?
OptionB: A 26-year old woman G2 P1; 20 (+0) weeks pregnant
OptionC: A 31-year old woman G1 P0 (twin pregnancy); 16 (+4) weeks pregnant
OptionD: A 39-year old woman G2 P1. First child has Down's syndrome. 18 (+6) weeks pregnant
OptionE: A 40-year old woman G3 P0; 19 (+2) weeks pregnant
Explanation:
Quadruple test is not recommended for multiple pregnancies 

 

If anyone is struggling to understand the use of gravida and parity, the link below is from patient.co.uk but is really helpful in explaining 

 

http://www.patient.co.uk/doctor/gravidity-and-parity-definitions-and-their-implications-in-risk-assessment

Question: Which of the following statements regarding Calcium metabolism is incorrect?
OptionB: Calcitonin is produced by the thyroid gland
OptionC: Parathyroid hormone increases phosphate reabsorption in the kidney
OptionD: Low plasma calcium increases parathyroid hormone secretion
OptionE: Parathyroid hormone causes an increase in osteoclast activity
Explanation:
A - Calcitriol (active form of Vitamin D) is produced by the Kidneys in response to increased PTH. Calcitriol increases the absorption of calcium by the intestine via calbindin

 

B - Calcitonin exerts the opposite effect to PTH, causing a general decrease in plasma calcium. It is produced by parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland.

 

C - PTH increases Calcium reabsorption in the kidney but increases phosphate excretion (by preventing reabsorption)

 

D - PTH release from the chief cells of the parathyroid glands in response to decreased serum Calcium

 

E - Function of PTH is to increase bone breakdown to increase serum Calcium levels. Osteoclasts are the cells which breakdown bone and therefore have increased activity with increase PTH.

Question: Which of the following is an example of an infradian rhythm?
Explanation: Sleep (as in the sleep cycles), appetite and urination all occur in less than a 24 hour period so are ultradian rhythms. Sleep-wake is the classic circadian rhythm as it occurs around every 24 hours. Menstruation is the only one that occurs less than once every 24 hours so is infradian

Question: Which of the following is not used to diagnose metabolic syndrome?
Explanation:
Metabolic syndrome, which can occur with patients on anti-psychotics, is an increasingly common syndrome. 


Taken from here, any three (or more) of the following factors constitute a diagnosis of metabolic syndrome:

Increased waist circumference: ethnicity specific 
- If body mass index is over 30 kg/m2, central obesity can be assumed and waist circumference does not need to be measured.
- Raised triglycerides
- Reduced HDL-cholesterol
- Raised blood pressure: (Systolic ≥130 mm Hg; Diastolic ≥85 mm Hg)
- Raised fasting plasma glucose:

Most people with type 2 diabetes will have metabolic syndrome based on these criteria

Question: In the embryological heart, which area gives rise to the SA node?
Explanation:
Truncus Arteriosus - forms aorta and pulmonary trunk

Bulbus cordis - forms conus arteriosus, part of ventricles (mainly right)

Primitive ventricle - forms trabeculated part of ventricles

Primitive atria - forms left and right atria, impression of bulbus cordis helps divide it

Sinus venosus - forms sinus venarum, SA node and coronary sinus, joins vena cava

Question: A 54 year old man presents to A&E with palpitations, pre-syncope and breathlessness. This has been occurring for the last 8 hours. You suspect atrial fibrillation. What is the most suitable immediate treatment?
Explanation:
Treatment for AF  under 48 hours: Heparin IV and cardioversion or amiodarone 

 

Treatment for AF over 48 hours would not be cardioversion as anticoagulation is required for 3 weeks previous, and 4 weeks after cardioversion

Question: You are in GP clinic. A 55 year old man who is hypertensive, has ischemic heart disease and type 2 diabetes complains of recurrent headaches. Which one of his medications is most likely to cause this problem?
Explanation: Nitrates may cause throbbing headache, dizziness and flushing as side effects due to vasodilation.

Question:
A member of Cardiff Medics Rugby Club comes into the clinic. He is a tall prop forward, who studies physiotherapy.  

 

Although he is a self-proclaimed 'boozy legend', he is worried about the size of is genitals, as Toga is coming up. 

 

On examination, you find a lack of hair, small testicles and a slight indication of gynaecomastia. He also seems a bit dull.

 

What is the most likely genetic abnormality?
OptionA: No genetic problem, they're all like that
Explanation:
The answer is Klinefelter syndrome.

 

This is a sex chromosome aneuploidy: XXY, or an abnormal added X chromosome. 

Common presentation is a 'womanly man' due to the additional X proteins being transcribed. Common symptoms include primary hypogonadism, lack of hair, gynaecomastia. There are also developmental problems, including learning and motor (he's a prop forward). 

There is a higher risk of Female linked diseases, such as breast cancer and osteoporosis. 

 

B - Down's Syndrome or 21 trisomy, is characterised by it's distinct physical abnormalities, such as a transverse palmar crease and epicanthic folds. A lack of any obvious abnormality removes this possibility 

 

C - DiGeorge Syndrome is from micro deletions of 22q. Although one symptom is learning disability which is inherent in prop forwards, it is very common to have palate problems, in addition to being short with long fingers. They have an increased risk of many systemic abnormalities, including CV, renal, thymus and hypercalcaemia. 

 

E - Turner Syndrome is another Sex chromosome aneuploidy, X monoploidy, but this is obviously in women.

Question: Mr Jones- 46, who has suffered from depression for several years, presents with acute hypertension, vomiting, kidney failure and increased intra-cranial pressure. Which of the following antidepressants is he likely to be on?
Explanation: Monoamine oxidase inhibitors are not routinely used anymore because of there extensive adverse drug and food interactions. Mr Jones is likely to be suffering a hypertensive crisis caused by an adverse reaction between Phenelzine and a tyramine containing food. This type of adverse reaction is AKA the 'cheese reaction' because some cheeses are high in tyramine.

Question: Which class of antidepressants inhibits L-type Calcium channels and therefore risks cardiac side effects?
Explanation: TCA inhibit the SERT and NET transporters- increasing synaptic serotonin and norepinephrine, but they also inadvertently inhibit sodium and L-type Calcium channels. In overdose TCA can increase the Q-T interval and cause cardiotoxiticy and death. For this reason they have been used in suicide attempts and aren't prescribed routinely anymore but rather as a last resort where SSRIs are ineffective.

Question: Mrs Jones, who has been on anti-psychotic medication for 8 years, is diagnosed with bone marrow suppression. Which of the following drugs has caused this?
Explanation:
Clozapine, a second generation anti-psychotic, is linked to increased risk of bone marrow suppression. This is also the only drug which is recommended for suicidal patients. 

 

Note: Citalopram is an antidepressant. 

 

This is from our Neuropharmacology lecture in case 12.

Question: The suprachiasmic nucleus (SCN) is AKA the 'maser clock' and is involved in regulation of sleep and wakefulness. Where in the brain is the SCN located?
Explanation:
D- hypothalamus is the correct answer. 

 

This was in case wrap up- case 12.

Question: Which of the following neurotransmitters is NOT synthesised from tyrosine?
Explanation:
Dopamine, noradrenaline and adrenaline are synthesised in the same pathway- originating from tyrosine. 

 

Serotonin is synthesised in a separate pathway- originating from tryptophan.

Question: Which of these best describes antigenic drift?
OptionA: massive changes in the genome of a virus though mutation, leading to a risk of pandemic.
OptionB: massive changes in the genome of a virus though reassortment, leading to a risk of pandemic.
OptionC: massive changes in the genome of a virus though mutation, leading to a risk of epidemic.
OptionD: small changes in the genome of a virus though reassortment, leading to a risk of epidemic.
OptionE: small changes in the genome of a virus though mutation, leading to a risk of epidemic.
Explanation:
Antigenic drift is the process of small mutations to a genome, and can lead to a risk of epidemics due to changes in surface Ags

Antigenic shift describes massive changes to genomes of virus through reassortment with two or more strains, and can lead to pandemics due to different surface antigens
Tags: Case 9, Immunology, Infectious Disease, Vaccination, Virology

Question: You are in a GP clinic when a mother brings in her 3-year-old son who is unwell.  The GP notices that there are spots on the patient's soft palate, which she describes as 'Forchheimer spots' - what illness is the child most likely suffering from?
Explanation:
Forchheimer spots are small petechial lesions on the soft palate that indicate rubella (though are not diagnostic).

The offending pathogen in rubella is a Rubivirus, Class IV (+ssRNA) of the Baltimore scheme.  The illness is generally mild and without complication except for in pregnant women when the Congenital Rubella Syndrome is a large problem, causing a number of defects in the foetus.

 

Source: Kumar and Clark's Clinical Medicine

Question:
Mr Smith, a 32 year old bus driver has had low mood, lack of appetite and low energy for  the last 6 months. For the last 4 days his wife has noticed he has had increased sex drive, lots of energy and has been speaking very quickly.

 

Which of the following might explain Mr Smith's symptoms?
Explanation: Type 2 bipolar disorder is characterised by severe depression and periods of hypomania lasting around 4 days.

Question: Mick Wilston, a 20 year old medical student has no motivation to revise. He has no drive to perform activities or pursue goals. Which of the symptoms of mental illness might he be suffering with?
Explanation: Avolition is a lack of motivation and drive to perform activities and pursue goals.

Question: Jack ,a 53 year old alcoholic, recently had the misfortune of having so much to drink that he ended up having a brawl in his local pub resulting in a black eye, two missing teeth and a trip to A and E two weeks ago. Since then he has decided to give up alcohol and change his life for the better. What sociological term best describes this situation?
Explanation:
Case 8 Sociological Terms:

 

Transition - a change in roles/statuses which represents a distinct departure from previous roles/statuses.

Trajectory - a long term pattern of stability and change which involves multiple transitions.

Life event - a significant life occurrence which involves an abrupt change which has serious long lasting effects, usually thought of as births, deaths and marriages etc.

Turningpoint - a life event which produces a change in the life course trajectory - this is the SBA for Jack's situation.

Question: Mr and Mrs Jones have 3 children - Rhodri, Nia and Huw. They are an example of what type of family?
Explanation: A nuclear family consists of a 2 generational family of parents and their children.

Question:
Batman comes into the surgery after a long night of fighting crime. 

 

He has been worrying recently about having a genetic abnormality, something to do with daddy issues. He keeps his face covered up with a kind of mask, but as creepy as this might be, he doesn't seem to have any craniofacial problems. He goes on about 'it's not who we are underneath, it's what we do that defines us'. Helpful. 

In fact, there are no obvious symptoms whatsoever.

 

If he were to have any, which of the following abnormalities is the most likely?
Explanation:
B - Correct.

XYY has no obvious symptoms, but research has shown that people with this can be abnormally aggressive/antisocial. Batman probably has it. 

 

A - XXXY is associated with serious craniofacial problems, as well as multiple systemic (cardiac, GI, renal) deformities, as well as a learning disability. 

 

C - 5p deletion is 'Cri-du-chat' syndrome. Batman has a husky voice, so it's not this one.

 

D - 7p deletion is Wolf-Hirshorn syndrome. - Retardation,  Craniofacial abnormalities: small head and peri-auricular tags, Poor Growth, Hypotonia, Cardiac Problems. Batman isn't retarded. 

 

E - 17p13.3 deletion is Miller Dieker. This is characterised by hypertelorism, or widely spaced eyes. It also has systemic defects, and learning disability. Batman has normal eyes, obviously.
Tags: Chromosomal Abnormalities, Genetics, Case 7, Superheroes with issues

Question: Sadly Mr and Mrs Jones have separated. Currently the children are living with Mrs Jones who has remarried to Mr Big. His son Kyle has also moved in with them. How would Mrs Jones' household now be described ?
Explanation: A blended family consists of a family which includes step parents with children from a previous relationship. In this case Mr Big and his son Kyle.

Question:
Alfred is a 28 year old soldier who returned from Afghanistan six months ago after serving a tour in which he watched his brother die. Since his return, Alfred has noticed his right arm becoming increasingly weak and desensitised and he now describes complete paralysis in the arm. 

 

What psychiatric disorder is Alfred most likely to be diagnosed with?
Explanation:
Conversion disorder is the correct answer - this occurs when an unresolved conflict is converted into a physical symptom, such as paralysis, abnormal movements, sensory loss, aphonia, disorders of gait and pseudocyesis. 

 

A dissociative disorder is a condition where there is loss of awareness or cognitive ability without medical explanation. 

 

PTSD classically involves flashbacks, nightmares, insomnia and feelings of guilt rather than presenting with a physical symptom.

Question:
Iron Man comes into the surgery.

 

He appears to be covering up his face with some kind of metal mask. On examination, he appears to have multiple per-auricular tags, as well as slightly small head underneath all of the fancy electronics. 

 

When you ask him to get out of his suit, he is very hypotonic, with evident poor growth: this whole time, Tony has been stark lying about his dependence on his outfit. 

 

What genetic abnormality does Mr Stark Have?
Explanation:
A- correct. 

Wolf-Hirschorrn Disease presents with retardation, small head, periauricular tags, hypotonia and lack of growth. It also has cardiac abnormalities associated

 

B- Cri du chat syndrome presents with a high, catlike crying. Iron man doesn't cry. It does however, present with a small head. 

 

C -  Edwards syndrome presents with more serious craniofacial problems, IUGR and most will die within a year due to the seriousness of the problem. Tony is a middle-aged man. 

 

D - 7q.11, or Williams is a good shout: people are hyper sociable, with motor problems, however, they don't have any craniofacial abnormalities. 

 

E - 22q deletion, or Digeorge syndrome, presents as learning disability with psychiatric problems, cleft palate and multiple systemic problems.
Tags: Chromosomal Abnormalities, Superheroes with issues, Genetics, Case 7

Question: Which of the following statements about the infant immune systems compared to adult immune system is true?
OptionA: Compared to adults, infants have higher numbers of circulating neutrophils but with a decreased response to chemokines
OptionB: Compared to adults, infants have improved TLR-dependent innate immunity
OptionC: Compared to adults, infants have higher levels of IgG
OptionD: Compared to adults, infants never stimulate better IFN-Y responses to certain immunogens e.g. BCG
OptionE: Compared to adults, neonatal CD4 cells are more able to provide help for Ig synthesis
Explanation:
A is true. 

The opposite of all other answers is true. 

Despite infants having higher levels of some subtypes of IgG compared to adults, overall they have lower levels than adults, this following table shows the average IgG levels in adults and children

Question:
Thor comes into the surgery. He's never been much of a looker, but ever since he came to Earth from Asgard, people have been pointing out his craniofacial defects. He takes off his helmet revealing low set ears. 

On examination, he has a palmar crease which he says 'is just cos I carry Mjolnir around the whole time'. You assume he is talking about his hammer, rather than some Nordic STI. 

 

What Genetic Abnormality has he got?
Explanation:
Answer: D (Downs syndrome)

Patients with down syndrome present with classic craniofacial defects: epicanthic folds, low-set ears and a large tongue. Other physical abnormalities include brushfeld spots and a transverse palmar crease. 

Other systemic symptoms include immunocompromised, cardiac defects, obesity and hearing loss. 

 

A 4p deletion (Hirshprungs disease) - this is an abnormality characterised by a small head, periauricular tags, hypotonia, lack of growth

 

B, 7q11 deletion, Williams disease - presents as hyper social/ sociable , but with motor problems and learning disabilities

 

C 13 Trisomy, Patau syndrome, is the most serious trisomy of the lot: Comes with severe craniofacial defects (proboscis, cyclopia) as well as obvious physical defects: omphacele (organs outside body) and arthryogryposis. 

 

E 1p36 deletion presents with deepset eyes in the face, with a very severe retardation and behavioural problems due to structural brain abnormalities.
Tags: Chromosomal Abnormalities, Superheroes with issues, Genetics, Case 7

Question:
Cyclops presents in the surgery. 

 

After being an X man for so long, he is ready to hang it all up due to his obvious genetic abnormality. 

 

Which genetic disorder has cyclopia as a presentation?
Explanation:
B - Of all Y2 genetic problems, this is the most severe with the most craniofacial defects - cyclopia,proboscis , micropthalamia

 

 

A- Downs syndrome craniofacial region is characterised by epicanthic folds, low set ears, but with a palmar crease

C- Miller-Dieker is characterised by wide apart eyes, and a difficulty to sleep (circadian disruption)

D - Cri du chat is characterised by small head and jaw, with wide eyes. It presents with the cat-cry like sounds.

E- 18 Trisomy, Edwards has many craniofacial problems, but not cyclopia. It's key presentation is arthrogryposis.
Tags: Chromosomal Abnormalities, Superheroes with issues, Genetics, Case 7

Question: Which of the following symptoms is likely to occur in pregnancy due to the action of oestrogen ?
Explanation:
Fatigue - likely to occur in the first trimester of pregnancy as the maternal sensitivity to insulin increases meaning that a slight drop in blood sugar can occur resulting in increased tiredness.

 

Constipation - Progesterone acts as a smooth muscle relaxant and will slow GI transit leading to constipation.

 

Fat deposition - Correct. Oestrogen increases fat deposition. It also causes enlargement of the breasts, uterus and external genitalia and increases vasodilation and vascularity.

 

Morning sickness - caused by increased hCG.

 

Heartburn - Oestrogen actually decreases HCl and pepsin secretion. Progesterone may cause relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter acting as the primary mechanism for heart burn/reflux in pregnancy.

Question: Which of the following vaccines would you be most cautious in giving to a child who is severely immunocompromised?
Explanation:
In those who are immunocompromised, live, attenuated vaccines should be used with extreme caution as they could result in infection due an impaired response to the vaccine. 

Oral rotavirus is the only one listed which live attenuated.

 

IPV is the inactivated polio vaccine and is therefore an inactive vaccine.

DTaP is a combination of diphteria and tetanus which are toxoid vaccines and acellular pertussis which is an inactivated vaccine. 

Meningoccocal C and Pneumococcal (PCV) are both conjugate vaccines which are often given to immunocompromised patients of all ages to prevent a wild infection of the bacteria.

Question: What is the biggest cause of death in patients with heart failure?
Explanation:
Heart failure modes of death:

Metabolic - 18%

Pump failure - 22%

Sudden death (seen 60 mins prior) - 19%

Presumed sudden (seen 72 hours prior) - 9%

Other - 19%

Unknown - 13%

 

These were taken from Dr Zaheer Yousef's lecture in Case 15.  Admittedly it was only from 74 consecutive deaths of HF patients in one centre, however I believe he added this statistics as they were representative of the whole population of heart failure patients.

Question: Which of the following nerves does not pass through the cavernous sinus ?
Explanation:
The cavernous sinus has a close relationship with the following structures:

 

CN III
CN IV
CN V - Opthalmic Division (V1)

CN V - Maxillary Division (V2)

CN VI 

 

 

Damage to the cavernous sinus in a traumatic head injury may implicate any of these structures resulting in pathological eye signs. The internal carotid artery also passes through the cavernous sinus.

 

Grey's Anatomy Flashcards - 247

Question: Josie is attending her first ultrasound scan where she is found to be at 11 weeks gestation. As part of the scan, the sonographer wishes to measure the size of Josie's baby. What is the best method of measurement at this stage of Josie's pregnancy?
Explanation:
The Crown - Rump length is used to measure the fetus in the first trimester of pregnancy.

 

- Symphyseal fundal height (SFH) can be used to give an estimation of the number of weeks gestation after 20 weeks. At 20 weeks the SFH will be at the level of the umbilicus and at 36 weeks at the level of the xiphisternum.

- Nuchal translucency is a measurement of the fluid behind the fetus' neck with an increased thickness being a prognostic marker for Down's Syndrome.

- Head circumference and femur length may be used as fetal measurements in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters.

Question:
Lucy has recently been diagnosed with Bipolar Affective Disorder (BPAD). As she is a second year medical student, and recently learnt about a number of different psychiatric disorders, she would like to find out which classification of the condition she has been diagnosed with. 

 

Lucy has suffered with four depressive episodes and two hypomanic episodes. Which classification of Bipolar Affective Disorder does her illness fall under?
Explanation:
Bipolar I - at least two episodes of depression accompanied by at least one manic episode, causing impairment of function and lasting at least one week

Bipolar II - at least two episodes of depression accompanied by at least one hypomanic episode, causing no severe impairment and lasting at least four days

Bipolar III - at least two episodes of depression accompanied by hypomania or mania as a result of treatment with antidepressants

 

Bipolar IV and V do not exist, as far as I am aware.

 

 

Source: 'Anxiety, Mood and Psychotic Disorders' lecture in Case 12

Question: Which of the following cytokines stimulates T cell proliferation?
Explanation:
IL-2 is released to promote the differentiation of T cells into effector T cells and memory T cells when the initial T cells is stimulated by an antigen

 

IL-1 is an important pro-inflammatory cytokine and a pyrogen

IL-5 stimulates B cell growth and increases immunoglobulin secretion. It is also a key mediator in eosinophil activation

IL-6 is an inflammatory cytokine and pyrogen

IL-12 is secreted by macrophages to assists in NK cell expansion and activation

Question: Alice the antibody is an IgA antibody. She's pretty amazing but she can't do everything so has a family of other antibodies which help her out. Which of the following features is incorrect regarding Alice the IgA antibody ?
OptionA: IgA is found in bodily secretions including tears, saliva and colostrum.
OptionC: In it's secretory form IgA molecules are bound by a J chain.
OptionD: IgA is able to cross the placenta.
OptionE: IgA helps to protect the internal lining of the GI tract.
Explanation: IgG antibodies are the only class of antibodies which are able to cross the placenta. All of the other statements are true about IgA antibodies.

Question: As Alice is waking from sleep one morning, she hears a man call her name. This is strange as Alice lives alone. Assuming that no one has broken into her house, what is it that Alice has experienced?
Explanation:
A - a delusion is a false belief that cannot be explained by the patient's cultural background

B - a hallucination is a false perception that occurs in the absence of an external stimulus

C - a hypnagogic experience is a hallucination that occurs when falling asleep

D - a hypnopompic experience is a hallucination that occurs when waking up 

E - an illusion is a misconception of an external stimulus

 

Source: 'Anxiety, Mood and Psychotic Disorders' lecture in Case 12

Question: Which region of the uterine tube does fertilisation most commonly occur?
OptionE: It doesn't occur in the fallopian tube it occurs in the uterus
Explanation: Fertilisation normally occurs in the ampulla where the fallopian tube is widest and closest to the ovary.

Question: You are wandering around UHW searching for the fabled undergraduate common room, when you stumble into the maternity ward and see a newborn baby with microcephaly, hypotonia and a high pitched cry. You overhear a doctor telling the mother that the baby has a genetic disorder caused by a terminal deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5. What disorder does the baby most likely have?
Explanation:
The correct answer is b - Cri-du-chat syndrome

This is characterized by a high pitched cat-like cry, microcephaly, hypotonia and low birth weight.

It also causes delayed development and intellectual disability later in life.

It is caused by a terminal deletion on the 5p chromosome.
Tags: Case 8, Chromosomal Abnormalities, Birth Defects, Genetics

Question: What is the biggest cause of heart failure?
Explanation:
IHD = 60%

Hypetension = 15%

Primary cardiomyopathies = 15%

Valvulopathies = 10%

 

Yousef Zaheer's first lecture.

Question:
A 35 year old man presents to the GP with breathlessness and palpitations on exercise. You notice pinkish-purple patches on his cheeks, and upon auscultation, hear a loud first heart sound, an opening snap, and a diastolic rumble. Your ECG findings are: 

All of the clinical signs and symptoms lead you to believe that the man is suffering with mitral stenosis. Using his ECG, can you work out his QRS axis?
Explanation:
His presentation is characteristic of mitral stenosis. 

The history of breathlessness and palpitations are explained by a reduced cardiac output. His age is also important as symptoms of mitral stenosis usually manifest during the third or fourth decade of life (http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/155724-clinical#a0216). 

The presence of mitral facies (pinkish-purple patches on the cheeks) indicate chronic severe mitral stenosis leading to a reduced cardiac output and vasoconstriction (http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/155724-clinical#a0217) 

 

The heart sounds heard are explained here - http://www.easyauscultation.com/cases?coursecaseorder=14&courseid=31 

 

The question concerns the axis deviation. The way to work this out is:

1. Identify the isoelectric lead - this is the lead where the positive deflection is equal to the negative deflection, i.e. the R wave is the same size as the S wave 

2. The QRS axis is at 90° to this, giving you two options 

3. Find the positive leads (i.e. with R waves going upwards) 

4. The QRS axis is travelling in the direction of these leads 

 

It's easier to understand with the example:

1. So here, the isoelectric lead is lead II, as the R waves and S waves are of an equal size. Lead II is located at 60° on the normal axis, when considering the direction of depolarisation (see diagram below)

2. The QRS axis must be at 90° to lead II, so it is either at +150° or -30° 

3. The positive leads here are mainly III (120°) and aVF (+90) - these are the leads in which the R wave is positive 

4. So if the QRS axis is travelling in the direction of these leads, it is at 150° 

 

Any QRS axis over +90° is considered right axis deviation, which would be consistent with mitral stenosis. 

 

For reference: 

Normal QRS axis - between -30° and +90°

Left axis deviation -  <-30°

Right axis deviation - >+90° 

Extreme axis deviation - between -90° and +180°
Tags: Investigations, The ECG, ECG, Cardiology, Case 13

Question: Which of the following is not one of the 4 main tissue types?
Explanation: Bone is classified as special connective tissue

Question: What tissue does the histological section below show?
Explanation:
Fibrocartilage can be identified by the prominent collagen fibre bundles arranged in parallel, which help the cartilage to resist stretch. There is alternating layers of hyaline cartilage and thick layers of dense collagen fibres. The cells that can be seen are chondrocytes. 

 

Fibrocartilage is found in IV discs, pubic symphysis.
Tags: Case 1, PCS, Year 1 Revision, Case 16, Histology

Question: Which muscle produces the Anorectal angle, important for maintaining faecal continence?
Explanation:
Puborectalis forms a sling around the anorectal junction and plays a major part in maintaining faecal continence.  It is part of the levator ani group.  Puborectalis relaxes upon 'bearing down' so that the anorectal angle may increase for the passage of stool.

 

Sources: Dr Allen's Lecture from Case 11 and Essential Clinical Anatomy

Question: Which layer is present in the epidermis of thick skin but not in thin skin?
Explanation:
The Stratum lucidum isn't present in thin skin. 

 

I remember the layers of the epidermis of thick skin using the nemonic Come Let's Get Sun Burned:

  • Stratum Corneum
  • Stratum Lucidum
  • Stratum granulosum
  • Stratum Spinosum
  • Basement Membrane

Question: Which of the following extra-intestinal manifestations of inflammatory bowel disease is not related to disease activity (i.e. continues even when the bowel disease is in remission)?
Explanation:
All of these features may occur/get worse when there is a flare up of the patient's bowel disease with the exception of central arthropathy - this continues even when they are in remission, before they develop any colitis, and even after having their colon resected.  The central arthropathy occurs most commonly in colitis patients with the HLA B27 allele, and may consist of sacro-iliitis, ankylosing spondylitis, or both.

 

Source: Inflammatory Bowel Disease lecture and provided notes, Case 11.

Question: which of these drugs is used to carry out retinal exams?
Explanation:
tropicamide is a mACh receptor antagonist, thus blocks parasympathetic impulses.

this causes pupil dilation and cyclopegia (paralysis of ciliary muscle resulting in loss of accommodation)

 

Phenylephrine is also used:

it is an adrenoceptor agonist acting on the SNS

it causes myadriasis (pupil dilation) and peripheral vasoconstriction. therefore you would see large pupils and white sclera

Question: In the Electron Transport Chain what is Complex II also known as?
Explanation:
Complex I = NADH dehydrogenase. Establishes H+ gradient by moving 4H+ into the intermembrane space. Accepts electrons from NADH. Link between glycolysis, TCA, fatty acid oxidation and Electron transport chain. 

 

Complex II = Succinate dehydrogenase. Receives FADH2 and removes electrons creatingFAD. Direct link between TCA cycle and Electron Transport Chain. 

 

Ubiquinone (Q) = accepts pairs of electrons from complex I and II and delivers them to complex III

 

Complex III = Coenzyme Q reductase. Transfers electrons to Q to Cytochrome C causing reduction, they are then transported to complex IV. Pumps H+ into intermembrane space. 

 

Complex IV = cytochrome C oxidase. Transfers electrons from cytochrome C in order to reduce O2 to form H2O

 

Complex V = ATP synthase. Proton channel (moves H+ back in) and an ATPase. Binds to ADP and Pi and converts it to ATP when rotate. Proton flow leads to ATP release.

Question: Melaena (black/very dark stools resulting from partially digested blood) may be a sign of bleeding from which portion of the gastrointestinal tract?
OptionC: Proximal to the fourth part of the duodenum
Explanation:
Any bleeding from distal to the ileocaecal junction (i.e. from the colon/rectum) will resulting in actual red blood being found in the stool, rather than melaena.

 

Source: Kumar and Clark's Clinical Medicine.

Question: A man comes in complaining of back pain. You suspect that he has a herniated disc with nerve compression. Which of the following symptoms would you expect to see?
Explanation:
Absent/Reduced reflexes are a sign of a lower motor neurone lesion, which occurs in nerve compression following a herniated disc. 

 

All the other symptoms are linked with upper motor neurone lesions.

Question:
Mr. Williams presents with dyspnoea and peripheral oedema. He has a history of hypertension and is obese. You perform an ECG and it comes out as follows:

 

From his ECG you discern that the P waves in lead II have a higher amplitude than they should, as they are >2.5mm. 

 

Using his history, presentation and ECG, what best describes his condition?
Explanation:
The history and symptoms would suggest pulmonary hypertension or cor pulmonale due to right sided heart failure - oedema is a classic sign of elevated right heart pressures. 

The tall peaked P wave in lead II is a sign of right atrial enlargement and is known as P pulmonale.

 

This is because in right atrial enlargement, right atrial depolarisation lasts for longer (as there is more muscle to depolarise) and its waveform extends to the end of the left atrial depolarisation.
Tags: Investigations, The ECG, ECG, Cardiology, Case 13

Question: Congenital Hypertrophy of the Retinal Pigment Epithelium (CHRPE) is most associated with which condition?
Explanation:
CHRPE is almost diagnostic of FAP, and is one of its extra-intestinal features, with the others being desmoid tumours, osteomas, sebaceous cysts and dental abnormalities.  

 

Source: Genetics of the GI Tract Lecture, Case 11.

Question: If there were no other changes apart from efferent arteriole constriction what would happen to filtration?

Hulk comes into the surgery. 

He is upset, confused, and clearly severely retarded. He also moves his arms around with very little control suggesting hypotonia.

On Facial examination, you find a broad face with very deep-set eyes. 

You decide the green skin pigment is probably just tattoos, and nothing to do with any anger-management issues. 

 

Before he says 'Hulk Smash' and destroys your Practice, what genetic abnormality best fits his presentation?
Explanation:
The answer is E. The main buzz-word is the deep-set eyes with broad face, a craniofacial problem only present in those with 1p36. 

 

Hypotonia is also present in Downs, Wolf-Hirschorn and Williams, but the craniofacial presentation is different.

B Downs - epicanthic folds, hypertelorism with palmar crease

C Williams - sociable/hyperverbal but retarded (not very serious disease)

 

D, DiGeorge, tends to only present with palate problems, in conjunction with Hypocalcaemia and psychiatric problems

A, Patau Syndrome, is an incredibly serious disease with very prominent craniofacial (eg. proboscis, cyclopia, microopthalmia) and systemic defects.

Question: During a GP placement a 15 year old girl presents with absent menses, she say she is worried because all her friends have started their periods and she feels left out. You notice she has a short webbed neck, and appears below average height for her age. Apart from this she appears completely normal. What do you think her most likely diagnoses will be?
OptionE: She is healthy and just needs reassurance that every woman starts menses at different stages.
Explanation:
A - Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common condition responsible for as many as one in three cases of absent periods. However her physical appearance suggests she may have Turner syndrome. 

 

B - Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can cause absent periods

 

C - correct. Turners Syndrome - 45,X. Seen in females who are completely or partially missing an X chromosome. Although they are of normal intelligence and can lead normal lives they are infertile and tend to have a short stature and webbed neck.

 

D - Klinefleters syndrome - 47,XXY. This is only seen in males, who's main symptom is sterility. However they may have other subtle symptoms such as increased height, muscle weakness, poor coordination, breast growth, less hair, smaller genitals.

 

E - Although this is true her physical appearance may point you to test for Turners syndrome

Question: Even in diabetics with chronic hyperglycaemia it is very unusual for glucose to be excreted in the urine due to the high threshold and the efficient handling of glucose by the kidney. Where in the kidney is most of glucose reabsorbed?
Explanation:
The proximal tubule absorbs nearly all of it especially along the first 1/3 or the the PT. 

Glucose is freely filtered at the glomerulus. 

In the kidney it is mainly absorbed via a transcellular route, 

At the beginning of the proximal tubule luminal glucose concentration = plasma concentration, however as glucose is removed from the tubular fluid the luminal concentration drops. This means that glucose transport is active. 

The apical transport is done by Na/Glucose cotransporters, which are part of the SGLT family. The basolateral Na/K pump maintains the low intracellular Na concentration needed for the GLUT transporter to work. 

In the initial part of the PT Glucose transport is done by a high capacity/low affinity transporter = SGLT2 and removed basolaterally by GLUT 2.

In the late part of the PT Glucose transport is done by a low capacity/high affinity transporter = SGLT1 and removed basolaterally by GLUT 1.

Question: In the distal proximal tubule, which GLUT transporter is dominant?
Explanation:
GLUT 1 is dominant in the latter part of the proximal tubule. 

GLUT 2 is dominant in the proximal part of the proximal tubule.

Question:
It is May 2016 and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have brought Princess Charlotte into your surgery for her first MMR vaccination. Wills says "One remembers George having two MMR vaccinations, how old will our little Princess be when she needs her second one?"

What do you answer the future King?
OptionE: She will not need a booster, her Royal Blood shall protect her from measles, mumps and rubella.
Explanation:
A) - wrong

B) - correct (sse below).

C) - wrong

D) - wrong, she may however have her HPV vaccine here.

E) - wrong, Royal blood does not protect against viruses.
Tags: Case 9, Infectious Disease, MMR, Vaccinations, Royal Baby

Question: If you had just pooped out a perfect, seamless, cumberland sausage - what score would you most likely get on the Bristol Stool Chart?
OptionE: Screw the stool chart and get a medal instead.
Tags: Inflammatory Bowel Disease, Diarrhoea, Nutrition, Case 11, Gastroenterology

Question: Using the Bristol stool chart you are told a patient's stool was assessed to be a 5. Which of the following describe healthy stools?
OptionE: None on the chart are healthy, it only describes pathological poop
Tags: Diarrhoea, Diet, Case 11, Gastroenterology, Gastrointestinal System

Question: What is the normal initial response to decreased renal artery pressure?
Explanation:
The myogenic response, which is part of autoregulation. When there is a decrease in hydrostatic pressure there is decreased stretch of myocytes, which stimulates the myogenic reflex > dilation. In an effort to increase blood flow to the kidney. 

 

This is an intrinsic response and doesn't depend on any neurohormonal mechanisms. 

 

The opposite also occurs when there is an increase in hydrostatic pressure, which increases stretch of myocytes, the response is constriction, which aims to reduce perfusion pressure back to baseline by reducing blood supply.

Question: Which of the following is not a fat-soluble vitamin?
Explanation: Fat soluble vitamins = A, D, E and K

Question: What is the function of Cholecystokinin?
OptionA: Increases gastric motility and decreases gallbladder contraction.
OptionB: Stimulates gallbladder contraction and increases gastric motility
OptionC: Stimulates gastric acid secretion and gallbladder contraction
OptionD: Stimulations gallbladder contraction and increases production of pancreatic enzymes
OptionE: Increases food intake and increases production of pancreatic enzymes.
Explanation:
CCK release is stimulated by the presence of food in the duodenum. It stimulates gallbladder contraction causing it to release bile and increases pancreatic production of enzymes. It inhibits gastric emptying and gastric secretion. Also acts a hunger depressant. 

 

CCK is synthesised by I cells of the SI and secreted into the duodenum.

Question:
Fill in the gap..

 

_________________ haemorrhage/haematoma is the most frequent traumatic brain lesion
Explanation:
C- Subarachnoid Haemorrhage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is the most frequent traumatic brain lesion. It results from rupture of corticomeningeal vessels and from hemorrhagic contusions of the brain. Usually it is diffuse and does not exert localized pressure.

Question: Which Germ layer is primarily responsible for the development of the Gastrointestinal Tract?
Explanation: The GI tracts is the main organ system derived from the endodermal germ layer, in addition to the epithelial linings of the respiratory tract and urinary bladder.

Question: Which of these conditions can occur in a healthy individual living at high altitude?
Explanation:
The correct answer is secondary polycythemia, an overabundance of erythrocytes due to decreased oxygen concentrations at altitude is seen in people living at high altitude. It is caused by decreased oxygenation of tissues resulting in the stimulation of erythropoiesis.

 

Source - http://www.medicinenet.com/polycythemia_high_red_blood_cell_count/page3.htm

Question: Which of the following is NOT secreted by the anterior pituitary?
Explanation:
The posterior pituitary releases ADH and oxytocin

The anterior pituitary releases ACTH, TSH, LH, FSH, Prolactin, GH and MSH.

Question: A man who's blood group is B- requires a transfusion. Which donors can he receive the transfusion from?
Explanation:
He can only receive blood from donors who are O- or B-.

He is rhesus negative so cannot receive blood from anyone who is rhesus positive.

He is group B and therefore will have anti-A antibodies, therefore he cannot receive blood from anyone who is group A or AB.

 

Source - http://www.wisemedic.net/medical-answers/what-determines-blood-type-of-a-person/

Question: The Reading FC goalkeeper Adam Federcici lets in a goal during a tight FA cup semi-final against Arsenal, which causes his team to be knocked out. In the months following this his team-mates notice he is no longer interested in playing football, always seems tired and has a very low mood. The club doctor diagnoses him with depression. What is the next appropriate step to manage Federcici's depression?
Explanation:
Cognitive behavioural therapy is the first step in the management of moderate depression.

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant.

Citalopram is an SSRI.

Venlaxafine is an SNRI.

For mild depression, you may consider reassessing him in a few months time, but in this case Federici probably has moderate depression, so you would not do this.

 

Source - Nice guidelines on management of depression

Question: Which of the following Toll Like Receptors (TLRs) detects lipopolysaccharide (LPS)?
Explanation:
TLR 4 is the LPS detecting TLR and is found on the plasma membrane of cells. 

 

The other 4 options (TLR 3,7,8,9) are all endosomal TLRs which detect PAMPs within cells themselves. These are important in the innate detection of viral infections.

Question: Which of the following is considered a professional antigen presenting cell?
Explanation:
The three professional APCs are:

B lymphocytes
Dendritic cells
Macrophages

 

These cells all express MHC II and so can then interact with CD4+ T cells

Question: What is the normal hearing frequency range a human likd Govind can detect?
Explanation: Basic year 1 knowledge. Get to know.

Question: Jane has successfully given birth and thinks it's all over however as a 2nd year medical student you know that this is not the case! Jane must still progress through the third and final stage of labour to deliver the placenta and its membranes. The 3rd stage of labour is considered prolonged if it is greater than what duration?
Explanation: The 3rd stage of labour is considered to be prolonged if it is greater than 30 minutes duration. Most women will progress through this stage within 10-15 minutes normally. An intramuscular injection of oxytocin into the vastus lateralis muscle of the thigh may be given to stimulate myometrial contractions to assist with this stage to expel the placenta and its membranes.

Question: What are the amygdala part of?
Explanation: This is an SBA question not MCQ. We are sitting an SBA exam. The amygdala are part of the limbic system of which are part of the temporal lobe, located medially and deeply.

Question: Whilst on placement the doctor asks you to take a history of a 30 year old patient on a cardiology ward.  From this, you discover he has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy but no family history of any heart problems.  He has recently been admitted to hospital due to episodes of fainting and palpitations.  The palpitations were later diagnosed as ventricular tachycardia (episodes eventually stopped after 20s).  You see in the patient notes that he is classed as a high risk patient for sudden cardiac death and tests have found his heart's septum to be over 30mm.  According to risk stratification of the chances of patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy dying from sudden cardiac death, how many risk factors is this patient showing from the history and notes (first number), and how many does he need to have to make him a high risk patient (second number)?
Explanation:
According to risk stratification for HCM patients dying of SCD, the risk factors are the following:

1) Family history of SCD

2) Syncope

3) Non-sustained VT (less than 30s)

4) BP response to exercise

5) Septum > 30mm

 

The patient exhibits risk factors 2, 3 and 5 --> 3 risk factors

To be high risk, they must exhibit at least 2 risk factors from the list of 5

 

Source: Dr Yousef Zaheer lecture on non-ischamic cardiomyopathies

Question: Which of the viruses listed below would carry an RNA dependent RNA polymerase enzyme?
Explanation:
Ebola is a class V virus (-ssRNA) on the Baltimore Classification Scheme. These viruses are composed of a negative sense strand of RNA. In order to function within a host cell and replicate they must first convert their genetic code into a complementary base sequence using their own RNA dependant RNA polymerase enzyme. The sense strand then created can then be translated by the host cells ribosomes. Since RNA dependant RNA polymerase enzymes are specific to -ssRNA viruses they provide a good target for creating antiviral drugs.

 

Other examples of Class V -ssRna viruses include: Influenza, Rabies, Measles and Mumps. 

 

Herpes - Class I (dsDNA)

Reovirus - Class III (dsRNA)

HIV - Class VI (reverse RNA)

Rubella - Class IV (+ssRNA)

Question: Which species from the Campylobacter genus causes the most cases of infectious diarrhoea in the UK?
Explanation:
Campylobacter jejuni causes more than 90% of infectious intestinal disease in the UK, and the genus as a whole is the most common cause of IID.  The diarrhoea due to Campylobacter is not bloody, and is most commonly caused by eating undercooked food (particularly poultry).  

Campylobacter coli tends to be found in swine rather than poultry, and it accounts for most of the remaining 10% of IID from Campylobacter.  

Campylobacter pylori is the former name for Helicobacter pylori, the bug responsible for recurring peptic ulceration.

Campylobacter ilei and Campylobacter oesophagi do not exist as far as I can tell.

 

Source: Microbiology of the GI tract lecture, Case 11 and Gladden et al, Clinical Microbiology made ridiculously simple (2014).
Tags: Abdomen, Infectious Intestinal Disease, Diarrhoea, Microbiology, Case 11

Question: Rhomboid major and minor contribute to the superficial extrinsic back muscle group. What nerve innervates rhomboid major and minor?
Explanation:
A) Axillary nerve innervates the deltoids. To test the deltoid, the arm is abducted, against resistance, starting from approx 15 degrees 

B) Dorsal scapular innervates the rhomboids. These muscles retract the scapula and rotate it to depress the glenoid cavity 

C) Spinal accessory nerve innervates the trapezius muscle, also part of the superficial extrinsic back muscle group. Descending part elevates scapula, ascending part depresses, middle part retracts scapula.

D) Suprascapular innervates supraspinatus (initiates and assists deltoid in abduction of the arm) and infraspinatus muscles (laterally rotate arm) 

E) Thoracodorsal nerve innervates latissimus dorsi, also part of the superficial extrinsic back muscles. This muscle extends, adducts and medially rotates humerus.

Question: Which neurotransmitter is released by the cells in the Raphe nuclei?
Explanation:
The Raphe nuclei is a term often given to the bundle of cell bodies grouped in the pons and upper medulla, close to the midline, that project throughout the brain releasing serotonin. 

 

Source: 'Neuropharmacology' lecture in Case 12

Question: The presence of HBsAg in the blood suggests what?
Explanation: HBsAg is the surface antigen of the hepatitis B virus (HBV) an indicates current hepatitis B infection. A cleared infection and vaccination would cause presence of Anti-HBs but not HBsAg as the infection is no longer active in the body.

Question: Which of the following organisms are likely to cause constipation?
Explanation:
Salmonella typhi is the organism responsible for Typhoid Fever, a febrile illness with insidious onset, and often presents with cough and constipation.  Salmonella enteritides cause diarrhoea. 

 

All of the others cause diarrhoea except Helicobacter pylori, which causes peptic ulceration, but has no effects on the passage of stool.

 

Source: Microbiology of the GI tract lecture, Case 11
Tags: Abdomen, Infectious Intestinal Disease, Diarrhoea, Microbiology, Case 11

Question: A 27 year old man visits his GP, clearly bent forward and complaining of lower back pain. On examination, the man struggles to extend his vertebral column and complains of pain when trying to do so. The GP suspects the pain results from a back strain. What muscle/s are most likely implicated?
Explanation:
Back strain involves some degree of stretching or tear of muscle fibres- muscles usually involved are those producing movements of the lumbar IV joints, usually the erector spinae. Most common cause of back pain

 

Erector spinae: extends vertebral column and head, laterally flex vertebral column 

Latissimus dorsi: adduct, extend, medially rotate humerus- not an intrinsic muscle of the back 

Serratus posterior, superior, inferior: more likely to be proprioceptive than motor in function- intermediate back muscles 

Splenius: laterally flex head and rotate head to side of active muscles 

Transversospinalis: 3 muscles; extend head and thoracic and cervical regions, rotation to contralateral side, function as organs of proprioception

Question: Which of the following statements regarding MHC Class II is incorrect?
OptionE: HLA-DQ and HLA-DR are examples of MHC II genes.
Explanation: MHC II is present on professional antigen presenting cells as they are part of the exogenous pathway. That is, APCs engulf pathogens and present peptide fragments on MHC II for interaction with CD4+ T cells. It is MHC I which presents endogenous peptides (from endogenous infection i.e. viral infection) therefore B is incorrect.

Question: Which of the following acts as C3 convertase in the alternative pathway of complement?
Explanation:
A is C3 convertase in the classical and MBL pathways

B is C5 convertase in the classical and MBL pathways

C is simply C3 which is what C3 convertase breaks down into C3a (an anaphylatoxin) and C3b which joins with C3 convertase to from C5 convertase

D is correct as in the alternative pathway C3b is constantly being formed which bind to bacteria and then along with cleaved factor B (Bb) form C3 convertase (C3bBb). This then can form many more C3b molecules and amplify the response. This is why alternative pathway is the most important in the complement response.

E is C5 convertase of the alternative pathway

Question: Where in the body would you find a Kuppfer cell ?
Explanation: Kuppfer cells are stellate macrophages found in the hepatic sinusoids.

Question: Where in the body would you find the cell type outlined in the black box below?
Explanation:
The cell is a Peyer Patch - a mucosa associated lymphoid tissue found in the ileum of the gut.

 

Peyer's patches are important in the immune defense against gut microbial pathogens. M cells which overlie the Peyer's patches detect and process foreign pathogens which are then presented to T and B lymphocytes which initiate the production of IgA to clear the pathogen. This however may not always be effective and the pathogen may enter the bloodstream as in the case of Polio which becomes viraemic and can enter the dorsal route of the spinal cord where it can cause paralysis.

Question: Which is the main dopaminergic pathway in the central nervous system?
Explanation:
All of the above pathways are dopaminergic pathways in the CNS, although tuberohypophyseal and tuberoinfundibular are alternative names for the same pathway. 

 

The pathway that accounts for ~75% of dopamine in the brain is the nigrostriatal pathway, which consists of cell bodies in the substantia nigra whose axons terminate in the corpus striatum. 

 

 

Source: 'Neuropharmacology' lecture in Case 12

Question: What is the pathology likely to be on this ECG?
Explanation:
ST elevation in the leads II, III and aVF indicate an inferior infarction. 

The posterior part of the infarction comes from the pathological R waves in leads V1-V3 (R/S ratio is >1). 

The RBBB is indicated by the M-shaped QRS complex in lead V1 and W-shaped QRS complex in lead V6 (although that is more difficult to see sorry!) Remember MarroW for RBBB.

I got this question from The Myocardial Infarctions quiz on this website http://ecg.utah.edu/tests which is very good (think it goes into a bit more detail than we need at the moment but the MI section is great).

Question: What is a useful landmark when performing lumbar puncture to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid?
OptionB: A horizontal line drawn between posterior superior iliac spines
OptionC: A horizontal line drawn between the highest points of the iliac crest
Explanation:
2.5cm posterosuperior to anus- coccyx can be palpated at this point

 

Horizontal line drawn between PSIS- where S2 spinous process lies- level indicates the inferior extent of the subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern) 

 

Horizontal line drawn between highest points of iliac crest- passes through tip of L4 spinous process and l4-L5 IV disc. Useful landmark when performing lumbar puncture. 

 

Posterior median furrow- spinous processes of lumbar vertebrae are large and easy to observe when the trunk is flexed and can be palpated in the posterior median furrow 

 

Sacral triangle- lines joining the PSIS and the superior part of intergluteal cleft. The sacral triangle outlining the sacrum is a common area of pain resulting from lower back sprains 

 

Source: Essential clinical anatomy. Back page 284-285

Question: The zygopophysial joint is what type of synovial joint?
Explanation:
Condylar- permit fairly wide range of flexion and extension e.g MCP joints 

Hinge- permit flexion and extension only e.g elbow joint 

Pivot- allow rotation e.g alantoaxial joint between atlas and axis 

Plane- permit gliding or sliding movements 

Saddle- concave and convex where the bones articulate e.g joint between first metacarpal and trapezium

Question: Which of the following is true about the tongue and taste sensation?
OptionA: Taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rds of the tongue is carried by the facial nerve, taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue is carried by the hypoglossal nerve.
OptionB: All taste sensation from the tongue is carried by the facial nerve.
