Explanation: In terms of fine motor control, Brian is only 9 months old so does not yet have a well developed pincer grip, however he will achieve this developmental milestone when he is 1 year old (hopefully). However, when it comes to fine motor control Brian is able to move his eyes in unison following activities across the room, transfer objects, finger feed, use a palmar grasp, and exhibits casting and purposeful alertness.

Question: Which of the following statements is not true about the structural features viruses have in common?
OptionA: The caspid of a virus is formed from a number of individual protein molecules called capsomeres.
OptionB: The virus creates an envelope using its own lipoproteins, which encloses the nucleocapsid.
OptionC: The nucleic acid genome of the virus can be single or double stranded.
OptionD: The combination of the genome and capsid is called the viral nucleocapsid.
OptionE: The lipoprotein envelope of the virus contains viral-specific proteins that make it unique.
Explanation: Although viruses do tend to have lipoprotein envelopes surrounding the nucleocapsid, they are obtained from the host cell during the replication process, and do not orginate from the virus itself.

Question: Herpes virus has a double stranded (ds) DNA genome (dsDNA). To which class of the Baltimore Classification does it belong?
Explanation:
Herpes viruses has a dsDNA genome, so is a Baltimore Classification class I virus. In dsDNA viruses, the designations of positive/negative sense aren't important as mRNA can come from either strand. 

NB: Herpes virus also has an envelope (if you're interested).

Question: Poliovirus is a Baltimore Classification class IV virus. Which of the following describes the genome of a Baltimore Classification class IV virus?
Explanation: Baltimore Classification class IV viruses have a single stranded (SS) positive-sense RNA genome. Positive-sense (5' to 3') indicates that the viral RNA sequence may be directly translated into the desired viral proteins, therefore in positive-sense RNA viruses, the viral RNA genome can be considered the same as the viral mRNA, and can be immediately translated by the host cell. Other examples of Baltimore class IV viruses are Hepatitis A virus, Hepatitis C virus, and Foot-and-mouth disease virus.

Question: Which of the following about Eccentric hypertrophy is CORRECT?
OptionC: It is due to pressure overload within the heart
Explanation:
The photo below explains it well.  Eccentric hypertrophy is seen more in systolic heart failure as it causes dilation cardiomyopathy, whereas concentric is commonly present in diastolic.

A is correct, as it is the only answer present in eccentric hypertrophy, the rest are seen in concentric.

Question: Baby Brian is born with congenital rubella, which he acquired from his mother Brenda. What is the name of this kind of viral transmission?
Explanation: Vertical transmission occurs when a disease causing agent (virus) is passed down from a parent to their offspring. Examples of viruses that can be transmitted in this way are; leukaemia viruses and congenital rubella.

Question: Mr. Praha has been spending a lot of time at the library in an attempt to join a coveted group known as "the lanyards". Suddenly he finds he can no longer remember his revision despite spending all of last week in the library. What kind of memory loss is Mr. Praha suffering from?
Explanation:
Semantic is a form of declarative memory, but so is episodic.

Therefore the SBA is semantic memory.

Question: Which is the only virus known to only infect the upper respiratory tract?
Explanation: Rhinovirus is dedicated to the upper respiratory tract because it has a temperature restriction; it cannot grow where it is hotter than approximately 30 degrees.

Question: Which of the following statements is not true of Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and Parainfluenza virus (PIV)?
OptionC: Both cause infections of both the upper and lower respiratory tracts.
OptionE: There is no vaccine or therapy for either.
Explanation: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) has 1 serotype, whereas Parainfluenza virus (PIV) has 4 serotypes. This is significant because it means there is more scope for reinfection with PIV than with RSV, as PIV has more serotypes.

Question: You are a GP and Brian comes to see you for a consultation. He is not feeling well because he has caught the influenza virus, and thinks he should be immune to it because he already had influenza 15 years ago. One of the reasons he may have become infected with the influenza virus again is antigenix drift. In antigenic drift, small changes over time occur to which of the following?...
OptionC: Both surface protein hemagglutinin and surface protein neuraminidase.
Explanation: In antigenic shift small changes occur slowly over time to surface proteins hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. These changes accumulate over time, and ultimately result in viruses that are antigenically different from each other. When this happens, the body's immune system may not recognize those viruses. This process occurs in both influenza A and B, and can result in small epidemics.

Question: Which of the following classes of CD4 cells acts to recruit neutrophils?
Explanation:
CD4 cells can differentiate into a variety of cells under urge stimulation of cytokines. They have varying functions:

 

  • TH1 produce cytokines that activate macrophages to destroy intracellular microorganism that they contain
  • TH2 produce cytokines that recruit and activate eosinophils, mast cells and basophils. Also promote barrier immunity.
  • TH17 help protect against extracellular pathogens through the secretion of IL-17, which induces epithelial and stromal cells to produce chemokines that recruit neutrophils. 
  • TFH provides B cell help in secondary lymphoid tissue to produce high affinity antibodies. Can secrete a variety of cytokines. 
  • Treg involved in limiting the immune response and preventing autoimmune reaction. There are natural and induced Treg cells. 

 

Source: Janeway's immunobiology. TH17 cells were also mentioned in the immunology revision session.

Question: Which of these is not one of the 'big three' worldwide infections?
Explanation: The 'big three' are the three infections worldwide that cause the biggest problem in terms of number of cases, and number of deaths.

Question:
You have had the misfortune of being placed in a laboratory for your SSC week up at the Heath. After pipetting multiple serial dilutions of chemicals that you can't pronounce into test tubes you are offered the chance to tag along with a Professer of Embryology. She shows you the following image and asks you to identify the structure labelled 1. What is it?

 

Id
Explanation:
1. Primitive Streak

2. Epiblast

3. Hypoblast

4. Mesoderm

 

This is an image of an embryo at the very start of gastrulation (week 3) due to the emergence of the primitive streak. During gastrulation the embryo forms a trilaminar disc from its previous bilaminar structure.

 

http://intranet.tdmu.edu.ua/data/kafedra/internal/histolog/classes_stud/en/stomat/ptn/1/04Gastrulation.Histo-%20and%20organogenesis.%20Extraembryonic%20organs.%20Crucial%20periods%20of%20embryogenesisn.htm

Question: As you are desperate to get out of your SSC lab-based practical you show great enthusiasm for embryology as the Professor shows you around. She produces you a further picture and asks you to identify the part labelled 3. What is it?
Explanation:
1. Neural Tube

2. Ectoderm

3. Notochord

4. Mesoderm

 

The notochord becomes the nucleus pulposus in the IV disc in the fully formed fetus.

Question: Below is a picture of the pre-embryo stage. Identify the cells highlighted in blue.
Explanation: The epiblast cells are located at the centre of the pre-embryo (epi = centre). They are tall columnar cells which surround the amniotic cavity with the epiblasts forming the upper border (adjacent to the cytotrophoblast) being termed amnioblasts as they secrete the amniotic fluid. Epiblast cells will go on to form the ectoderm in gastrulation.

Question: Below is a picture of the placenta. Identify structure 2.
Explanation:
1. umbilical arteries

2. stem villus

3. decidual septa

4. decidual basalis (basal plate)

5. myometrium

6. spiral arteries

7. maternal veins

8. chorion

9. amnion

10. intervillus space

11. umbilical vein

http://intranet.tdmu.edu.ua/data/kafedra/internal/histolog/classes_stud/en/stomat/ptn/1/04Gastrulation.Histo-%20and%20organogenesis.%20Extraembryonic%20organs.%20Crucial%20periods%20of%20embryogenesisn.htm

Question: Which of the following best describes the period of ventricular systole?
Explanation:
During ventricular systole, ventricular pressure increases (A incorrect) as it contracts forcing blood out into the aorta/pulmonary trunk. Its end is marked by closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves (E incorrect)

P-R interval represents atrial systole (B incorrect).

QRS complex may seem like a valid option however electrical activity does not immediately translate to contraction and the ventricles are in a contractive state from around the Q wave to near the end of the T wave (C, incorrect, D correct). 

A visual representation, taken from Dr Claire Williams' lecture, is shown below:

Question: Where would you find a Brunner's gland and what does it secrete ?
Explanation: Brunner's glands are found in the duodenum and secrete an alkaline fluid to neutralise the acidic pH of chyme from the stomach. This helps to provide an optimum pH for further digestion.

Question: The WHO had aimed to eradicate Polio by 2015, until it re-emerged in Syria. What is meant by 'eradicate'?
OptionA: The organism still exists in reservoirs, but not longer causes disease in humans.
OptionB: The organism still exists in some intermediate carriers, but is no longer present in humans.
OptionC: The organism has mutated to such an extent that it no longer causes disease in humans.
OptionD: The organism no longer exists in reservoirs, and has gone for good.
Explanation: Eradication means to get rid of for good, with no organism left in reservoirs. Smallpox is an example of a disease that has been eradicated. Elimination means that the organism still exists in reservoirs, but no longer causes disease in humans.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding bisoprolol is correct?
Explanation: Bisoprolol is known, and used for, its β1-selectivity (cardioselective). It should not be given if patient is bradycardia as it will induce further bradycardia and decrease in cardiac output. Whilst bisoprolol has less effect on the β2 (bronchial) receptors and is relatively cardioselective, it can still induce bronchial constriction and so like all beta blockers is contraindicated in asthmatics. It is PKA which prevents phospholamban from inhibiting SERCA and so beta agonists will cause an increase in PKA and a greater uptake of Calcium via SERCA. Bisoprolol however will mean phospholamban can still inhibit SERCA and Calcium uptake will be decreased in myocytes. This will lead to decreased lusitropy.

Question: Brenda brings her son 3-month old son Brian into your GP surgery for his vaccinations. Considering his age, what vaccinations will you be giving him today?
OptionB: DTaP, IPV, Hib, MenC, and Rotavirus oral vaccine.
OptionE: DTaP, IPV, Hib, PCV, and Rotavirus oral vaccine.
Explanation:
At 3 months babies should be given Diptheria, Tetanus and acellular Pertussis vaccine (DTaP), Inactivated Polio vaccine booster (IPV), Haemophilis influenza type B vaccine booster (Hib), Meningococcal C vaccine (MenC), and Rotavirus oral vaccine. 

 

Go to http://mumsru.club/mumsru-vaccination-plan/ to see the full vaccination schedule.

Question: Which of the following is a live attenuated vaccine?
Explanation: Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Typhoid (injected), Pneumococcal, Influenza (injected), Hib and MenC, and DaPT are all killed vaccines. MMR, BCG, Influenza (nasal), Rotavirus (oral), Typhoid (oral), Varicella zoster (VZV), and Yellow fever are all live attenuated vaccines.

Question: Your housemate, a fellow medical student, has suddenly realized he missed all his occupational health appointments this year and last year, so hasn't got any of the required vaccinations. As a 'healthcare worker', what vaccines does he need to book appointments to get?
OptionD: Hepatitis B, flu, BCG, MMR and VZV.
OptionE: DTaP, IPV, Hib, PCV, and Rotavirus oral vaccine.
Explanation: A healthcare worker requires the vaccines in D. The vaccines in A are the vaccines an animal handler requires (i.e. vet). The vaccine in B is what someone aged over 75 needs. The vaccines in C are required by a pregnant woman. The vaccines in E are the ones that would be given to a 2 month old baby.

Question: On a growth chart, what is a reference (normal) range considered to be?
Explanation: A reference (normal) range is usually considered to be the mean +- 2 SDs. This gives a 95% reference range.

Question: During the accommodation reflex which of the following occurs?
Explanation:
During the accommodation reflex three key things occur:

 - The lens becomes more convex to shorten its focal length. This is done by contraction of the ciliary muscle which relieves tension on lens and allows it to thicken.

 - The pupil constricts to prevent peripheral light from entering the lens and blurring the close up image

 - The medial rectus contracts to bring the eyes to focus on an object which is usually in the midline

 

All three of these contraction are brought about by fibres from CN III

Question: A 33 year old presents to his GP with lower back pain which seems to be worse in the morning. He is in clear discomfort when talking to the doctor. On examination the doctor notes that upon performing Schober's test there is limited flexion of the lumbar vertebrae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
AS usually presents between 15 and 45 years of age. The pain/stiffness is classically worse in the morning and is often relieved upon movement. Schober's test is also a test which indicates presence of AS. 

 

Reason others are less likely:
Prolapsed IV disc - No radiculopathy and pain is worse in morning, Schober's test would be negative in this case.

Spinal stenosis - Pain is usually worse on walking and relieved on sitting down (claudication). Also would not be that likely given his age.

Scoliosis - No mention of deformation and pain character not indicative of scoliosis. 

Spondylosis - Highly unlikely in a young patient

Question: What is a measure of high haemoglobin called?
Explanation:
A - Anaemia is low haemoglobin levels.

B - Thrombocytopenia is too few platelets.

C - Thrombocytosis is too many platelets.

D - Haemoglobinopathy is a genetic defect that results in abnormal structure of one of the globin chains of the hemoglobin molecule.

E - Polycythaemia is a high haemagolbin - it is caused by too many cells. A high haemoglobin reading can also come from dehydration as there is too little plasma (Haemoglobin is the concentration of red cells in the blood, not an actual count).

Question:
Viruses use varying molecular mechanisms to replicate depending on which class they are. 

 

What of the following provides the best description for Hepatitis B's Virus replication?
OptionA: Using Host DNA Polymerase to create 2 different RNA intermediaries: a subgenomic RNA which will be used for protein synthesis and a normal genomic RNA for genetic material for new virions
OptionB: Using Host reverse transcriptase to create 1 RNA strand to be used for both protein synthesis and genetic material for new virions
OptionC: Using viral reverse transcriptase to create two separate RNA intermediaries: one will be used as mRNA for protein synthesis and one subgenomic form is used to provide viral +ssDNA
OptionD: Using viral reverse transcriptase to create two separate RNA intermediaries: one will be used as mRNA for protein synthesis and one subgenomic form is used to provide viral dsDNA
OptionE: Using host reverse transcriptase to create two separate RNA intermediaries: one subgenomic form will be used as mRNA for protein synthesis and the other form is used to provide viral +ssRNA
Explanation:
Hepatitis B is a Baltimore Class VII virus. 

This virus will use viral reverse transcriptase to create two separate RNA intermediaries: one will be used as mRNA for protein synthesis and one subgenomic form is used to provide viral dsDNA

 

The only classes to use host polymerases are Classes I and II. These classes are highly dependent on the cell cycle to provide themselves with new proteins and genetic information. They will sometimes overstimulate the cell, leading to uncontrolled cell replication, and cancer. 

eg. HPV, Herpesvirus, Adenovirus

 

Classes, III, IV and V are all standard RNA viruses: ds, +ss and -ss. They all will use viral RNA polymerase. As -ssRNA is not readily transcribable; the sense, or +ve strand is used in transcription; it must be converted to it's +ve counterpart before transcription. dsRNA will be unwound before the +ve strand is used. These all replicate in the cytoplasm. 

 

Class VI, exemplified by HIV, uses it's own reverse transcriptase to create a +ssDNA intermediary which is spliced into host DNA using retroviral integrase. It then will produce viral proteins and viral RNA from this.

Question: A 23 year old man is brought into the ED with a suspected spinal fracture following an RTC. An x-ray is performed and the result is shown below. What type of fracture does this most likely show?
Explanation: This is a distraction fracture as defined in the spinal trauma lecture of Case 14. It is also known as flexion-distraction fracture as it is common in individuals who are involved in RTCs and the seat belt fixes their pelvis but the force flexes their upper spine causing a ripping of the vertebra in a fashion which is shown in the X-ray.

Question: What could a Mean Cell Volume reading of 110fl indicate (outside of pregnancy)?
Explanation:
Mean Cell Volume is used to work out the cause of anaemia. Normal values are between about 80 and 100 fl.

A - an iron deficiency would give a mean cell volume reading of <80fl.

B - an increased MCV reading could be caused by a B12 deficiency, a folate deficiency or a haematological problem.

C - it is actually very difficult to lose iron unless you are bleeding.

D - Vitamin C is not related to anaemia.

E - Hemoglobinopathy is a kind of genetic defect that results in abnormal structure of one of the globin chains of the hemoglobin molecule.

Question: A primary, malignant tumour is found in the vertebrae of a 25 year old man. Which of the following would you most likely suspect is present?
Explanation:
"A primary, malignant tumour" provides all the information needed as primary rules out metastases, malignant rules out haemangioma and meningiomas (rarely malignant). AML does not cause a solid tumour. 

 

Osteosarcoma is the most common tumour of the bone as discussed in the Spinal cancer lecture of Case 14. Multiple myeloma could also be the cause of this tumour, however it was not an option.

Question: The primary afferent fibres in muscle spindles are?
Explanation:
Ia fibres are primary afferent (sensory) fibres of muscle spindles.

Ib fibres are the primary afferent fibres in Golgi tendon organs

II fibres are secondary afferent fibres in muscle spindles

Alpha and Gamma fibres are efferent fibres to muscle spindles. 

 

Source: Case 14 - "Normal nerve physiology and nerve injury"

Question: Which of the following statements about mast calls and basophils is untrue?
OptionA: Mast cells and basophils are activated to degranulate by IgE.
OptionB: Mas cells and basophils secrete major basic protein, which can attack parasitic infections like worms extracellularly.
OptionC: Mast cells and basophills both secrete leukotrienes to attract eosinophils to parasitic infections like worms.
OptionD: Mast cells and basophils secrete histamine, a vasodilator that also increases capillary wall permeability.
OptionE: Mast cells and basophils appear with dark, bi-lobed nuclei and numerous, large, darkly-staining granules.
Explanation: All are true except B; It is eosinophils that secrete major basic protein (along with peroxidase and cationic protein) after they have been attracted to the site of the worm infection by the leukotrienes from the mast cells and basophils. MBP attacks the worm extracellularly, and cationic protein is a neurotoxin.

Question: Which of the following statements are untrue about the lectin pathway of the complement system?
OptionD: Mannan-binding lectin (MBL) binds to carbohydrate on the pathogen surface.
OptionE: C3 convertase cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.
Explanation:
1. Mannan-binding lectin (MBL) binds to carbohydrate on the pathogen surface.
  2. MASP (MBL-associated serine proteases) is activated by this binding.
  3. MASP cleaves C2 and C4.
  4. C4b2a is formed (C3 convertase).
  5. C3 convertase cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

C3bBb is formed via the alternative pathway.

Question: You are sitting in on a consultation with a 19 year old patient who is suspected of having a spinal tumour. The tumour was found in the anterior column of the spine, after having increasing pain over the last couple of weeks. The mass is not palpable however, and he has no other symptoms. You have become emotionally attached to the patient and their story and you are desperately hoping it's not a malignant tumour. Which part of the history most supports that the tumour is benign?
Explanation:
Pain is often the only symptom of a spinal tumour and so lack of other symptoms does not give indication if benign or malignant. Only 22% of spinal tumours are palpable. Acute onset is associated with a poorer prognosis as is being located in the anterior column of the spine. 

 

Their age however is indicative of a benign prognosis (68% benign if under 21). 

 

All facts taken from Mr McCarthy's lecture on spinal tumours.

Question: A patient has Activation Induced Deaminase deficiency, which immunoglobulin is likely to have be increased in their plasma?
Explanation:
In AID deficiency class switching is significantly reduced as AID is involved in the DNA rearrangement of the heavy constant region.

Therefore they have high levels of IgM as this is the first antibody produced and doesn't need any gene rearrangement in order to be produced. There would also be a lack of antibodies of other classes, which is likely to cause some immunodeficiency. 

 

This is known as hyperIgM deficiency and can also be caused by a genetic deficiency of the CD40 ligand, which prevents interactions between B cells and helper T cells, which are also essential for class switching to occur!

Question: Which of the following statements regarding hunger and satiety is correct?
OptionD: A lesion to the lateral hypothalamus causes anorexia
Explanation:
The ventromedial hypothalamus promotes satiety, it is the lateral hypothalamus which promotes hunger. Hence a lesion to the lateral hypothalamus will stop these hunger signals and lead to decreased appetite and feeding (anorexia). 

 

CCK, along with PYY, are released in the short term after a meal to increase satiety. High blood glucose is likely to cause feelings of satiety not hunger. Orexin promotes wakefulness and hunger, not satiety.

Question: Which of the following areas of the brain is NOT correctly matched with it's associated neurotransmitter pathway?
Explanation: D is the answer - The tuberomammillary nucleus is associated with the histamine pathway, not acetylcholine.

Question: Which of the following receptors is diazepam an agonist?
Explanation:
Diazepam is a benzodiazepine. These drugs are common short term anxiolytics and are agonists of GABAA receptors which are fast acting inhibitor receptors in the nervous system. Benzodiazepines therefore cause CNS depression.

 

Note; 5-HT3 receptors are found in the GI tract and brain and are involved in nausea etc. Antagonists of these receptors are used to treat nausea.

Question: Which of the following statements about neurotransmitters is incorrect?
OptionA: Glutamate binds to NMDA and AMPA receptors on the post-synaptic membrane.
OptionB: Low dopamine levels are associated with Schizophrenia.
OptionC: Damage to the acetylcholine pathways is associated with memory deficits in Alzheimer's disease.
OptionD: Serotonin is found to be low in some patients with depression.
Explanation:
The answer is B - Dopamine levels tend to be high in schizophrenia not low. Low levels of dopamine are often found in patients with Parkinson's disease.

All of the other options are correct.

Question: A 67 year old patient presents to you with localised pain in the right regimental badge area of the shoulder. Which of the following infections would you want to ask specifically about given this presentation?
Explanation: The pain is over a specific dermatome area which is indicative of varicella-zoster virus infection. The virus causes shingles and infects certain dermatomes. Following the infection there may be nerve damage which leads to pain in the dermatome area, this is known as postherpetic neuralgia.

Question: Where do the mesothelials cell which form the epicardium originate?
Explanation:
Epicardium becomes the Visceral Pericardium. 

 

Mesothelial cells from the outflow also contribute. 

 

Source: Langmans

Question: In this image of a dilated heart tube, what structure, coloured green,  is the  label pointing to?
Explanation: Source - langmans and heart development lecture

Question: Cardiac progenitor cells migrate to which area of the mesoderm, which becomes the initial site of cardiovascular development.
Explanation:
Axial Mesoderm forms the notochord

Paraxial mesoderm forms the somties

Intermediate connects the lateral and axial mesoderms. 

Somatic Mesoderm associates with the ectoderm and forms the body wall.

Question: By the start of the 3rd week the mesoderm starts to be arranged into somitomeres, which become somites. What do the medial cells of somites become?
Explanation:
The medial cells migrate to the notochord and become sclerotomes, which form the axial skeleton, ribs and vertebrae

Ventrolateral cells form myotomes, which give rise to dorsal epimeres (forms erector spinal), ventral hypomeres (muscles of the body wall) and limb bud (gives rise to limb musculature)

Dorsomedial cells form dermatomes, which gives rise to the dermis of the skin

 

.

Question: Which of the following would you expect to be raised when a foetus has Edward's Syndrome?
Explanation: All the other results would be decreased in Trisomy 18/Edward's syndrome.

Question: A patient is brought into the ED after an RTC. His breathing is heavy, his pulse is 130 and he has a BP of 120/60. The patient flexes to pain, does not open his eyes and is mumbling unintelligible words. What is an appropriate first step in management?
Explanation: This patient has a GCS of 6. This indicates airway management is needed as GCS is less than 8. A CT scan may well be needed however the airway is a more urgent concern. Cricothyrotomy could be used if intubation is unsuccessful as the upper airway is blocked, as may as tracheotomy, however neither would be performed before intubation. DC cardioversion may also be needed however not enough information is given here to indicate it.

Question: You visit a patient on a ward who was recently involved in an accident. You notice that they have bruising around the eyes as shown below. What injury do you suspect they may have sustained?
Explanation: Basilar skull fracture will cause periorbital ecchymosis (bruising around the eyes) and Battle's sign which is brusing behind the ears. The other options may also have occurred however they are not in indicated simply by periorbital ecchymosis.

Question: Which of the following is a muscular change during pregnancy?
Explanation:
In pregnancy there are:

  • Shortened Hip flexors, Low Back muscles and pectorals
  • Elongated Abdominal muscles and upper back muscles

Question: Which of the following signals the end of the 1st stage of labour?
Explanation:
1st stage - onset of regular contraction to full dilation of the cervix

2nd stage - Complete dilatation to the baby being born. Can be split into 2 stages: Propulsive/passive phase and expulsive/ejective phase.

3rd stage - Delivery of placenta - approximately 30mins later. Syntometrine decreases this time.

Question: Which of the following is a pro-labour factor?
Explanation:
Although the precise mechanism of labour is unclear. It is thought to be a balance between pro-labour and pro-pregnancy factors. 

 

Pro-labour factors

  • Oestrogens - increase oxytocin receptor expression
  • Oxytocin - potent uterine contractility stimulator
  • Prostaglandins - promote cervical ripening and increase contractility (both directly and indirectly by increasing oxytocin receptors). Potentiate contractions by stimulating gap junctions. Increasing levels may be mediated by maternal corticotrophin releasing hormone. 

Pro-pregnancy factors:

  • Progesterone decrease uterine oxytocin receptor sensitivity and increases SM relaxation. 
  • NO
  • Catecholamines act on myometrial cell membrane to alter contractility 
  • Relaxin

Question:
A 35 year old woman comes in to see you. She has a BMI of 28 (higher than her last recording) and has a past history of smoking and heavy drinking, though she has recently given up. 

 

Her ECG shows inverted T-waves in lead III, deep Q waves in leads I and II and some left axis deviation. 

 

What has most likely caused these abnormalities?
Explanation:
The rise of the diaphragm during pregnancy can lead to a change in orientation of the heart, which causes some abnormalities in the ECG (even if it is a healthy pregnant woman)

  • left axis deviation is common
  • sagging ST segments
  • inversion or flattening of the T wave in lead III 
  • deep Q waves in leads I and II.

I did not mention that she is pregnant (to try and catch you out), however the fact that she has recently given up smoking and drinking and has an increased BMI may be of some indication.

Question: The motor cortex of the brain is derived from which embryological part of the central nervous system?
Explanation:
The telencephalon gives rise to the cerebral hemispheres and basal ganglia, thus the cortex is part of this part. 

Diencephalon gives rise to the thalamus in the forebrain

Mesencephalon is the midbrain

Myelencephalon gives rise to the medulla oblongata

Metencephalon gives rise to the pons and cerebellum

Question: Which immune system cells/molecules are thought to be related to depression?
Explanation: There is an increase in cytokine release in some depressed patients. Cytokines provoke HLA activity. It is also thought that cytokines can induce the expression of the tryptophan-metabolising enzyme indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase. This causes a decrease in tryptophan.

Question: What is the effect of total sleep deprivation on a depressed patient?
Explanation: Total sleep deprivation and selective REM deprivation can temporarily alleviate mood in depressed patients.

Question: Which of these is unlikely to occur in a depressed patient?
OptionC: Increased latency to the onset of REM sleep
OptionD: Increase in the proportion of REM sleep early
Explanation: C is incorrect, depressed patients often show a decreased latency to the onset of REM sleep, whilst all the others are commonly seen changes in the sleep patterns of depressed patients.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding TLRs is incorrect?
OptionA: TLR2 and TLR6 are sometimes expressed as a hetrodimer
OptionB: TL3, 7, 8 and 9 are all found on Endosomes
OptionC: TLR 7 is expressed in Natural Killer Cells
OptionE: TLR 5 is expressed in cells in the Intestinal Epithelium
Explanation:
A - correct - TLR 2 can be expressed as a hetrodimer with TLR 6 as well as TLR 1

B - correct - TLR 3, 7, 8 and 9 are all expressed on the endosomes

C - correct - TLR 7 is expressed in NK Cells along with dendritic cells, eosinophills and B cells

D - incorrect - TLR 3 detechs double stranded viral RNA

E - correct - TLR 5 is expressed within the intestinal epithelium and detects flagellin with is present on most motile bacteria

 

Source: James Matthew's Lecture, Case 9

Question: Which of the following statements regarding blood sugar levels is correct?
OptionA: Haemoglobin only becomes glycated in hyperglycaemic conditions
OptionC: Hypoglycaemia leads to breath smelling like "pear drops"
OptionE: Diabetic ketoacidosis is significantly more common in Type 2 diabetics
Explanation:
A is incorrect as haemoglobin will become glycated (to form HbA1c) in the presence of glucose. A greater percentage becomes glycated in hyperglycaemic states however in non-diabetics a certain level of haemoglobin will be glycated (about 20–40 mmol/mol (4–5.9 DCCT %))

 

B is correct as DKA has a significantly raised blood glucose which will mean the kidneys will be unable to reabsorb all filtered glucose. This means that water will enter the urine down its osmotic gradient. This in turn draws sodium and other ions into the urine, depleting ions and causing hyponatraemia. This process is known as osmotic diuresis and is why IV NaCl is part of the emergency treatment of DKA.

 

C is incorrect, the pear drop smell is caused by excess ketones and so is a common sign of DKA i.e. hyperglycaemia.

 

D is incorrect, giving insulin to a patient having a hypo will likely cause coma and death. 

 

E is incorrect, DKA is relatively uncommon in T2DM but is a common presentation in T1 diabetics. Type 2 diabetics can have hyperglycaemic hyperosmolar, non-ketosis (HONK) which is where there is the issue associated with hyperglycaemia but without the ketones present.

Question: Complements are part of the...
Explanation: Plenary - Immunological responses to viruses phase a (case 9)

Question: Which of the following statements regarding Angiotensin II is correct?
OptionC: Angiotensin II directly increases sodium reabsorption in the kidney
OptionD: Angiotensin II is formed from cleaving of peptide bond from angiotensinogen
OptionE: Increased NaCl detected by the macula densa will lead to increased angiotensin II
Explanation:
A is incorrect as Ramipril is an ACE inhibitor and so competitively inhibits ACE, the enzyme which forms Ang II from Ang I. It is Losartan which blocks AT1 receptors. 


B is incorrect as it is AT1 receptors which mediate angiotensin II's effects of increased blood volume, increased blood pressure etc. AT1 are present on the adrenal cortex and stimulate aldosterone release.

 

C is correct. Ang II, whilst causing aldosterone release, also binds directly to the kidney and stimulates sodium reuptake (via Na/H exchanger)

 

D is incorrect, it is Angiotensin I which is formed from Renin cleaving angiotensinogen. Angiotensinogen is mainly released by the liver.

 

E is incorrect as a decrease in NaCl concentration sensed by the macula densa will cause stimulation of juxtoglomerular cells to release renin and therefore lead to raised Ang II. This is part of the tuberoglomerular feedback to ensure normal GFR as a low NaCl indicates low GFR.

Question: Which class of antidepressants block and Na+/Ca2+ coupled transporter to cause their effects?
Explanation: SSRI's MOA is blocking an Na+/Ca2+ coupled serotonin transporter which prevents the re-uptake of serotonin.

Question:
Which antidepressant is the following the adverse effect profile of?

Dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, postural hypotension, arrhythmias, sedation and weight gain.
Explanation:
Because TCA's are non-specific blockers of monoamine uptake they have a very wide side effect profile.

The effects can be split into these groups, depending on what kind of neurones are affected:

Muscarinic ACh receptors - dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation.

Alpha 1 & 2 adrenergic receptors - postural hypotension.

Noradrenaline uptake block in the heart - arrhythmias.

H1-blocking effects - sedation.

5-HT, neuropeptide Y in the hypothalamus - decreases leptin (weight gain).

Question: Whilst in the St David's Centre on a Saturday afternoon you encounter a member of the public who looks extremely confused and seems to be clammy and agitated. You ask them what is wrong and they say they are a diabetic and they may have forgotten to take their insulin. They don't have a blood sugar monitor on them but they do have a few preparations of insulin. Which of the following would be best to give in this situation?
Explanation:
The symptoms of this patient are more suggestive of a hypoglycaemic event. The fact that the patient is telling you that they missed their insulin is not enough of a reason to give insulin especially considering they are confused. If this patient was indeed having a hypo giving them insulin could kill them and so without a blood sugar reading giving insulin is a bad idea. Giving them lucozade will help bring them out of a hypo if that's what they have but even if they're having a hyperglycaemic event, lucozade will do little to exacerbate the condition. 

Calling 999 would probably be advised in this situation especially if they did not respond to the lucozade.

Question: Deborah has recently been diagnosed with glaucoma. Her GP has prescribed her the drug Pilocarpine which acts to open the canal of Schlem to drain excess aqueous humour thereby relieving the intraocular pressure. This is achieved by contraction of the ciliary muscle. With this information what is the mechanism of action of Pilocarpine?
Explanation:
The parasympathetic ANS is responsible for accommodation, causing the lens to change into a thick, convex shape which then can focus light better for near objects. During accommodation, the ciliary muscle contracts and the suspensory ligaments slacken off causing the lens to become thicker. This action opens the canal of Schlem helping to drain excess aqueous humour and is a treatment for glaucoma. Pilocarpine therefore acts as a mAChR agonist. 

 

Tropicamide - mAChR antagonist - causes pupil dilation.

Cocaine - Na+ voltage gated channel blocker and sympathiomimetic - loss of corneal reflex, pupil dilation and white sclera (peripheral vasoconstriction)

Tetracaine - Na+ voltage gated channel blocker - loss of corneal reflex

Phenylephrine - Alpha adrenoceptor agonist - pupil dilation, white sclera (peripheral vasoconstriction))

Question: Which of the following does not induce lipolysis?
Explanation: Insulin is the key "anti-lipolytic" hormone as it causes adipose tissue to take up lipid molecules in the blood and from triglycerides. All the other hormones induce lipolysis. Note that glucagon also induces lipolysis.

Question: A 29 year old patient comes into the GP surgery as he's been suffering headaches and has lost a bit of weight. Upon taking a more detailed history he tells you he's being having some palpitations (his pulse is 130) and sudden intense feelings of panic. You also note that he was prescribed ramipril a few weeks ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: It is unlikely that he is having all these symptoms due to the ramipril. The fact he is on ramipril at his age is significant however as essential hypertension is unusual in under 30s. Whilst the feelings of panic could indicate anxiety, the combination of palpitations, tachycardia weight loss, headaches and hypertension all indicate phaeochromocytoma. A phaeochromocytoma is a tumour of the adrenal medulla which leads to hypersecretion of adrenaline leading to the symptoms described above. It is most common in younger patients. Another possible differential would be hyperthyroidism.

Question: You are performing an abdominal exam on a 57 year old man and notice that his nails are spoon-shaped. What is the most likely cause of this nail deformity?
Explanation:
The characteristic spoon nails are called called koilonychia and are often caused by a chronic iron deficiency.

 

http://diseasespictures.com/koilonychia/

Question: In the Foetal Circulation which feature leads to bypass of the foetal liver?
Explanation:
Ductus Venosus-corrrect answer, becomes Ligamentum venosum (after closing within minutes of birth and anatomically within 1wk)

Foramen Ovale-incorrect (is the Right atria to Left atrial bypass duct) becoming the fossa ovale after the first breath (due to pressure in LA>RA)

Ductus Arteriosus-incorrect (is the shunt from pulmonary vessels to the aorta for the blood that gets into the Right ventricle-closed on first breath due to bradykinin release from the lungs) becomes the ligamentum arteriosus after 1-3 months.

Question: The primary somatosensory cortex is found in which anatomical area of the brain ?
Explanation: The Primary Somatosensory Cortex (Broadman's Area 1,2,3) is located directly behind the central sulcus so belongs to the parietal lobe.

Question: During the corneal reflex which cranial nerve causes the eyes to close?
Explanation:
The efferent (motor) limb is the facial nerve which innervates Orbicularis oculi muscle (blinking muscle). It's the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (V1) of which provides sensory innervation to the cornea which is then relayed to CN VII.

The corneal reflex can be used to assess brain function in unconscious and comatosed patients. It is also part of a cranial nerve examination.

Question:
During auscultation of a healthy heart, the first heart sound may be occasionally split by a very small interval (20-30 milliseconds) with the first sound being louder than the second. 

 

What causes this separation in the first heart sound?
OptionB: The closure of each AV valve: tricuspid first (loud) followed by mitral (quiet)
OptionD: The closure of each AV valve: mitral first (loud) followed by tricuspid (quiet.)
Explanation:
The first heart sound can be very slightly split in the healthy heart (by about 20-30milliseconds) due to the closure of the mitral valve happening just before the tricuspid. The closure of the mitral valve is usually louder than the closure of the tricuspid. 

 

http://www.easyauscultation.com/cases?coursecaseorder=2&courseid=23

 

In RBBB, the first heart sound is also split, however the separation is quite significant (about 50 milliseconds.)

Question: You are examining a patient on a ward and upon feeling their carotid pulse notice an irregularity. The waveform of that pulse is shown below. What condition do you suspect this patient may have?
Explanation: The pulse is known as pulsus alternans as the pulse alternates between one strong beat and one weak one. It is a classic sign of significant left sided heart failure. It is due to a weak contraction increasing the end-diastolic volume and stretching during the next contraction, leading to a great contraction (Frank-Starling law). This cycle is then perpetuated creating pulsus alternans.

Question: Regarding structural brain development in adolescents, which of the following is correct?
OptionA: Grey matter does not change at all, except when the adolescent takes a bang to the head due to 'risk taking behaviour' typical of their age.
OptionB: Grey matter increases up to puberty, then decreases from then on, and is uniform across all brain areas.
OptionC: White matter decreases through puberty, thought to be due to synaptic pruning of scarcely used neurons.
OptionD: White matter increases most in the telencephalon (cerebral hemispheres) and least in the diencephalon (thalamus and hypothalamus), peaking in the person's 40s.
OptionE: White matter increases uniformly across all brain areas, most evident in males
Explanation:
White matter increases through adolescence, thought to be due to increased myelination of axons.  This occurs uniformly across all brain areas, is more evident in males, and peaks in 40s.

Grey matter changes vary by brain area.  Overall however, grey matter increases prior to puberty then decreases during and after puberty (so occurs 1-2 years earlier in girls) - this is thought to be due to synaptic pruning.

 

A is incorrect because grey matter does change even without trauma resulting from risk taking.

B is incorrect because grey matter changes are not uniform across the brain

C is incorrect because it refers in general terms to the changes that occur in grey matter, rather than white matter

D is incorrect because white matter increases uniformly across the brain

 

Source: Adolescent Neurocognitive Development lecture, Case 12

Question: A female patient comes to see you in your genetic counselling clinic. They are concerned about the risk that their offspring could develop a genetic condition. This condition is autosomal recessive, and from a family history, you deduce that their father has a 1/3 chance of carrying the condition. If the father is a carrier, then she has a 50% chance of also being a carrier. She has a genetic test which is 80% sensitive and 100% specific, to determine whether she is a carrier. The test comes back negative. What is the chance that the lady is still a carrier of the condition?
Explanation:
The way I lay out the solution to these sorts of question is different to the way we have been taught, so it may suit some of you but not others. If anyone studied statistics at A level, this might make more sense as it puts it in similar terms to what we learnt back then.

 

Let A and B be events, such that:

A = the mother is a carrier

B = the test is negative

 

These events are governed by the relationship : P(A given that B has occurred) = P(A and B) / P(B)

 

P(B) = P(mother is a carrier but the test is negative) + P(mother is not a carrier and the test is negative)

 

P(mother is a carrier but the test is negative) = (1/3 x 1/2) x 1/5 = 1/30

(1/3 x 1/2) is the chance the mother is a carrier

1/5 is the chance the test is negative when the mother is in fact a carrier (as the test is 80% sensitive)

 

P(mother is not a carrier and the test is negative) = (1/3 x 1/2) + 2/3 = 5/6

(1/3 x 1/2) is the chance the father is a carrier but this is not passed on to the mother, and therefore the test will be negative (as it is 100% specific)

2/3 is the chance the father is not a carrier, and therefore the mother is definitely not a carrier and the test will be negative (as it is 100% specific)

 

Therefore P(B) = 1/30 + 5/6 = 13/15

 

 

P(A and B) = P(mother is a carrier but the test is negative)

P(mother is a carrier but the test is negative) = (1/3 x 1/2) x 1/5 = 1/30

(1/3 x 1/2) is the chance the mother is a carrier

1/5 is the chance the test is negative when the mother is in fact a carrier (as the test is 80% sensitive)

 

Therefore, P(A and B) = 1/30

 

 

Therefore, P(A given that B has occurred) = (1/30) / (13/15) = 1/26

Question: Gwenda has been admitted to hospital following a fall down the stairs 45 minutes ago. Scans reveal a fracture at the Pterion which may result most likely in damage to which artery underlying the region?
Explanation: The pterion is a H shaped suture at the joining of he sphenoid, frontal, temporal and parietal bones.It is te weakest point of the skull and can be damaged eithere directly or indirectly via trauma to the top or back of he head. Underlying it is the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery

Question: What is the most common cause of heart failure?
Explanation:
Sources: Kumar and Clark, Dr Yousef's lectures. 

 

ALL of the above can cause heart failure.

Question:
Mr James, aged 76, has been diagnosed with heart failure as a result of heart attack 2 years ago. In the last few days, his symptoms have worsened, in particular his breathlessness.

Although he seems relatively comfortable in his chair, he now finds it difficult to walk from room to room in his house. He says he has been sleeping in his chair the last few nights as he finds it much more comfortable, although he still wakes up at night feeling breathless. 

 

In the NYHA classification of Heart Failure, what class does Mr James fall into?
Explanation: Taken from Kumar and Clarke

Question: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a complication of which of the following?
Explanation: Virology tutorial sheet + plenary [case 9]

Question: A 26 year old nulliparous women in her first trimester is addmitted to hospital with intractable vommiting,  7% of prepregnancy weight has been lost, dehydration and ketosis and shows clear signs of fatigue. Which of the following conditions do you most likely suspect?
Explanation:
• Hyperemesis gravidarum is the most severe form of nausea and vomiting in pregnancy, characterized by persistent nausea and vomiting associated with ketosis and weight loss (>5% of prepregnancy weight). This condition may cause volume depletion, electrolytes and acid-base imbalances, nutritional deficiencies, and even death. Severe hyperemesis requiring hospital admission occurs in 0.3-2% of pregnancies. 
  • Although some of the other conditions share symptoms such as nausea and vommiting, the combination of all thesse symptoms given the lady is pregnent most likey points to hyperemesis gravidarum 
  • For some basic further information on symptoms:
  1. a. http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/thyroid-over-active/pages/introduction.aspx
  2. b. http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/pregnancy-and-baby/pages/morning-sickness-nausea.aspx#close
  3. c. http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/pregnancy-and-baby/pages/severe-vomiting-in-pregnancy-hyperemesis-gravidarum.aspx
  4. d. http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/thyroid-under-active/pages/introduction.aspx
  5. e. http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hypoparathyroidism-hyperparathyroidism/pages/introduction.aspx

Question:
Although Rhodri likes to grow healthy prize winning veg his true love is eating Krispy Kreme doughnuts. Over the years his weight has increased dramatically and last year he presented to his GP with signs of peripheral neuropathy, blood tests revealed:

  • Fasting glucose 8mmol/L
  • Random glucose 14mmol/L

Part of Rhodris treatment involved Gliclazide, what is wrong with Rhodri and how does this drug work?
Explanation:
Fasting glucose >7.0mmol/L

Random glucose >11.1mmol/L

strong genetic component as very high concordance in mono zygotic twins

type 2 most likely as overweight, presenting with complications of hyperglycaemia suggesting long term development (type 1 has rapid onset and presents with acute symptoms of hypoglycaemia/DKA)

Gliclazide is an example of a sulfonylurea which works by inhibiting membrane bound K+ channels resulting in depolarization of the B islet cell and insulin release

Metfromin is an example of  a biguanide which works by increasing peripheral glucose uptake and decreasing glucose release from the liver

Question: B12 deficiency is best described as which type of anaemia?
Explanation:
B12 and folic acid deficiency anaemia are both Megaloblastic Anaemias, which do fall under the Macrocytic (MCV>100) branch but the question asked which 'best describes' B12 deficiency.

Pernicious anaemia is also a form of megaloblastic anaemia.

Non-Megaloblastic also falls under the Macrocytic group.

Microcytic anaemias (MCV<80) include anaemia of chronic disease and iron deficiency anaemia.

 

A lot of you are picking Macrocytic Anaemia, you are indeed correct but the question asks which 'best' describes B12 anaemia.

I havent designed this as a trick question, just one to provoke looking at the question and reading it properly as in the SBA exam it might be set out in this kind of way :)
Tags: Anaemia, Blood Cells, Gastroenterology, Gastrointestinal System

Question: Which statements regarding the acid-base system is incorrect?
OptionA: There are two major sources of acid in the body, volatile and non-volatile
OptionB: Ammonium ions secreted in the kidney are produced from glutamine
OptionC: Intercalated cells are the cells in the kidney involved in acid-base homoeostasis
OptionD: An increase in PaCO2 concentration will cause an increased respiratory drive
OptionE: High levels of CO2, causes the Bohr shift (causes the O2-saturation curve to shit to the left)
Explanation:
A - there are two forms of acid: Volatile (mainly carbonic acid removed from the lungs) and non-volatile acid (such as the phosphate system, removed by the kidneys) 

B - Ammonium ions are produced from the deamination of glutamine (and there subsequent formed glutamate), which forms two Ammonium ions 

C - Intercalated cells are involved with acid-base control, while the principle cells are involved in electrolyte balance

D - An increased PaCO2 is sensed by the peripheral chemoreceptors and this triggers the respiratory centre in the medulla to increase respiratory drive

E - Carbon Dioxide does indeed bind to haemoglobin (forming carbaminohaemoglobin) and causes the Bohr shift, however this caused a shift to the right of the curve.

Question: On placement with a health visitor you see a healthy 9 month old baby boy, whose development is at a normal rate. How have his speech and language skills so far developed?
OptionA: he is beginning his first early words
OptionC: he is waving and clapping, babbling and responds to "no" and his name
OptionD: can say 50 words and some 2 word phrases
Explanation:
A - This is what you would expect of a 1 year old 

B - cooing and gurgling is what you would expect of a normal 3-6 month old 

C - correct! you would expect this in normal development at 9 months old 

D - 2 years old 

E - newborn 

 

 

Information is from case 9, plenary 1, Child Development

Question: During meiosis I when does the crossing over of homologous chromosomes occur?
Explanation:
The interchange of chromatid segments between homologous chromosome, known as crossing over occurs in Meiosis I during late prophase. 

 

It doesn't occur in Meiosis II as homologous chromosomes don't exist.

 

http://cyberbridge.mcb.harvard.edu/mitosis_6.html

Question: When at an annual family gathering one of your distant relatives has had a baby girl in the past year. You notice the baby can roll prone to supine, she can sit up and when she is prone can push up on extended arms. You know that the baby is developing normally and you guess that her age is..
Explanation:
A - at 0-3 months you would expect the baby to be able to turn head to side when supine, and prop up on forearms when prone 

 

B - this is partly correct as they can roll prone to supine and push up on extended arms, however do not begin to sit until 5-9 months 

 

C - correct! babies begin to sit up 5-9 months in normal development 

 

D - at 9 months the baby should be able to roll supine to prone, crawl on their hands and knees, and pull to stand with support 

 

E - At 1 the baby should be able to cruise with support, crawl upstairs and begin walking on average at 13 months 

 

 

 

Information from Case 9, Plenary 1, Child Development

Question: Which statements regarding insulin secretion and its functions is incorrect?
OptionA: Incretins such as Glucagon like Peptide suppress the secretion of insulin
OptionB: Insulin is required for Glucose uptake via the GLUT-4 transporters
OptionC: Insulin activates  Phosphoprotein Phosphatase which activates PFK-2 in the liver
OptionD: Insulin binds to a glycoprotein surface receptor and causes the activation of tyrosine kinase
OptionE: Glucokinase is present in the pancreatic beta cells
Explanation:
A - Incretins actually increase the levels of insulin produced in the pancreas 

B & D- GLUT-4 is insulin responsive glucose transporter, when insulin binds to the glycoprotein receptor which causes a conformational changes activating tyrosine kinase

C - Half of the insulin secreted by the pancreas is extracted and degraded in the liver. In the liver is activates Phosphoprotein Phosphatase which activates PFK-2. This increases the rate of glycolysis and therefore glycogenesis and TAG synthesis

E - glucokinase is hexokinase izozyme, and is only found in pancreatic and liver cells. It is not inhibited by its products whereas hexokinase is

Question: For which of these would you NOT advise DC cardioversion
Explanation: You would defibrillate someone in VF in order to convert them back to sinus

Question:
Brenda walks into the GP surgery, and you look over at the computer where her drug history is recorded. 

It mentioned a consultation where Brenda reported some hair loss, diarrhoea and increased appetite. 

You see that propylthiouracil was prescribed after the consultation. 

 

Propylthiouracil is a...
OptionA: Drug to treat hypothyroidism - by increasing the stimulation of the pituitary cells
OptionB: Drug to treat hypothyroidism - by increasing the amount of iodine that enters the follicular cell
OptionC: Drug to treat hyperthyroidism - by decreasing the hypothalamus's sensitivity to the negative feedback from T4 and T3
OptionD: Drug to treat hyperthyroidism -  by blocking iodination of thyroglobulin
Explanation:
Propylthiouracil is a drug to treat hyperthyroidism as it blocks the iodination of thyroglobulin. Thyroglobulin (glycoprotein) is released by the thyroid follicular cell as the iodine moves through the apical membrane. This leads to a decrease T4 and T3 production. 

 

Plenary 4, Case 10, Slide 28
Tags: Hypothalamus, Endocrine, Thyroid Gland, Case 10, Physiology

Question:
Avagadro has a law, Starlings got one too, Einstein has more, But La place has quite a few.

What does La place's law describe?
OptionA: The relationship between the reduction potential of a half-cell at any point in time to the standard electrode potential, temperature, activity, and reaction quotient of the underlying reactions and species used
OptionB: Equal volumes of all gases, at the same temperature and pressure, have the same number of molecules
OptionC: The relationship between the radius of the chamber, the pressure of the cavity, the regional wall thickness and the stress on the wall
OptionD: Stroke volume of the heart increases in response to an increase in the volume of blood filling the heart when all other factors remain constant.
OptionE: Volume flow through the heart is determined by pressure and viscous resistance. The viscous resistance depends on viscosity and size of the chamber as well as its radius.
Explanation:
A- Nernst

B - Avagadro

C - La Place: it tell us that if a ventricle hypertrophies, it normalises wall stress. So initially if there is hypertrophy (triggered by increased pressure) then the tissue (i have the heart in mind) will compensate allowing the heart to continue normal function (until a combination of factors results in decompensation)

D - Starlings law

E - A slightly wrong Poiseuille's Law

Question: Insulin is coded for on which chromosome?
Explanation: 11 is the correct answer. The genes that code for insulin at located on this p arm of this chromosome.

Question: When would Metformin be the first line treatment for someone who is just been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes?
Explanation:
NICE guidelines on management of diabetes type 2 (1.5.1.2) state "Consider metformin as an option for first-line glucose-lowering therapy for a person who is not overweight".

This is because lifestyle changes is unlikely to affect them as they are already at an optimum weight.

Question: Which cardiac biomarker has the highest specificity and sensitivity in the detection of acute myocardial infarction?
Explanation:
Cardiac Troponin I and T are the preferred markers of myocardial injury.  Troponin is a protein released from myocytes when irreversible myocardial damage occurs.  It is highly specific to cardiac tissue.  Cardiac troponins T and I are of equal clinical value in terms of their sensitivity and specificity for cardiac damage.

 

Myoglobin is the most sensitive early marker for myocardial infarction (i.e. its levels rise the fastest)

 

CK- MB is found mainly in the heart, but is not as sensitive or as specific as troponin levels.

Question: What is the main abnormality shown in this ECG?
Explanation:
RBBB shown by rSR' pattern in V1 and V2 and wide S waves in lateral leads (V5, V6, I, aVL).

 QRS >120ms

 

 

 

http://lifeinthefastlane.com/ecg-library/basics/right-bundle-branch-block/ Example2

Question: Which of the following is not a suitable treatment for crohns disease?
Explanation:
Mesalazine or 5-aminosalicylic acid is suitable for treatment of UC but not cRohns

Immunosuppressives, corticosteroids and anti TNF drugs can also be used for UC as well as crohns

Question: Which of the following stimulate neutrophil production during inflammation?
Explanation:
• G-CSF (granulocyte-colony stimulating factor) stimulates neutrophil production during inflammation. G-CSF is produced mainly by the endothelium and macrophages. The G-CSF-receptor is present on precursor cells in the bone marrow, and, in response to stimulation by G-CSF, initiates proliferation and differentiation into mature neutrophils (and other granulocytes).
  • IL-8 and TNF are both produced by macrophages to induce chemotaxis in neutrophils, causing them to migrate toward the site of infection. IL-8 also induces phagocytosis once they have arrived.
  • IgE activates mast cells and basophils to degranulate.
  • Leukotrienes are important in parasite infections, as they are secreted by mast cells and basophils to attract eosinophils to the site of the parasite.
Tags: Case 9, Cell Signalling, Immunology, Leukocytes, Blood Cells

Question: A patient presents in A&E from an ambulance with tremor, hyperthermia and cardiovascular collapse. On examination you see that she is tachycardic, sweaty, and is showing hyperreflexia. She is mydriatic. Her friend tells you that she is currently receiving treatment for depression and is on a couple of drugs. He can tell you that one of the drugs is fluoxetine, what do you suspect that the class of the other might be?
Explanation: She is suffering from serotonin syndrome and is a result of the drug-drug interactions between SSRIs and MAOIs. It has been suggested that it can occur with SNRIs and TCAs, but there is much less evidence to support this.

Question: What do Thalassaemia and Sickle Cell disease protect against?
Explanation: The answer is Malaria. Although they are recessive diseases they survive and are prominent in Mediterranean countries especially because they have advantageous properties.

Question: 65 year old George has come into surgery after his wife nagging him to see a doctor about his tingling feet. George has a BMI of 28 and you decide to send him for a blood test, results reveal fasting glucose of 6.5 mmol/L and glucose tolerance (75g 2hr) of 11.0. From this information?
Explanation:
As George is older and overweight and has possible signs of diabetic neuropathy it would be fair to assume that he may have type 2 diabetes. However the diagnostic requirement for diabetes according to the WHO is a fasting glucose of greater than or equal to 7.0 mmol/L and 2hr plasma glucose of greater than or equal to 11.1 mmol/L . In this case his results of 6.5mmol/L and 11.0 mmol/L indicating impaired glucose tolerance. 

Diabetes
Fasting plasma glucose - ≥7.0mmol/l (126mg/dl)

or
2–h plasma glucose* - ≥11.1mmol/l (200mg/dl)
Impaired Glucose Tolerance (IGT)
Fasting plasma glucose - <7.0mmol/l (126mg/dl)

and
2–h plasma glucose*≥7.8 and <11.1mmol/l (140mg/dl and 200mg/dl)
Impaired Fasting Glucose (IFG)
Fasting plasma glucose - 6.1 to 6.9mmol/l (110mg/dl to 125mg/dl)

and (if measured)

2–h plasma glucose* - <7.8mmol/l (140mg/dl)

 

* Venous plasma glucose 2–h after ingestion of 75g oral glucose load
* If 2–h plasma glucose is not measured, status is uncertain as diabetes
or IGT cannot be excluded

 

http://www.who.int/diabetes/publications/Definition%20and%20diagnosis%20of%20diabetes_new.pdf

Question: Which is the key factor in the development of type 2 diabetes?
Explanation: All factors are implicated in the pathogenesis of T2DM, especially peripheral insulin resistance. But evidence suggests that the key factor is the beta cell impairment that ultimately leads to the symptoms. Functioning beta cells can increase insulin release to compensate for resistance, maintaining plasma glucose.

Question: Which of the following is not a part of the immediate innate immune response?
Explanation:
The immediate innate immune response lasts from 0-4 hours following invasion of the pathogen. The pathogen is recognized by the following preformed soluble effector molecules;

  1. Antimicrobial enzymes like lysozyme, which begins to digest bacterial cell walls.
  2. Antimicrobial peptides likes defensins, which lyse bacterial cell membranes.
  3. The complement system (lectin pathway or alternative pathway).

Natural killer cells are a part of the induced innate immune response, which occurs 4 hours to 4 days following the invasion of the pathogen, if the immediate innate immune response has failed to eliminate the pathogen. Phagocytes (macrophages and neutrophils) and degranulating cells (mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils) are also a part of the induced innate immune response.

Question: Brian is feeling unwell because a gram negative bacteria has invaded his body. Which pattern recognition receptor is responsible for recognizing the lipoplolysaccharide (LPS) in this gram negative bacteria?
Explanation:
• TLR4 is the toll-like receptor responsible for the recognition of lipopolysaccharides on gram-negative bacteria. TLR4 is found in the plasma membrane of macrophages, dendritic cells, mast cells, and eosinophils.
  • TLR9 is the toll-like receptor responsible for the recognition of unmethylated CpG-rich DNA is bacteria and viruses. TLR9 is found in the endosomes of plasmacytoid dendritic cells, B cells, eosinophils, and basophils. 
  • TLR5 is the toll-like receptor responsible for the recognition of the flagellin of motile bacteria. TLR5 is found is the plasma membrane of the intestinal epithelium.
  • TLR7 is the toll-like receptor responsible for the recognitions of single-stranded viral RNAs from viruses (e.g. HIV). TLR7 is found in the endosomes of plasmacytoid dentritic cells, NK cells, eosinophils, and B cells. TLR8 is similar, but is only found in NK cells.
  • TLR3 is the toll-like receptor responsible for the recognition of double-stranded viral RNA from viruses (e.g. the West Nile virus). TLR3 is found in the endosomes of NK cells.

Question: Which of the following toll-like receptors are not expressed in endosomal compartments?
Explanation: Toll-like receptors 3, 7, 8, and 9 are all located in endosomes. TLR4 is located in the plasma membrane.

Question:
A patient has been sent to you with bloody diarrhoeaa and abdominal pain. This is an image from their endoscopy.

Which of these is the mostly likely diagnosis?
OptionD: Inflammatory bowel disease, cannot tell if UC or CD more likely
Explanation:
The endoscopy shows cobblestoning which is indicative of Crohn's disease

Cobblestoning (having a cobblestone appearance) can occur in a number of hollow organs with mucosa, most commonly the bowel, in the setting of Crohn's disease.

Longitudinal and circumferential fissures and ulcers separate islands of mucosa, giving it an appearance reminiscent of cobblestones.

Question: 4 of these descriptions describe the pathology of Chron's disease, 1 describes Ulcerative colitis. Identify the statement that is more indicative of UC than CD.
OptionB: Antibody screening positive for pANCA but pANSA negative
OptionC: Fissures can be full thickness of GI tract wall
OptionD: Mean age of diagnosis between 20-40 but commonly presents in adolescence
OptionE: Whole GI tract may be affected, particularly terminal ileum, colon or both.
Explanation:
CD:

Risk factors:

  • smoking 3/4 fold increase risk
  • Appendectomy is a risk factor
  • Certain foods, especially a diet high in fatty foods
  • Exposure to antibiotics, especially in kids/teens likely to develop in next 12 months due to growth of microbes
  • Good domestic hygiene is also a risk factor as intestinal system may not be exposed to enough micro-organisms e.g. helminths
  • NSAID asc. with onset and flare-ups
  • Breast feeding may be protective 
  • chronic stress/depression, NSAIDs likely trigger relapses/flare-ups

Pathology CD

  • Affects whole GI tract, especially small intestine (terminal ileum), colon and anorectal junction. Can less commonly affect mouth, stomach or oesophagus
  • Inflammation is not continuous, skip lesions are commonly present
  • Ulcers can be full thickness of GI tract wall (through muscle/transmural). Deep fissures are formed, scarring down into crypts which can lead to fibrosis and stricture formation
  • Damage can descend into mesentry and cause perforation
  • Bowel will have a thickened, granulomatous wall and a narrowed lumen
  • Cobblestoning often present - longitudinal fissures in transverse mucosal folds
  • Granulomas, fissures and fistulae are common
  • Cancer risk slightly raised
    Clinical signs of CD
  • Symptoms include: diarrhoea (usually containing blood/pus/mucus) with/without malabsorption, abdo pain, tenderness, palpable inflammatory masses in RIF, perianal lesions, apthous mouth ulcers, weight loss
  • Systemic inflammatory response characterised by fever, malaise and weight loss tends to be more pronounced than in CD than UC as most absorption in small bowel (not affected in UC)
  • May have symptoms of anaemia or gall stones due to decreased B12 and bile salt absorption 
  • Blood results show: commonly anaemia (normocytic, normochromic of chronic disease or iron /folate deficiency. Megaloblastic anaemia due to low B12 unusual although B12 may be below normal range
  • FBC: ESR and CRP raised, WBC raised and platelet count raised
  • Hypoabluminaemia
  • pASCA may be positive but pANCA usually negative
  • pan-proctolectomy only used for stricture/abscesses and CD will very often recur after

UC

Risk factors

  • increased risk in non/ex smokers
  • NSAIDs asc. with onset and flare-ups
  • Breast-feeding may be protective
  • Appendectomy also protective
  • Chronic stress/depression can cause flare-ups

Pathology UC

  • Only affects large intestine, not extending to small intestine
  • Rectum almost invariably affected/worst affected, inflammation extends proximally to variable extent but never beyond colon
  • Occassionally can get inflammation of terminal ileum but due to backwash ileitis/ incompetent ileocaecal valve rather than UC itself
  • Damage is contiguous without a break, no skip lesions
  • Ulceration does not extend beyond mucosa
  • damage results in thinner wall and dilated lumen (opposite to CD)
  • Mucosa is granular and haemorrhagic so can lose blood
  • Acute and chronic inflam cells infiltrate mucosa and aggregates of polymorphs seen in crypts 
  • healing of ulcers leads to periods of remission but in healing areas the normal colonic epithelium replaced by layer of simple mucus-secreting cells without crypts, lack of goblet cells
  • Normal colonic crypts are destroyed/distorted and become branched rather than short and straight 
  • Can lead to distension (expands due toinability to clear gas and faeces) and perforation of colon in acute fulminating cases with continuous bleeding. Leads to thin wall predisposing to perforation and death due to faecal peritonitis (toxic megacolon)
  • Blood loss due to haemorrhage can lead to anaemia
    Clinical picture UC
  • Mean age diagnosis 20-40 but can occur at any age
  • Main symptom: bloody exudative diarrhoea
  • Other symptoms: abdo pain, anorexia, malaise, urgency and incontinence (can be disabling), tenesmus 
  • May have symptoms of anaemia
  • Systemic inflammatory response characterised by fever, malaise and weight loss tends to be milder as most absorption in small bowel (not affected in UC)
  • Panproctolectomy usuall curative
  • Blood results: moderate/severe attacks iron def anaemia due to blood loss
  • FBC: WBC and platelet counts raised, ESR and CRP often raised
  • Liver biochem may be abnormal with hypoalbumiaemia occuring in severe disease
  • pANCA may be positive but pANSA negative

Question: The key step in the formation of the mesoderm in gastrulation is?
Explanation:
Formation of the mesoderm is a result of the invagination of epiblast cells (movement toward the primitive streak before being forced downwards, becoming cone shaped and then pinching off), followed by the lateral migration of those epiblast cells.

 

Some of those epiblast cells will also infiltrate the hypoblast and this layer will become the endoderm

Question:
You carry out a Mental State Examine on Mr Lowe. 

 

He tells you "I feel crap, just really really down and just don't want to do anything"

He is smiling and laughs hysterically while telling you this.

 

Which of these would be the best way of recording these findings?
OptionA:
Affect: "I feel crap, just really really down and just don't want to do anything"

Mood: Euphoric, mood incongruous with affect
OptionB:
Affect: Sad, depressed 
Mood: Euphoric, mood incongruous with affect
OptionC: Affect/Mood: Patient told me they felt sad but seemed happy.
OptionD:
Mood: "I feel crap, just really really down and just don't want to do anything"
Affect: Euphoric, incongruous affect
Explanation:
Mood and Affect are different things.

• Mood = subjective, what they say, record quotes e.g. I feel rubbish
• Affect = objective, what the doctor observes, our description, e.g. depressed, euphoric, suspicious restricted, flattened, inappropriate, perplexed, anxious
o Congruous/incongruous
o Do mood and affect match up or is the affect incongruous? A disorganised schizophrenic patient may say they feel very low whilst laughing hysterically – an incongruous affect
o Range of reactivity, good and bad (all one of the other?), may not be able to show much emotion and we could describe this as blunted affect, chronic schizophrenic patient with negative symptoms may show absolutely no emotion= flattened affect.
o Stability: how quickly does mood go up and down? Very quick, may swing from anger to crying to laughing in the space of a few minutes = labile
o Appropriate reactions, touch on various subjects, some happy and some sad and you would expect the person’s affect to react to them. If they show a an appropriate range of affect we can describe this as normal reactivity

Question:
You are speaking to a patient but what they are saying doesn't appear to make much sense. They ponder: "The traffic is rumbling along the main road. They are going to the north. Why do girls always play pantomime heroes"

Which of these best describes what might be going on?
Explanation:
Normal human thinking has three characteristics

1. Content: what is being thought about – this would include delusions and obsessional thoughts

2. Form: in what manner, or shape, is the the thought about; abnormalities of the way thoughts are linked together

3. Stream or flow: how it is being thought about – the amount and speed of thinking

 

Capgras' syndrome

Delusional belief that a close relative has been replaced by an imposter - this is an abnormality of thought content rather than form.

 

Flight of ideas is when the content of speech moves quickly from one idea to another so that one train of thought is not carried to completion before another takes its place. The normal logical sequence of ideas is generally preserved although ideas may be linked by distracting cues in the surroundings and from distractions from the words that have been spoken. These verbal distractions may be of three kinds: clang associations, puns and rhymes. Here there appears to be now link between one sentence and the next.

 

Loosening of associations denotes a loss of the normal structure of thinking. The patient’s discourse seems muddled and illogical and does not become clearer with further questioning; there is a lack of general clarity, and the interviewer has the experience that the more he/she tries to clarify the patient’s thinking the less it is understood. Loosening of associations occurs mostly in schizophrenia

Three kinds of loosening of association have been described:

Knight’s move thinking or derailment where there are odd tangential associations between ideas.

Talking past the point (= vorbeireden) where the patient seems to get close to the point of discussion, but skirts around it and never actually reaches it

Verbigeration (= word salad = schizophasia = paraphrasia) where speech is reduced to a senseless repetition of sounds and phrases (this is more of a disorder of thought form)

 

Nihilism “I am already dead” – seen in severe depression, schizophrenia or dementia. Feel don’t have blood, organs etc., can smell own corpse rotting and can be hard to convince to eat, drink and look after themselves

 

Peseveration is the persistent and inappropriate repetition of the same thoughts. In reply to a question a person may give the correct answer to the first but continue to give the same answer inappropriately to subsequent questions. This is especially seen in ‘organic’ brain disorders like dementia.

 

Useful links:

http://frontierpsychiatrist.co.uk/formal-thought-disorder/

http://www.mental-health-today.com/clinicians/psychosis.htm

Question: How is endosomal toll-like receptor 7 able to bring about transcription of interferon alpha and beta?
Explanation:
A) This is true as interferon response factor 7 (IRF7) is 'activated' so to speak, but this is not the single best answer as it is more correct to say that interferon response factor 7 (IRF7) is phosphorylated.

B) This is incorrect. Interferon response factor 7 (IRF7) actually brings about transcription of interferon alpha and beta. 

C) This is correct. Interferon response factor 7 (IRF7) is phosphorylated, which means it can enter the nucleus to initiate interferon alpha and beta mRNA synthesis.

D) This is incorrect, glycolysis isn't involved in a key way in this pathway.

Question: Which of these statements is not true of interferons?
OptionA: Interferons can activate natural killer cells to kill virus-infected cells.
OptionB: Interferons are usually the cause of systemic symptoms associated with viral infection (including malaise, myalgia, fever etc.)
OptionC: Interferons can induce resistance to viral replication in cells.
OptionD: Interferons can increase expression of ligands for receptors on natural killer cells.
OptionE: Interferons are mainly produced by sentinel cells, macrophages, dendritic cells, and NK cells.
Explanation: E is untrue, as nearly every cell is capable of producing type I interferons (alpha and beta). Toll-like receptors are, however, mainly produced by sentinel cells, macrophages, dendritic cells, and NK cells.

Question: Which of these is most likely a primary delusion rather than a secondary delusion?
OptionA: A bipolar patient believes they are the messiah
OptionB: A depressed patient believes they were responsible for the financial crash
OptionC: A previously divorced patient with low mood suffer's from Othello's syndrome
OptionD: A crying patient believes the world has been subtly altered for the worse and is anticipating a disaster
OptionE: A schizophrenia patient believes their family are under threat
Explanation:
Primary - occur in the mind, fully formed with no preceding reasons; strongly suggestive of schizophrenia. These are distinguished by a transformation of meaning, so that the world, or aspects of it, are interpreted in a radically different way by the delusional person. To others, this intepretation is 'un-understandable' in terms of the normal mental causality, mood, environmental influences and other psychological or psychopathological factors.

Jaspers describes four types of primary delusion:

delusional intuition - where delusions arrive 'out of the blue', without external cause.
