delusional perception - where a normal percept is interpreted with delusional meaning. For example, a person sees a red car and knows that this means their food is being poisoned by the police.

delusional atmosphere - where the world seems subtly altered, uncanny, portentous or sinister. This resolves into a delusion, usually in a revelatory fashion, which seems to explain the unusual feeling of anticipation.

delusional memory - where a delusional belief is based upon the recall of memory or false memory for a past experience. For example, a man recalls seeing a woman laughing at the bus stop several weeks ago and now realises that this person was laughing because the man has animals living inside him.

Secondary delusions (sometimes called delusion-like ideas) are considered to be, at least in principle, understandable in the context of a person's life history, personality, mood state or presence of other psychopathology. For example, a person becomes depressed, suffers very low mood and self-esteem, and subsequently believes they are responsible for some terrible crime which they did not commit eg depressed person feeling worthless.

  • Persecution “someone’s trying to kill me” - In schizophrenia classically persecutory delusions of them or family being under threat, not just someone looking at you funny, being convinced that someone is going to harm or kill you
  •  Grandiosity “I am the new messiah!” (mania)
  • Guilt “I caused the financial crisis”
  • Nihilism “I am already dead” – seen in severe depression, schizophrenia or dementia. Feel don’t have blood, organs etc., can smell own corpse rotting and hard to convince to eat, drink and look after themselves

 

All the other options make sense in context of the patients background

There is no understandable reason why someone, even if you know they are crying, would believe the world had be altered.

Question: Which TLRs are expressed at high levels in plasmacytoid dendritic cells?
Explanation: TLR7 and TLR9 are expressed at high levels in plasmacytoid dendritic cells. These plasmacytoid dendritic cells are extremely important in producing interferon alpha and interferon beta. Plasmacytoid dendritic cells have a large amount of ER which is devoted to protein synthesis, and a large amount of protein output from these cells is IFN alpha and beta. Plasmacytoid dendritic cells produce up to 1000x more interferon than any other cell type.

Question: Which of these is released by NK cells in response to binding with a macrophage in order to make the macrophage a more efficient phagocytes?
Explanation: A macrophage that has phagocytosed a virus will be producing IL12, which activates NK cells and attracts them to the macrophage. The activated NK cells form a synapse with the macrophage, and the macrophage releases IL15 to assist in NK cell expansion and activation. In response, the NK cell releases interferon gamma, which causes a change in the macrophage that makes it a more efficient phagocyte.

Question: After reading about all the possible psychoses and disorders you could have, you develop an unpleasant feeling of being detached from your body and sense of self. Luckily because you are a top notch medical student, you can worry more specifically. Which of these should you be most worried about?
Explanation:
Capgras delusion: is a disorder in which a person holds a delusion that a friend, spouse, parent, or other close family member (or pet) has been replaced by an identical-looking impostor.

 

Charles Bonnet syndrome: common condition among people who have lost their sight. It causes people who have lost a lot of vision to see things that aren't really there,  they experience of complex visual hallucinations. Can occur in person with partial or severe blindness

 

Cotard's delusion/ nihilism: rare mental illness, in which the afflicted person holds the delusion that he or she is dead, either figuratively or literally. “I am already dead” – seen in severe depression, schizophrenia or dementia. Feel don’t have blood, organs etc., can smell own corpse rotting and hard to convince to eat, drink and look after themselves

 

Pereceptional disturbances such as Depersonalisation and derealisation are important as these can occur in the context of anxiety, sleep deprivation, sensory deprivation and drug intoxication. Up to 50% of normal people have experienced this as well

  • Depersonalisation is the unpleasant feeling that you feel detached from your own body and sense of self
  • Derealisation is the feeling that everything around you is not real, fake, plastic or has a “movie-like” quality to it.

Question:
Dora is a 31 year old woman, in labour with her second child. She says she is in a lot of pain. She says it is similar, but worse, than period pain and when asked where the pain is she gestures to her whole abdomen and pelvis. 

Which stage of labour is Dora in and what type of nerve fibres carry the signals?
OptionB: Second stage, slow, unmyelinated A delta fibres
Explanation:
Dora is in the first stage of labour as the pain is described to be crampy and poorly localised. The nerve fibres in the first stage come from T10-L1 via slow, unmyelinated C fibres. 

The second stage of labour causes well localised, sharp pain which comes from T10-L1 and S2-S4 and is caused by fast A delta fibres.

Question: You have witnessed the miracle of birth for the first time. You go back to see the baby a few weeks later and notice that he has short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion borders and a smooth philtrum. Which condition are these a sign of?
Explanation:
The characteristic clinical features of FASD include three facial dysmorphisms (short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border, and smooth philtrum), growth retardation, and central nervous system (CNS) abnormalities. 

 

The predominant clinical features may vary with age. Facial dysmorphisms may be apparent at birth (though may not be recognized). Growth retardation may occur prenatally or postnatally. CNS impairment may not be apparent until the child is in school. Most individuals with FASD are diagnosed during childhood.

 

Other abnormalities that may occur are: 

  • Epicanthal folds
  • Short, upturned nose
  • Ear anomalies including “railroad track ears” (ie, a prominent horizontal crus and prominent and parallel inferior crus of the anthelix)
  • Micrognathia (small jaw)
  • Clinodactyly (curving of the 5th finger
  • “Hockey stick” configuration of the upper palmar crease

Question:
A 72-year-old male with a two year history of type 2 diabetes presents with light headedness, sweats and confusion.
His glucose monitor reveas that he has hypoglycaemia and this responds to a glucose drink.
Which of the following tablets that he takes is most likely to be responsible for this hypoglycaemic episode?
Explanation:
Hypoglycaemia is a feature of sulphonylurea therapies such as gliclazide. glimeperide and glibenclamide through increased pancreatic insulin secretion.

Metformin reduces hepatic glucose output and pioglitazone improves peripheral insulin sensitivity.

Neither of these really produce hypoglycaemia per se.

Question:
A 62-year-old male presented with an eight hour history of double vision.
He has generally been well but has a history of hypertension for which he takes amlodipine and atenolol.
He also has a four year history of diet controlled type 2 diabetes.
On examination he has some watering of the right eye, there is a slight droop of the eyelid and the eye is displaced to the right. Pupil size is the same as on the left and the left eye appears to have a full range of movements.

What is the likely cause of his symptoms?
Explanation:
This man has a painless partial third nerve palsy which affects his eye but there is pupil sparing.

The most likely cause is diabetes as part of a mononeuritis multiplex. This is one of the commonest mononeuropathies associated with diabetes and is thought to be due to a microangiopathy with occlusion of the vasa nervorum.

Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery is associated with an often painful third nerve palsy with pupillary dilatation being typical.

Question:
A patient tells you that their feel really unhappy and tired all the time. They don't have any energy or appetite either. 

 

How many of the classic triad of symptoms of depression is this patient displaying?
Explanation:
Unipolar depression is a psychopathological state with a classic triad of symptoms; low/depressed mood, anhedonia and low energy/fatigue. These symptoms form a depressive illness when they have become pervasive or interfere with normal functioning, and have gone on for more than 2 weeks. Patients can also suffer with physical symptoms, as well as delusions and psychoses in major depression

Anhedonia: defined as the inability to experience pleasure from activities usually found enjoyable, e.g. exercise, hobbies, music, sexual activities or social interactions

Question: Which of the following is a start codon?
what is the action of isoniazid
Explanation: yes, affects cell membranes

Question:
A patient comes into your GP surgery and is found to have high blood pressure.  The doctor does some tests and finds the patient suitable for antihypertensive drug treatment and prescribes a specific drug.

Two days later the patient is admitted to A&E with an arrhythmia and hyperventilation.  What drug did the doctor prescribe?
Explanation:
The doctor prescribed an ACE inhibitor. ACE inhibitors can cause hyperkalaemia, especially in those with renal dysfunction.

Hyperkalaemia can cause metabolic acidosis (less K+ secretion linked with reduced H+ secretion) --> hyperventilation - one of the signs of hyperkalaemia.

Hyperkalaemia can also cause arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death.

The arrhythmia could be caused by digoxin however it wouldn't cause hyperventilation.
Tags: Acid Base Balance, Kidney, Case 10, Case 15, Hypertension

Question: Which of the following statements is not true of MHC molecules?
OptionA: In MHC class I molecules, viral proteins are cleaved and processed into peptide fragments in the cytosol of the infected cell via a proteasome.
OptionB: In MHC class II molecules, viral proteins are cleaved and processed into peptide fragments in an endocytic vesicle in the cytosol.
OptionC: In MHC class II molecules, binding of the viral peptide occurs before the MHC has been through the endoplasmic reticulum.
OptionD: In MHC class II molecules, binding of the viral peptide occurs after the MHC endosome and viral peptide lysosome fuse.
OptionE: In MHC class I molecules, binding of the viral peptide occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum.
Explanation:
Antigen presentation in MHC class I:

  1. Viral peptides are processed in the cytosol of the infected cell in a proteasome.
  2. The peptides are transferred and transported across into the ER.
  3. In the ER, the viral peptides meet and bind to maturing MHC class I.
  4. Once the peptide binding groove is filled the MHC class I is stable and can be trafficked to the cell membrane to present to the T cells.

Antigen presentation in MHC class II:

  1. Viral peptides are processed in the cytosol of the infected cell in endocytic vesicles.
  2. Meanwhile, the MHC class II molecule moves through the ER alone and is taken up into an endosome.
  3. In the cytosol, the MHC class II endosome and the viral phagolysosome meet and fuse, and the MHC class II and viral peptides bind.
  4. Once the peptide binding groove is filled the MHC class II is stable and can be trafficked to the cell membrane to present to the T cells.

Question: A 52 year old gentleman comes into his GP for a check up having been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 6 months ago. He was diagnosed after a short history of typical diabetics symptoms having been previously healthy. Which of the following is the patient least likely to have?
Explanation: The presence of proteinuria is unlikely given the patient has only a short history of diabetes and the onset of nephropathy is usually over many years. Even then only occurs in a small proportion of patient. Raised GFR is a common change in early stages of nephropathy and diabetics due to hyperfiltration and would be more likely to be found in this patient than overt proteinuria. A blood pressure of 140/90 is the top end of what is acceptable in a diabetic but is normal in this kind of patient. A BMI of 26 indicates this patient is overweight and obviously this would not be an uncommon BMI for a diabetic. An HbA1C of 54 mmol/mol is slightly more than the target for this patient and so a change in management may be indicated.

Question: You examine a patient's lower limb neurological status, and note that they have no vibration sense in their feet.  Which skin receptor is most likely not working?
Explanation:
Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting vibration and deep pressure at the skin.  Each of the others are also surface receptors with specific sensory modalities.

 

Source: Wheater's Functional Histology

Question: What is the name of the structure that the ovarian follicle becomes following ovulation (day 14 of the menstrual cycle)?
Explanation: Following ovulation, the remains of the follicle becomes a glandular structure called the corpus luteum. The corpus luteum produces progesterone (and some oestrogen), which causes the endometrial glands to secrete 'uterine milk'. This marks the beginning of the luteal phase and prepares the endometrium for implantation.

Question: Which of the following is not a component of seminal plasma?
Explanation:
The term seminal plasma refers to the components of ejaculate that are not sperm, therefore sperm (C) is incorrect.

  • Fructose is released by the seminal vesicle and is the main energy source of the sperm cells.
  • Prostaglandins are released by the seminal vesicle, and are involved in suppressing an immune response by the female against foreign semen.
  • Zinc is released by the prostate and helps stabilize the DNA-containing chromatin in sperm cells.
  • Mucus is released by the bulbourethral glands and helps increase the mobility of sperm cells by creating a less viscous channel for the sperm to swim through.

Question: What triggers the acrosome reaction?
OptionA: The fusion of the membranes of the egg and sperm.
OptionB: The sperm binding to the corona radiata cells.
OptionC: The sperm entering the ampullary region of the uterine tube.
OptionD: The sperm binding to the cumulus cells.
OptionE: The sperm binding to the zona pellucida.
Explanation:
• The oocyte is surrounded first by the corona radiata (also called cumulus cells), and then by the zona pellucida. The sperm must first burrow through the corona radiata (cumulus cells) before binding to the zona pellucida, which initiates the acrosome reaction. 
  • The fusion of the membranes of the egg and sperm initiates the cortical reaction.
  • The ampullary region is simply the most common site of fertilization.

Question: The main site for malignant spinal tumours occurs where?
Explanation: case 14 plenary 4

Question: Which of the following statements about the cleavage stage of prenatal development is unture?
OptionA: Cleavage occurs during the Zygote and Morula phases.
OptionB: The blastomeres form a morula on approximately day 3.
OptionC: There is rapid mitotic division but a lack of growth in cleavage.
OptionD: The number of blastomeres triples with each mitotic division.
Explanation: The number of blastomeres doubles with each mitotic division.

Question: What event signals that a compacted morula has become a blastocyst?
OptionB: The formation of the embryoblast (inner cell mass).
OptionC: The formation of the trophoblast (outer cell mass).
OptionD: The embryoblast being pushed to one end to become the embryonic pole.
OptionE: When the morula is made up of more than 16 cells.
Explanation: The formation of the blastocoel (also called blastocyst cavity) occurs when the morula has descended into the uterus, and signifies that the compacted morula has become a blastocyst. Trophoblast cells pull luminal fluid from the uterine cavity into the centre of the morula, forming the fluid filled blastocoel.

Question: Which of these makes up the bilaminar germ disc?
Which of these statements relating to fuel metabolism during starvation is correct?
OptionD: Increase in total concentration of thyroid hormones
OptionE: Total dependence on glucose as an energy source
Explanation:
Prolonged fasting (starvation) is a chronic low-insulin, high glucagon state

  • Decrease in thyroid hormones to decrease the metabolic rate
  • Amount of GLUT-4 transport (adipose tissue and skeletal muscle) decreases, which decreases cellular glucose uptake and saves more glucose 
  • Almost total dependance on fat as an energy source 
  • Ongoing gluconeogenesis depletes oxaloacetate (TCA metabolite), activity of TCA cycle decreases

Question: What type of cells make up the hypoblast of the bilaminar disc?
Explanation: The hypoblast is made up of cuboidal cells, and the epiblast is made up of columar cells.

Question: Which of these events signifies the initiation of gastrulation?
Explanation: Gastrulation is initiated at about day 15 with the formation of the primitive streak. The primitive streak runs as a depression on the epiblastic surface of the bilaminar disc and is restricted to the caudal (tail) half of the embryo. Towards the cephalic (head) end of the embryo there is a round mound of cells called the primitive node, surrounding the primitive pit.

Question: Which of the following is not formed by the endoderm?
Explanation: The medulla of the adrenal gland is formed by the ectoderm. Broadly speaking, the ectoderm will form the epidermis and the CNS, the mesoderm is the major contributor to the embryo and its cells (forming bone, muscle, the cranium etc.), and the endoderm essentially creates the epithelia of internal passages.

Question: Which of the following statements about brain development is false
OptionA: Girls develop white matter more slowly than boys
OptionB: Boys have a peak in grey matter production before girls
OptionC: Girls grey matter starts decomposing before boys
OptionD: Girls tend to have smaller brains than boys
OptionE: Girls brains work in a ways that us boys will never understand
Explanation:
B false - other way round.

Source: adolescence and brain lecture.

Question: A patient comes to see you at the GP practice complaining of worsening abdominal pain following starting new treatment for intermittent IBS. You are shwon the medication which turns out to be Mebeverine Hydrochloride. What potential trigger for IBS do you now suspect?
Explanation:
C. Mebeverine Hydrochloride (brand name Colofac) contains lactose and therefore should be avoided if a potential diagnosis of lactose intolerance stimulating Irritable Bowel Syndrome is suspected.

 

Source: Kumar and Clark (Functional Gastrointestinal Disorders)

Question:
A 22 year old medical student presents to the ED as they have been ill the last few days and have a bad headache and nausea. Upon examination they have a stiff neck and show classic signs of meningitis.

A CSF sample is taken and the results were as follows:

Appearance - Normal

White Cells - Raised lymphocytes

Red Cells - Normal

Protein - Slightly raised

Glucose - Normal

 


What is the most likely causative organism?
Explanation:
The CSF results show a viral infection is likely. The fact that the CSF appearance is clear is evidence of this as bacterial causes lead to a turbid or purulent appearance. The fact that protein is only slight raised and that glucose is normal both suggest this is viral rather than bacterial. The raised lymphocytes help confirm that this patient does have meningitis. 

As it is a viral cause can be narrowed down to HIV and mumps. In a student population mumps is not uncommon and especially considering the history of a few days of malaise this patient is most likely to have a mumps infection.

Question: A diabetic patient has his annual eye check-up, when he is informed that his retinopathy has advanced to the proliferative stage. Which of the following signs is seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy but not in background retinopathy.
Explanation:
The answer is C - formation of new blood vessels is characteristic of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Hard exudates are caused by lipid deposition that typically occurs at the margins of haemorrhages.

Microaneurysms are small vascular dilatations that occur in the retina, often as first signs of retinopathy. They appear as red dots.

Cotton wool spots are white areas on the retina that occur in late stage background retinopathy. They can be a sign of impending proliferative retinopathy.

Dot haemorrhages are small haemorrhages in the middle layers of the retina that appear as tiny red dots on the retina.

 

Source - http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1225122-overview

Question: A patient presents to the ED and is given an x-ray. What does the x-ray show?
Explanation: The x ray shows a fluid build up in the lung tissue i.e. pulmonary oedema. The hazy white appearance of the lung especially around the hilum is the classic appearance of pulmonary oedema. The patient is likely to have presented with breathlessness. Whilst HF is a common cause of pulmonary oedema (esp. if there is cardiomegaly which is not obviously present here) there are many other non-cardiogenic causes and therefore is not specifically what the x-ray shows.

Question: What are the effects of PROGESTERONE and/or OESTROGEN in the development of the breasts?
OptionA:
Progesterone: Duct sprouting and branching

Oestrogen: Formation of granular cell masses (alveoli) at end of ducts
OptionB:
Progesterone: Fat deposition resulting in increased breast size
Oestrogen: No effect
OptionC:
Progesterone: Fat deposition resulting in increased breast size
Oestrogen: Duct sprouting and branching
OptionE:
Progesterone: Formation of granular cell masses (alveoli) at end of ducts 
Oestrogen: Duct sprouting and branching
Explanation:
At puberty: Anterior pituitary secrete gonadatrophins -> Ovaries produce oestrogenic hormones -> Initiates breast development = Sprouting and branching of ducts

 

At menstruation commencement: Progesterone secreted = Formation of granular cell masses at ends of ducts

 

- Oestrogen and progesterone required for formation of a fully developed breast

 

- Fat deposition occurs during adolescence

Question: Rhodri finally has some good news his first grandchild has recently arrived. Ffion turns her head from side to side in the supine position and props on her arms in the prone position. She is currently still communicating through crying. Approximately how old is Ffion?
Explanation:
child development lecture case 9

 

GM- turns head side to side in supine position, props on forearms in prone position and minimal headlag when pulled to sit.

FM-focusses and follows, opens hands momentarily, extensor movements of limbs and fanning of hands

Visual-briefly holds gaze. interested in lights, fixes on mothers face at 6-8 weeks blinks at bright lights and tracks horizontally and vertically

personal social/communication- recognises mother, social smile, follows moving person at close distance, brings hands to mouth and communicated through crying

Question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a tendon reflex
Explanation: tendon reflexes are ipsilateral, polysynaptic and there to prevent muscle damage as a result of stretching

Question: Which of these chromosomal abnormalities leads to symptoms of severe developmental delay, seizures, rocker bottom foot, clenched hand and structural abnormalities (including ventricular septal defect) with many of the foetuses dying before birth?
Explanation:
Trisomy 13-Patau Syndrome

=characterised by severe developmental delay, neural tube defect and failure of the forebrain to divide.With only 20% of sufferers surviving their first year of life.

 

Trisomy 21-Down Syndrome

=characteristic facial features (including large tongue and low set ears), muscle hypertonia, single palmar crease, duodenal atresia (absence or complete closure of duodenum n 8%), shot stature, handle gap, intellectual disability.

 

CORRECT ANSWER=Trisomy 18-Edwards Syndrome

Only 5-10% survive their first year of life, 80% of those affected are female, and the majority of them die before birth. INcreased age of mother=increased risk of Edwards.

 

D=Cri-du-Chat syndrome

 

E=made up translocation

Question: Which of the following could be classed as an uncapslated receptor
Which cell type is involved with the primary presentation of an antigen to T cells?
Explanation:
The answer is dendritic cells. 

 

Pathogens travel to the lymph node via the dendritic cell. It is this ability that distinguishes them from macrophages. The pathogen is detected by PAMPs on the dendritic cell, and this upregulates the co-stimulatory ligand B7 on the dendritic cell.

If the naive T cell in the lymph has the correct TCR (T cell receptor) to recognise the MHC peptide complex, the T cells are able to become activated through engaging with the B7 ligand on the dendritic cell.

They then expand in number massively; they themselves drive this proliferation, as CD8 T cells produce IL-2 when activated, driving differentiation. During this period, the T cells lose the ability to leave the lymph node temporarily. 

After expansion, the naive T cells differentiate into effector T cells, and then regain the ability to exit the lymph node. 

 

CD8 cells differentiate into CTL cytotoxic cells and are useful in initiating apoptosis on target cells. 

CD4 cells differentiate into virus-specific helper effector cells; they can either remain in the lymph as follicular helper cells, where they interact with B cells, or can traffic to the site of infection. In viral infections, these cells become Th1 cells, and enhance macrophage phagocytosis. 

 

All info from Dr. Matthew's lectures in Case 9 :)

Question: Which of the following best describes the changes that you would expect to see in an ECG in a person with Mobitz Type II heart block?
OptionA: For every QRS complex there is 2 P waves.
OptionB: Progressive increase in PR interval then a failure to conduct a beat seen as a P wave not followed by a QRS complex. The cycle repeats
OptionD: Most complexes show a constant PR interval, but occasionally there is a P wave without a subsequent QRS complex.
OptionE: No relationship between P waves and QRS complexes.
Explanation:
A = 2:1 Heart block

B = Mobitz Type I

C = 1st degree heart block

D = Mobitz Type II

E = complete or 3rd degree heart block

Question: Which cell type produces the antibody IgE?
Explanation:
Plasma cells are short-lived antibody-producing cells derived from B cells. B cells differentiate into plasma cells so they can also be called effector B cells. 

 

Basophils are part of the white blood cell group called granulocytes. They synthesise and store histamine. When antibodies of IgE class bind to basophils, they release inflammatory chemicals including histamine, serotonnin and leukortienes, causing many effects including vasodilation. 

 

Eosinophils are also granulocytes, and are important in mediating allergic reactions. They are also involved in defence against parasites; eosinophils and IgE work together to destroy parasites. 

 

Mast cells mediate inflammatory responses. They store chemical mediators such as histamine, interleukins, proteoglycans and other enzymes in granules; upon stimulation by an allergen, they release their contents via degranulation, and cause the local responses such as inflammation and swelling.

Question: The angiotensis-renin system is used to regulate BP and Na+ concentration in the blood. Which of these statements it true?
OptionA: Angiotensin I is converted to Angiotensin II in the kidney by Renin
OptionB: Angiotensin I is converted to Angiotensin II by ACE in the kidney
OptionC: Angiotensinogen is converted to angiontensin I by ACE in the lungs
OptionD: Angiotensin I is converted to Angiotensin II by ACE in the lungs
OptionE: Angiotensinogen is converted to Angiontensin II by Renin in the lungs
Explanation:
Renin is produced in the kidney through renal sympathetic activity, decreased blood pressure detected in the renal system at the juxtaglomerular cells or through decreased Na+ delivery to the macula densa. Angiotensinogen is converted to angiotensin I by renin, AI has no biological function and serves as a precursor for AII. AI converted to AII by ACE, angiotensin converting enzyme, primarily found in the lung.

A - Incorrect as it is by ACE in the lungs

B - Incorrect, takes place in the lung

C - Incorrect, converted by Renin

D - Correct! Well done, gold star for you!

E - Angiotensinogen is converted to Angiotensin I by Renin

Question:
Stepping on Lego (Figure 1.) is widely considered the most painful experience in the world, though to understand why it hurts so much, first we need to understand nociception. What are the fibres that are responsible for the initial sharp pain sensation, and what are their characteristics?

(Figure 1. Blue piece of Lego)
OptionA:
Alpha fibres
 Simple naked nerve ending
 Low threshold mechanoreceptor
 Responds to light mechanical stimulus
 Thinly myelinated axon
OptionB:
Alpha fibres
 Simple naked nerve ending
 High threshold mechanoreceptor
 Responds to intense mechanical stimulus
 Thickly myelinated axon
OptionC:
Alpha fibres
 Simple naked nerve ending
 High threshold mechanoreceptor
 Responds to intense mechanical stimulus
 Thinly myelinated axon
OptionD:
C fibres
 Simple naked nerve ending
 Responds to intense mechanical stimulation, temperature and chemicals.
 Unmyelinated axon
OptionE:
C fibres
 Simple naked nerve ending
 Responds to intense mechanical stimulation, temperature and chemicals.
 Myelinated axon
Explanation:
The initial sharp, well localised pain is caused by Alpha Fibres.
They are characterised by:
 Simple naked nerve ending
 High threshold mechanoreceptor
 Responds to intense mechanical stimulus
 Thinly myelinated axon
Tags: Nerves, Neurology, Pain, Case 14, Year 1 Revision

Question:
Mrs Smith, a 63-year-old female patient presents to you, her GP, complaining of breathlessness when doing tasks such as walking to the shops, and she believes this is worse in her than in other people she knows that are her age.  On examination, she has some ankle oedema, is hypertensive but has no basal crepitations.  She has no PMH of myocardial infarction or angina. 

 

You suspect that Mrs Smith may be in heart failure with NYHA functional class II.  What should be your first action?
OptionA: Call 999 to be taken straight to A&E
OptionC: Prescribe a salbutamol inhaler and tell the patient to take two puffs each time she feels breathless and to come back if there is no change
Explanation:
Patients who present with symptoms suspicious of heart failure should be referred immediately for echo if:

  • there is a history of MI
  • they have basal crepitations
  • they are a male with ankle oedema

otherwise, their BNP should be measured first, and the patient should then be referred depending on the result - the acceptable levels depend on patients' sex and whether they have ankle oedema or not (females).

 

The NYHA functional class does not affect the course of these initial investigations.

 

Source: Diagnosis of Heart Failure lecture, Case 15; Mant, J et al, Systematic review and individual patient data meta-analysis of diagnosis of heart failure, with modelling of implications of different diagnostic strategies in primary care, Health technology assessment 2009; 13:32

Question: Liver Function tests are really useful for making a specific diagnosis of what is going on in the patients liver. A 28-year old comes into the clinic for a check up, and blood is taken from him to test his liver function. Levels of his Alkaline Phosphatase are raised, what is like likely to have been caused by?
OptionA: Decrease in synthetic function of the liver
Explanation:
A: Albumin is most commonly associated with synthetic function
B: Aspartate Transaminase levels increase in hepatic necrosis
C: Correcto!
D: Gamma Glutamyl Transpeptidase tends to increase in fatty liver disease
E: Prothrombin Time can test for vitamin K deficiency, though it is usually used to test for synthetic function of the liver and vitamin K deficiency is excluded through administration of 10mg IV vitamin K
Tags: Abdomen, ISCE, Year 1 Revision, Liver Tests

Question:
Concerned about his weight, Fat Bastard (Figure 1.) a morbidly obese henchman hailing from Scotland, looks to the textbooks to help him work out the composition of different lipoproteins in his large body. He wants to know what the major component of LDL is. You tell him...

(Figure 1. Fat Bastard)
Explanation: 50% of LDL is Cholesterol, which LDL transfers to tissues from the liver. 20% is protein and another 20% is phospholipid. The remaining 10% is triglycerides.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the baroreceptor blood pressure reflex is correct?
OptionA: An increase in blood pressure causes reduced signals to be transmitted to the nucleus tract solitarii
OptionB: Baroreceptor afferent fibres from the carotid body travel with the vagus nerve (CN X)
OptionC: Standing up quickly causes a reduction in baroreceptor activity
OptionD: The nucleus tractus solitarii lies in the pons of the brainstem
OptionE: Increased baroreceptor activity is likely to cause sinus tachycardia
Explanation:
A is incorrect as the increased blood pressure causes increased activity in the baroreceptors which leads to increased signals to the NTS. This leads to inhibition of the vasomotor centre and increased vagal innervation to the heart i.e. decreased chronotropy.

 

B is incorrect, it is the baroreceptors from the aortic body which are transmitted by CN X, the baroreceptor fibres from the carotid body travel via the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

 

C is correct, standing up quickly causes pooling of blood in the lower extremities which leads to a decreased blood pressure and decreased activity in baroreceptor activity.

 

D is incorrect the NTS lies in the medulla

 

E is incorrect, as mentioned above, increased baroreceptor activity causes an increase in parasympathetic activity. This causes bradycardia which is termed "reflex bradycardia".

Question: An ectopic pregnancy is most likely to occur where?
Explanation:
Correct answer is C - fallopian tube as 90% of ectopic pregnancies occur here

Doughlas' pouch is the most frequent place of implantation within the abdominal cavity but NOT overall

 - Implantation in the internal OS results in a placenta previa - the placenta is too close to the cervix here and can cause bleeding in later pregnancy and requires a C section at birth

Question:
You are asked to see a 1 year old baby because his parents are concerned that he isn't progressing as he should be. 

Upon observation, he can roll from prone to supine, communicates by cooing and gurgling, briefly fixes on objects and appears to recognise his parents. He also shows signs of attempting to sit up.

How delayed, in months, do you think he is?
Explanation:
His level of development is that of a 3-6 month old baby, and the fact that he is starting to sit indicates that he is between 5-9 months (as opposed to being around the stage of a 3 month old and having a 9 month delay).

 

Therefore, he is 12 months (actual age) - approx 6 months (age of development) = 6 months delayed

Question: Which of the following statements about the pancreas is incorrect?
OptionA: Within the islets of Langerhans, beta cells are the most abundant cell type
OptionB: The endocrine component of the pancreas is more abundant than the exocrine component
OptionC: Pancreatic polypeptide (PP) is produced from gamma cells in the islets of Langerhans
OptionD: The main and accessory pancreatic ducts both empty into the second part of the duodenum
OptionE: The main proteases produced from the pancreas are trypsinogen and chymotypsinogen
Explanation: The answer is B - The endocrine component of the pancreas (islets of Langerhans) only account for around 2% of the pancreas.
Tags: Diabetes, Endocrine, Case 10, Gastrointestinal System, Case 17

Question:
Your niece comes to visit and you are expected to babysit. She kicks you and runs around, climbing the stairs. She scribbles all over the walls and is possessive of all her toys. You remember why you don't like babysitting and hand her back to her parents ASAP. 

In a few days, it is her birthday, but you can't remember how old she is going to be. From observing her development, how old will she be?
Explanation:
A 2 year old is expected to be able to :

  • Gross motor - run in a controlled start stop manner, kick, and climb the stairs 
  • Fine motor - scribble, build a tower of cubes, point, turn the pages of a book and have a potential hand preference 
  • Vision - recognise faces in a photo, inspect objects without touching, and read pictures in a book
  • Personal/social - pretend play, possessive of toys, helps with dressing, drinks from a cup and sucks through a straw 
  • Speech and language - 50 words and some 2 word phrases 

 

Taken from the child development lecture case 9.

Question: A 22 year old is brought into the ED has they have been having some palpitations and feel faint. They describe how they feel very lightheaded and are unable to stand up. An ECG reveals a narrow complex tachyarrythmia and their blood pressure is 85/60. What is a suitable first step in management?
Explanation:
This patient is haemodynamically unstable given their hypotension and pre-syncope. In a haemodynamically unstable tachyarrythmia with a pulse, DC cardioversion should be first line. Adenosine can also be given as well if needed however the main indication in this case is urgent DC cardioversion.

 

If this patient had a stable narrow complex SVT then vagal manoeuvres and then adenosine would be attempted to return the rhythm to sinus. 

 

Defibrillation should only be used if the patient is pulseless and in a shockable rhythm i.e. VT or VF.

 

Good source for management of SVTs - http://www.uptodate.com.abc.cardiff.ac.uk/contents/overview-of-the-acute-management-of-tachyarrhythmias?source=search_result&search=svt&selectedTitle=1%7E150

Question:
John is a 66 year old male, who comes into your GP surgery complaining of 'feeling faint all the time' for the past 4 days. He has been on medication for hypertension for the past 18 months. 

Upon questioning he reveals that the previous week he fell and twisted his knee and admits he has been taking ibuprofen to help with the pain. 

You believe there has been an adverse drug interaction. Which of the following medications is John likely to be taking?
Explanation:
John is likely to be suffering from hypotension caused by an interaction between the NSAID he has been taking for his knee pain and the ACE Inhibitor he is taking for his hypertension. 

A) Furosemide is a loop diuretic which can be used to treat hypertension. Hypotension is an adverse effect, however as he has been taking the drug for 18 months, it is unlikely to cause problems without a trigger.

B) Hydralazine is another anti-hypertensive but hypotension is not a common side effect. 

C) Losartan is an angiotensin II-receptor-blocker (ARB) (or antagonist). Orthostatic hypotension is an adverse effect in ARBs.

D) Propranolol is a B-blocker which can have hypotension as an adverse effect. 

E) Ramipril is an ACE Inhibitor. ACE inhibitors should not be taken with NSAIDs as they can interact and cause hypotension. This is the SBA as, although most of the other drugs can cause hypotension, it is more likely that the interaction caused the hypotension and not a new adverse effect, 18 months after starting taking the drug.

Question: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) primarily breaks down which of the following lipoproteins?
Explanation: Lipoprotein lipase is an enzyme found primarily in endothelial cells and peripheral tissues and hydrolyses circulating TAGs. VLDL and Chylomicrons are the two main transporting lipoproteins for TAGs. Chylomicrons transport TAGs from the gut and VLDL transport TAGs from the liver.

Question: A recently diagnosed type 2 diabetic comes to see his GP as he is having muscle pains and stiffness. The GP suspects it is being caused by one of the medications he is on. Which of the following is most likely to be causing these symptoms?
Explanation: One of the most commonly reported side-effects of statins is muscle pain and stiffness (myalgia). Some studies suggest it affects 10-15% of those taking them.

Question: Tony, a 70 year old enters your GP surgery for his diabetic check up. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 3 months ago and was prescribed metformin after initial lifestyle changes had not been effective. Following a history you elicit he also suffers from hypertension and mild renal disease. His bloods also show an HbA1c of 8% (63mmol/mol). What would be the most appropriate next step?
OptionA: Do nothing. Ask Tony to see you again in 3 months to check on HbA1c
OptionD: Add a long acting Sulfonylurea such as Glibenclamide
Explanation:
A - The ideal level of HbA1c in a Type 2 Diabetic is 7% or 53mmol/mol, and an additional therapy should be added given his increased level of HbA1c

B - Insulin therapy is recommended as a second line treatment when HbA1c is above 8.5%

C - Diet plan should have been implemented at the time of diagnosis along with other lifestyle changes so further adjustment would be unlikely to help

D - Glibenclamide is not indicated in renal failure as its metabolites build up in renal failure and can cause severe hypoglycaemia

E - Gliclazide is the correct answer as it is used as second stage treatment in type 2 DM. Inactive metabolites are built up in renal failure meaning that hypoglycaemia doesn't occur, however dose should be carefully monitored

Question: Which of the following is NOT one of the five factors that is used to measure personality?
Explanation:
The five factor model consists of five factors that can be measured by quizzes in order to determine a patient's personality type. The five factors can be remembered using the acronym OCEAN (sorry that I swapped an E for an E to make it more tricky). 

 

Openness - having wide ranging interests, being creative, imaginative, intellectually curious and insightful

Conscientiousness - being organised, thoughtful, scrupulous, meticulous, dependable and self disciplined

Extraversion - being gregarious, assertive, excitement seeking, warm, enthusiastic, sociable and emotionally expressive

Agreeableness - compliant, friendly, trusting, empathic, sympathetic and cooperative

Neuroticism - anxiety, emotional instability, tension, moodiness and easily upset

 

 

Source: 'Personality, Well Being and Health' Workbook from Case 12

Question: A dedicated medical student goes to the SDL and has a fellow student check his blood pressure. It is found to be high, indicating hypertension. This naturally sends the medical student in to a spiral of hypochondriasis. He then gets his blood pressure checked in his legs and it is found to be a lot lower. What could explain the difference in blood pressure between his arms and legs?
OptionA: This is normal and the student should not worry
Explanation: Hypertension in the upper limbs and signifcantly lower pressure in the legs is a classic sign of coarctation of the aorta. Milder cases may be asymptomatic even in adulthood and only be picked up on examination. There would also likely be decreased circulation to the feet and radio-femoral delay (or even absence of the femoral pulse).

Question: The glutamate hypothesis of schizophrenia attributes the symptoms of the disease to hypofunctioning of which glutamate receptor?
Explanation:
AMPA, Kainate and NMDA receptors are all receptors for glutamate, but it is hypofunctioning of the NMDA receptors that has been linked to the symptoms of schizophrenia. 

 

Cannabinoid receptors are receptors for endocannabinoids, plant cannabinoids and synthetic cannabinoids.

 

D1 receptors are receptors for dopamine.

Question:
Whilst on placement in the acute admissions unit you examine a 25 year old patient who was admitted with a fever the night before. Upon examination you notice the following on their hands (see figure 1). What do you suspect this patient may have?

 

Figure 1
Explanation: The image is of Janeway's lesions which are a clinical sign that indicates presence of infective endocarditis. Osler's nodes (which look similar) and splinter haemorrhages may also be present. Fever is almost always present in infective endocarditis patients.

Question: Which of the following statements about insulin is incorrect?
OptionB: Insulin release can only be stimulated by glucose
OptionC: Insulin causes an increase in GLUT-4 transporters in the cell membranes of fat and muscle cells
OptionE: Following a meal, insulin is released in a non-continuous pulsatile fashion
Explanation:
The answer is B - insulin release can be stimulated by many substances other than insulin - e.g. arginine, leucine and mannose.

 

A is correct as insulin decreases lipolysis and gluconeogenesis, promoting a decrease in blood glucose levels.

C is correct as insulin upregulates the expression of GLUT-4 in the cell membranes of muscle and fat cells. This promotes glucose uptake into these tissues and decreases blood glucose concentration.

D is correct as insulin upregulates the expression of Na+/K+ATPase on the cell membrane in muscle cells, leading to an increase in intracellular potassium levels.

E is correct as the rate of insulin release oscillates every 3-6 minutes following a meal.
Tags: Diabetes, Endocrine, Case 10, Gastrointestinal System, Case 17

Question: Which transporter present on the apical membrane is responsible for the majority of glucose re-absorption in the kidneys?
Explanation:
The answer is D - the majority of glucose re-absorption occurs in the proximal tubule, coupled to sodium via SGLT-2. It accounts for around 90% of glucose re-absorption.

GLUT-1 and GLUT-2 are both found on the basolateral membrane of cells in the proximal tubule.

SGLT-1 is also found on the apical membrane but is responsible for only a small amount of glucose re-absorption.

Question:
Sam is a 12 year old boy who is brought to the GP by his mum. Sam hasn't been doing very well at school recently, which his mum says is "out of character". He has also stopped playing football for his local team and his mum says he spends all his time in his room as doesn't want to meet up with his friends or ever go and do anything.The other week, Sam ran away from home. He says this is because he feels his parents don't love him as he's not as clever as his older brother. 

 

What is the best medication to prescribe for Sam?
Explanation:
D is the correct answer. 

Sam has depression. This commonly presents in children with things such as poor performance at school, running away from home, social withdrawal, bad behaviour, boredom and insomnia. Younger children may be tearful and sad and slightly older children can feel unloved and treated unfairly. Teenagers often present with the feelings of guilt seen in adults.

Mood is much more variable in children and they are more likely to have mood swings, rather than consistent low mood. 

 

The only antidepressant licensed for use in children is Fluoxetine - other antidepressants such as SSRIs and SNRIs have been found to increase the risk of suicidal behaviour and self harm in patients under the age of 25 and should NOT be given to children or adolescents.

An antidepressant in children should only be prescribed in combination with psychological therapy.

Question:
A certain fictional doctor (see figure 1) is extremely insecure about their giant Adam's apple. What is the Adam's apple formed from?

 

Figure 1
Explanation:
The Adam's apple is known anatomically as the laryngeal prominence and is formed from a raised midline part of the thyroid cartilage as shown below:

 

Reference: Scrubs, season 4 episode 4 - "My first kill"

Question: A 70 year old diabetic patient visits her GP complaining of a tingling sensation in both feet. Before diagnosing diabetic neuropathy, the GP should rule out any other possible causes of peripheral neuropathy. Which of the following is NOT a common cause of peripheral neuropathy?
Explanation:
The answer is B - Hyperthyroidism does not typically cause peripheral neuropathy. HYPOthyroidism however does present with peripheral neuropathy.

Vasculitis is inflammation of blood vessels and can cause neuropathy.

Guillain-Barre syndrome is an autoimmune disease which attacks nerve roots and peripheral nerves.

B12 deficiency can cause neuropathy.

Varicella-Zoster virus causes shingles which can present with burning/tingling in the extremities.

 

I doubt we need to know the causes of peripheral neuropathy in detail, but it's probably worth knowing some of the main causes other from diabetes.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding GLP-1 is incorrect?
OptionA: It is secreted in response to carbohydrates in the intestine
OptionB: Secreted by K cells in the intestine
OptionD: GLP-1 reduces the rate of Gastric Emptying
OptionE: GLP-1 increases insulin secretion by increasing the expression of GLUT-2 and Glucokinase within the Beta-cells
Explanation:
B is incorrect - it is secreted by the L cells in the ileum (small numbers of cells in the duodenum and jejunum) in the response to the presences of carbohydrates, proteins and lipids. 

 

GLP-1 is a effective incretin as it stimulates the proliferation of the beta-cells as well as preventing apoptosis of the cell mass. Furthermore it stimulates insulin secretion from the B-cells by increasing the expression of GLUT-2 transporters and the glucokinase enzyme. This means that the cells are more sensitive to the glucose. 

 

Other functions of GLP-1 including reducing the rate of gastric emptying as well as reducing the acid secretion in the stomach. It also has increases satiety in the brain (you feel full), in addition to increasing insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues.

Question: Which of the following would not be used in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome in a 54 year old Caucasian male?
OptionA: A large waist line of more than 40 inches
OptionB: A low serum HDL cholesterol level of less than 40mg/dL
OptionC: A high fasting glucose level of more than 100mg/dL
OptionD: A high blood pressure of more than 130/85mmHg
OptionE: An age of more than 40 years old
Explanation:
The answer is E - although the incidence of metabolic syndrome increases with age, it is not a factor that would be used to diagnose metabolic syndrome.

The other options are all factors that could be used to diagnose metabolic syndrome.

Question: John, a 20 year old male, comes for a routine appointment and it is found that his blood pressure is abnormally high. You see that he is very concerned and appears very anxious. What would the most appropriate initial step be?
OptionE: Ask him to return to see you in a week.
Explanation:
The reading is abnormally high so both D and E wouldn't be suitable as it should be investigated. 

Statin's are prescribed in response to Hypercholesterolemia and wouldn't be prescribed for hypertension. 

Ramiprill - an ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension 

Blood pressure monitoring - as the individual is very anxious there is a high chance that the blood pressure could be high due to 'white coat effect' and this would be making the blood pressure look higher than it would do normally. This monitoring would mean that you could check his blood pressure over a 24 hour period to get an accurate reading for his blood pressure.

Question: Which type of drug, used to treat type 2 diabetes, works by inhibiting the breakdown of GLP-1 and GIP?
Explanation:
The answer is B - DPP-4 inhibitors inhibit an enzyme called dipeptidyl peptidase-4 which breaks down GLP-1 and GIP. This has the effect of increasing insulin production and lowering blood glucose levels.

 

Sulphonylureas increase insulin production by binding to specific sulphonylurea receptors on pancreatic beta cells.

Thiazolidinediones act by increasing the expression of GLUT-4, which increases insulin sensitivity in muscle and fat cells.

Alpha glucosidase inhibitors are saccharides that act as competitive inhibitors of the enzymes needed to digest carbohydrates.

Incretin mimetics are agents that act like GLP-1 and GIP and increase insulin secretion from beta cells.
Tags: Diabetes, Gastrointestinal System, Case 17, Pharmacology, Hormones

Question: Leydig cells produce which of the following?
Explanation:
LH stimulates leydig cells which produce testosterone

inhibin b is produced by sertoli cells

FSH stimulates sertoli cells

TSH is synthesized by thyrotrophs in the anterior pituitary

Question: Aldosterone has which of the following effects?
OptionA: Acts on the DCT increasing H+ and waterreabsorption and K+ excretion
OptionB: Acts on the PCT increasing H+ and water reabsorption and K+ excretion
OptionC: Acts on the DCT increasing Na+, H+ and water reabsorption and K+ excretion
OptionD: Acts on the loop on Henley increasing H+ and water reabsorption and K+ excretion
OptionE: Acts on the DCT and collecting duct increasing Na+ and water reabsorption and K+ and H+ excretion
Explanation: aldosterone acts on the DCT and collecting duct leading to reabsorption of sodium ions in exchange for potassium and hydrogen ions, water is also reabsorbed and blood volume and pressure increase. Aldosterone acts on the nucleus via an intracellular receptor upregulating the expression of genes in the DCT and collecting duct associate with ion transport proteins

Question: Ovulation occurs on what day of the typical 28 day menstrual cycle?
Explanation: Ovulation typically occurs around day 14 following a large LH surge.
Tags: Case 8, Endocrine, Year 1 Revision, endocrinology, Hormones

Question: What makes intraglomerular mesangial cells unique among phagocytotic cells?
OptionB: They are resident in tissue and do not circulate.
OptionC: The phagocytose fragments of cells that have undergone apoptosis
OptionD: The are derived from smooth muscle cells
Explanation: Intraglomerular mesangial cells are from smooth muscle cells. They are found in the basement membrane of glomerular capillaries. As well as aiding the regulation of blood flow through the glomerular capillaries, they aid neutrophils in phagocytose basal lamina and Ig components as well as other apoptotic mesangial cells.

Question: A 17 year old female present to the GP concerned that she has not yet had her first period. This can be best described by which of the following terms?
Explanation:
A. amenorrhoea is when menstruation has not occurred within the last 6 months (this is normal before puberty, during pregnancy and after the menopause), if menstruation has not occurred in the last 42 days it is referred to as oligomenorrhoea

B. Dysmenorrhoea is associated with painful menstrual periods

C. Menorrhagia is excessive menstrual bleeding

D. primary amenorrhoea is when a girl fails to menstruate by 16 years of age

E seconday amenorrhoea is when a women who has begun menstruating has not done so in the previous 6 months common causes include:

  • weight loss (35%0
  • polycystic ovaries (25%)
  • pituitary insensitivities (15%)
  • hyperprolactinaemia (15%)
  • primary ovarian failure (5%)

Question: Deficiency of which vitamin, a cofactor for the Link Reaction, can be caused by malnutrition in alcohol misuse?
Explanation:
Thiamine deficiency as a purely nutritional deficit normally results in the condition known as Beri Beri (divided into wet and dry forms), which is now only present in the poorest parts of South East Asia where only rice is consumed.  Occasionally alcohol-dependence can cause wet beri beri, but more commonly the Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome develops, which involves central neurological and psychiatric features.  Urgent treatment with thiamine and glucose may make it reversible but it becomes irreversible with time.

 

Thiamine Pyrophosphate is a cofactor for the link reaction - Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

Source: Kumar and Clark's Clinical Medicine

Question: Which of the following signs would you most likely expect to find in a patient suffering from secondary hyperaldosteronism?
Explanation:
Aldosterone leads to sodium and water retention and potassium and hydrogen ion secretion, therefore you would expect to see:

  • hypertension 
  • hypokalaemia 
  • alkalosis
  • polyuria and polydipsia
  • normal/high end normal sodium

the most common cause of secondary hyperaldosteronism is excessive diuretic therapy but it is also associated with congestive heart failure and renal artery stenosis amongst others
Tags: Kidney, Endocrine, Year 1 Revision, Hormones, Progress tests

Question: What does the following ECG show?
Explanation: There is a constant PR interval before a dropped beat shown by the absence of the QRS complex.

Question: The following ECG was taken from a patient who arrived in the ED complaining of palpitations and breathlessness. What would the following ECG suggest?
Explanation: This ECG shows the typical sawtooth appearance of atrial flutter, which is best seen in II, III and aVF.

Question: The following vertebrae is most likely to be found at which vertebral level?
Explanation: The image shows a lumbar vertebrae as there is a large body with a short spinous process. There is also a relatively large triangular spinous process.

Question:
Mr Govind is a peculiar man. He enjoys spending his time driving his Ibiza chasing wild ducks. One day he comes across an ECG tracing, which seems to have been abandoned. He picks it up, gives it a sniff and begins to look at it.

 what is Govind's diagnosis?
Explanation:
Correct, left axis deviation

 

More govind stories to come!

Question: What vaccines/ boosters are given to a baby at their 3 month visit?
Which cytokine is produced by Stroma cells in the bone marrow and thymus and promotes the growth and maturation of thymocytes?
Explanation: The answer is B - IL-7 is produced by Stroma cells in the bone marrow and thymus and promotes maturation of thymocytes.

Question: Which of the following, produced mainly by macrophages, induces an inflammatory response, attracts neutrophils and promotes the expression of adhesion molecules on the surface of endothelial cells?
Explanation:
The answer is D - TNF-alpha is mainly produced by macrophages. It has the following effects:

  • Induces an inflammatory response
  • Is a potent chemoattractant for neutrophils
  • Increases the expression of adhesion molecules on the surface of endothelial cells
  • Stimulates phagocytosis in macrophages

Question: Which of the following, produced mainly by fibroblasts, promotes the action of NK cells via the process of ADCC (antibody dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity)?
Explanation:
The answer is D - IFN-beta is produced mainly from fibroblasts and promotes NK cell activity via ADCC.

IL-17 is produced by T helper cells and induces a pro-inflammatory response.

IFN-alpha is produced mainly by monocytes/macrophages, not fibroblasts.

TNF-alpha is mainly produced by macrophages.

IFN-gamma is produced mainly by T cells and NK cells.

 

Might be a bit of a harsh question but in the immunology revision session, Dr James Matthews said it'd be good to know about some of the main cytokines like the ones listed above :)

Question: Intestinal bacteria can be good for us! Which of the following vitamins are not metabolized by intestinal bacterial enzymes?
Explanation: correct, B1, commonly known as thiamine is not metabolised by intestinal bacteria

Question: Herpangina is caused by which virus?
Explanation: Question taken from the virology tutorial SBAs in Case 9. Herpangina is a painful mouth infection characterised by lesions and ulcerations in the back of the mouth and a sore throat. It commonly occurs in the summer in young people and children. It is caused most often by a strain of Coxsackie A virus

Question:
Jane is doing her weekly shop in Sainsburys, and is having a relaxing time doing so as she has left her 3 month old daughter at home, with her father. While paying for her groceries, the sound of a baby crying at a nearby checkout causes milk to be secreted from her breasts- the horror! She is very embarrassed and following research on arrival back home, she discovers it was a 'conditioned response'. 

Which hormone is released during this response to cause milk ejection?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C- Oxytocin. 

 

Oxytocin is the hormone responsible for ejection and letdown of milk. Most commonly, suckling stimulates afferent impulses to the hypothalamus (via the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei) where they stimulate production and secretion of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary gland.

Oxytocin then travels through the blood and upon reaching the breast tissue causes the contraction of the myoepithelial cells in the basement membranes of the alveoli which cause ejection of milk, into the lactiferous ducts, to the lactiferous sinus and exit via the nipple. 

The sound of a baby crying in some mothers can cause increased secretion of oxytocin, which results in let down. As they are used to feeding their own at the sound of its cry.
Tags: Baby, Breast, Pituitary Gland, Hormones, Case 8

Question: During early neurulation the notochord acts as a signalling centre that signals to the cells of the overlying ectoderm using soluble growth factors. Which of the following is not one of these soluble growth factors?
Explanation:
• There is no such thing as Tfp proteins. 
  • Wnt proteins appear to functions as inducers of ectodermally and mesodermally derived tissues and organs.
  • Shh induces neural patterning as well as patterning in the somites.
  • TGF-beta and BMP proteins regulate cell differentiation.

Question: Following the creation of the neural tube the notochord degenerates, but persists as which of these structures?

A diabetic patient attends the retinopathy screening clinic. Upon examination you see the following picture:

What grade of diabetic retinopathy does he have?
Explanation:
The answer is mild non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy. In this picture you can see microaneurysms and haemorrhages (mainly dot and blot). 

 

  • Background DR - dot and small blot haemorrhages 
  • Mild non-proliferative DR - hard exudates and microaneurysms 
  • Severe non-proliferative/ pre-proliferative DR - venous beading, flame haemorrhages, cotton wool spots 
  • Proliferative DR - growth of new blood vessels which are fragile, leaky and bleed easily

Question:
Mary is a 67 year old Type II diabetic with sensory neuropathy. Although you have explained to her the importance of checking her feet for sores each night before she goes to bed, Mary presents to the GP surgery with deep ulcers, shown below.

 

Which nerve provides cutaneous innervation to the area where Mary's ulcers have developed?
OptionC: Medial calcaneal branches of the tibial nerve

Question:
At the retinopathy screening clinic, a diabetic patient comes in and admits he hasn't come to be screened before because he's been scared of the results. You look in his eye and see the following image: 

 

What grade of diabetic retinopathy does he have?
Explanation:
The answer is proliferative diabetic retinopathy, as you can see extensive retinal haemorrhages and neovascularisation of the optic disc. 

 

  • Background DR - dot and small blot haemorrhages
  • Mild non-proliferative DR - hard exudates and microaneurysms
  • Severe non-proliferative/ pre-proliferative DR - venous beading, flame haemorrhages, cotton wool spots
  • Proliferative DR - growth of new blood vessels which are fragile, leaky and bleed easily

It is not quite at tractional detachment yet, which would look like this:

Question: Baby Brian is born with a problem with his hypothalamus. From which of the secondary brain vesicles does the hypothalamus arise?
Explanation:
A) The mesencephalon gives rise to the midbrain. The mesencephalon is the only primary brain vesicle that does not 'split' into two secondary brain vesicles and remains as the mesencephalon.

B) This is true, but is not the correct answer as the primary brain vesicle the hypothalamus arises from is the prosencephalon, not the secondary brain vesicle.

C) The metencephalon is a secondary brain vesicle which arises from the rhombencephalon, The metencephalon gives rise to the pons and cerebellum.

D) The telencephalon is a secondary brain vesicle that arises from the prosencephalon, and gives rise to the cerebral cortex and basal ganglia.

E) The diencephalon is the correct answerm and is a secondary brain vesicle that arises from the prosencephalon. The diencephalon gives rise to the optic cup and stalk, pituitary gland, thalamus, hypothalamus, and pineal body.

Question: Which of the following best describes a dromotrophic effect on the heart?
Explanation: Dromotrophic refers to the rate of conduction at the AV node. A dromotrophic effect will also have inotrophic and chromotrophic effects, but E is the single best answer.

Question: Baby Brian is born with a neural tube defect. In his neural tube defect, a few of the vertebrae in the region of L5-S1 have failed to fuse, and his meninges and spinal cord nerve roots are protruding out through this gap. Which neural tube defect does Brian have?
A woman presents to you with polydipsia, polyurea and nocturia. You realise that she has diabetes insipidus. At what part of the nephron is water not reabsorbed at in diabetes insipidus?
OptionA: The thin descending limb of the loop of Henle
OptionB: The thick ascending limb of the loop on Henle
OptionC: The last 2/3 of the distal tubule and the collecting duct
OptionD: The last 1/3 of the distal tubule and the collecting duct
Explanation: Diabetes inspidius is caused by a lack of ADH. ADH causes the aquaporins 2 and 3 to be inserted onto the apical membrane of the epithelium of the last 1/3 of the distal tubule and the collecting duct causing water to be reabsorbed. When ADH is not present the last 1/3 of the distal tubule and the collecting duct are impermeable to water.

Question: Which neurone of the ascending spinal tracts usually decussates?
Explanation: It is the second order neurones of the ascending tracts which decussate. The DCML pathway's second order neurones decussate in the medulla via the medial lemniscus. Spinothalamic neurones decussate in the spinal cord usually a level or two above the nerve root of the first order neurone.

Question: Damage or a lesion to the post-central gyrus is most likely to result in what symptom?
Explanation:
The post-central gyrus lies posterior to the central sulcus and contains the primary somatosensory cortex (Brodmann's area 3,1 and 2). It is arranged in the sensory homunculus. Hypoesthesia is loss of sensation or numbness and can be caused by damage to the PSSC. 

 

Hemiparesis is weakness in half of the body (at is most severe is known as hemiplegia which is paralysis to half the body). Hemiparesis can be caused by lesions or damage to the pre-central gyrus as this is the location of the motor cortex.

 

Ataxia (uncoordinated movements) is often caused by damage to the cerebellum although can be due to damage to the sensory neurones and areas of the brain. However it is not as likely as hypoesthesia. 

 

Hyperacusis is sensitivity to noise and can be due to CN VII palsy or damage to the auditory areas of the brain

 

Homonymous hemianopia is loss of vision in half of the eyes which is the same on both sides i.e. both left halves lost. Can be caused by damage to various areas of the brain which contain spinal tracts from the optic chiasm. This will cause contralateral loss.

Question: Biological clocks are groups of interacting molecules in cells throughout the body, there is a master biological clock that co-ordinates all the body clocks in the body so they are synchronised. Where is this master clock?
Explanation:
The suprachiasmatic nucleus or nuclei (SCN) is a tiny region located in the hypothalamus, situated directly above the optic chiasm. It is responsible for controlling circadian rhythms. The neuronal and hormonal activities it generates regulate many different body functions in a 24-hour cycle, using around 20,000 neurons. The SCN interacts with many other regions of the brain. It contains several cell types and several different peptides (including vasopressin and vasoactive intestinal peptide) and neurotransmitters.

 

The amygdala are two almond-shaped groups of nuclei located deep and medially within the temporal lobes of the brain in complex vertebrates, including humans. These perform a primary role in the processing of memory, decision-making, and emotional reactions, the amygdalae are considered part of the limbic system.

 

The limbic system The limbic system is a complex set of structures that lies on both sides of the thalamus, just under the cerebrum. It includes the hypothalamus, the hippocampus, the amygdala, and several other nearby areas. It appears to be primarily responsible for our emotional life, and has a lot to do with the formation of memories. In this drawing, you are looking at the brain cut in half, but with the brain stem intact. The part of the limbic system shown is that which is along the left side of the thalamus (hippocampus and amygdala) and just under the front of the thalamus (hypothalamus)

The caudate nucleus plays a vital role in how the brain learns, specifically the storing and processing of memories. It works as a feedback processor, which means it uses information from past experiences to influence future actions and decisions. This is important to the development and use of language. Specifically, communication skills are thought to be controlled mostly by the left caudate and the thalamus.

Each of the brain's hemispheres contains a caudate nucleus, and both are located centrally and near the basal ganglia. They are also situated near the thalamus, which is deep in the brain, close to the midbrain.

See this link for 3D views of brain structures: http://www.healthline.com/human-body-maps/caudate-nucleus

 

Nucleus accumbens: is a region in the basal forebrain rostral to the preoptic area of the hypothalamus. The nucleus accumbens and the olfactory tubercle collectively form the ventral portion of the striatum, which is part of the basal ganglia.
The nucleus accumbens has a significant role in the cognitive processing of motivation, pleasure, and reward and reinforcement learning, and hence has significant role in addiction. It plays a lesser role in fear, impulsivity, and the placebo effect. It is involved in the encoding of new motor programs as well.

 

Pineal gland: The pineal gland/body is a small endocrine gland in the brain. It produces melatonin, a serotonin derived hormone, which affects the modulation of sleep patterns in both seasonal and circadian rhythms. Its shape resembles a tiny pine cone (hence its name), and it is located in the epithalamus, near the center of the brain, between the two hemispheres, tucked in a groove where the two halves of the thalamus join. (See first diagram for location)

 

 

 

 

 

More info on the hypothalamus:

The hypothalamus is a small part of the brain located just below the thalamus on both sides of the third ventricle. (The ventricles are areas within the cerebrum that are filled with cerebrospinal fluid, and connect to the fluid in the spine.) It sits just inside the two tracts of the optic nerve, and just above (and intimately connected with) the pituitary gland.

The hypothalamus is one of the busiest parts of the brain, and is mainly concerned with homeostasis. Homeostasis is the process of returning something to some “set point.” It works like a thermostat: When your room gets too cold, the thermostat conveys that information to the furnace and turns it on. As your room warms up and the temperature gets beyond a certain point, it sends a signal that tells the furnace to turn off.

The hypothalamus is responsible for regulating your hunger, thirst, response to pain, levels of pleasure, sexual satisfaction, anger and aggressive behavior, and more. It also regulates the functioning of the autonomic nervous system (see below), which in turn means it regulates things like pulse, blood pressure, breathing, and arousal in response to emotional circumstances.

The hypothalamus receives inputs from a number of sources. From the vagus nerve, it gets information about blood pressure and the distension of the gut (that is, how full your stomach is). From the reticular formation in the brainstem, it gets information about skin temperature. From the optic nerve, it gets information about light and darkness. From unusual neurons lining the ventricles, it gets information about the contents of the cerebrospinal fluid, including toxins that lead to vomiting. And from the other parts of the limbic system and the olfactory (smell) nerves, it gets information that helps regulate eating and sexuality. The hypothalamus also has some receptors of its own, that provide information about ion balance and temperature of the blood.

In one of the more recent discoveries, it seems that there is a protein called leptin which is released by fat cells when we overeat. The hypothalamus apparently senses the levels of leptin in the bloodstream and responds by decreasing appetite. It would seem that some people have a mutation in a gene which produces leptin, and their bodies can’t tell the hypothalamus that they have had enough to eat. However, many overweight people do not have this mutation, so there is still a lot of research to do!

The hypothalamus sends instructions to the rest of the body in two ways. The first is to the autonomic nervous system. This allows the hypothalamus to have ultimate control of things like blood pressure, heartrate, breathing, digestion, sweating, and all the sympathetic and parasympathetic functions.

The other way the hypothalamus controls things is via the pituitary gland. It is neurally and chemically connected to the pituitary, which in turn pumps hormones called releasing factors into the bloodstream. As you know, the pituitary is the so-called “master gland,” and these hormones are vitally important in regulating growth and metabolism.

http://webspace.ship.edu/cgboer/limbicsystem.html
Tags: Sleep, Endocrine, Case 12, Physiology, Head and Neck

Question: What is the best estimate for the percentage of corticospinal fibres which decussate at the lower part of the medulla?
Explanation: The decussation of corticospinal tracts depends on whether they are part of the lateral or medial corticospinal tract. The lateral corticospinal tract is the main tract for the limbs and is the most clinically relevant as it forms around 80-90% of the corticospinal tract. The lateral tract decussates in the lower part of the medulla (medullary pyramids) hence the percentage that decussate is 80-90%. The medial corticospinal tract remains ipsilateral and the decussates in the cervical and thoracic spinal cord. The anterior corticospinal forms around 20% of the corticospinal fibres and supply only axial muscles etc. The

Question: Baby Brian is born with hypotonia, an umbilical hernia, prominent epicanthic folds, bilateral sandal gap deformity, bilateral fifth finger clinodactyly, and single transverse palmar creases. Which aneuploidic abnormality do you suspect?
Explanation:
• Trisomy 21 is Down Syndrome, which can present with all of these features and more including; a large tongue, Brushfield spots on the iris, a flattened nose, low-set ears, and upslanting palpebral fissures.
  • Trisomy 8 and trisomy 22 are only viable in mosaic forms, and are rare.
  • Trisomy 18 is Edwards Syndrome.
  • Trisomy 13 is Patau Syndrome.

Question: Which one of these muscles belongs to the Deep Posterior Compartment of the Leg?
Explanation:
The main 3 muscles in the Deep Posterior Compartment of the Leg can be remembered with the mnemonic 'Tom, Dick and Harry'

 

Tom - Tibialis Posterior

Dick - Flexor Digitorum Longus

Harry - Flexor Hallucis Longus

Question: The Cori cycle is most associated with which of the following?
Explanation:
Lactate produced in glycolysis under anaerobic conditions (most likely from active muscle) is transported to the liver where it enters gluconeogenesis, to be converted back to glucose.  If there is still a glucose demand in the body this will be released back into the blood to return to muscle to be reused, or it may enter glycogen synthesis for storage - this is the Cori cycle.

 

Source: Medical Biochemistry by Baynes and Dominiczak

Question: Brenda is told that her newborn son Brian has mosaic Edwards Syndrome. By what notation would this aneuploidy be represented?
Explanation:
A) This would indicate mosaic trisomy 8.

B) This is mosaic Edwards Syndrome (trisomy 18).

C) This would be a mosaic form of monosomy 18.

D) This would indicate mosaic Down Syndrome.

E) This would indicate mosaic Patau Syndrome.

Question: Your patient, Brenda, comes to see you for an ultrasound. Her baby has triploidy, and Brenda is now about 5 months pregnant. On ultrasound, you can see a large placenta and a small foetus. By what mechanism would you suspect the triploidy has occured?
Explanation:
Triploidy can be caused by two different mechanisms;

  • Diandry - Occurs when an egg is fertilized by 2 sperm or by a diploid sperm. Results in a large placenta and a small foetus ('Dad wants mum to do all the work').
  • Digyny - Occurs when a diploid egg is fertilized by a single sperm. Results in a small placenta and a small foetus.

Question: A patient comes in following a bike accident. As he walks into the room, you notice that he is dragging his toes along the ground. Upon neurological examination, he doesn't have any sensation in the webbing between his big toe and second toe. You conclude that he has damaged a nerve during the accident. Which nerve is it?
Explanation:
He is suffering from foot drop, which is a sign of paralysis of the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg. These muscles are supplied by the deep fibular nerve.

The loss of sensation also directs you towards the deep fibular nerve; the rest of the dorsum of the foot is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve (labelled as superficial and deep peroneal on the diagram):

 

The other nerves:

  • Tibial nerve - supplies the muscles of the posterior leg (plantarflexion and inversion), and the skin of the posterolateral leg/ lateral and plantar surface of the foot 
  • Femoral nerve - supplies the muscles of the anterior thigh (extend knee) and the skin of the anteromedial thigh/ saphenous nerve (branch of femoral) supplies medial leg and foot
  • Sciatic nerve - supplies the muscles of posterior thigh (extend hip, flex knee) and the indirectly the skin of the lateral leg/heel/foot

Question: A woman comes in to your GP practice complaining of numbness on her medial thigh. Upon examination, she can only weakly adduct her thigh. She tells you that she recently had an operation on her pelvis, and you think her problems might be as a consequence of that. What nerve do you think she has damaged?
Explanation:
She has damaged her obturator nerve, which supplies the medial thigh muscles (the adductors) and the skin of the medial thigh:

 

This nerve is often damaged through surgery to the pelvis or abdomen. 

 

The other nerves:
