  • Tibial nerve - supplies the muscles of the posterior leg (plantarflexion and inversion), and the skin of the posterolateral leg/ lateral and plantar surface of the foot
  • Femoral nerve - supplies the muscles of the anterior thigh (extend knee) and the skin of the anteromedial thigh/ saphenous nerve (branch of femoral) supplies medial leg and foot
  • Sciatic nerve - supplies the muscles of posterior thigh (extend hip, flex knee) and the indirectly the skin of the lateral leg/heel/foot
  • Common fibular nerve - supplies the biceps femoris short head and indirectly the anterior and lateral leg, as well as the skin of the anterolateral leg and dorsum of the foot
Tags: Anatomy, Innervation, Lower Limb, Nerves, Case 1

Question: 13 year old Brian is brought to clinic. He has Prader-Willi Syndrome, and suffers with behavioral problems, obesity, hyperphagia, and learning disabilities as a result of this. Which of the following deletions has caused Brian's Prader-Willi Syndrome?
Explanation:
A) A 5p deletion causes Cri du Chat Syndrome.

B) A 22q11.2 deletion causes DiGeorge Syndrome.

C) A 4p deletion causes Wold-Hirschhorn Syndrome.

D) Prader-Willi Syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15 (15q11-q13 deletion). NB: Angelman Syndrome is caused by a deletion on the maternal chromosome 15.

E) A 17p11.2 deletion causes Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

Question: Govind is on the train. He is thinking to himself, which of the following is not part of antenatal screening programme?
Explanation: Correct, iron levels are not screened for, infact, heamoglobin is measured to check if mother is anemic

Question: Baby Brian is born without one of his hands due to Amniotic Band Syndrome. Amniotic Band Syndrome is best described by which of the following terms?
Explanation:
• Birth defect and congenital anomaly are synonyms, and it is correct to say that they are terms which describe Amniotic Band Syndrome. However, in terms of single best answer, they are not the most correct/accurate of the potential answers.
  • Amniotic Band Syndrome is a disruption. A disruption occurs when a foetal structure is growing normally, but then growth is disrupted by a destructive process.
  • Deformations occur due to long term mechanical stress on normal foetal tissue (e.g. oligohyramnios leading to clubfoot).
  • Malformations occurs during the actual formation of structures when foetal growth and development does not proceed normally.

Question: Which of the following causes the greatest number of miscarriages per year in the UK?
Explanation: Correct, none of the above do. Trisomy 16 does

Question: This is a cross section of the thigh. Given that number 23 = femur, what is the muscle labelled 12? It is part of the posterior muscle group, and is so responsible for extending the hip and flexing the leg at the knee joint.
Explanation:
• Gracilis - 9 
  • Biceps femoris long head - 15 
  • Biceps femoris short head - 16
  • Semimembranous - 10 

Semitendinous, semimembranous and the biceps femoris are all part of the posterior comparment of the thigh, and therefore all do the action described above. They are innervated by the tibial branch of the sciatic nerve. 

Gracilis is part of the medial compartment and so adducts the hip, and is innervated by the obturator nerve. 

 

http://www.anatomyatlases.org/HumanAnatomy/7Section/04.shtml

Question:
Brenda is 12 weeks pregnant and undergoes a number of lab tests. Her results are as follows;

  • hCG: Elevated
  • INH-A: Elevated
  • MSAFP: Low
  • Oestriol: Low
  • PAPP-A: Low

Which of the following could these findings be due to?
Explanation:
• These results would be indicative of Down Syndrome.
  • Edwards Syndrome would give low MSAFP, oestriol, and hCG.
  • An open neural tube defect would give high MSAFP.

Question:
Below is a description of a personality model. Which theory is it describing?

"Cognitive expectations about the world shape personality. As such, cognitive processes work in conjunction with environmental influences".
Explanation:
A) - Behavioural theory: Personality is the result of interactions between the individual and the environment, where the individual responds to an external stimulus and the consequence of that response shapes behaviour.

 

B) - Biological & Trait theories: Traits are heritable and can be described biologically. Personality is made up of a number of distinct traits (relatively enduring patterns of thoughts, feelings and actions). Traits are relatively stable across time and contexts and can be used to predict behaviour. 

 

C) - Humanistic theories: Highlight the importance of freewill and individual experience on the development of personality. Actualising tendency – all humans tend to move toward completion or fulfilment of potentials.

 

D) - Social Learning Theory - Correct answer :) 

 

E) - Type theories: Refer to the psychological classification of different “types” of people. Personality “types” can be distinguished from personality “traits”, which come in different degrees. For example, according to type theories, there are two types of people – introverts and extraverts.

Question: Which factor of a Type A personality is thought to be linked to an increased risk of coronary artery disease?
Explanation:
Recent studies have suggested that “hostility” may be the key element associated with coronary disease, with people who repress hostility being more vulnerable.

Source: Personality workbook, Case 12

Question: Which of the following is not a personality trait described in the 5 factor model of personality?
Explanation:
A) - Agreeableness (compliant, compassionate, trusting, empathetic, sympathetic, friendly and cooperative nature).

B) - Conscientiousness (thoughtful, scrupulous, meticulous, principled behaviour guided by conscience, good impulse control. Tend to be organised). 

C) - Neuroticism (Emotional stability, emotional tendency to ander, depression, anxiety, vulnerability to stress).

D) - Openness to experience (Wide interests, imaginative, insightful, curious, preference for variety).

E) - Sexual behaviour is not a measure used in the 5 factor model of personality.

 

The 5th factor is Extraversion (Gregarious, assertive, outgoing, sociable, projecting personality outward (emotionally expressive)). 

 

http://personality-testing.info/tests/BIG5.php a nice personality quiz which uses the Big 5 if you fancy a revision break. 

Source: Personality workbook, Case 12

Question: Dylan comes into see his GP as he's been having a couple of health problems. He first mentions his terrible chat, of which there is no cure. He then mentions how he has not been feeling well and his cheeks have been really swollen. The GP suspects a mumps infection, causing parotitis. What cranial nerve provides motor innervation to the parotid gland?
Explanation: The glossopharygeal nerve (CN IX) provides parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland via the otic ganglia. A branch of V3 provides sensory innervation of the parotid gland and surrounding area. The facial nerve (CN VII) provides innervation to most of the other glands of the face including the lacrimal, sublingual and submandibular glands.

Question: A certain medical student has an unhealthy obsession with killer whales and whilst watching Free Willy becomes extremely emotional. They begin to cry uncontrollably. What nerve is causing this?
OptionA: Lacrimal nerve, a branch of CN V1
OptionB: Frontal nerve, a branch of CN V1
OptionC: Pterygopalatine nerve, a branch of CN V2
OptionE: Greater petrosal nerve, a branch of CN VII
Explanation: The facial nerve via the greater petrosal nerve supplies the visceral motor innervation of the lacrimal gland whilst the lacrimal nerve supplies the sensory innervation.

Question: Which descending spinal tract is involved in maintaining  the balance and upright position of the head?
Explanation:
MRST - excites extensor muscles in the legs for balance 

LRST - inhibits extensor muscles

Medial Vestibulospinal Tract - CORRECT ANSWER

Lateral Vestibulospinal Tract - maintains balance by innervating body and lower limb. 

Rubrospinal Tract - involuntary adjustment of arm position for balance. 

 

Note. These are only the functions of these pathways related to balance.

Question: You are working your summer holidays away in a busy restaurant where you go to wait on the new table that has come in. Already being extremely awkward and requesting the best window seat in the restaurant; and having their children knock over the wine rack you are then at a loss to find out that one of the customers is a coeliac. After relaying this information to the chef who informs you this does not mean that they have a profound allergy to celery, you are informed that the customer is intolerant to what?
Explanation:
Coeliac disease is caused by a gluten intolerance. Foodstuffs containing gluten are those which contain wheat, rye or barley - commonly found in bread, cereals and pasta.

 

(Question based on personal experience...)

Question: Which of the following would you not expect to occur in the absorptive state?
Explanation: After a meal the level of insulin increases causing cells to take up fats from chylomicrons and increase lipid synthesis. Insulin also inhibits hormone sensitive lipase to reduce lipolysis. Gluconeogenesis also decreases and synthesis of glycogen increases (glycogenesis). Glucokinase is upregulated as there is increased glucose entering the liver and pancreas causing glucokinase to phosphorylate glucose.

Question: Which ascending spinal tract carries information on fine touch?
Explanation:
Spinothalamic: 

    Anterior = crude touch and firm pressure

    Lateral = pain and temperature

Spinoreticular:

    Pain and possibly temp and crude touch

Dorsal Column:

    Vibration, pressure, proprioception and fine touch (aka tactile sensation)

Spinocerebellar:

    Proprioception (particularly related to posture)

Spinohypothalamus:

    Pain

 

 

Crude Touch is where you know that you have been touched, but can't localise where. 

Fine Touch is where you can both sense the touch and localise it.

Question: A 49 year old woman presents to the GP feeling very thirsty and tired. They have a BMI of 24. Upon blood tests it is revealed they have a high level of certain autoantibodies present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation: The later presentation suggests this is not typical type 1 diabetes as this is normally diagnosed in young people. Both monogenic (MODY) and standard type 2 diabetes don't have an autoimmune component so would not explain the raised autoantibodies. LADA is essentially late onset type 1 diabetes and is the most likely diagnosis given the autoimmune antibodies and the age and which the patient is presenting.

Question: During a hand examination, how would I test for a fractured scaphoid?
OptionD: Checking for sensation provided by the radial nerve in the first dorsal web space
Explanation:
Tinel's test - detects carpal tunnel syndrome, in which the median nerve would be compressed. 

MCP Squeeze - is tender in inflammatory disease such as RA. 

Sensation is testing the nerve. 

Unlikely to feel a scaphoid fracture during palpation, during which you are looking for tenderness, warmth or disformity.

Question: Which of these is NOT a respiratory cause of clubbing?
Explanation:
Other respiratory causes of clubbing include: 

 

Suppurative Lung Disease (which includes bronchiectasis, CF, Empyema, Abscesses)

 

Lung Cancer

Question: Which of these is NOT a GI cause of nail clubbing?
Explanation:
MILC

 

Malabsoption

IBD

Lymphoma

Chronic Liver Disease

Question: What breath sound is a sign of pulmonary fibrosis?
Contraction in skeletal muscle cells is best matched to which of the following statements?
OptionA: Ca2+-calmodulin complexes must activate myosin light chain kinase in order that contraction may proceed
OptionE: Dependent on some calcium entry from the extracellular space
Explanation:
This is Skeletal Muscle, so contraction is thin filament-regulated, meaning calcium binds to troponin, causing a conformational change in tropomyosin to expose the binding sites on actin (thin) filaments.  In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine receptors are directly coupled to ryanodine receptors (RyRs) on the SR at T-tubules, meaning when an action potential propagates down the T-tubule, DHPRs are activated, directly activating RyRs to release calcium from the SR into the cytosol.

 

Answers A and B are relevant to Smooth Muscle contraction, while answers D and E both refer to the same thing - CICR which occurs in Cardiac Muscle.

 

Source: PCS Muscle contraction lecture

Question: Barry the baroreceptor is having a hard time. He is living in the carotid sinus and has noticed increased stretch due to increased pressure. However he can't remember what he should do. Barry should...
OptionA: Decrease firing rate to decrease sympathetic drive
OptionB: Increase firing rate to increase sympathetic drive
OptionC: Decrease firing rate to decrease sympathetic drive and increase parasympathetic drive
OptionD: Increase firing rate to decrease sympathetic drive and increase parasympathetic drive
OptionE: Increase firing rate to increase sympathetic drive and decrease parasympathetic drive
Explanation:
Barry is an arterial baroreceptor located in the carotid sinus and has noticed an increased stretch in the vessel wall indicating an increase in blood pressure.

  • increase stretch = increased firing rate
  • increased firing rate = decreased sympathetic and increased parasympathetic drive
  • acts to decrease heart rate and decrease total peripheral resistance thus lowering blood pressure 

If however Blood pressure decreased

  • decrease stretch = decrease firing rate
  • decrease parasympathetic and increase sympathetic drive
  • results in increased heart rate and contractility, peripheral vasoconstriction and venoconstriction, catecholamine secretion, increased renin secretion
  • increased heart rate, peripheral resistance and circulating blood volume to restore blood pressure to normal values

carotid sinus = glossopharangeal nerve, aortic arch = vagus nerve

Question: The saphenous nerve provides cutaneous innervation to which aspect of the lower limb?
Explanation: Below shows the cutaneous innervation of the leg. The dorsum of the foot is mainly supplied by the superficial fibular apart from a small area in the webbing between the big toe and 2nd toe which is the deep fibular. The anterior and medial thigh are innervated by the anterior cutaneous branches of the femoral nerve. The posterior thigh is supplied mainly by posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh (again a branch of the femoral nerve).

Question: The sural nerve, which innervates lateral and posterior aspects of the leg as well as the lateral malleolus is formed by the joining of branches from which two nerves?
Explanation: From wikipedia - "The medial cutaneous branch arises from the tibial nerve and the lateral branch arises from the common fibular nerve. The tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve arise as the sciatic nerve divides into two branches in the popliteal fossa. As the tibial nerve travels down the popliteal fossa, and before it goes beneath the gastrocnemius, it gives off a cutaneous branch which is the medial sural cutaneous nerve. This nerve courses laterally over the lateral head of the gastrocnemius. The common fibular nerve also gives off a small cutaneous branch which is the lateral sural cutaneous nerve"

Question: The dorsalis pedis artery, which can be palpated lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon, is a continuation of which artery?
Explanation: The anterior tibial artery which itself is formed from the popliteal artery begins at the lower border of popliteus muscle. It then passes through the top of the interosseus membrane of the tibia and fibular and then runs down the medial aspect of the leg to the anterior aspect of the ankle joint where it forms the dorsalis pedis artery.

Question: During childbirth, following crowning of the baby's head, which of the following is the correct subsequent series of events?
OptionA: Extension, Restitution, Internal rotation of the shoulders, Posterior shoulder, Anterior shoulder, Lateral flexion.
OptionB: Extension, Restitution, Internal rotation of the head, Posterior shoulder, Anterior shoulder, Lateral flexion.
OptionC: Extension, Restitution, Internal rotation of the shoulders, Anterior shoulder, Posterior shoulder, Lateral flexion.
OptionD: Extension, Restitution, Internal rotation of the shoulders, Anterior shoulder, Posterior shoulder, Descent.
OptionE: Restitution, Extension, Internal rotation of the shoulders, Posterior shoulder, Anterior shoulder, Lateral flexion.
Explanation:
The mechanism of labour is as follows; Descent, Flexion, Internal rotation of the head, Crowning, Extension, Restitution, Internal rotation of the shoulders, Anterior shoulder, Posterior shoulder, Lateral flexion.

The mnemonic to remember this by is; Do Frogs In Cardiff Ever Ride In A Pink Limo

Question: A 59 year old man presents with breathlessness while walking and swelling of his ankles. You discover that he had a myocardial infarction two years ago and on auscultation you find basal crepitations. From this history and examination, you suspect heart failure. What is the most appropriate next step?
OptionE: Carry out a BNP (brain natriuretic peptide) test
Explanation:
The answer is C - You would refer him directly for an echocardiography.

This is taken straight from Prof Alan Fraser's lecture in case 15.

In a patient presenting with symptoms such as breathlessness, in whom heart failure is suspected, then if the patient:
• has a history of myocardial infarction
• has basal crepitations
• is a male with ankle oedema
refer directly for echocardiography.
Otherwise, carry out a BNP (or NT-proBNP) test first.

Question:
An elderly woman is admitted to your ward with a suspected intracapsular fracture of the neck of the femur after falling. She complains of pain that radiates to her knee, and struggles to move her hip. 

You are worried about her blood supply being compromised, leading to avascular necrosis to the femoral head. 

Which artery do you think she has damaged?
OptionB: Perforating branches of the profunda femoris artery
Explanation:
Intracapsular fractures (femoral neck fractures) are fractures between the edge of the femoral head and insertion of the capsule of the hip joint. They can follow relatively minor trauma in the elderly, and would be caused by high-energy impact in the young. They can disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to avascular necrosis. 

http://www.patient.co.uk/doctor/femoral-fractures 

 

 

The medial circumflex femoral artery wraps round the posterior side of the femur, supplying the neck and head of the femur. In a fracture of the femoral neck, this artery can easily be damaged, and avascular necrosis of the femur head can occur.

http://teachmeanatomy.info/lower-limb/vasculature/arterial-supply/
Tags: Anatomy, Lower Limb, Case 1, Trauma, Fractures

Question:
You see a patient with a popliteal aneurysm on your ward round. You see an obvious palpable pulsation in the popliteal fossa.

You know from your revision that due to the tough popliteal fascial layer, the aneurysm cannot expand fully and so has consequences for the other contents of the popliteal fossa. You suspect that the tibial nerve is compressed. 

How would the patient have presented if this was the case?
OptionA: Anaesthesia over the lateral leg and an inability to evert the foot
OptionB: Anaesthesia over the anterolateral leg and an inability to dorsiflex the foot
OptionC: Anaesthesia over the plantar surface of the foot, and an inability to plantarflex the foot
OptionD: Anaesthesia between the hallux and 2nd toe, and an inability to dorsiflex the foot
OptionE: Anaesthesia over the plantar surface of the foot, and an inability to dorsiflex the foot
Explanation:
• Anaesthesia over the lateral leg and an inability to evert the foot - this would be damage to the superficial fibular nerve 
  • Anaesthesia over the anterolateral leg and an inability to dorsiflex the foot - damage to the common fibular nerve 
  • Anaesthesia between the hallux and 2nd toe, and an inability to dorsiflex the foot - damage to the deep fibular nerve 
  • Anaesthesia over the plantar surface of the foot, and an inability to dorsiflex the foot - wouldn't necessarily occur, as the majority of the plantar surface of the foot is supplied by branches of the tibial nerve but the motor function is to the posterior leg which is responsible to plantarflexion

http://teachmeanatomy.info/lower-limb/vasculature/arterial-supply/

Question: Where does the rubrospinal tract originate from in the brain?
Explanation:
The correct answer is D, Rubrospinal indicates this tract originates from the red nucleus of the midbrain.

A - The Vestibulospinal tract receives information from the bony labyrinths in the cerebellum.

B & C - both Reticulospinal tract, the medial = pons (Pontoreticulospinal) whilst lateral = medulla (Medullary-reticulospinal tract).

E - The Tectospinal tract originates from the superior colliculi of the midbrain (Tecto = tectum/roof of the midbrain)

Question: Which of the following is indicated for antibiotic treatment
Explanation:
"microbiology of the GI tract" plenary case 11

indications for antibiotics are:

  • Parasitic infections (e.g. Giardia and cryptosporidium)
  • Early campylobacter 
  • Invasive salmonella - S Typhi/typhimurium strains (not necessarily enterides)
  • Severe disease of any aetiology in consultation with ID/micro

Antibiotics not useful for rotavirus because it is a virus not a bacterium

Toxigenic E coli not indicated as antibiotics thought to increase toxin production.

Question:
When walking home, you see someone fall off their bike after being hit by a car. You run over to try and help. 

When you squeeze his nail bed, the man pulls his arm away. He also opens his eyes briefly every time you apply a painful stimulus. He is moaning and doesn't answer your questions. 

The paramedics arrive quickly and ask you what his GCS score is. What do you tell them?
Explanation:
The answer is 8 - he withdraws from pain, which is a motor response of 4, he is incomprehensible with moaning but no words, which is a verbal response of 2, and he opens his eyes in response to pain, eye response of 2. 

M4, V2, E2 

 

The list of responses are found here - http://www.patient.co.uk/doctor/glasgow-coma-scale-gcs

Question: Jon Snow has been prescribed a drug a rate control drug for his Atrial Fibrillation. He comes to see you a week later suffering from impotence , understandably he is very upset and embarrassed. Which drug has he been given?
Explanation:
The answer is C , Metoprolol. This is a Beta blocker (class 2). Common side effects include impotence, exacerbation of COPD and asthma and CNS effects such as sedation and sleep alterations. 

 

As an additional point, Beta Blockers may mask signs of hypoglycemia. B blocker overdose can be treated with saline, atropine and glucagon.

Question: Raymond is prescribed Hydrochlorothiazide (a thiazide diuretic) What is the possible toxicity of this drug?
OptionE: Cough , Angiodemia , Teratogenic effects , increased Creatine , hyperkalemia, hypotension
Explanation:
A is correct: Hyperglycemia, Hyperlipidemia , Hyperuricemia , Hypercalcemia are all possible side effects of Thiazide diuretics. (A good way to remember this is HyperGLUC) In addition , Metabolic alkaolsis and hyponatremia are also possible side effects. 

 

B: Endocrine effects - e.g. gynecomastia , antiandrogen are side effects of K+ sparing diuretics such as Spironolactone

 

C: Incorrect , Metabolic Acidosis is not caused by Thiazide diuretics. In fact they cause alkalosis. Acetazolamide is an example of a diuretic that can cause Metabolic acidosis. 

 


D: Ototoxicity, Hypokalemia , Dehydration , Allergy, Nephritis , Gout are side effects of a loop diuretic such as Furosemide. (A good way to remember side effect of Loop diuretics is OH DANG)

 


E: Cough , Angiodemia , Teratogenic effects , increased Creatine , hyperkalemia, hypotension are side effects of ACE inhibitors. 

 

Hope this helps!

Question: Dany is prescribed a diuretic. She begins suffering from Gout. From which of the following is Gout a possible side effect of?
Explanation: B is the correct answer. Gout is a possible side effect of Loop Diuretics , of which Furosemide belongs to. Other possible side effects include Ototoxicity, Hypokalemia, Dehydration , Allergy and Nephritis

Question: Sarah is a 26 year old female who presents with episodic mechanical back pain. One of the possible differentials for episodic back pain, especially in a woman of her age, is degenerative spondylolisthesis. This occurs when one vertebrae slips forwards over the one below it. Where is the most common site for degenerative spondylolisthesis?
Explanation:
Nb. Spondylolisthesis is not the same as a slipped disc, it is the movement of a vertebrae not a disc.

Many patients are asymptomatic but symptoms can include lower back pain, sciatica and cauda equina syndrome.

Question:
Simon has an acute lumbar disc prolapse. A disc prolapse occurs when the extrusion extends beyond the limits of the fibrous zone.

Where is the weakest point of the disc and therefore most likely to prolapse?
Explanation: The weakest point is posterolateral, where the disc may impinge on emerging spinal nerve roots in the root canal.

Question: One of your patients has the following karyotype.  Which description would be best suited to the patient?
OptionA: A blood test would show reduced LH and testosterone
OptionE: They would have had difficulties with language and reading when growing up
Explanation:
The karyogram indicated a male patient with an extra X chromosome, so the patient has the karyotype 47XXY.  This is called Klinefelter's syndrome, which only affects males.  Every sufferer of this syndrome will be infertile therefore this statement best suits this condition - answer is D.  A lot of the time, this condition isn't diagnosed until the sufferer attempts to have children and seeks medical help when his partner and him can not conceive.

 

A - they will present with primary hypogonadism i.e. raised FSH and LH, but low testosterone.

B - often they will present like this, however not all the time.

C - Klinefelter's syndrome only affects men.

E - some do have these problems, but again ti doesn't occur all the time.

 

Sufferers of Klinefelter's syndrome may also have pubertal gynaecosmastia, small testes, delayed or incomplete development of secondary sexual characteristics, tall stature, variable developmental delay (with motor function or language and reading ability).  There is an increase risk of health problems associated with women e.g. breast cancer, osteoporosis and reduced risk of X linked diseases.  

Treatment/Management - testosterone supplements, surgery for gynaecosmastia, fertility treatment - e.g. testicular sperm aspirations and intracytoplasmic injection.

Occurs 1/2 in every 1000 births.

 

 

Source: Chromosome Abnormalities lecture

Question: What are the Neurotransmitter changes associated with Alzheimers disease?
Explanation:
A is correct

B are the changes seen in Anxiety

C are the changes seen in Depression (remember by everything down)

D are the changes seen in Huntington disease

E are changes seen in Parkingson disease

Question: What cranial nerve supplies the sub mandibular and sub linguinal glands to bring about salivation?
Explanation:
C is correct. 

 

Note: The Glossopharygeal nerve supplies the paratoid gland which also causes salivation.

Question:
What is the name of this process:
Within 6 hours of injury, the nucleus of a nerve migrates to the periphery of the cell, Nissl granules and RER break up and disperse.
Explanation:
A - chemotaxis is the movement of an organism in response to a chemical stimulus. 

B - Correct! Chromatolysis is triggered by neuronal injury and is thought  to act as a signal for glial cells to extend processes to aid recovery. Chromatolysis is reversed when the cell is prepared for axon regeneration. It takes place proximal to the lesion. 

C - Nissl degeneration is degeneration of the cell body occurring after transection of the axon (I thought I made it up for this question but checked and it is a real thing!) 

D - Phagocytosis is is the process by which a cell engulfs a solid particle to form an internal vesicle known as a phagosome.

E - Wallerian Degeneration is a process in which the part of the axon separated from the neurone's cell body by injury, degenerates. It takes place distally to the lesion. 

Source: Nerve Injury lecture, Case 14.

Question: You suspect a sex chromosome disorder in a patient. Which test would then be carried out?
Explanation:
B is correct. Array CGH allows systemic testing allows systemic testing of thousands or millions of genomic regions at one time. It has replaced karyotyping for postnatal cytogenic testing or when sex chromosome disorder is suspected. 

 

Option A , FISH is used when the 22Q11.2 deletion is suspected (Di George Syndrome)

 

Source: The lecture

Question: Which of the following terms refers to the ejection of milk from the breast?
Explanation:
The physiological basis of lactation is divided into 4 stages:

  1. Mammogenesis - Preparation of the breasts.
  2. Lactogenesis - Synthesis and secretion of milk from the breast alveoli.
  3. Galactokinesis - Ejection of milk from the breast.
  4. Galactopoiesis - Maintenance of lactation.

Question: What is used for the rapid / immediate reversal of warfarin?
Explanation:
A: Vitamin K is used for reversal but it takes days to take effect - 

B: Correct , Fresh Frozen Plasma is used for immediate reversal

C: Protamine Sulfate is Heparin antidote. 

D: Flumazenil is used in Benzo overdoses 

E: NOAC's have no antidote

Question: Dany comes in with a UTI. What is the leading cause of a UTI infection?
Explanation:
All of these bugs can cause UTI's. However, Escherichia coli is by far the most common. 

Straphlococcus saprophyticus is the 2nd leading cause of UTI's and is seen in sexually active women

Klebsiella pneumoniae is the 3rd leading cause of UTI's

Question:
You are with a 30 year old patient who tells you he was diagnosed with a chromosome abnormality but he can't remember which one.  He said the doctor, at the time, had suspicions as the patient had severe acne when he was going through puberty, aggressive streaks and antisocial behaviour.  The doctor tested his testosterone which was normal and did a karyotype to confirm the diagnosis.  

Whilst talking to this patient, he seems pretty tall and of reasonable intelligence.  He mentions he has a daughter, and another child who sadly died in-utero pre-term.

 

What chromosomal abnormality is he mist likely to have?
Explanation:
The signs and symptoms listed by the patient is typical of XYY syndrome.  This presents with tall stature, normal IQ, possible developmental delays, severe acne, aggression and antisocial behaviour.  They have normal testosterone levels and normal fertility.

Most are unaware they have the condition.

Admittedly the signs and symptoms are quite generic/vague but there is no chance it could be any of the other conditions.

 

Klinefelter's - 47 XXY, patients are infertile, often shy and testosterone deficient.

Patau's - trisomy 13, would have been picked up at birth.  Very little chance of someone with Patau's surviving to 30.

Turner's - 45 X, affect women only, causes infertility.

XXYY syndrome - presents similar to Klinefelter's syndrome.

 

The miscarriage is a red herring.

Question: An Influenza pandemic is striking through out Westeros. What causes a Pandemic?
Explanation:
D is correct.  Genetic Shifts cause pandemics. This is a re-assortment of viral genome segments, for example when human flu A virus reassort with swine flue A virus. 

 

Genetic drift causes epidemics. This is when minor changes based on random mutations in hemagglutinin or neuranindase genes occur. 

 

A good way to remember this is "Sudden Shift is more deadly than Gradual Drift" 

 

Other options just made up :)

Question:
A patient presents are an infertility clinic you are observing. The consultant carries out a physical exam and finds testicular atrophy, eunnchoid body shape , long extremities , gynecomastia  and female hair distribution. 

 

What are these findings classical of?
Explanation: A is correct, these findings are classical of Klinefleter syndrome. It often presents as infertility problems.

Question: 39 year old Hilary has come in with her 3 month old baby Hugo for him to have his vaccinations of DTap/IPV/Hib, Men C and second rotavirus dose. Whilst at the doctors, she ceases the opportunity to discuss something thats irritating her. Hilary describes "these lumps that come out of my back passage when I go to the loo, and I kind of have to push them back in". You think she is describing something other than her faeces and try to classify which type of Haemorrhoids Hilary has.
Explanation:
First degree are internal and do not prolapse

second prolapse on straining but reduce spontaneously

third prolapse but can be reduced manually

fourth are permanently prolapsed and cannot be reduced

 

RF for haemorrhoids is increased abdominal pressure i.e. baby Hugo

 

I don't know if there are 5th degree

Question: Brenda is in labour and is in a lot of pain. She has been given an IM injection of pethidine, however, she begins to exhibit symptoms of respiratory depression, CNS depression, and hypotension. You realize that she has been given an overdose, and give her Naloxone to counter the effects of the opioid. Brenda recovers. Which of the following opioid receptors has the Naloxone acted upon?
Explanation: Naloxone is a competitive antagonist at the mu opioid receptor.

Question: A 45 year old Caucasian man was prescribed ramipril for hypertension a few months ago, after lifestyle changes failed to bring down his blood pressure. Unfortunately, even with the ramipril, his blood pressure is still too high. What is the most appropriate next step in his treatment?
OptionA: Replace the ramipril with an angiotensin receptor blocker
OptionB: Continue with the ramipril for another month
OptionC: Change his treatment to a dual therapy by adding an angiotensin receptor blocker
OptionD: Change his treatment to a dual therapy by adding a calcium channel blocker
OptionE: Change his treatment to a triple therapy by adding a calcium channel blocker and a thiazide diuretic
Explanation:
The answer is D - You should change his treatment to a dual therapy by adding a calcium channel blocker.

A - You wouldn't replace the ramipril with an ARB because he has not had any adverse reactions to it.

B - You wouldn't leave him for a month as having high blood pressure is increasing his risk of CHD.

C - ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptor blockers should never be given together.

E - This is the 3rd line treatment that you would move him onto should the dual therapy with an ACE inhibitor and a calcium channel blocker not work.

 

Source - NICE guidelines for treatment of hypertension

http://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg127/chapter/1-recommendations#initiating-and-monitoring-antihypertensive-drug-treatment-including-blood-pressure-targets-2

Question: Brenda has come to see you. She is now 41 weeks pregnant and has not gone into labour. What is the best treatment option in this situation?
Explanation:
• At 41 weeks a cervical sweep is given in order to try and stimulate the release of prostaglandins around the cervix and to induce contractions/labour. 
  • At 41 weeks, if 3 cervical sweeps haven't worked a prostaglandin E2 tablet or gel would be inserted into the vagina.
  • At 42 weeks, syntocinon will be given.
  • Cesarean section only occurs in an emergency.

Question: At what day does initial implantation of the Blastocyst into the endometrium occur?
Explanation:
Day 6 is correct. It "sticks" at day 6 

By association this is also when hCG secretion begins

Question:
Your patient is experiencing horrible diarrhoea after coming back from holiday in India having not taken all the necessary vaccinations. There is no blood or pus visible in the stool sample.

What type of diarrhoea is most likely being experienced?
Explanation:
This patient is most likely suffering from the results of a cholera infection. cholera causes Cl- to be drawn in to the lumen and therefore followed by water. this is Secretory diarrhoea as the body is basically releasing the water into the lumen

If exudative there would likely be the presence of blood or pus e.g. IBD

if dysentry, there would be blood visible in the sample as a trace of an invasion into the bowel tissue

Inflammatory is more caused by autoimmune problems like IBD, but also infections and colon cancer. There is a defective ability to absorb fluids and electrolytes . the Mucosal lining or brush border is damaged.

Osmotic is caused by too much water being drawn into the lumen because the patient has ingested a non-absorbable susbstance like cellulose or gluten if coeliac. 

 

I find it difficult to distinguish between secretory and osmotic but basically osmotic is malabsorption and what ever it is thats can't be absorbed draws the water in. Whereas in secretory e.g. cholera, the bug is causing the Cl- to leave the cells and enter the lumen.

Question: In the gastroenterology clinic and a patient has come in with FAP, on which chromosome is there a mutation causing them this problem?
Explanation: they have an autosomal dominant condition arising from germline mutations of the APC gene on chromosome 5

Question: Brenda hasn't been feeling too great recently, and you order a blood test. Her blood test comes back showing low haemoglobin levels and a high mean corpuscle volume. What does this indicate to you?
Explanation: Thrombocytopenia is low platelets, and thrombocytosis is high platelets. Low haemoglobin indicates anaemia, and if there is also a normal MCV this is normocytic, if there is a high MCV this is macrocytic, and if there is a low MCV this is microcytic.

Question: A mother comes to see you concerned her baby hasn't started crawling yet. When should crawling normally be seen?
Explanation:
Rolls and sits :  6 months (sits at six)

Crawling: 8 months

Standing: 10 months

Walking: 12 - 18 months

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the thigh is correct?
OptionB: The adductor hiatus lies within adductor magnus
OptionC: All adductor muscles are innervated by the femoral nerve
OptionE: The femoral canal transmits the femoral artery medially
Explanation:
A is incorrect as semitendinosus lies lateral relative to semimembranosus

B is correct, the adductor hiatus which transmits the femoral artery and vein, is a small opening which is found within the adductor magnus

C is incorrect, all adductor muscles are innervated by the obturator nerve

D is incorrect as the small saphenous vein drains into the popliteal vein at the knee and is not involved in the thigh region

E is incorrect as the femoral canal, the most medial compartment of the femoral sheath contains deep lymph nodes. If the answer was regarding the femoral sheath then it would be correct.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the leg is correct?
OptionA: Fibularis tertius is part of the anterior compartment
OptionB: The tibial nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot
OptionC: Distal to the popliteal fossa the sciatic nerve splits into the tibial and common fibular nerves
OptionE: The anterior compartment is mainly supplied by the fibular artery
Explanation:
A is correct fibularis tertius is a part of the anterior compartment. Confusingly fibularis longus and brevis are part of the lateral compartment,

B is incorrect as the tibial nerve runs posteriorly and divides into the medial and lateral plantar nerves which innervate the plantar aspect of the foot. It is the superficial fibular nerve which supplies the dorsum (other than the space between big and 2nd toe which is deep fibular nerve)

C is incorrect as the sciatic nerve splits at the superior aspect of the popliteal fossa forming the tibial nerve which runs centrally through the fossa and the common fibular which runs laterally following the tendon of biceps femoris.

D is incorrect as tibialis anterior inverts.

E is incorrect, the anterior compartment is supplied by the anterior tibial artery. The fibular artery supplies part of the lateral compartment.

Question: Which of these statement about Schizophrenia is true?
OptionB: Average onset is earlier in women than men
OptionD: Schizophrenia only affects life expectancy if the patient commits suicide
OptionE: Schizophrenia is the most common form of psychosis
Explanation:
Prevalence is roughly 1% of global population, while we are unlikely to be required to list statistics for the epidemiology of disorders, is you use some common sense, 5%, or 1 in 20, of the population having Schizophrenia would be very high and we should really be able to recognise it is not that common.

Average age of onset is actually younger in men, 15-25, while in women the average age of onset is 25-35 

Schizophrenia is more common in men (unlike depression), with a male to female ration of 1.4:1

Schizophrenia reduces life expectancy in general by 15-20 years, but this is not only due to suicide. Cormorbid somatic conditions and suicide are the main causes of death with younger males being at higher risk of suicide. Metabolic syndrome, CV disease and depression are also common and can be fatal if not monitored so it would be wrong to say the only reason for reduced life expectancy is suicide.

Question: A 44 year old man is brought into A and E after falling off his mountain bike and hitting his head. He has his eyes closed but opens them when you talk to him. He is unsure of where he is and what the date is, and seems keen to talk about how blue the curtains are. He won't move his limbs when you ask him to, but reacts to supraorbital pressure by moving his hand up to his face The consultant asks you what his GCS score is. What is it?
Explanation:
Eye opening- - 4 spontaneous, 3 to speech, 2 to pain, 1 no response

Verbal response - 5 orientated, 4 disorientated, 3 inappropriate, 3 unintelligible sounds 1 none.

Motor response - 6 obeys commands, 5 localises to pain, 4 withdraws from pain, 3 abnormal flexion, 2 abnormal extension, 1 no response .

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the foot is correct?
OptionA: The tarsal tunnel contains the tendon of tibialis anterior
OptionC: The calcaneus and tibia form the ankle joint
OptionD: Dorsalis pedis pulse is palpated just posteriorly to the medial malleolus
OptionE: The tibial nerve provides sensation to plantar aspect of the foot
Explanation:
A is incorrect, the tarsal tunnel contains from anterior to posterior:

- Tibialis posterior tendon
- Flexor digitorum longus tendon
- Posterior tibial artery
- Posterior tibial vein
- Tibial nerve
- Flexor hallucis longus tendon

Can be remembered by Tom, Dick And Very Nervous Harry

 

B is incorrect as the big toe has only 2 phalanges just as the thumb does

C is incorrect as it the talus and tibia which form the ankle joint. The calcaneus forms the heel bone which bears the weight of the ankle bone

D is incorrect as this is the site of the posterior tibial artery. The dorsalis pedis pulse is palpated just lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon.

E is correct the tibial nerve provides the majority of sensation to the plantar aspect of the foot.

Question: Which of the following best describes ribs 8,9 and 10.
Explanation:
1-7 are true

8-10 false as they are attached to the sternum indirectly

1,2,10,11,12- atypical

3-9 are typical

11 and 12 are floating

Question: Which of these is NOT a hyperglycaemic hormone (a hormone which opposes the action of insulin)?
Explanation:
In addition to glucagon. All of these work to increase blood glucose levels: 

 

Glucocorticoids aka adrenal cortical steroids, act as gene activators and stimulate gluconeogenesis to maintain glycogen stores and inhibit glucose uptake. 

GH - it depressed glucose uptake (particularly in muscle), stimulates glycogenolysis and increased the breakdown of adipose tissue. 

Thyroid hormones  have many different effects. At low concentrations they could assist insulin. But at high concentrations they stimulate glycogenolysis, glyconeogenesis and absorption from the GI tract. 

Catecholeamines - stimulate glyogenolysis in the liver, and inhibit the secretion of insulin. 

 

Insulin is the only true hypoglycaemic hormone.

Question: What is a Virion?
OptionE: a cellular derived outer lipid membrane of a virus
Explanation:
A - this is the core of a virus

B - this is the capsid of a virus

C - this is a peplomer

D - correct

E - this is the envelope of a virus - not all viruses have these

 

 

info from Case 9, Introduction to Viruses plenary

Question: Princess Jasmine and Aladdin are thinking about having children. Aladdin becomes inquisitive and wonders, 'if it takes one sperm and one egg to make a baby; what happens if more than one sperm fertilises the egg'. This phenomenon is known to us as polyspermy. Which of the following processes prevents polyspermy?
Explanation:
Acrosomal reaction - results in exocytosis of hydrolytic enzymes as the outer acrosomal membrane fuses with the plasma membrane of the sperm.

Capacitation - removal of proteins from the plasma membrane of the sperm over the acrosomal region.

Cortical reaction - prevents polyspermy as penetration of the oocyte plasma causes the release of enzymes that act on glycoproteins to harden the zona pellucida.

Fertilisation - fusion of male and female gametes.

Second meiotic division - occurs after penetration and results in the formation of the second polar body and a female pronucleus.

Sourced from Boron and Boulpaep and the lecture on 'Early Human Development"

Question: How does a lack of insulin found in Type I diabetes (and in some cases, Type II diabetes) cause/lead to Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)?
OptionB: No inhibition of fatty acid transport into cells
Explanation:
DKA is caused by a lack of insulin because insulin inhibits the transportation of fatty acids into cells. Insulin also increases glucose transport into cells, meaning that the main source of the Kreb's cycle is from glycolysis, with few fatty acids (therefore little beta oxidation). 

If there is a lack of insulin there are more fatty acids in the cell and less glucose --> this leads to more beta oxidation, and therefore more ketone production. These case acidosis in the body, specifically an anion gap acidosis. 

For more information, see this video, it is well worth the watch even though it's 13 minutes: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yIc2XFNLhm8

A - There is increased beta oxidation in DKA

B - Correct 

C - There is inhibition of glucose into cells but this is not the primary cause of DKA 

D - Incorrect

E - There is an increase in the anion gap in DKA

Question: Which of these best describes a 4th degree peripheral nerve injury?
OptionA: Local conduction block leading to sensory-motor defects distal to the injury, but no axon damage. Recovery is complete and is usually days to weeks.
OptionB: Only the epineurium remains intact. Surgery is required for a recovery, but it is unlikely to be full.
OptionC: The whole nerve is served. Recovery of any form is very unlikely without surgery.
OptionD: Loss of axonal continuity and its myelin sheath, but the surrounding connective tissue framework is intact. Wallerian degeneration occurs distal to the injury before recovery. Full recovery can be made without surgery.
OptionE: Nerve fibre interruption with scarring to the endoneurium, but the peri- and epineurium remain intact. Wallerian deregulation will occur. Some recovery is possible, but it is more likely that surgery will be needed.
Explanation:
A = 1st degree

B = 4th degree

C = 5th degree

D = 2nd degree

E = 3rd degree

Question: Miles is a patient with Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus. He is 47 years old and was diagnosed when he was 9 years old. He recently came into A&E with an episode of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). Which of the following is not a possible cause of his DKA episode?
Explanation:
A) & E) - Infections can precipitate DKA

B) - Hyperkalaemia is a consequence of DKA, not a precipitant

C) - MI's can precipitate DKA

D) - Poor compliance with insulin is a common cause of DKA

Question: Which of the following is not a component of Metabolic Syndrome?
OptionE: They all are components of Metabolic Syndrome
Explanation:
Also could include type 2 diabetes. 

 

Sources: NHS and this journal article: Microvascular and Macrovascular Complications of Diabetes http://clinical.diabetesjournals.org/content/26/2/77.full

It explains all of the complications of diabetes really well.

Question: Miranda, a 21 year old woman who is pregnant is worried about contracting Rubella as she never had the MMR vaccine. She heard that Rubella can harm the baby. She asks you when is the baby most at risk harm from the virus? You reply..
Explanation:
A - minimal risk 

B - Correct! - there is a 100% risk of the foetus being congenitally infected - resulting in major abnormalities 

spontaneous abortion occurs in 20% of cases

C - 15% risk of deafness and retinopathy

D - normal development, slight risk of deafness and retinopathy

 

 

 

info from case 7, congenital malformations and teratology plenary

Question: Which of the following is a macrovascular complication of diabetes?
Explanation:
Retinopathy, Neuropathy and Nephropathy are all microvascular complications. 

 

Type 2 diabetes can be a component of metabolic syndrome but metabolic syndrome is a collection of pathophysiologies, not a complication of one disease.

Question: Which of the following tissues is insulin dependent?
Explanation:
Source: Pocock and Richards. 

 

Insulin Independent tissues rely on the glucose concentration gradient between extracellular and intracellular environments. 

 

Therefore they are particularly vulnerable to hyperglycaemia. 

 

These are the tissues which sustain damage in diabetes: blood vessels which stimulates atherosclerosis due to damage and inflammation of the endothelial cells, retinopathy, neuropathy and nephropathy.

Question: Where would you find Brunner's Glands?
Explanation:
They are found in the part of the duodenum that is higher than the spinchter of Oddi (hepatopancreatic sphincter)

They produce an alkaline secretion which is mucous and bicarbonate rich. 

This means that they

1)help to protect the duodenum from the acidic contents leaving the stomach,

2)help create an environment best suited to activate intestinal enzymes 

3) lubricate

Question: where would you find Peyers patches?
Explanation:
The gut meets a lot of bugs and the Peyers patches act as the look-out for the immune system

Their epithelium has Microfold cells (M) that take the antigen straight from the lumen to be given to APCs on their basolateral side. These APCs can then go straight to the mesenteric lymph nodes. (though, I imagine the last 2 sentences are beyond what we need to know.)

Question:
Jill comes to A&E with what she describes as a "racing heart". After performing an ECG the doctors tell her she has an arrhythmia. 

What is the most common type of supra-ventricular tachy-arrhythmia?
Explanation:
Source! http://www.aafp.org/afp/2010/1015/p942.html I think it was also in a lecture in Case 13 but can't find which one and I know you guys love your sources!

According to the "Mechanisms of Arrhythmias" lecture from Case 13, Automaticity Arrhythmias are the least common type of tachy-arrhythmia.

Question: when there is a high concentration of glucose in the intestinal lumen, which transporter (that isn't involved in absorption in low glucose concentrations) is used to transport the glucose into enterocytes?
Explanation:
SGLT1 is used in low glucose concentrations so we rule that out

 

When SGLT1 is saturated, its increased activity causes an intracellular signalling cascade so that GLUT2 is inserted on to the apical membrane; thus the two transporters in this situation are SGLT1 and GLUT2.

 

GLUT2 is the 'chosen' transporter as it has a higher Km.

Question:
Turbulent flow of blood in arteries can contribute to the formation of atherosclerotic plaques. These can lead to MI's and strokes. Having an MI is a risk factor for arrhythmias. 

Which of these is not a feature of turbulent blood flow?
Explanation:
A - with increased turbulent flow there is decreased vasodilation.

B - there is also increased endothelial permeability which can lead to leukocyte adhesion.

C - decreased blood viscocity in turbulent blood flow because a decreased blood viscocity leads to a decreased Reynolds Number --> the lower the Reynolds Number the more turbulent the blood flow. 

D - there is decreased endothelial repair with increased turbulent blood flow.

E - turbulence increases the energy required to drive blood flow because turbulence increases the loss of energy in the form of friction.

For more information see http://www.cvphysiology.com/Hemodynamics/H007.htm

Question: A 66 year old lady presents to you with atrial fibrillation. As a 3rd year medical student you have been asked to evaluate her CHADS-VASC score.  Her blood pressure is consistently 150/100 and she had a transient ischaemic attack 5 years ago. She has no other medical problems. What score do you give her?
Explanation:
C - Congestive heart failure -1

H- Hypertension: Blood pressure consistently above 140/90mmHg -1

A2- Age >75 (including) - 2

D- Diabetes mellitus -1

S2- Prior stroke/ TIA/ Thromboembolitic event -2

V- Vascular disease -1

A- Aged 65-74 -1

Sc- Being female -1

 

The higher the score the greater the risk of stroke. This is used to tell if anticoagulation therapy is needed (normally if score is 2 or above)
Tags: Clinical skills, Investigations, Case 13, Heart, ISCE

Question: Which of these molecules is orexigenic?
Explanation:
Ghrelin is orexigenic (stimulates hunger), insulin is an anorexigenic (reduces hunger) in response to energy and XS fat. 
Ghrelin secreted by empty stomach and signals to lateral hypothalamus (Lusts Hunger) by increasing release of orexin. Will also increase gastric secretion and motility

Remember G-relin for grumbley tummy!

CCK: secreted by mucosal epithelial cells of duodenum, stimulates digestion of fat and protein by causing digestive enzyme and bile release from pancreas and gall bladder respectively. Suppresses hunger (anorexigenic) and decreases rate of gastic emptying

Leptin: made by adipocytes, is a satiety, anorexigenic hormone. Regulates energy balance by decreasing hunger. It acts on arcuate nucleus of hypothalamus and opposed ghrelin

Obestatin: Secreted by full stomach sensed by stretch, released from specialised epithelium cells of stomach and small intestine. Opposes action of ghrelin (and GH) so suppresses hunger. This is slow acting so may eat more than you need by it is produced 

Remember: obese-stop-in so decreases hunger

PYY: secreted by ileum and colon in response of feeding and food passing through tract. Enters blood, signals to ventral medial hypothalamus (Vacate my hunger) to decrease hunger. Although this can actually increase hunger if injected into CNS
Tags: Nutrition, PCS, Case 12, Year 1 Revision, Gastrointestinal System

Question: Which molecule, involved in inflammatory response to injury, causes the transmigration of phagocytes?
Explanation:
o Rolling – selectins
 P selectin redistribution
 Cytokine causes endothelial adhesion molecule expression
 Increased avidity of integrins

 

o Firm adhesion - Integrins B1/B2

 

o Transmigration - CAM (cellular adhesion molecules) eg PCAM-1
Tags: Cell Signalling, Immunology, Case 1, Year 1 Revision, year 1

Question: Paul presents with a loss of sensation just above his top lip. Which branch of the trigeminal nerve (CNV) is he likely to have damaged?
Explanation:
Here is the dermatome distribution of the trigeminal nerve:

V1 = Ophthalmic

V2 = Maxillary

V3 = Mandibular

The optic nerve is obvs a separate cranial nerve and the philtrum is the depression under the nasal septum but not a branch of the trigeminal nerve. 

This is the best video I've found on remembering the cranial nerves: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kqNFmBGHs2I

Question: In the serum of individuals are naturally occurring antibodies to the antigens which are absent on that individual's red blood cells.  They destroy any incompatible red blood cells, but what isotope are they?
Explanation:
Source - Blood Transfusion lecture Case 8.

Also makes sense as IgM are the first isotope on the scene of infection.

Destruction of red blood cells in inappropriate transfusions can lead to acute haemolytic transfusion reaction, which may be life threatening.
Tags: Blood Cells, Blood Groups, Haematology, Case 8

Question:
Although she avoided being captured and phagocytosed, Velma the Virus accidentally triggers an alarm! Nearby cells start releasing interferons! Velma must escape before they trigger an antiviral state!

 

Which of these is not an effect of interferon release?
OptionA: Resistance to viral replication in nearby cells
OptionB: Increased expression of ligands for NK cell receptors
OptionD: Activation of movement of sentinel cells to the lymph nodes
Explanation:
The first three options are all effects of the release of interferons. 

 

Movement of sentinel cells to the lymph nodes is triggered when the cells' TLRs and LLRs are activated by an invading organism.

Question:
As she dodges around immune cells, Velma the Virus curses loudly, and wishes that she were an ebola virus.

 

Why does she wish this?
OptionA: The ebola virus prevents creation of cytokines by deactivating TLR4.
OptionB: The ebola virus prevents activation of NK cells by deactivating interleukin-12.
OptionC: The ebola virus prevents production of interferons by deactivating intracellular RLRs.
OptionD: The ebola virus prevents activation of B cells by deactivating MHC receptors.
OptionE: The ebola virus hangs out mainly in bats, which have sucky immune systems.
Explanation:
The ebola virus can deactivate intracellular rig-like receptors. These receptors recognise bacterial RNA and trigger interferon release:

- RLRs bind to viral DNA, forming a dimer

- This binds to MAVS

- This activates IRF3

- This triggers the creation of interferons

- This activates an antiviral state

Question: Which of these is best suited for defining the role of the Hippocampus?
OptionA: Required for the formation of long-term memories  and maintenance of cognitive maps
OptionB: Involved in signalling the cortex of motivational significant stimuli such a fear and reward
OptionC: Carries signals to the maxillary body and septal nuclei
OptionE: Provides critical interconnections between the limbic system
Explanation:
These are all structures within the limbic system.

 

Hippocampus Required for the formation of long-term memories and maintenance of cognitive maps for navigation 

 

Amygdala Involved in signalling the cortex of motivational significant stimuli such as those related to fear and reward in addition to social functions such as mating

 

Fornix Carries signals to the maxillary body and septal nuclei

 

Mammillary body Important for the formation of memory

 

Septal nuclei Provides critical interconnections between the limbic system

Question:
Escaping round a corner in the artery, Velma the Virus has the opportunity to sit down on a nearby erythrocyte and reflect about her life in general.

 

"Who am I?" wonders Velma. "What is my purpose?"

 

Suddenly, Velma's existential crisis is interrupted by the arrival of a hungry-looking macrophage.

 

 

Which of these is not a correct description of a property shared by all viruses?
OptionA: Viruses are inert structures which cannot undergo metabolic activity outside cells.
Explanation:
Viruses all contain nucleic acids and proteins.

 

The nucleic acids can be RNA or DNA.

 

RNA found in viruses can be positively, negatively or double stranded. It can also be either segmented or non-segmented.

Question:
Barnaby the Bacterium is gram positive. He is spread by aerosol, and causes a disease so horrible that the British public is vaccinated against him in the first few months of life, at preschool level and at secondary school level.

 

Given these clues, what species is Barnaby the Bacterium?
Explanation:
Pneumococcus is gram positive, and transmitted by aerosol. Vaccines are given at 2 and 3 months, 1 year and over 65 years.

 

Pertussis is gram negative, and transmitted by aerosol. Vaccines are given antenatally and at 2, 3 and 4 months and at preschool entry.

 

Meningococcus is gram negative, and transmitted by aerosol. Vaccines are given at 3 months, 1 year, secondary school and university entry.

 

Tetanus is gram negative, and transmitted through open wounds. Vaccines are given at 2, 3 and 4 months, preschool entry, secondary school and upon suspected infection.

 

Diphtheria is gram positive, and transmitted through aerosol. Vaccines are given at 2, 3 and 4 months.

 

 

Gram staining is irritating to learn, but of all the bacteria I've come across this year, only 5 are positive. These are:

  • Diphtheria
  • Pneumococcus
  • Tetanus
  • Staph aureus
  • C. diff

All the rest are negative, with the exception of TB, which Wikipedia describes as "impervious to gram staining".
Tags: Immunology, Infectious Disease, Childhood immunisations, Vaccination, Vaccinations

Question: Which of the following statements about JVP (jugular venous pressure) is correct?
OptionA: JVP has one positive pulsation per heartbeat
OptionB: The a wave of the JVP corresponds with right atrial diastole
OptionC: The y descent is due to blood flow into the right ventricle
OptionD: The external jugular vein is used to observe JVP
Explanation:
The answer is C - The y descent is due to blood flowing from the right atrium into the right ventricle.

A - the JVP has two positive pulsations per heartbeat, the a and v waves.

B - The a wave corresponds with right atrial systole, not diastole.

D - The internal jugular vein is the one that is used to observe JVP.

E - JVP decreases with inspiration, not expiration.

Question: Heart failure can be caused by either systolic or diastolic dysfunction. Which of the following statements about systolic dysfunction is incorrect?
OptionA: It is characterized by a decrease in myocardial contractility
OptionB: It is defined as having a left ventricular ejection fraction of less than 40%
OptionC: It is a common characteristic of dilated cardiomyopathy
OptionD: It is defined as having a left ventricular ejection fraction of more than 40%
OptionE: It can be seen in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Explanation:
The answer is D - Systolic dysfunction is characterised by a LVEF of less than 40% (option B).

A, B and C are correct.

E is correct as although hypertrophic cardiomyopathy normally causes diastolic dysfunction, it can cause systolic dysfunction is some patients.

Question:
You are asked to perform an vaccination injection at an OSCE station. While you prepare your equipment, you check the use-by date of the vaccine and notice a black inverted triangle.  

What does this mean?
OptionA: It is a newly released vaccine and is under monitoring by the CDC
OptionC: It is only available in the UK
OptionD: It has recently been safety alerted by the CDC
OptionE: It is only required by certain 'at risk' groups of people
Explanation:
The correct answer is A

This is the Black Card Scheme, whereby new medications and vaccines are labeled with an inverted black triangle. They are thus under additional monitoring and all ADR's for these products should be reported.

https://www.gov.uk/the-yellow-card-scheme-guidance-for-healthcare-professionals

Question:
A recently diagnosed Type II diabetic has her first diabetic retinopathy screening.

The following image of her retina is obtained: 

The image shows some dot and blot haemorrhages. What grade retinopathy does she have and what action is now needed?
OptionA: Pre- proliferative retinopathy and Annual screening only
OptionB: Back ground retinopathy and Annual screening only
OptionC: Pre- proliferative retinopathy and non- urgent referral to ophthalmologist
OptionD: Proliferative retinopathy and urgent referral to opthalmologist
OptionE: Back ground retinopathy and referral to ophthalmologist
Explanation:
She is (or should be) shown to have background retinopathy which is characterised by dot and blot haemorrhages, hard exudates, cotton wool spots/cytoid bodies. There is no immediate action taken here and annual retinopathy screening will continue

In pre- proliferative retinopathy: there would be the above, with venous beading and venous loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities, round deep haemorrhages and wold require non- urgent referral to opthalmologist. 

In proliferative retinopathy: there would be neovascularisation, pre retinal haemorrhage, vitreous haemorrhage (in advanced retinopathy tractional retinal detachment would be seen and retinal fibrosis). These findings would require urgent referral to an ophthalmologist, however significant sight would have already been lost in advanced retinopathy.

I know these aren't quite as detailed as what the Screening service actually use, with regard to disc diameter and things, but it's what Kumar and Clarke had, so i went from that, plus it's abit easier to remember.

Question:
Mary is in labour with her first child, baby Jesus. She is in a lot of pain and screams at her husband to get her something to help with it. She and Joseph do not have access to any Entonox or Pethidine (two of the most commonly analgesics used in labour in the UK). Joseph did however, manage to bring a basic first aid kit with him on their trip to Bethlehem, which contains some household medicines such as Paracetamol and Ibuprofen. 

He tries to give Mary two Ibuprofen tablets but she remembers reading in "What to expect when you're expecting the Christ child" that NSAIDs are contraindicated after 30/40.

Why should NSAIDs not be used during labour?
OptionB: They can cause the foramen ovale to shut too early
OptionC: They can cause the ductus arteriosus to shut too early
OptionD: They can cause a potentially fatal drop in blood pressure in the mother
OptionE: They cause a dangerous increase in temperature in the baby
Explanation:
A - Aspirin can cause Reye's disease at any stage of pregnancy, until a child is 16 years old. It is not the main reason NSAIDs are contraindicated in labour though.

B - To my knowledge, there are no known effects of NSAIDs on the foramen ovale.

C - Correct. NSAIDs inhibit the production of prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are responsible for maintaining the ductus arteriosus by dilation of the vascular smooth muscles.

D - NSAIDs can cause hypertension if the patient has renal problems but are not linked to hypotension.

E - False.

Source: Question & Answer - Anaesthesia and Analgesia in Childbirth lecture, Case 8. Explanation - Wikipedia.

Question: A 9 year old has been infected with Morbillivirus, which of the following are they likely to be suffering from?
Explanation:
Morbillivirus is a genus of viruses which contains the measles virus. Morbillivirus is part of the paramyxovirus family which are group V viruses.
A is incorrect as although mumps is a paramyxovirus it is of the genus Rubulavirus

B is incorrect as rubella is caused Rubellavirus which is a Togavirus (a group IV)

C is incorrect as whilst the common cold can be caused by a variety of viruses most commonly the rhinovirus, morbilivirus is not one of them.

D is incorrect as varicella zoster is herpesvirus type 3 (a group I)

Question: Azeem has had a cough for 10 days, and is worried that he might not be able to play at his senior flute recital in a week. His doctor takes a sample of his sputum and tells him that he has an infection caused by a single stranded, negative sense RNA virus. Using this information, which virus could Azeem NOT have?
Explanation:
The answer is C - Rubella is caused by a Togavirus which is a ssRNA(+) virus, group 4 of the Baltimore classification.

All the other viruses are ssRNA(-) viruses, group 5 of the Baltimore classification.

Question:
Tally-ho! Major-General Crispin Butterworth-Toast, the Veteran of a Thousand Viruses, has been brought into A&E by his hunting pals. They were riding to hounds when Crispin took a tumble off his horse and cut his head on a most inconvenient rock. He apparently passed out for a while but has since regained consciousness, and has suddenly started complaining of: "Worst ruddy headache I've ever had, if you'll pardon m'French." The cut to his head has been cleaned and examined, and is long but shallow. He appears exquisitely sensitive to light and complains of neck pains.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Subarachnoid haemorrhage is the most likely diagnosis, based on the mechanism of injury coupled with the characteristic sudden-onset and very severe headache - 'thunderclap headache', which is often described as the worst ever . Subarachnoid haemorrhage also commonly presents with photophobia. The condition may also present with altered consciousness states and neck pain, although these are less specific to the condition.

 

A is incorrect because although the Major-General is exhibiting some symptoms of meningitis, the apparent mechanism of injury (fall off a horse) coupled with the characteristic signs described above, make it a less likely option.

 

B is less likely due to the presence of characteristic signs of the subarachnoid haemorrhage.

 

D is, again, less likely due to the presence of characteristic signs.

 

E is incorrect - Terson's syndrome is a collection of symptoms that may develop in severe subarachnoid haemorrhage. These symptoms are subhyaloid haemorrhage and vitreous haemorrhage, which would be visible on fundoscopy. As no mention of fundoscopy was given in the question, this option is a less favoured choice.

Question: A patient is in severe shock after being involved in a severe RTC and has a traumatic below knee amputation. The Welsh Air Ambulance arrives on scene and because they are now able to carry blood with them, he is given a transfusion. Which blood type is he likely to be given?
OptionE: He can't be given blood unless his blood type is known.
Explanation: In emergency situations where blood transfusions are necessary urgently and blood can not be lab tested for type then O negative blood is given. O negative group is known as the "universal blood donor" as it does not have Anti-A or Anti-B present nor does it have any rhesus D antigens therefore no reactions will occur when given to people no matter what their blood type.

Question:
You are on placement in A&E, and a patient comes in with a severe laceration on the base of their thumb.  Before treating it, the doctor is going to give the patient some local anaesthetics to reduce pain.  The doctor asks you what would be the most suitable local anaesthetic to give, given that you want the anaesthetic to be as potent as possible and last as long as possible.

 

Which local anaesthetic would you say?
Explanation:
The local anaesthetics potency wise rank as follows:

1) High lignocaine plus adrenaline

2) Low lignocaine plus adrenaline

3) High bupivacaine

4) Low bupivacaine

5) High lignocaine

 

Duration of effect wise, they rank as follows:

1) High lignocaine plus adrenaline
2) Low lignocaine plus adrenaline
3) High bupivacaine
4) High lignocaine
5) Low bupivacaine

(4 and 5's order is questionable - could be switched around)

 

As the affected region is the thumb you would not give a local anaesthetic plus adrenaline as the thumb doesn't have collateral perfusion from multiple arteries (i.e. only supplied by one artery).  Adrenaline helps prolong the duration and potency of a local anaesthetic by causing vasoconstriction of the local arteries so the local anaesthetic has more time to work.  If used in this example it will reduce the blood supply to the thumb, reduce healing time and may cause ischaemia --> severe problems (worst case scenario is loss of the thumb).

 

This rules out lignocaine (high or low) plus adrenaline, therefore high bupivacaine is the answer.

 

Bupivavcaine has a much longer duration and is 4 times more potent than lignocaine (on its own) dose for dose.

 

Source: Local Anaesthetics Practical - Case 8.

Question:
A man presents at A&E with paralysis of both legs. He is panicking because he does not know what has caused this- he has no history of trauma or previous medical problems. 

Upon neurological examination, the patient cannot feel pain or temperature change on his legs. However, he can recognise when you move his leg up and down, and is able to feel the vibration when you place a tuning fork on his medial malleolus. He also has intact 2 point discrimination.

You discern that he has a spinal cord syndrome. Which one do you think he has?
Explanation:
His symptoms point towards anterior cord syndrome. 

 

Anterior cord syndrome is caused by ischaemic injury to the anterior aspect of the spinal cord, due to occlusion of the anterior spinal artery. This is normally not a traumatic process, and may be as a result of atherosclerosis, aortic pathology or external compression. 

 

Patient present with following features:

  • complete motor paralysis below the level of the lesion due to involvement of corticospinal tract.
  • loss of pain and temperature at and below the level of injury due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract
  • intact 2-point discrimination, proprioception and vibratory senses due to intact posterior column.
  • autonomic dysfunction: orthostatic hypotension
  • bladder and bowel dysfunction and sexual dysfunction may arise depending on the level of the lesion

This is because the anterior 2/3rd of the spinal cord contains corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. 

 

Prognosis of anterior cord syndrome is worst among all other spinal cord injury syndromes. It is associated with high mortality and poor functional outcome in terms of poor recovery of motor power and co-ordination.

 

P.S. I made lateral cord syndrome up!

 

http://radiopaedia.org/articles/anterior-cord-syndrome and lectures are the source!

Question:
A 30-year-old male patient weighing 85kg is to receive an injection of Lidocaine hydrochloride 0.5% as a local anaesthetic for a minor operation.  They are given 15ml as a starting bolus.  

 

Given that the maximum dose is 2.5mg/kg, how much more Lidocaine hydrochloride may be administered if it was deemed necessary?
OptionA: 0 ml - the patient has already received the maximum dose
Explanation:
For this question it is easiest to first convert the concentration from percentage w/w to concentration proper in mg/ml.  The percentage is the percentage mass of the drug by mass of diluent - i.e. for 0.5% in 1g of diluent there will be 1x0.005g = 0.005g of lidocaine.  The diluent will be water, and 1ml of water weighs 1g, so we can say that there is 0.005g lidocaine per ml of water.  0.005g=5mg, so the concentration is 5mg/ml.

 

The patient weighs 85kg and max dose is 2.5mg/kg so 85x2.5 = 212.5mg is the maximum amount of lidocaine to give.  212.5mg / 5mg/ml = 42.5ml lidocaine is maximum volume. 

 

The patient has already received 15ml, so 42.5-15 = 27.5ml still available.

 

With any concentrations expressed as percentages it will work to multiply the percentage by 10 to get it as a concentration in mg/ml.

Question: The Maxillary Branch of the Trigeminal nerve passes through which foramen in the base of the skull?
Explanation:
Cribiform Plate=CN I

Optic Canal=CN II

Superior Orbital Fossa= CN's III, IV, V1, VI

Foramen Rotundum= CN V2

Foramen Ovale=CN V3

Internal Acoustic Meatus=CN's VII, VIII

Jugular Foramen= CN's IX, X, XI

Hypoglossal Canal= CN XII

Question: Jaime Lannister is taking part in a tournament , gets knocked off his horse by Gregor Clegane and develops retrograde amnesia. What is meant by retrograde amnesia?
OptionA: Inability to remember things that occur before a CNS insult
OptionB: Inability to remember things that occurred after a CNS insult  (i.e. decreased acquisition of new memory)
Explanation:
A is correct.

B is Anterograde amnesia (After = Anterograde) 

C is Dissociative amnesia

D is Korsakoff syndrome. This is caused by B1 deficiency and is commonly seen in alcoholics. It presents with both types of amnesia (anterograde > than retrograde though)

Question: Thrombin is an important molecule in the wound healing process and is formed from prothrombin by a prothrombinase complex. This complex is formed of two clotting factors. One of these is factor Xa, what is the other factor involved?
Explanation:
It is factor Va which combines with Xa (along with Ca2+and phospholipid membrane) to form a prothrombinase complex that converts prothrombin to thrombin. This greatly increases the generation of thrombin (also known as factor II) which causes formation of fibrin (also known as factor I) clots.
