Question: Which fibres carry pain associated with the first stage of labour?
Explanation:
In the first stage

  • crampy visceral poorly localised pain
  • associated with uterine contractions and cervical dilation
  • T10-L1
  • slow unmelinated c fibres

In the second stage

  • well localised sharp pain
  • associated with uterine contraction and distension of vagina pelvic and perineal structures
  • T10-L1 and S2-S4
  • fast myelinated a delta fibres

Question: Which class of antibody would you expect to find in colostrum?
Explanation: Breast milk contains IgA (the antibody class found in secretions like saliva, mucus and tears.

Question: The foetal portion of the placenta is called...
Explanation: The foetal part if called the chorion fondosum (bushy chorion) while the maternal part is called the decidua basalis, haemangioblasts are the hypothetical common progenitor cell for haematopoietic and vascular endothelial cells and the bulbus cordis is part of the primitive heart (partly gives rise the ventricles)

Question: You are on placement, when the doctor in the ED spontaneously produces the scan above.He questions you what structures are indicated by 4, 5 and 6. What will be your answer?
OptionA:
4 is the thalamus

5 is the internal capsule

6 is the red nucleus
OptionB:
4 is the caudate nucleus

5 is the putamen

6 is the internal capsule
OptionC:
4 is the caudate nucleus

5 is the internal capsule

6 is the putamen
OptionD:
4 is the choroid plexus of the lateral ventricle

5 is the internal capsule

6 is the putamen
OptionE:
4 is the fornix

5 is the putamen

6 is the internal capsule
Explanation: C is correct, 4 would be the caudate nucleus, 5 is the anterior arm of the internal capsule and 6 is the putamen.
Tags: Anatomy, Investigations, Emergency Medicine, Case 12, Case 16

Question: Which type of memory is most prominently affected in patients with Alzheimer's disease?
Explanation: Most commonly AD affects episodic memory which is essentially remembering moments or the act of doing things i.e. forgetting that they turned the over on. Episodic (or autobiographical) memory is a form of declarative long term memory, of which semantic is another type. Therefore whilst long term is technically correct, episodic is the SBA here. Semantic memory is less commonly affected in AD especially in early stages but is a form of declarative memory like episodic. Procedural is an example of non-declarative memory, this tends to be well preserved in AD patients. Short term memory is not usually affected as it is only memory for the previous 20/30 seconds.

Question: How does Flecanide work?
OptionB: hyperpolarization by triggering K+ efflux and inhibits Ca2+ entry into the SA node
Explanation:
A. B blockers (vw class II) e.g. bisoprolol (limits sympathetic activity, cardioselectve of B1 adrenorecpetors, decrease slope of phase 4 potential)

B. adenosine (vw class V)

C. Ca2+ channel blockers (vw class IV) e.g. diltazem (decrease Ca2+ mediated impulses through the AV node)

D. K+ channel blockers (vw class III) e.g. amiodarone (K+ channel blockade slows repolarization prolonging the refactory period)

E. Na+ channel blockers (vw class I) e.g. flecanide (works by frequency dependent block of fast path Na+ channels)
Tags: Thorax, Case 13, Case 15, Heart, Heart failure

Question: Which of the following can be used to reverse the actions of heparin?
Explanation:
Heparin activates antithrombin III which inactivates thrombin and factor Xa so antithrombin II certainly wouldn't reverse the effect of heparin

I don't believe B12 has any involvement

Dabigatran is a NOAC which works as a direct thrombin inhibitor

Protamine sulphate is correct

Vit K is used to reverse the effects of Warfarin
Tags: Blood clotting, Case 13, Case 15, Pharmacology, Physiology

Question:
You diagnose a patient with type II diabetes. You advise your patient to make some lifestyle changes including a change of diet and increased exercise. 

 

The patient returns to your clinic having clearly lost some weight. Unfortunately, their blood sugar remains uncontrolled and they still have hyperglycaemia. 

 

What would be your next line of treatment?
Explanation:
The only example of a biguanide used in the UK is metformin, which is the first line drug treatment for Type II diabetes. 

 

Sulfonylureas e.g. glicazide are second. 

 

d

Question: What is the main component of VLDL?
Explanation:
1. chylomicron
  2. VLDL
  3. LDL
  4. IDL
  5. HDL
  6. lipoprtein a

From 1-6 cholesterol increases, TAG decreases and protein increases.

Question: 51 year old Joe had recently been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease following his sister noticing his memory was deteriorating. Joe has Down syndrome a chromosomal abnormality strongly linked to early onset dementia. Atrophy will be most evidently seen in which lobes?
Explanation:
• Considerable brain atrophy is most evident in the superior and and middle temporal gyri. 
  • The causes of alzheimers are not fully understood although the prevalence of the disease in patients with Down syndrome suggest the B amyloid precursor gene found on chromosome 21 is one of the most important candidate genes
  • Imaging largely undertaken to exclude more treatbel forms of dementia shows brain atrophy, flattened gyri, widening of the sulci and dilation of the ventricals

Question:
Gary has been involved in a major RTC and is suffering internal bleeding. Initially what effect will this have on:

  1. BP
  2. heart rate
  3. renin secretion
Explanation: Haemorrhage will result in a decreased circulating volume which will result in a decreased blood pressure, this will result through mechanisms such as the arterial baroreceptors which will decrease firing and therefore decrease parasympathetic drive and increase sympathetic drive to increase heart rate and contractility as well as trigger the secretion of renin.
Tags: Blood clotting, First aid, Haematology, Physiology, Heart

Question: Which of the following statements are true of parathyroid hormone?
OptionC: Secreted in response to low blood calcium
OptionE: Secreted in response to high levels of vitamin D
Explanation:
Parathyroid hormone is secreted in response to low blood calcium, it acts on the kidneys to increase calcium reabsorbtion and on the bones to stimulate calcium release and activate vitamin D, it has a negligible effect on the intestines and effectively acts to increase blood calcium levels

Vitamin D is secreted in response to PTH and acts to incrase calcium reabsorbtion in the kidney, trap calcium  in the bones and increase calcium absobtion in the intestines

Calcitonin is secreted in response to high blood calcium and results in calcium excretion from the kidneys, calcium trapping in bone and has a negligible effect on intestinal absorption it essentially acts to lower blood calcium

Question: Which of the following antibiotics is not correctly matched with it's mechanism of action?
Explanation:
The answer is A - Azithromycin is a type of macrolide that inhibits the 50s sub-unit, not the 30s sub-unit.

Trimethoprim is a folic acid synthesis inhibitor, along with the sulfonamide class of antibiotics.

Vancomycin and penicillin both inhibit cell wall synthesis.

Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that inhibits the 50s sub-unit, like azithromycin.

Question: A mother brings her child of 13 months to have the MMR vaccine. A week later she brings her child back and asks for the doctor to give her child the BCG vaccination as they live in an area of London where it's known for TB to be present. The GP agrees this is a good idea, what should he suggest next?
OptionB: Ask the mother to come back tomorrow
OptionC: Ask the mother to come back in a weeks time
OptionD: Ask the mother to come back in at least 3 weeks
Explanation:
The correct answer is D. Both the MMR and BCG are live attenuated vaccines and should be either be given together or wait at least 4 weeks in between. therefore asking the mother to come back in at least 3 weeks would be a suitable length of time after the initial MMR. 

This is because the interferon's that the child will develop with the first virus may suppress the replication of the second virus and lesson the response of the second vaccine.

Question: According to the 2001 National Cholesterol Education Program ATP III, which of these traits aren't used to define Metabolic Syndrome?
Explanation:
The 5 criteria for this classification is: 

• Central Obesity – waist circumference >37inches, however this can be different between ethnic groups
• Serum Triglycerides – levels of >150mg/dL (1.7mmol/K) or drug treatment for high TAGs
• Serum cholesterol – HDL<40mg/dL (1mmol/L) or drug treatment for low HDL
• Blood pressure – elevated blood pressure of >130/85mmHg or drug-treated hypertension
• Fasting Plasma Glucose - >5.6mmol/L or drug treatment for hyperglycemia

 

3 of these 5 traits must be present for the diagnosis of Metabolic Syndrome. The risk of developing cardiovascular disease is higher in these individuals, along with the risk of developing diabetes and neurological disorders.

Question: Which of the following methods of contraception has the GREATEST failure rate?
Explanation:
1. COCP failure rate approx (hormonal)
  2. IUD failure rate approx 2% (prevents implantation)
  3. IUS e.g. Mirena failure rate approx 0.1% (hormonal)
  4. Rhythm method failure rate approx 2.5-30% (natural method approved by catholic church but dependent on high motivation and control)
  5. Vasectomy failure rate approx 0.05% per lifetime (surgical sterilization)

It is important that only barrier methods e.g. condoms can protect against STI's

Question:
A women presents to the doctor at 14 weeks pregnant. She was not planning to fall pregnant and is slightly worried that she has not been aware of her pregnancy up until now. 

 

You run some blood tests, and find that her mean cell volume (MCV) is at 115fl (normal is up to 105fl in pregnancy). This, in conjunction with some other tests, suggests that she has a certain type of anaemia. 

 

With this in mind, what are you most worried about for the newborn?
OptionE: You are not concerned about any problems
Explanation:
She has megaloblastic anaemia, caused by a deficiency of folate. This is a fairly common anaemia in pregnancy because folate requirements are raised to 300-400μg/day from 100μg/day. The diet is often inadequate to meet this demand, and so folate supplements are routinely given in pregnancy. 

 

As she has presented late, the patient has not been taking folate supplements. Folate deficiency has been linked with an increased incidence of neural tube defects in the foetus, and so it has been recommended that folate supplementation starts prior to conception and then taken particularly in the first 12 weeks of gestation. 

 

Therefore, you would be worried about neural tube defects as her clinician. 

 

 

Source - case 8 lecture on haemotology in pregnancy :)

Question: Soon after implantation (around day 6) hCG secretion begins form which group of cells?
Explanation: About 6 days after fertilization the blastocyst binds to the endometrial lining, this usually occurs in the bosy of the uterus with the embryoblast nearest the endometrium and the cavity closer to the uterus lumen. The trophoblast layer grows rapidly and differenciates to form 2 layers. The cytotrophoblast in the layer nearest the embryoblast and is composed of dividing cells that will join the syncytiotrophoblast, the syncytiotrophoblast is the layer nearest the endometrium  and developes finger like projections that invade the surrounding endometrium to hold the blastocyst in place, it also secretes hCG which acts on the corpus luteum to prevent regression and maintain rising progesterone levels. The corpus luteum continues to be the main source of progesterone until about 6 weeks when the placenta starts to take over the majority of production

Question: A 23 year old male is admitted to A and E following a bar fight where he was stabbed. When performing a neurological assessment you find ipsilateral paralysis and loss of proprioception, fine touch and vibration and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. Which spinal cord injury do you suspect?
Explanation:
Anterior cord syndrome interrupts the spinothalamic and corticospinal tracts bilaterally resulting in motor loss, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation. The dorsal columns are unaffected however resulting in preserved vibration and proprioception

Brown sequard syndrome results from hemisection of the spinal cord commonly due to traumatic injuries such as stab and bullet injuries. It affects all tracts on one side resulting in ipsilateral loss of vibration,fine touch and proprioception and motor control due to damage to the dorsal columns and corticospinal tract and loss of contralateral pain and temperature due to damage to the spinothalamic tract (crosses over at spinal level)

For complete sectioning of the cord you see total deficits bilaterally

Posterior cord syndrome affects the dorsal columns resulting in vibration, fine touch and proprioception deficits bilaterally

Tabes dorsalis is associated with third degree syphylis and affects the dorsal columns bilaterally with no perception of fine touch bilaterally and no proprioceptive feedback about movement bilaterally below the lesion resulting in a stamping gait and damage to joints
Tags: Spine, Nerves, Emergency Medicine, Neurology, Neuroscience

Question: Which commonly prescribed hypoglycaemic drug can cause lactic acidosis?
Explanation:
The main side effect of bilgluanide drugs is lactic acidosis along with a bad taste in the mouth and GI disturbances. 

Glicazide is a sulfonylurea which has ADRs including hypoglycaemia, as well as nausea (disulfram-like-effect)

Alpha Glucosidase Inhibitors cause flatulence and diarrhoea. 

Gliptins cause headache, nausea, an increased risk of pancreatic cancer and heart problems. 

Glitazones cause mild weight gain, increased risk of pancreatic cancer and hepatitis.

Question: Barry has had type 2 diabetes for the past 12 years and at his last visit to the GP it is decided that he should be started on gliclazide. How does gliclazide work?
OptionA: Inhibits intestinal enzymes involved in the digestion of starch
OptionB: Stimulates insulin release from B islet cells
OptionC: Increase peripheral glucose uptake and decrease glucose output from the liver
OptionE: Promotes insulin sensitivity and reduces insulin resistance
Explanation:
A. Acarbose inhibits intestinal enzymes preventing the digestion of starch and causing blood glucose to rise more slowly after a meal, side effects include flatulence and diarrhoea]
B. CORRECT gliclazide is a sulphonylurea which work by inhibiting membrane b bound K + channels resulting in depolarization of the B islet cell membrane and insulin release, side effects include weight gain and hypoglycaemia
C. Biguanides e.g. metformin increase peripheral glucose uptake and decrease glucose output from the liver, their MOA is not fully understood, side effects include nausea, diarrhoea and lactic acidosis
D. INCORRECT
E. Thiazolidinediones e.g. pioglitazone are drugs that promote insulin sensitivity and reduce insulin resistance and are used in combination with other drugs they may carry a risk of heart failure and liver toxicity

Question: In which pathway and in which direction is it thought that dopamine changes to give rise to the negative symptoms of Schizophrenia?
Explanation:
Dopamine theory of Schizophrenia

It is thought that there is a decrease in dopamine concentration in the Mesocortical pathway to lead to the negative symptoms of Schizophrenia;

5A's=avolition (no motivation), alogia (poverty of speech), anhedonia (decreased pleasure), affective flattening (no emotion) and sociality (lack of social interest).

 

A raised concentration in the Mesolimbic pathway is thought to lead to the positive symptoms of Schizophrenia;

=thought: insertion, broadcast and withdrawal and auditory hallucination.

Question: You see a patient on the psychiatric ward who is said to suffer symptoms of thought insertion, withdraw and broadcast and while you are talking to him he appears to be having auditory hallucinations. These symptoms are thought to be due to a neurotransmitter imbalance in the brain, in which pathway is the imbalance present and in which direction is the imbalance?
Explanation:
The symptoms are typical of the positive symptoms of Schizophrenia and are due to an increased concentration of dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway.

 

Dopamine theory of Schizophrenia
It is thought that there is a decrease in dopamine concentration in the Mesocortical pathway to lead to the negative symptoms of Schizophrenia;
5A's=avolition (no motivation), alogia (poverty of speech), anhedonia (decreased pleasure), affective flattening (no emotion) and sociality (lack of social interest).

 

A raised concentration in the Mesolimbic pathway is thought to lead to the positive symptoms of Schizophrenia;
=thought: insertion, broadcast and withdrawal and auditory hallucination.

Question: Brian, aged 12, comes to see you for a fasting plasma glucose test, having previously had a random plasma glucose test. Over the past 3 weeks has been feeling tired, has had blurred vision, and has been drinking and urinating much more than usual, and you are concerned he may have type I diabetes. Which of the following glucose test results would confirm your suspicion?
OptionA: A fasting plasma glucose of 6.8mmol/L and a random plasma glucose of 10mmol/L
OptionB: A fasting plasma glucose of 7.9mmol/L and a random plasma glucose of 9.5mmol/L
OptionC: A fasting plasma glucose of 7.6mmol/L and a random plasma glucose of 10.7mmol/L
OptionD: A fasting plasma glucose of 7.3mmol/L and a random plasma glucose of 11.4mmol/L
OptionE: A fasting plasma glucose of 6.5mmol/L and a random plasma glucose of 11.5mmol/L
Explanation:
A) Here, both values are a little too low to diagnose Brian with diabetes.

B) Here, Brian's random plasma glucose is over the threshold for diabetes, but his fasting plasma glucose is not. 

C) Here, Brian's random plasma glucose is over the threshold for diabetes, but his fasting plasma glucose, although high, is not.

D) This is the correct answer. The criteria for diagnoses of diabetes is;

  • A fasting plasma glucose of >7.0mmol/L
  • A random plasma glucose of >11.1mmol/L

C) Here, Brian's fasting plasma glucose is over the threshold for diabetes, but his random plasma glucose is not.

Question: Type I diabetes is an autoimmune condition where autoantibodies bind to proteins in the beta cell islet. Some of these autoantibodies can be measured, and are predictive of who is going to develop type I diabetes in the future. Which of the following is not one of these islet autoantibodies that can be measured?
Explanation:
• Anti-GAD65 binds to glutamic acid dexarboxylase 65 in the beta cell islet, and can be measured. 
  • IA-2 binds to protein tyrosine phosphatase islet antigen-2 in the beta cell islet, and can be measured.
  • ZnT8 binds to zinc transporter 8 in the beta cell islet, and can be measured.
  • DR3/4 is the HLA which is the genetic factor which is most associated with type I diabetes, and is most predisposing of the condition. However, it is not an autoantibody that can be measured in the same way the autoantibodies can be.

Question: When there is a low concentration of glucose in the intestinal lumen, which transporter is used to absorb the glucose into the enterocyte?
Explanation:
Glucose is absorbed against the concentration gradient by sodium dependent co transporter SGLT1

It is then transported across the basal membrane via GLUT 2

a Na/K/ATPase channel on the basal surface maintains the sodium gradient

 

 

Human Physiology

Question: Brian, aged 16, has type I diabetes and his blood sugar is low. He starts experiencing autonomic symptoms of hypoglycaemia including tremors, anxiety, and tachycardia. Which of the following hormones is most likely to be causing these autonomic symptoms?
Explanation:
When the body is undergoing hypoglycaemia it instigates protective mechanisms in order to continue providing the brain with glucose. These protective mechanisms include release counter regulatory hormones, which work to push up the glucose levels. The main counter regulatory hormones are;

  • Cortisol
  • Adrenaline - which causes the autonomic symptoms of hypoglycaemia
  • Glucagon

Thyroid hormone is not really directly involved in an episode of hypoglycaemia. 

Insulin is involved is so much as excessive insulin is the cause of the hypoglycaemia.

Question: Which of the following antibiotics aren't correctly matched to their mechanism of action?
Explanation: Vancomyocin inhibits the cell wall synthesis in Gram Positive Bacteria

Question: Brenda, a 15 year old type I diabetic, is brought into A & E feeling extremely unwell. She reports excessive urination and vomiting over the past few hours. To you, she appears drowsy and uncoordinated, and you notice that she smells slightly of nail varnish or pear drops. You admit her, and suspect she is suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis. Which of the following test results would confirm your suspicion?
OptionA: Blood glucose levels of 12mmol/L, ketones of 3.0mmol/L, and HCO3 of 16.
OptionB: Blood glucose levels of 10mmol/L, ketones of 4.2mmol/L, and HCO3 of 15.
OptionC: Blood glucose levels of 11.6mmol/L, ketones of 5.1mmol/L, and HCO3 of 12.
OptionD: Blood glucose levels of 10.9mmol/L, ketones of 2.3mmol/L, and HCO3 of 13.
OptionE: Blood glucose levels of 10.3mmol/L, ketones of 2.4mmol/L, and HCO3 of 11.
Explanation:
A) Glucose levels= High, Ketones= On the threshold, HCO3= Fine

B) Glucose levels= Fine, Ketones= High, HCO3= On the threshold

C) These results would be diagnostic of DKA. The diagnosis of DKA can be made when;

  • Glucose levels >11mmol/L
  • Ketones >3.0mmol/L
  • HCO3 <15 or pH <7.3

D) Glucose levels= High, Ketones= Fine, HCO3= Fine

E) Glucose= Fine, Ketones= Fine, HCO3= Fine.

 

However, in real life you'd obviously admit this girl regardless as she is clearly very sick!! Also some of these results, whilst not diagnostic of DKA, would be worrying and would require further looking into.

Question: Which of the following best describes the action of Bisoprolol?
OptionB: K channel blocker which prolongs the refractory period
OptionC: Ca channel blocker which slows impulses through the AV node
OptionD: Inhibits adenylyl cyclase which causes cell hyperpolarisation triggering K efflux and inhibiting Ca entry to the SA node
OptionE: A B-adrenoreceptor antagonist that works by limiting sympathetic activity
Explanation:
A- describes Na channel blockers, class 1 vaughan williams classification eg flecainide used for SVT, AVNRT and Wolff parkinson white

 

B- K channel blockers are class 3 VW and work by blocking K channels which slows repolarisation and prolongs the refractory period. eg amiodarone used for VT, AF, WPW, atrial flutter

 

C-Ca channel blockers (class 4 VW)  these slow Ca mediated impulses through the AV node eg Diltiazem used for paroxysmal SVT, and to reduce ventricular rate in AF

 

D- This describes the action of Adenosine a class 5 VW drug. it is used to treat AV node dependent SVT

 

E- CORRECT- Bisoprolol is a B1 adrenoreceptor antagonist class 2 VW drug used for SVT. It works by decreasing sympathetic activity by preventing the binding of adrenaline and noradrenaline.

Question:
A newly pregnant woman attends the midwife clinic and has a blood sample taken to determine her blood type. 

 

The sample of patient red cells was mixed with Anti-A and Anti-B serums. The results showed agglutination with both serums. 

The plasma of the patient sample was then mixed with type A and type B blood. There was no agglutination observed. 

 

After determining her ABO type, you went on test her Rhesus system. 

When the red cells were mixed with Anti-D serum, there was no agglutination seen. 

 

What blood type is the woman?
Explanation:
The woman is AB-. 

 

The first step of blood typing is ABO typing. The RBCs of the blood sample are mixed with antibodies against type A and type B blood and the sample is observed for agglutination (sticking/clumping together). If the cells do agglutinate, it means that the blood reacted with one of the antibodies:

  • If it agglutinates with anti-A serum, you have type A blood
  • If it agglutinates with anti-B serum, you have type B blood
  • If it agglutinates with both anti-A and anti-B serums, you have type AB blood (as in this case)

The second stage is called back typing. The serum of the patient's blood is mixed with blood that is known to be type A and type B:

  • If the blood agglutinates only when B cells are added to the sample, the blood type is A
  • If the blood agglutinates only when A cells are added to the sample, the blood type is B
  • If the blood agglutinates when either types are added, the blood type is O
  • A lack of agglutination indicates AB blood (as in this case)

The Rhesus typing classifies blood as Rh positive or Rh negative based on the presence of Rh antibodies in the blood:

  • If blood agglutinates when mixed with anti-Rh serum, blood type is Rh positive 
  • If blood doesn't agglutinate when mixed with anti-Rh serum, blood type is Rh negative (as in this case) - this is because the blood doesn't contain D antigen, so does not clump with anti-D antibodies 

Hope this all makes sense, found this a confusing topic myself. Used this source:

http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/003345.htm 

Which explains it quite well, along with the case 8 lectures.

Question: It has been 9 hours since Brian's last meal, and he has has nothing to eat since then. Which of the following terms describes most accurately the 'state' Brian is now in?
Explanation:
• Up to approximately 6 hours following a meal, you are in the 'absorbative', 'postprandial', or 'fed' state.
  • 6 to 12 hours of fasting is called the 'postabsorbative' state.
  • Fasting that lasts longer than 12 hours is the 'prolonged fasting' or 'starvation' state.

In the case of this question, option E (fasting) is technically correct, but in terms of single best answer, the most accurate, most correct answer is option D (postabsorbative).
Tags: Diabetes, Biochemistry, Case 10, Year 1 Revision, year 1

Question: In the fed state, glucose is taken up into the liver by which of the following transporters?
Explanation:
• In the fed state, glucose from the intestines is taken up into the liver by the GLUT-2 transporter and channeled into glycolysis (creating pyruvate to lead on to the TCA-Cycle), glycogenesis (synthesis of glycogen for storage), and lipogenesis (creating VLDL for transport to peripheral tissues).
  • GLUT-4 transporters take up glucose into the muscle and adipose tissue in the fed state.
Tags: Diabetes, Biochemistry, Case 10, Year 1 Revision, year 1

Question: Brenda has recently finished her lunch - a delicious magic wrap. In her adipose tissue, VLDL and chylomicrons are being turned into triacylglycerol for storage. During this process, the VLDL and chylomicrons are hydrolysed, but which of the following enzymes catalyses this?
Explanation:
• A - Glucokinase is used in the first irreversable step of glycolysis (glucose to glucose 6-phosphate) in the liver, rather the hexokinase. 
  • B - Aldolase is used in glycolysis in the conversion of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate into dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP).
  • C - Phosphoglycerate mutase is used in glycolysis to convert 3-phosphoglycerate to 2-phosphoglycerate.
  • D - Glucose 6-phosphatase is used in gluconeogenesis to covert glucose 6-phosphate back to glucose.
  • E - Lipoprotein lipase is used in the adipose tissue to hydrolyse chylomicrons and VLDL into free fatty acids and glycerol. The free fatty acids are then synthesized to form triacylglycerol, in a reaction that requires glycolysis-derived glycerol.
Tags: Diabetes, Biochemistry, Metabolism, Case 10, Year 1 Revision

Question: During fasting, metabolism moves from storage and synthesis to promoting gluconeogenesis - the generation of glucose from non-carbohydrate carbon substrates. Which of the following is the main site of gluconeogenesis?
Explanation: In the fasting state, the liver is transformed from a glucose-utilizing to a glucose-producing organ, as the liver is the main site of gluconeogenesis.
Tags: Diabetes, Biochemistry, Case 10, Year 1 Revision, year 1

Question: In the fasting state, what does the enzyme PEP carboxykinase (phosphenolpyruvate carboxykinase) do?
OptionA: Converts pyruvate to the phophenolpyruvate via a hydration reaction
OptionB: Converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate via a carboxylation reaction
OptionC: Converts oxaloacetate to phosphenolpyruvate via a dehydration reaction
OptionD: Converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate via a dehydration reaction
OptionE: Converts oxaloacetate to phosphenolpyruvate via a decarboxylation reaction
Explanation:
The answer is E. In gluconeogenesis during the fasting state, there are 3 'irreversible' reactions of glycolysis that must be overcome. The first is the irreversible phosphenolpyruvate to pyruvate via pyruvate kinase reaction. This is overcome in a two-step reaction;

  1. Pyruvate is converted to oxaloacetate via pyruvate carboxylase in a carboxylation reaction (addition of CO2).
  2. Oxaloacetate is then converted to phosphenolpyruvate via PEP carboxykinase (phosphenolpyruvate carboxykinase) in a decarboxylation reaction (removal of CO2).

Thus, phosphenolpyruvate is formed.
Tags: Diabetes, Biochemistry, Case 10, Year 1 Revision, year 1

Question: Which of the following is not a substrate used is gluconeogenesis?
Explanation:
The three key substrates for gluconeogenesis are lactate, alanine, and glycerol, although glutamine is also used.

  • Lactate is released from the muscle, taken up into the liver, and oxidised to pyruvate before entering gluconeogenesis. Glucose released from the liver then returns to the muscle later, closing the loop of the Cori Cycle.
  • Alanine and glutamine (but primarily alanine) are released from the muscle as low insulin levels stimulate proteolysis, leading to the release of amino acids. These too are taken up into the liver and converted to pyruvate before entering gluconeogenesis.
  • Glycerol is released from adipose tissue as glucagon stimulate the hydrolysis of TAGs (through lipolysis) by lipase.
Tags: Diabetes, Biochemistry, Case 10, Year 1 Revision, year 1

Question: Which of the following is not one of the three possible ketone bodies that can be generated through ketogenesis in the liver?
Explanation: Ketogenesis occurs in the mitochondria of liver cells, and ketone bodies are produced as a result of fatty acid breakdown. During starvation, ketone bodies are used as a source of energy in cardiac and skeletal muscles, and in the brain. This is to spare glucose and to reduce the demand on degradation of muscle protein for gluconeogenesis.
Tags: Diabetes, Biochemistry, Metabolism, Case 10, Year 1 Revision

Question: Which of the following molecules involved in lipid transport contains Apolipoprotein B48 (ApoB48)
Explanation: ApoB is synthesised in the small intestine and is only found in chylomicrons. ApoB100 is found in VLDLs, LDLs and IDLs. Apolipoprotein A (ApoA) is found only in HDL

Question: Which is the only enzyme to participate in both the TCA cycle and the electron transport chain?
Explanation: Succinate dehydrogenase is also known as complex II and converts succinate to fumarate in the TCA cycle. Doing this produces FADH2 which then contributes 2 H+ to be pumped out by the complex. Dr Shore's lecture from Case 10 illustrates the link quite well.

Question: You are a GP in a small valley's practise. Your next patient is Shanequa Jones who has come to talk to you about her current pregnancy (21/42). Shanequa tells you she is concerned about miscarrying due to 2 previous miscarriages, one at 20 weeks and one at 18 weeks, however her last pregnancy resulted in the birth of her daughter Diamond. You decide to refer her to a consultant obstetrician. On writing the referral what parity and gravidity would you include for Shanequa?
Explanation:
Shanequa would be Parity - 1 and Gravidity - 4.

 

Parity is the number of times a woman gives birth to a potentially viable foetus (>24 weeks.) --> Shanequa misscarried twice however BOTH were under 24 weeks and therefore are NOT counted. She does however have Daimond, her daughter, who was carried to full term. 

 

Gravidity is the number of times a woman is pregnant IRRESPECTIVE of the outcome. Shanequa has been pregnant 4 times, twice misscarried, once with Diamond and is currently pregnant. 

 

Source - Patient.co.uk

Question: 68 year old Mr Jones has just finished racing Mr smith to the post office and has found himself having another one of his 'little episodes'. He feels breathless and has central chest pain radiating down his arm. Mr Jones takes a sit down on a nearby bench and uses his sublingual GTN spray finding that he feels much more like himself after just a couple of minutes. What is most likely wrong with Mr Jones?
Explanation:
Stable angina is the most likely option given:

  • triggered by exertion
  • pain subsides with rest and GTN
  • another 'little episode'

unstable angina is far less likely as such attacks typically do not have a trigger and are less easily resolved by rest

acute MI is also unlikely as the patient rapidly improved with rest and GTN and the patient has experienced episodes before

xanthoma's are deposits of cholesterol rich material
Tags: Emergency Medicine, Thorax, Cardiology, First aid, Case 13

Question: Which of the following need to use the Carnitine Shuttle in order to get into the mitochondrial matrix to undergo beta-oxidation?
Explanation: Short and medium chain fatty acids are able to passively diffuse into the mitochondrial matrix, and are activated to their coA derivative within the mitochondrion. Long chain fatty acids are activated to their coA derivatives in the cytoplasm and in order to get into the mitochondrial matrix, the Carnitine Shuttle in needed.
Tags: Diabetes, Biochemistry, Case 10, Year 1 Revision, year 1

Question: Which drug is injected for a spinal anaesthetic?
Explanation:
Fentanyl is an opioid that is injected into the subarachnoid space. It provides quick pain relief, but wears off after about 1hr.

 

Bupivacaine is infused into the epidural space for an epidural. It provides regional pain relief but continued mobility and some sensation.

Lidocaine is an anaesthetic that has a lower potency and shorter duration than bupivacaine.

Pethidine is an analgesic that is given as an IM injection.

Question: What is the name of the stage of beta-oxidation where 3-Ketoacyl-CoA is formed from L-3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA, in a reaction catalysed by Hydrocacyl-CoA-Dehydrogenase?
Explanation:
The process of beta-oxidation is as follows;

  1. Dehydrogenation: Acyl-CoA ---> Trans-2-Enoyl-CoA (catalysed by Acyl-CoA-Dehydrogenase)
  2. Hydration: Trans-2-Enoyl-CoA ---> L-3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA (catalysed by Enoyl-CoA-Hydratase)
  3. Oxidation: L-3-Hydroxyacyl-CoA ---> 3-Ketoacyl-CoA (catalysed by Hydroxyacyl-CoA-Dehydrogenase)
  4. Thiolysis: 3-Ketoacyl-CoA ---> Acy-CoA + Acetyl-CoA (catalysed by Thiolase)

Question: Incretins are secreted after a meal to help keep glucose levels normal and aid insulin. Glucagon-like peptide is one example of an incretin. Which cell type are they released from?
Explanation: Glucagon-like peptide is released from L cells which are found mainly in the ileum and large intestine.

Question: Where in the body in insulin from the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas released into?
Explanation:
In a non-diabetic person, the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas release insulin minute-by-minute, depending on the glucose levels in the portal vein. Insulin is also released into the portal vein.

 

Source: 'Insulin Therapy in Type I Diabetes' lecture in case 10

Question: Which of the following options best describes the blood supply to the retina?
OptionA: From the central retinal artery and the choroidal blood vessels
OptionC: From the central retinal artery and the optic artery
Explanation:
• There is no such thing as the optic artery.
  • Blood supply to the retina comes from the central retinal artery and the choroidal blood vessels. The choroid receives the greatest blood flow and is vital for the maintenance of the outer retina (as well as the macula and the anterior part of the optic nerve). The central retinal artery nourishes the inner retinal layer.
  • Both the choroidal vessels and the central retinal artery are branches of the opthalmic artery, but the choroidal blood vessels enter the eyeball without passing the optic nerve, whereas the central retinal artery passes inferiority along with the optic nerve.

Question: What does the term thrombocytosis mean?
Explanation:
Polycythaemia = increased RBC count

Thrombocytopenia = decreased platelet count

Thrombocytosis = increased platelet count

Question: A patient experiences rapid weight gain, they quickly go from a healthy weight to obese. Investigations show a lesion somewhere in the brain. Based on your knowledge of appetite regulation, where is the lesion most likely to be?
Explanation: The obesity is due to a lesion of the ventromedial hypothalamus. This is because this part of the hypothalamus contains the satiety centre. If there is a lesion here, the patient experiences hyperphagia (excessive eating) as they never feel full or satisfied from their food. A lesion in the lateral hypothalamus will lead to rapid weight loss and starvation. This is because this part of the hypothalamus contains the feeding centre. A lesion here means that the patient will not experience the urge to eat, leading to aphagia.

Question: Which of the following do not occur in the inner or outer retinal layer?
Explanation:
• Dot haemorrhages are vertical haemorrhages in the inner retinal layers, and appear as 'dots' because they are limited by the fact they are vertical.
  • Blot haemorrhages occur in the outer retinal layers and are not vertical, so appear larger as the blood can spread out.
  • Flame haemorrhages occur in the nerve fibre layer of the retina.
  • IRMAs are a sign that blood vessels are very pre-proliferative - they are getting gunky and lot of VEGF is being produced. They occur in the outer retinal layers.

Question: Which of the following descending spinal tracts provides ipsilateral innervation, i.e. they don't decussate.
Explanation: Vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts don't decussate and so provide ipsilateral innervation (remember -ulo- is ipsilateral). All the others provide contralateral innervation.

Question: Patients who are heterozygous (Ss) for Sickle-cell anaemia tend to survive better than either of the homozygous conditions (SS or ss) (due to it providing protection against Malaria). If 9% of an African population is born with a severe form of sickle-cell anemia (ss), what percentage of the population will be more resistant to malaria because they are heterozygous (Ss) for the sickle-cell gene?
Explanation:
Uses the Hardy-Weinberg Equation: p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1

9% = 0.09 = ss = q2

To find q, simply take the square root of 0.09 to get 0.3. Since p = 1 - 0.3, then p must equal 0.7

2pq = 2 (0.7 x 0.3) = 0.42 = 42% of the population are heterozygotes (carriers).

I stole this question from this website, it's pretty good! http://www.k-state.edu/parasitology/biology198/hardwein.html

Question: Your are out on placement, observing a patient undergoing an endoscopy after suffering from lower GI symptoms. The doctor doing the procedure reports a finding of pseudomembranous colitis. She then asks you what the most likely cause of this is? You respond...
Explanation: Pseudomembranous colitis is often known as C. diff colitis. It is mentioned in the small group tutorial and is shown histologically as the formation of a pseudomembrane on top of the normal colonic mucosa and is associated with inflammation of the colon which can in severe cases be life threatening. According to the small groups management involves "maintaining fluid balance, orally or intravenously, stopping the causative antibiotic, giving vancomycin and or metronidazole for severe cases, and being alert for complications such as bowel perforation".

Question: A certain medical student sustains himself on only chicken nuggets and chips. Subsequently he develops a B12 deficiency. Which of the following is he most likely to have?
Explanation:
Firstly B12 is found in poultry however these chicken nuggets lack any real poultry so do not contain adequate B12.

 

Neuropathic symptoms are very common in B12 deficiency along with mood changes and general neurological changes. B12 deficiency symptoms are highly varied so I had to choose 4 which were highly unlikely to be caused by it.

B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anaemia (high MCV)

Hair loss and seborrhoeic dermatitis do occur in some B vitamin deficiencies but not B12

Hypocalcaemia in the context of vitamin deficiency is likely due to vitamin D deficiency as active vitamin D, calcitriol is required for uptake of calcium in the duodenum and jejunum (see below)

 

Wikipedia on Calcium absorption:

"Calcium is absorbed across the intestinal brush border membrane, passing through ion channels such as TRPV6. Calbindin is a vitamin D-dependent calcium-binding protein inside intestinal epithelial cells which functions together with TRPV6 and calcium pumps (PMCA1) in the basal membrane to actively transport calcium into the body. Active transport of calcium occurs primarily in the duodenum portion of the intestine when calcium intake is low; and through passive paracellular transport occurs in the jejunum and ileum parts when calcium intake is high, independent of Vitamin D level"

Question:
You see a 25-year-old patient. She tells you she has a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder.
She reports hearing voices inside her head that tell her to harm herself. She also sees her dead grandmother and her dead dog. She is not scared by these experiences as she knows these are not real. 
What is the best description of her abnormal perceptions?
Explanation:
This is a pseudo-hallucination because the patient recognizes that what they are seeing is not real. In a hallucination the patient is completely convinced that what they are seeing is real in the absence of a stimulus. 

 

Patients with personality disorders, particularly borderline (emotionally unstable personality disorder), present with variety of semi-psychotic and pseudo-hallucinatory experiences that are difficult to treat with medication.

Question:
A 21 year old female has developed a fear of public places, particularly markets, nightclubs and busy shops after an incident in a nightclub which left her injured. She avoids these places so much that now she is afraid to leave home and it is affecting her social life. 

What term best describes what she is experiencing?
Explanation:
Agoraphobia - fear of public places, crowds, being in open spaces

 

Arachnophobia - fear of spiders

 

Claustrophobia - fear of being in a closed and confined space

 

Social phobia - anxiety disorder characterized by overwhelming anxiety and excessive self-consciousness in everyday social situations.

 

Post-traumatic stress disorder - occurs after an individual suffers from an event in which their life or safety (or that of someone else present) is placed in danger. This can result in intrusive memories and flashbacks of the event, on a background of emotional numbness.

Question: A 79-year-old female presents with severe pain over her left forehead and eye. There is a vesicular rash over the left side of her forehead and upper eyelid. What cranial nerve is most likely to be involved?
Explanation:
The lady has shingles. The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve can be affected by herpes zoster infection. Typically, a vesicular rash is found on the forehead and upper eyelid and may extend to involve the nose. 

 

Shingles is due to a reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which is the virus that causes chickenpox. This is Herpes Virus 3.

Question:
A 65-year-old male presents with chronic productive cough and dyspnoea.
He is a smoker of 10 cigarettes per day and has smoked for 30 years.
To how many pack years does this equate?
Explanation:
Number of pack-years = (packs smoked per day) × (years as a smoker)

 

For reference there are 20 cigarettes in one pack. 

 

Therefore for this question pack years = (0.5) x 30 = 15

Question: which would be indicative of WPW syndromw on an ECG?
Explanation:
WPW syndrome

ECG shows increased PR interval

delta wave

right axis deviation

raised heart rate

Question: My Type II diabetic boss shouted at me at work for leaving a staple on the floor. She said if she stood on it she could develop an ulcer. Why?

A 65-year-old man presents with bilateral leg pain that is brought on by walking. His past medical history includes osteoarthritis. He can typically walk for around 5 minutes before it develops. The pain subsides when he sits down. He has also noticed that leaning forwards or crouching improves the pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is a classic presentation of spinal stenosis, the pain getting better as he leans forward as the spinal canal gets bigger. 

 

Spinal stenosis presentation: 

  • Usually gradual onset
  • Unilateral or bilateral leg pain (with or without back pain), numbness, and weakness which is worse on walking. Resolves when sits down. Pain may be described as 'aching', 'crawling'.
  • Relieved by sitting down, leaning forwards and crouching down
  • Clinical examination is often normal
  • Requires MRI to confirm diagnosis

Question: A 21 year old medical student wakes up following a heavy night at the Lash unable to extend their wrist. They recall not making it to bed and sleeping in a hard chair. What is the most likely cause of the weakness?
Explanation:
This is due to compression of the radial nerve. It has been called 'Saturday night palsy' in the past, as it is caused by compression of the radial nerve against the humeral shaft, possibly due to sleeping in a hard chair with the arm draped over the back 

 

Revision of radial nerve:

 

Roots: C5-C8 

 

Motor: extensor muscles of forearm, wrist, fingers, thumb 

 

Sensory: dorsal lateral 3 and a half fingers

 

Damage patterns: Wrist drop
Tags: Anatomy, Upper Limb innervation, Year 1 Revision

Question: Which one of the following is not associated with carpal tunnel syndrome?
Explanation:
Carpal tunnel syndrome will cause wasting of the thenar eminence. 

 

History

  • pain/pins and needles in thumb, index, middle finger
  • unusually the symptoms may 'ascend' proximally
  • patient shakes his hand to obtain relief, classically at night

Examination

  • weakness of thumb abduction (abductor pollicis brevis)
  • wasting of thenar eminence (NOT hypothenar)
  • Tinel's sign: tapping causes paraesthesia
  • Phalen's sign: flexion of wrist causes symptoms

Causes

  • idiopathic
  • pregnancy
  • oedema e.g. heart failure
  • lunate fracture
  • rheumatoid arthritis
Tags: Upper Limb innervation, Upper limb, Year 1 Revision

Question: A 33-year-old woman presents with back pain which radiates down her right leg. This came on suddenly when she was bending down to pick up her child. On examination straight leg raising is limited to 30 degrees on the right hand side due to shooting pains down her leg. Sensation is reduced on the dorsum of the right foot, particularly around the big toe and foot dorsiflexion is also weak. The ankle and knee reflexes appear intact. A diagnosis of disc prolapse is suspected. Which nerve root is most likely to be affected?
Explanation:
L5 lesion causes: loss of foot dorsiflexion and sensory loss to the dorsum of the foot

 

The reflexes also supply another clue: it cannot be S1 as the ankle reflex is intact as it cannot be L4 as the knee reflex is intact.

Question: Which of the following is not a function of the mesangial cells of the kidney?
Explanation:
• Mesangial cells provide structural support for glomerular capillaries, exhibit phagocytosis, secrete prostaglandins, and are contractile (helping regulate blood flow through glomerular capillaries).
  • Juxtaglomerular cells (part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus) synthesize, store, and secrete renin.

Question: Which of these increase motility in the GI tract?
Explanation:
Enteroglucagon and Neurotensin=decerases GI motility released in the Ileum when there is excess fat and glucose (slowing motility to increase the uptake).

Aldosterone also decerases gut motility (due to water and Sodium uptake in the gut)

 

TLP is made up

 

VIP is the one that increases gut motility by increasing water and chloride release, it also relaxes SMCs of the gallbladder and the sphincter of oddi

-Serotonin and Motilin also increase gut motility

Question: Interstitial cell of Cajal (ICCs) are important cells in the motility of the small intestine. They display pacemaker activity due to cyclic release of which ion?
Explanation: Taken directly from Dr Allen's Case 11 lecture "￼ICCs display pacemaker activity due to cyclic release of Ca2+ from intracellular stores. Depolarisations are transmitted to smooth muscle cells generating slow waves. Slow waves propagate in the antral direction"

Question: Which part of the placental membrane largely disappears in the 3rd trimester?
Explanation:
From the 4th months the placental membrane becomes thinner as the capillaries enlarge and lie closer to the syncytiotrophoblast. The amount of CT decreases and the cytotrophoblast layer largely disappears. 

 

SOURCE: Embryology: An Illustrated Colour Text.

Question: Terry, a 45 year old man enters your GP surgery feeling unwell. He describes abdominal pain (right upper quadrant), along with nausea and vomiting. On further examination the sclera of his eyes are yellow. He has recently arrived back into the country after travelling in Asia for a month. Terry is most likely suffering from a viral infection. From the information provided which class do you expect the most likely virus to be classified under?
Explanation:
From the history and examination the most likely cause of Terry's symptoms is an acute Hepatitis A infection. This is common in countries with poor food hygiene and is more common in developing countries.

 

Hepatitis A belongs to Class IV of the Baltimore Classification meaning that it is a positive sense ssRNA virus. If the infection was a Hepatitis B then it would be in Class VII (a reverse DNA virus).

Question:
A woman presents to her GP just having found out she is pregnant. 

She has had one previous miscarriage at 10 weeks during her last pregnancy. Apart from that, she has never delivered a baby or been otherwise pregnant. 

 

What term best describes her?
Explanation:
She is multigravida. 

 

Parity is defined as the number of pregnancies a woman has had that have each resulted in delivery of a foetus with a gestational age of 24 weeks or more (regardless of whether this is a stillbirth or not). Therefore, despite having been pregnant once, she would be considered nulliparous. 

She will be primiparous once she has given birth for the first time. 

She would be grand multiparous when she has delivered five or more infants. 

 

Gravidity is defined as the number of times that a woman has been pregnant, including the current pregnancy, previous live births, miscarriages and abortions. Therefore, she is not nulligravida, as she has been pregnant previously, and is in fact multigravida, as this is her second pregnancy. 

 

Source - http://www.patient.co.uk/doctor/gravidity-and-parity-definitions-and-their-implications-in-risk-assessment

Question:
A 25 year old nulliparous woman 15/40 presents to the midwife. She is concerned that she hasn't yet got a 'baby bump', although her friends who have previously been pregnant have usually started showing by now. She asks whether should she be concerned. 

 

What is your response?
OptionA: There is no immediate cause for concern, as nulliparous women usually show after 20 weeks gestation
OptionB: There is no immediate cause for concern, as nulliparous women usually show between 12-16 weeks gestation
OptionC: There is perhaps reason to be concerned, as nulliparous women usually show by 14 weeks
OptionD: There is perhaps reason to be concerned, as nulliparous women usually show by 10 weeks
OptionE: There is no immediate cause for concern, as nulliparous women usually show between 15-19 weeks
Explanation:
There is no immediate reason for her to be worried, as nulliparous often begin to show between 12-16 weeks. 

Multiparous women may show earlier as their uterine muscles and abdominal muscles are already stretched from previous pregnancies. 

 

Out of interest:

  • Women with a retroverted uterus would show late
  • Women with an anteverted uterus may show early

Question: Which of the following results in posterior cord syndrome?
Explanation: refer to lecture in case 14

Question: At what age will a child pull to stand with support?
Explanation:
Also crawls at 9 months

Walks at 1yr (average is 13 months)

Question:
During a morning clinic at the GP surgery, you see a 12 year old girl who has come in for help controlling her period pain. She has only just started her periods, and tells you that she has started noticing changes in her body and is a little embarrassed about them, so you explain to her that the changes she is noticing are completely normal.

One of the main things that concerns her is that her breasts are growing, and she feels as if she looks different to the other girls in her class. You explain that the parts of her breast called lactiferous ducts are sprouting and becoming more branched, which is why they are growing.

What hormones are responsible for this during puberty?
Explanation:
The hormones responsible are oestrogen, growth hormon and progesterone. 

 

  • Until puberty, the immature breast consists almost entirely of lactiferous ducts. During puberty, these ducts begin to sprout and become more highly branched, under the influence of these hormones. 
  • Menstruation sees progesterone stimulating the formation of spherical masses of granular cells at the end of each duct, resulting in immature alveoli.
  • These only develop into milk-secreting alveoli during pregnancy, due to exposure to placental hormones (oestrogen, progesterone, hPL, and prolactin).

Question: What is the mechanism of action of Biguanides?
OptionA: inhibits DDP-IV, thus increasing the incretin response.
OptionB: Binds to the KATP effluxer, triggering Ca2+ release and increasing insulin response
OptionC: raises cytosolic AMP ultimately decreasing PEPCK and glucose-6 phosphatase to decrease plasma glucose
Explanation:
A- gliptin class e.g. saxagliptin. With DPP-4 no longer inhibited; insulin secretion increases, glucagon secretion decreases and ultimately plasma glucose decreases. ADRs: headache, nausea, possible increase in risk of pancreatic cancer

 

B - sulphonylurea e.g gliclazide and glibenclamide: binds to the KATP effluxer so K enters the beta cell. this causes depolarisation of the cell and therefore opens the voltage gated Ca channels allowing Ca to flood into the cell. This triggers the IP3 signalling cascade and causes insulin to be released. ADRs: hypoglycaemia, cholestasis

 

C - correct. e.g. metformin: raises cytosolic AMP, which activates AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPPK). this decreases the expression of phosphoenyol-pyruvate carboxykinase (gluconeogensis pathway) and glucose 6 phosphase (preventing glucose 6-phosphatase being dephosphorylated to become glucose). This results in:

  • a decrease in hepatic gluconeogensis
  • an increase in insulin insensitivity
  • an increase in GLUT4 activity

D- alpha glucosidase inhibitors e.g.acarbose competetivly inhibit alpha-glucosidases in brush borders on small intestines so limits how much glucose gets into the blood plasma. ADRs: flatulence and hepatitis

 

E-Glitazone e.g pioglitazone. agonist of the peroxisome-proliferator Activated Receptor gamma (PPRAgamme). This complex then acts as a transcriptional factor activating the nuclear hormone receptor in adipose tissue. this results in:

  • adipocyte differentiation
  • increased lipogenesis
  • increased FA uptake
  • increased glucose uptake

Question: Which of these laxatives work by stimulating the enteric nervous system thus increasing motility in the GI tract?
Explanation:
All of these are laxatives.

Emollients: are stool softners that incorporate water and fat into he stool for it to pass easier

Hyperosmotic agents: cause water retention in the gut (osmotic pull) i.e. Lactulose

Stimulant agents: alter the water/elctrollyte balance by acting on the enteric NS to enhance peristalsis i.e. Senna

Lubricant Agent:coat the stool in lipid to decerase colonic absorption and increase motility

Serotonin agonists: act on the enteric NS and cause increased motility (act as PNS agonists)

 

Extra

=natural fibres i.e. kiwi/bananas

=chloride channel activators: produce chloride rich flud in lumen so softens the stool through water secretions (also increasing motility)

Question: Which of the following vaccines is a killed vaccine?
Explanation:
Live vaccines: MMR, BCG, Influenza (nasal), Rotavirus (oral), Typhoid (oral), Varicella Zoster, Yellow Fever

Killed vaccines: DaPT, Hib and Men C, Influenza (injected), Pneumococcal, Typhoid (injected), Hep A, Hep B

Question: What does the following symbol mean: ∇ (blacked out)
Explanation: New vaccines have a downward pointing black triangle to identify them.

Question: Which of the following cells, based in the ileum, release a substance that decreases motility of the gut in response to glucose and fat?
Explanation:
The correct answer is L cells which release enteroglucan in the distal ileum

 

• enteric (NANC) neurons: VIP relaxes smooth muscle

• EC cells :serotonin activates local motor reflexes

• enteric neurons: enkephalins regulate peristaltic reflex

• N cells in ileum release neurotensin in response to fat,

– fat normally absorbed before this section

• acts to decrease motility

• L cells in distal ileum release enteroglucan, released in response to

glucose & fat,

– glucose & fat normally absorbed before this section

• acts to decrease motility

 

(TJ lecture, case 11)

Question: Which class of Anti-arrhythmic drugs does Diltiazem belong to?
Explanation:
Diltiazem belongs to the class of Calcium channel blockers (along with verapamill) which have a number of effects. By blocking the Calcium channels they:

  • Reduce Heart Rate
  • Slow Rate of conduction through the AV node
  • Reduces contractility of myocytes

Class I - VG sodium channel blockers 

Class II - B-adrenoceptor antagonists 

Class III - Potassium channel blockers

Class IV - Calcium Channel Blockers

Question: Which of the following best describes the arrhythmia produced in Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome?
Explanation:
delta wave produced due to premature depolarisation of part of the ventricle as the action potential bypasses the AVN. 

 

extra p waves (as the depolarisation reenters the atria) which are not followed by QRS complexes.

Question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing osteoporosis?
Explanation:
The answer is C - It is LOW BMI that is a risk factor for osteoporosis, not high BMI.

Other risk factors not mentioned above are age, family history and alcohol abuse.

 

Source - Taken straight from the Bone health and disease plenary in case 14.

Question: Sue is a 68 year old female is suffering from hypertension and has recently started experiencing a 'crushing' chest pain during exertion. She is diagnosed with Angina Pectoris. She additionally has hypercholestrolaemia. In light of this new diagnosis, what is her updated CHADS-VASc score?
Explanation:
Her score is 4. 

C - Congestive Heart Failure

H - Hypertension 

A - Age (>75) - 2 points

D - Diabetes 

S - Stroke/TIA - 2 points 

V - Vascular Disease 

A - Age (65-74) 

S - Sex (Female) 

 

Sue therefore has a score of 4 for the hypertension, vascular disease (angina), age and being female.

Question: While on ward round with the Paediatric consultant you come across a a 14 year old girl with neck webbing and who is short of stature. The consultant tells you that she will most likely be unable to naturally conceive a child in the future and asks you which chromosomal abnormality you think she may have, you reply...
Explanation:
D 45X is correct as the clinical features suggest Turners syndrome characterised by neck webbing/thickening, short stature, widely spaced nipples, streak ovaries, primary amenorrhoea and lack of development of sexual characteristics

A is down syndrome, b is edwards syndrome

Question:
A nervous, ginger-bearded medical student has started second guessing himself when answering questions on peerwise as his exams approach.  He has failed to groom his ginger beard recently and has stopped watching his beloved Sale persistently lose, two activities he greatly enjoyed before.  He has been complaining recently of severe tiredness and lack of energy but he thinks it only due to his 2am ASSL sessions, which has disturbed his sleep pattern.  Apart from this everything else is fine.

 

What, if anything, is he suffering from?
OptionE: Nothing he is fine. But he needs to start backing himself.
Explanation:
He has mild depression as he has 2 core and 2 associated symptoms:

2 core = anhedonia and anergia.

2 associated = lack of confidence and disturbed sleep.

 

Acute stress reaction - tends to be due to a life event.
GAD - persistent and chronic anxiety presenting with dry mouth, ado pain, hyperventilation, palpitations, chest pain, increased urination, fatigue, blurred vision, dizziness, trembling, headaches.

Moderate depression = 2 core and 3 associated.

Answer E is completely correct too and I was very tempted to make it the right answer.  However mild depression is more relevant.

Question:
In U-turn in events, the ginger bearded medical student is feeling a lot better and started to back himself.  In celebration of his good mood he decides to go to his favourite pub and have one of their guest ales.  He sees on the table next to him a group of ladies, one of whom refuses to drink as she is pregnant as it can lead to fetal alcohol syndrome.

 

Which of the following is not a symptom of fetal alcohol syndrome?
Explanation: FAS actually presents with a thin upper lip as well as smooth skin between nose and lips.  facial abnormalities, development abnormalities, behavioural problems and the four listed above.

Question:
A patient presents to A&E with sudden-onset right-sided hemiplegia and difficulty speaking.  On examination, they are unable to feel vibration and proprioception in their limbs all down their right side.  When you ask them to stick out their tongue, it deviates to the left side.  The rest of the cranial nerve exam is unremarkable.

 

Where does the patient most likely have a lesion?
Explanation:
This is the Medial Medullary Syndrome, characterised by contralateral hemiplegia and dorsal column medial lemniscus sensory loss, and ipsilateral twelfth nerve palsy.  This is due to ischaemia in the pyramids, the medial lemniscus and the twelfth nerve nucleus.  

 

This most commonly occurs due to occlusion of the anterior spinal artery at its superior end, near its origin (the anastomosis of a branch of each of the vertebral arteries)

 

Source: http://www.strokecenter.org/professionals/stroke-diagnosis/stroke-syndromes/medial-medullary-syndrome/

 

I doubt this will come up, but brainstem strokes were brought up a couple of times during Case 16: in the anatomy practical and in Dr Watson's lecture so I thought I'd write a question on them anyway :)

Question: Which of the following statements regarding synaptic transmission is correct?
OptionC: Depolarisation of the presynaptic membrane causes activation of voltage-gated sodium channels
OptionD: Electrical synapses form the majority of synapses
OptionE: Excitatory neurotransmitters are likely to cause a sodium influx on the post-synaptic membrane
Explanation:
A is incorrect, electrical synapses can be bidirectional due to presence of gap junctions which allow movement of signals in both directions.

B is incorrect as metabotropic receptors, by activating secondary signalling mechanisms, are generally slower than ionotropic receptors. Ionotropic can have an immediately excitatory or inhibitory effect on post synaptic membrane due to influx of ions being linked directly to binding example being AMPA and GABAA receptors. 

C is incorrect as it is calcium channels which open upon depolarisation and trigger vesicles to bind and release neurotransmitter

D is incorrect, chemical synapses are the main form of synapse.

E is correct, excitatory neurotransmitters cause EPSPs on the post synaptic membrane to help trigger an action potential. EPSPs are very often sodium influx which causes the membrane potential to increase, closer to the threshold potential.

Question: Whilst at the pub, the ginger bearded medical student pucks up the courage (as he is know backing himself) to chat up a girl.  He is successful and gets her number.  After numerous cheeky nandos, the ginger bearded medical student takes the girl home one drunken night and engages in sexual intercourse, however due to their state they are not very careful and don't use protection.  The next day they go to the GUM clinic to get the emergency contraception - levonorgestrel.  How does this work to prevent pregnancy?
Explanation: Coffeys lecture in case 2.  Levonorgestrel (a large dose of progesterone) is enough hormonal disturbance to stop fertilisation.  Can cause nausea, vomiting, headache and irregular bleeding - not for routine use.

Question: Carol and Rob enter the Toronto half-marathon. At the half-way stage Carol can no longer continue. What is the cause of this?
OptionC: She 'hit the wall' because she ran out of fatty acids in both liver and muscles
OptionD: She 'hit the wall' because she used up all her glycogen stores in both liver and muscles
Explanation: Carb loading and increased training will improve Carol's glycogen storage in the future. Train harder next time Carol ......

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the circadian rhythm is correct?
OptionA: The main regulatory centre is found in the thalamus
OptionB: Melatonin secretion is likely to increase in the morning
OptionC: The cardiovascular system is at its most efficient upon waking up
OptionD: Cortisol secretion is at its highest in the morning
Explanation:
A is incorrect as the structure that is known as the "master clock" is the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) which lies in the hypothalamus. 

B is incorrect as melatonin, released from the pineal gland, is inhibited by daylight. It is released in the evening and causes drowsiness and induces sleep.

C is incorrect as whilst blood pressure will increase significantly in the morning, the CV system and BP are at it's peak in the afternoon, evening.

D is correct, Cortisol peaks in the morning and is low at night

E is incorrect, bowel activity tends to be inhibited during the night and then increases upon waking inducing the need to take a morning trip to the toilet...

Question: After the emergency contraception was successful, the ginger bearded medical student and his "partner" now decide to use proper contraception in the form of the oral contraceptive pill.  The doctor they see lists a series of contraindications.  Which of the following isn't a contraindication?
Explanation:
The following are contraindications for the "pill":

  • Pregnancy
  • Pre-existing CV disease
  • Obese
  • Hypercholesterolaemia
  • Smoker over 40
  • Oestrogen sensitive breast or bowel cancer
  • Liver cirrhosis

Question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of Brown-Sequard syndrome?
OptionD: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation
Explanation:
The answer is B - You would get an ipsilateral loss of fine touch sensation, as the dorsal column fibres decussate in the lower medulla, above any possible sites of spinal cord lesion.

 

Brown Sequard syndrome would present in the following way:

Ipsilateral

- Ascending dorsal columns result in ipsilateral loss of proprioception, touch, and vibration sense.
- Descending lateral corticospinal tracts result in ipsilateral spastic paralysis
Contralateral
- Ascending lateral spinothalamic tracts (which cross 1-2 levels above the level of their respective dorsal root) result in contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation

 

I found the Radiopaedia website really good for the spinal cord syndromes, link is below :)

http://radiopaedia.org/articles/brown-sequard-syndrome-1

Question:
After a recent thunder storm in Wales, in which the ginger bearded medical student was only wearing a t-shirt, he contracts the common cold.  He wonders to himself, as he gets into bed to warm up, what virus causes this and what cytokines establish an anti-viral state in his body.

 

What are they?
Explanation:
A is correct.  Rhinovirus causes the common cold and IFN alpha and beta both cause an anti-viral state.  Released from leukocytes and fibroblasts respectively.

 

IFN gamma - released from T and NK cells.  Recruits neutrophils and potentiates the effects of IFN alpha and beta.

IL-17 - released from Th17.  Recruits neutrophils.

IL-1 - from macrophages, endothelial cells, B cells, Fibroblasts.  A pro-inflammatory and a pyrogen.  Promotes PG and oedema.
Tags: Immunology, Infectious Disease, Cytokines, Virology, Case 9

Question: What are the areas labelled 2, 6 and 7?
OptionA:
2 = Renal cortex
6 = Minor calices
7 = Renal pelvis
OptionB:
2 = Pyramids of the renal medulla
6 = Renal column
7 = Ureter
OptionD:
2 = Pyramids of the renal medulla

6 = Minor calices

7 = Renal pelvis
OptionE:
2 = Pyramids of the renal medulla
6 = Minor calices
7 = Major calyx
Explanation:
In order, the structures are as follows:

 

1 = Cortex

2 = Pyramids of the renal medulla

3 = Renal papilla

4 = Medullary rays

5 = Ureter

6 = Minor calices

7 = Renal pelvis

8 = Major calices

9 = Renal column

 

Courtesy of Netters Anatomy.

Question: Which of the following epidemiological terms is correctly matched to its definition?
OptionA: Sensitivity - The proportion of persons with disease who are correctly identified by a screening test as having the disease.
OptionB: Negative predictive value - The proportion of persons without disease who are correctly identified by a screening test as not having the disease
OptionC: Prevalence - Rate at which new cases occur in a population during a specified period
OptionD: Incidence - Proportion of a population that are cases during a specified period of time
OptionE: Specificity - The number of true negatives out of all the negatives given by the test
Explanation:
A is the correct definition for sensitivity

B is the definition for specificity i.e. the true negative rate

C is the definition for incidence

D is the definition for prevalence

E is the definition for negative predictive value

 

The difference between negative predictive value and specificity is that negative predictive value is how many of the negatives from the test were actually negatives. Specificity is the percentage of those without the condition who were found to be negative.

Question: Which of the following statements regarding psychosis and schizophrenia is correct?
OptionA: 1 in 5 people will have some form of psychotic episode
OptionC: Schizophrenia causes only a small percentage of psychosis cases
OptionE: Psychosis is more common than type 1 diabetes
Explanation:
A is incorrect, whilst psychosis is more common than often suggested, it is thought to have a lifetime risk of around 2.5-3.5%

Thought around 2% will experience some sort of psychotic episode

B is incorrect, onset is thought to be 2-3 years later in women than men

C is incorrect, schizophrenia is a leading cause, if not the main cause of psychotic episodes. 

D is incorrect, onset if very often between the ages of 15 and 30. 

C is correct, according to the lecture schizophrenia is 6 times more prevalent than type 1 diabetes. This makes sense given that it is estimated that 1-2% of young people experience a psychotic episode.

Question: John has back pain when he bends backwards. Which of the following is he most likely to be suffering from?
You are a junior doctor in A and E. You see a wild Asmaf arrive at the hospital with a knife stuck in the left side of his spinal cord. Where would you expect to find a loss?
OptionA: Contralateral = light touch and proprioception; Ipsilateral = pain, vibration, temperature
OptionB: Contralateral = vibration, proprioception and 2 touch discrimination; ipsilateral = light touch, pain, temperature
OptionC: Ipsilateral = vibration, proprioception, motor control ; contralateral = pain, temperature, light touch
OptionD: Ipsilateral = vibration, proprioception ; contralateral = pain, temperature, light touch, motor control
OptionE: Contralateral = vibration, pain, motor control; Ipsilateral = temperature, light touch
Explanation:
C – Only the Lateral Spinothalamic tract crosses over in the spinal cord. So a lesion in the spinal cord will cause CONTRALATERAL loss of pain, temperature and light touch.
The DCML (vibration, proprioception), Spinocerebelar (proprioception) and corticospinal (limb motor) cross in the medulla *, so a lesion to the spinal cord will cause loss on the SAME (IPSILATERAL) side, as they nerves have already crossed over.
*Apart from Spinocerebelar – doesnt cross, stays on same side.

Question: A patient visits her GP for an annual check up. You take her blood pressure and it is 165/105mmHg. A double check gives the same result. What is your next management step.
OptionD: Ask her to return in within 2 weeks to check again
OptionE: Ask her to return tomorrow to check again
Explanation:
NICE Clinical Knowledge Summaries - Hypertension

 

Arrange same day admission and start anti-hypertensives immediately if over 180/110mmHg

Start or anti-hypertensives at 160/100mmHg

Check their other CV risk factors to decide if they need treatment if they're at 140/90mmHg

Have another check-up soon if they're close to 140/90mmHg

 

http://cks.nice.org.uk/hypertension-not-diabetic#!diagnosissub

Question:
The ginger bearded medical student is grooming his ginger beard, an activity he absolutely adores.  However, whilst doing so he cuts himself quite severely and starts bleeding profusely due to the anticoagulant therapy he is on - he has been over-anticoagulated.  He is rushed into hospital where he is give Protamine Sulphate to store coagulation levels.

 

What anticoagulant was he on and how what doctors check anti-coagulation levels were restored to normally?
OptionA:
Heparin

Prothrombin time compared against activated partial thromboplastin time
OptionB:
Warfarin

Prothrombin time compared against activated partial thromboplastin time
Explanation:
The correct answer is Heparin and Prothrombin time compared against activated partial thromboplastin time.  The antidote for Heparin is Protamine Sulphate.  Administered via IV in hospital.

 

Warfarin's antidote is vitamin K and anti-coagulation state is measured using the INR.  It is administered orally and is for home use.

 

Rivaroxaban is a NOAC which doesn't have an antidote or a way of measuring the state of anti-coagulation in the patient.  Other NOACs include dabigatran and apixaban.
