Question: Jerry comes into the GP surgery complaining of saddle anaesthesia and urinary incontinence. Given his symptoms and you're diagnosis of Cauda Equina Syndrome which bilateral reflex is he most likely to have lost and from which nerve routes does this reflex originate?
Explanation:
Jerry appears to be suffering from Cauda Equina Syndrome.

-Characterised by saddle, anaesthesia, decreased rectal tone, urinary incontinence, loss of bilateral ankle reflex (S1 and S2), sexual dysfunction.

 

Easy way to remember the reflexes...

S1 and S2=ankle

L3 and L4=knee

C5 and C6=biceps

C7=triceps

1-7, bottom to top.

Question: The ginger bearded medical student is on placement, and sees a man who has come into the ED after a RTC.  He has a CT scan done - see below.  What is the man suffering from?
Explanation:
The crescent shape of the suggests a subdural haematoma.  If it was convex (like a lens) shaped it would be extradural. 

A CT scan pictures are as if the patient is lying flat supine and you are looking up their feet, therefore these appear in reverse - the haematoma is on the left of the picture therefore is on the right of the body.
Tags: Case 16, Head and Neck, Head Injuries

Question: Which of the following best defines spondylolisthesis?
OptionA: Degenerative changes to the vertebrae and inter-vertebral discs
OptionB: Defect in the pars interarticularis of the facet joints
OptionE: Displacement of one vertebra over another, due to a defect in the pars interarticularis of the facet joint
Explanation:
The answer is C - Spondylolisthesis is the displacement of one vertebra over another.

A is the definition of spondylosis.

B is the definition of spondylolysis.

D is the definition of spondyloarthrosis.

E is the definition of spondylolytic spondylolisthesis.

Question:
This is the description of the life cycle of a virus. Which viral life cycle is being described? 


1. Haemagglutinin allows adsorption to the cell. Surface CD46 molecule, Signalling Lymphocyte Activation Molecule (SLAM) and the cell adhesion molecule Nectin-4 are the cellular receptors. 
2. The virus penetrates the cell surface and uncoats and the vision RNA polymerase transcribes the negative-strand genome to mRNA.
3. Specific viral proteins are formed and a helical nucleocapsid is assembled.
4. The virus is released by budding.
Explanation:
Even if you do not know that this is the measles life cycle, you can still get it down to Measles and Mumps because they are the only two which are negative single stranded RNA viruses (described in the question). The correct answer is measles.

My source is my notes from Case 9 and Wikipedia (apols)

Question:
A 28 year old male patient weighing 72kg undergoes minor surgery on his leg and requires an injection of 0.5% lidocaine as a local anaesthetic. The doctor gives him an initial dose of 10mL.

 

The maximum does is 2.65mg/kg.

 

To 1 decimal place how much more lidocaine can be administered?
Explanation:
A 0.5% lidocaine means that there is 0.5g per 100mL which works out as 500mg per 100mL.

At the moment he has taken on 10mL which is a 50mg dose.

 

He is allowed 2.65 x 72=190.8mg as a total dose due to his weight.

So if we take 50mg off this (what he has already taken) then he is allowed 140.8mg more lidocaine.

 

140.8mg divided by 50mg means that he is allowed another 2.816 times the dose he has already had so thats 10mL x 2.816 which is 28.16mL

 

Rounding to 1d.p. is 28.2mL.

Question: You are in clinic where you are introduced to Mrs Smith - an 84 year old female. On her prescription form she has been prescribed a new drug, Amiodarone. What Vaughan Williams Class does Amiodarone belong to?
Explanation:
I - Na+ Channel Blockers include: Lignocaine, Cocaine and Fleicanide

II - Beta-Adrenoceptor Antagonists include:  Propanolol, Atenolol, Bisoprolol

III - K+ Channel Blocker - Amiodarone, 

IV - Ca2+ Channel Blocker - Verapamil, Diltiazem, Amlodipine

Question: Brian's blood has a bicarbonate buffer system. When alkali (OH-) is added to his blood, which of the following will occur as a result of his bicarbonate buffer system?
Explanation:
A decreased ventilation rate will be seen. This is because;

  • OH- reacts with carbonic acid (H2CO3), yeilding H2O and HCO3-.
  • As a result of the subsequent decrease in H2CO3 concentration, carbon dioxide and water react together to produce carbonic acid. This replenishes the used H2CO3.
  • However, CO2 has been used to replenish carbonic acid stores, so is depleted. This depletion of carbon dioxide is compensated by a decreased ventilation rate.
Tags: Acid Base Balance, Kidney, Biochemistry, Case 10, Year 1 Revision

Question: In bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, with which ion is HCO3- transport from the proximal tubule cell into the blood specifically associated?
Explanation: Bicarbonate moves from the proximal tubule cell into the blood via a HCO3-/Na+ symporter, and both are reabsorbed.
Tags: Kidney, Biochemistry, Case 10, Year 1 Revision, Case 17

Question: During acid excretion in the distal convoluted tubule, the 'manufactured buffer' ammonia is synthesized by the kidney itself. From which of the following amino acids is ammonia manufactured?
Explanation: Renal tubular cells contain the enzymes glutaminase, which catalyses the production of NH3 from the nitrogen-rich amino acid glutamine. Ammonia is converted to ammonium, NH4+, in acidic environments.

Question: Caspase enzymes have a central role in which of the following cellular processes?
Explanation:
Caspases play a central role in apoptotic cell death.

Calpains are more associated with cell necrosis.

The enzyme responsible for inducing both isotype switching and somatic hypermutation in activated naïve B cells is activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID).

 

Source: Cellular Responses to Brain Injury Lecture, Case 16.

Question: From which secondary brain vesicle does the pons come from?
Explanation:
There is a Lecturer on youtube who I think is quite good at explaining the basic concepts etc. https://www.youtube.com/user/wendogg1/playlists

 

  • Telencephalon --> cerebrum
  • diencephalon-hypothalamus, thalamus and epithalamus (pineal gland)
  • mesencephalon - cerebral peduncles and tectoral plate (superior and inferior colliculi)
  • Metencephalon - pons and cerebellum
  • Myelencephalon - medulla oblongata

Question: A 73-year old gentleman presents to A&E with 'diarrhea, dementia and dermatitis (see below)' after suffering with chronic alcoholism for many years. Deficiency of what vitamin is likely causing the patient symptoms?
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with the '3 D's' (diarrhea, dermatitis and dementia) of Pellagra, a disease caused by chronic deficiency of Niaicn (B3). Many conditions are associated with niaicn deficiency including chronic alcoholism, Crohn's and poor diet. Treatment is with nicotinamide, which has the same vitamin function as niacin and a similar chemical structure, but has lower toxicity.

 

See Fundamentals of nutrition - Dr Rachael Barlow.
Tags: Diet, Nutrition, Case 11, Gastrointestinal System, Vitamins

Question: 37 yo Linda is having a baby. She is having a screening test done to assess if she may need further diagnostic testing. She has been brewing the baby for around 16 weeks now. The midwife (who you are shadowing) visits Linda in her home where she lives with her parter Lindo and her sister Lindi who has spina bifida. The midwife is explaining the screening test and talks about MSAFP. Linda wonders where this MSAFP comes from. Can you help Linda?
Explanation:
MSAFP is major plasma protein produced by the yolk sac and the liver during fetal development then excreted in foetal urine into amniotic fluid. it is thought to be the fetal form of serum albumin

during pregnancy, the AFP can cross the placenta and enter the mothers blood and has a good indication for risk of neural tube defects as well as Down syndrome

 

Linda is high risk as she is >35 and her sister has a birth defect

 

the really optimal time for this test is 16-18 weeks though can be done from 15-20 weeks

Question: Linda's baby is brewing nicely - in fact she just felt a fetal movement for the first time. Around how many weeks gestation is the fetus?
Explanation:
The fetus at 20 weeks:

  • ~25 cm long
  • ~223g
  • lanugo covers the whole body
  • mummy Linda can feel the movements
  • Heart sounds can be heard upon auscultation

Question: Linda and Lindo have not used contraceptives in 6 years, so far they have been unsuccessful in their attempt to become pregnant. But Lindo had no problems in a previous marriage as he already has 2 children. Which of these best describes Linda's infertility?
Explanation:
primary infertility is the absence of a live birth for women who desire a child and have been in union for at least 5 years without using contraceptives. WHO says that a failure of a live birth counts towards primary.

 

secondary is when there has not been a live birth for a woman trying for a baby despite not using contraceptives since her last child was born >5 years ago.

 

so here it depends on whether the mother has had a baby before. 

 

Lindo has children so it is unlikely to be an infertility on his side and therefore unlikely to be combined with all the knowledge. It could just be that together it doesn't work. Unfortunately this is SBA

Question: which description best fits the term life event
OptionA: change in roles/statuses that represents a distinct departure from prior roles and statuses
OptionB: long term pattern of stability and change which usually involves multiple transitions
OptionC: significant occurrence involving a relatively abrupt change that may produce serious and long-lasting effects
OptionD: change that produces a lasting shift in the life course
OptionE: When a transition coincides with a crisis
Explanation:
A- transition

B-Trajection

C life event

D turning point

E an example of when a transition becomes a turning point

Question: in 2013, which was the most common family type
Explanation:
7.7 million

 

married/civil P with dependent children had 4.7 million

 

pregnancy and parenting: an individual concern and a social matter lecture - case 8

Question:
'a nuclear family has positive social functions e.g. socialisation, economic support and reproduction.'

Which type of view is this?
Explanation:
B- family has negative social consequences e.g reproduction of gender norms and roles

C - correct

D - a realationship to the labour market as producer and consumer. Families are affected by employment, changes in labour market and welfare policy changes including tax credits

E - there are positive and negative effects of combining 'caring' and 'providing'

Question: Linda has been thinking about how pregnancy affects her body. How does maternal plasma volume change throughout pregnancy
OptionB: Decreases in first trimester then increases to normal levels in the third.
OptionD: increases in first trimester then decreases to normal levels in the third
Explanation:
plasma volume increases throughout pregnancy plateauing at ~ 32 weeks to term.

the increase in plasma volume is why you see dilutional anaemia

 

Haematological aspects of pregnancy lecture case 8

Question: Which of the following does digoxin inhibit?
Explanation:
A is correct as digoxin (which is a cardiac glycoside) inhibits this pump in cardiomyocytes which means Na+ stays in the sarcoplasm and so the intracellular concentration increases. This results in Na+/Ca2+ exchanger (Answer B) switching from its usual state of Calcium efflux to calcium influx. This is because the exchanger will act to remove the build of sodium in the sarcoplasm. Increased calcium builds up in the cardiomyocyte which leads to longer time for relaxation to occur meaning heart rate will slow. This is why digoxin can be used in atrial fibrillation and flutter to control the rate. The greater calcium levels will also increasing binding of Calcium to TnC and subsequent contraction (increased contractility). This is why digoxin can be used in heart failure to increase the ejection fraction.

 

B is incorrect, as mentioned above it is involved in digoxin's MoA, however it is not where digoxin inhibits

C is incorrect, these pumps are found in the gastric mucosa and pump acid into the stomach in exchange for potassium. They are directly inhibited by proton pump inhibitors such as Omeprazole

D is incorrect as this pump is 

E is incorrect, this cotransporter is inhibited by thiazide diuretics in the distal convoluted tubule and so increases the level of sodium excreted, drawing water into the urine and having the indirect effect of then lowering blood volume (hence treatment for hypertension)

Question: Calculate the z score of a baby's weight when born if they weight 3350g, the mean is 3500g and the standard deviation is 500.
Explanation:
B is the correct answer.

 

The z score is calculated by:

(baby's weight - mean weight)/standard deviation of weights

= (3350-3500)/500 = -0.3

 

Z score is the number of standard deviations an observation is away from the mean.  Using a conversion chart it can be used to find P(z) which identifies which centile the baby is in.  The centile is plotted on a growth chart to see if the baby is developing properly.

E.g. if P(z) for weight = 0.384, then they are in the 38.4% centile and are heavier than 38.4% of the population.

 

Source: Public Health tutorial

Question:
A 73 year old woman presents to the GP with a new diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. To determine her suitability for treatment with warfarin, you assess her CHADSVASC score.

She has a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg, and is currently being treated with ramipril. 

She has no previous history of stroke, vascular disease or heart failure, but does have a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. 

 

What is her score?
Explanation:
Her score would be 4, because:

  • Congestive heart failure - she doesn't have a history of HF
  • Hypertension - her blood pressure and treatment suggest she is hypertensive 
  • Age >75 - she is 73 so doesn't score for this
  • Diabetes - she has a history of diabetes so scores 1 
  • Stroke/TIA/thrombo-embolism - she hasn't got a history of stroke 
  • Vascular disease - she hasn't got a history of vascular disease
  • Age 65-74 - she scores 1 for this 
  • Sex - female scores 1 

Therefore, hypertension + age 73 + diabetes + sex = 4  

 

http://www.chadsvasc.org/

Question: A certain medical student, having struggled for form on the hockey pitch, becomes depressed. He is put on an antidepressant. However, this medical student survives off eating cheese and despite the doctor's warning he continues to eat it. After a particular bad binge he develops a terrible headache and becomes unwell. What medication is he likely to be on and what molecule is causing his symptoms?
Explanation:
This patient is suffering from the so-called 'cheese reaction' after consuming tyramine containing food whilst on a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (phenelzine). 

 

The inhibition of MOA-A means the liver can not take up and metabolise tyramine like it normally can. This causes levels in the blood to rise which causes a hypertensive crisis which causes symptoms that the foolish medical student is experiencing. 

 

Note; In reality this patient would almost certainly have not been put on MOAIs if they had been depressed as they are rarely used due to their side-effects etc

Question: You are on an SSC and your assigned role is to take a population sample and see if there is a difference in incidence of a certain disease between men and women. You set a null hypothesis which is that there is no difference between the two groups. Your alternative hypothesis is that it there is a difference. What would mean you could likely reject the null hypothesis?
OptionE: You can not reject the null hypothesis
Explanation: Taken from the Case 12 evidence based medicine workbook. Essentially the p-value indicates statistical significance and the usual value for statistical significance is 5% of 0.05, so if the p value is less than or equal to that value then the null hypothesis can be rejected.

Question: What does this ECG indicate?
OptionA: A person with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy
Explanation:
- C is the right answer. This shows an ECG of a person with asymmetric septal hypertrophy - a type of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.  -  - The ECG shows 'dagger-like' Q waves which can be seen in the lateral leads - leads 5,6 and 1 as well as the inferior leads - 2,3 and avF

 - An easy way to spot this is if the Q waves are close to/overlap each other on the ECG trace 

 - This type of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common and involves the asymmetric thickening of the septal wall. This can lead to problems such as mitral regurgitation, dynamic left ventricular outflow tract. 

 

Risk factors for people with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy dying from sudden cardiac death are:

 - family history of SCD

 - Syncope 

 - Non sustained VT

 - Septum of over 30mm

 

Any of these 2 puts a patient in a high risk catagory

 

SOURCES - Non-ischaemic Cardiomyopathies lecture + Life in the fast lane

Question:
You are concerned your patient may have hypertension after a couple high readings measured in clinic, because you think they might just a touch of 'white coat' syndrome so you decide to confirm the diagnosis with Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (non-invasive). 

You are looking at some of the hourly results whilst they were asleep think some may be abnormally high. There results are as follows:
Time   :   BP

23:00 = 128/78

00:00 = 114/72

01:00 = 110/70

02:00 = 109/68

03:00 = 119/70

04:00 = 127/78

05:00 = 138/89

06:00 = 144/93

 

How many of these reading do you think are abnormal?
Explanation:
The normal ABPM during the day should be <135/<85 and <120/<70mmHg at night. 
Levels above 140/90 during the day and/or 125/75 at night should be considered abnormal, this patient was asleep during these readings (as stated in the question) so 4 of these readings would be over normal levels. If they also had high recordings due the day they would be diagnosed with hypertension, furthermore, the results of ABPM are now considered to be superior to clinic BP recordings in predicting future cardiac events and target organ damage. 
This was covered in Case 13 lectures (sorry can't remember which one exactly!!)

Here is a nice diagram to visualize this:

Question: Asmaf and the rest of his pensioner pals have gone on a mad one and taken a stupendous amount of digoxin, as a result they are tripping balls! But not to worry, you are on the scene with the antidote, which is:
Explanation:
Digoxin is only removed by the kidneys → can lead to ADRs due to excess build up in those with renal impairment

 •Causes elderly to trip balls – as it can cross the BBB and has CNS effects, such as hallucinations and confusion

 

A: Protamine Sulphate is an antidote but for heparin not digoxin!

B: Vitamin K is an antidote but for warfarin not digoxin! 

C: Digimon was a crapper version of Pokemon in which small creatures band together to help their human friends.

D: Calbindin is a vitamin D dependent calcium binding protein 

E: Digibind is the correct answer - it is an antibody that mops up excess Digoxin

 

Taken from Coffey's lecture on Cardiac Failure Drugs in Case 15

Question: What is the B-antigen on blood cells?
Explanation:
the A antigen is n-acetyl-D-galatosamine

the B antigen is D galactose

 

(sorry probably a mean question, but it is in the blood groups in man lecture)

Question: A patient comes into the GP surgery after finding some warts on their genitalia. Which type of human papilloma virus (HPV) infection has most likely caused these warts?
Explanation:
HPV 2 (amongst other types) causes common warts

HPV 6 and 11 are the most common causes of genital warts

HPV 16 and 18 are the two types which are thought to cause most cases of cervical cancer

Question: The cardiovascular system is the first organ system that forms during embryonic development. The entire system originates from the mesoderm layer. There are 2 different mechanisms involved in the system's formation. When this process begins at around 17 days, from where does vessel development (vasculogenesis) start from?
Explanation:
The first aim in development is to provide nutrition; thus blood development starts in the yolk sac and trophoblast layer at about 17 days - the same time as somitogenesis, with the formation of mesodermal aggregates  called blood islands.

Blood islands are composed of haemoangioblasts in the extraembryonic tissues (between the trophoblast and yolk sac). These blood islands will then become the blood vessels

endodermal-mesodermal interactions are necessary for blood island formation and the fibroblast and transforming growth factors (FGF and TGF-B) play a role in the mesodermal induction.

Question: What is epigenetics?
OptionA: Genetic variant involving one nucleotide that is common
OptionC: Stable heritable modification of chromosomes without alterations in the DNA sequence
OptionD: Genome wide association study (GWAS) that test loads of SNPs across genome
Explanation:
A. definition of SNP

B. made up

D. definition of GWAS

Question: You are driving along the A470 and come across an RTA. You are first on scene, and after making the situation safe, you proceed to check for a response. Being the supreme medical student that you are, you choose to adopt the GCS scale instead of the AVPU scale. The patient is lying on the road after having been ejected through the window. They are unresponsive to voice, and when you pinch the lobe of the ear to elicit pain, their eyes open briefly. They are also seen lying with adducted arms, pronated forearms and flexed wrists. You try to talk to them but they are not making any audible sounds. When you call 999, what will you report their GCS as?
Explanation:
The CGS scale is detailed below, and the points scored for this patient in each section are in bold

 

Eye opening

4 = spontaneous

3 = to speech

2 = to pain

1 = no response

X

Verbal response

5 = oriented

4 = disoriented

3 = inappropriate words

2 = unintelligible sounds

1 = none

X

Motor response

6 = obeys commands

5 = localises to pain

4 = withdraws from pain

3 = abnormal flexion (decorticate)

2 = abnormal extension (decerebrate)

1 = no response

Question:
Bob, a 40-year-old chef, presents to A&E following an accident with a knife that has cut the lateral aspect of his neck.  You examine the wound's location and note that it is in the posterior triangle.

 

Which nerve is most likely to be damaged?
Explanation:
The accessory nerve runs through the posterior triangle of the neck, superficial to levator scapulae muscle, so this is the best answer here.

The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of vagus, that innervates the laryngeal vocal apparatus - damage can occur to this nerve in surgery on the thyroid gland, resulting in a hoarse voice.

The dorsal scapular nerve innervates levator scapulae, but does not run across its surface.

Picture from Essential Clinical Anatomy.

 

Source: Essential Clinical Anatomy and the Anatomy Practical in Case 16.

Question: Brian, a 34 year old man, comes to see you in clinic and claims he has been feeling very good in himself recently, and is worried he might be depressed. Which of the following options are the 'classic triad' of symptoms of unipolar depression that you would go on to ask Brian about?
Explanation:
The 'classic triad' of unipolar depression is;

  • Low (depressed) mood
  • Anhedonia (meaning the inability to experience pleasure from activities usually found enjoyable)
  • Fatigue/low energy

These symptoms form a depressive illness when they have become pervasive, interfere with normal functioning, or have gone on for more than 2 weeks. In unipolar depression, patients suffer from depressive episodes alone. Symptoms like irritability, suicidal thoughts, and insomnia can also certainly occur, but are not part of the 'classic triad'.

Question: Which of the following is a precursor for the monoamine serotonin?
Explanation:
• Tryptophan is a precursor to serotonin. Tryptophan --> 5-hydroxytryptophan --> 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin). This pathway can also continue on, and make melatonin. Dietary tryptophan depletion can have a depressive effect.
  • Tyrosine is a precursor to dopamine and to adrenaline/noradrenaline. Tyrosine --> L-DOPA --> Dopamine --> Noradrenaline --> Adrenaline.
  • 5-HT is another name for serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine). Serotonin receptors on the postsynaptic membrane are called 5-HT receptors, and these can be downregulated in sufferers of depression.
  • L-DOPA is part of the pathway that creates dopamine/adrenaline/noradrenaline from tyrosine.
  • Threonine is just another amino acid that doesn't really have anything to do with case 12.

Question: Which area in the heart is most likely to be the origin of aberrant electrical impulses in AF?
Explanation: Taken directly from the Case 13 wrap up, slide 12.

Question: Brenda, aged 15, has recently changed GPs and is coming to see you for the first time about her depression. Looking at her notes, you are surprised and very concerned to see that she taking a certain antidepressant at the moment, and you make sure to switch her onto a different antidepressant (with her agreement and consent). Which of the following antidepressants was it that caused you such concern?
Explanation:
• Sertraline is an SSRI, and should not be given to adolescents like Brenda, as it has been shown that adolescents can develop suicidal thoughts whilst on SSRIs. Therefore, if you saw that Brenda had been on Sertraline (or Citalopram), this would cause you concern.
  • NB: Whilst fluoxetine is also an SSRI, it is the only one of the SSRIs that is actually licensed in the UK for adolescents, as it is the only SSRI that doesn't seem to cause these suicidal thoughts. 

To be fair, you'd probably also be a bit worried if you saw she was on Amitriptyline because its a TCA so has loads of horrible side effects, but in this question the thing to pick out was the fact she was a teenager.

Question: Brian has come to see you in clinic. He is feeling pretty fed up - he has depression, and 2 months ago you prescribed him Imipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant) for this. However, Brian has been experiencing a number of side effects, including a dry mouth, tremor, constipation, urinary retention, and blurred vision. You think these side effects are due to the Imipramine blockading a certain type of receptor in Brian's body. The blockade of which of the following receptor types is causing Brian's adverse effects?
Explanation: TCAs block all of the receptors shown, but it is their blockage of muscarinic receptors that causes a dry mouth, tremor, constipation, urinary retention, and blurred vision. Their blockade of alpha-adrenergic receptors causes orthostatic hypotension, diziness, and reflex tachycardia. Their blockade of serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake transporters is their mechanism of action.

Question: Your patient, 49 year old Brenda, comes to see you. She is depressed, and was put on a monoamine oxidase inhibitor called Phenelzine just over a month ago by the psychiatrist. Brenda is complaining of seizures, palpitations, and breathlessness since starting Phenelzine. You take her blood pressure, and find that she is now hypertensive despite previously having a normal blood pressure for many years. You think it is the Phenelzine that is causing the effects, but what specific Phenelzine-related factor is causing Brenda's problems?
Explanation: Tyramine is found in foods such as meats, fish, cheese, and wine. It is normally inactivated by MAO-A in the gut, but MAO-A is blocked in the gut by people taking MAO inhibitors like Phenelzine. Therefore they are unable to degrade tyramine and it builds up. Tyramine can cause cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, stroke, and a dangerous hypertensive reaction.

Question: Patient presents with high levels of potassium and hydrogen ions in his urine. More investigations show there is an increase in renin and increase in aldosterone in the blood. What is the most likely condition?
Explanation: Most likely to be E, as this is a type of secondary hyperadosteronism.

Question: Where in the brain do noradrenergic neurons originate?
Explanation: Noradrenergic neurons originate in the locus coeruleus of the pons, of which in humans there are two (one on either side). The neurons then project extensively throughout the brain and the peripheral autonomic nervous system.

Question: Where in the brain do the serotonin neurons originate?
Explanation:
• Serotonin neurons originate within the nine raphe nuclei, each of which projects to different regions of the brain.
  • The raphe nuclei are found in the medulla, pons, and upper brainstem.
  • The medullary raphe nuclei projects to the spinal cord and brain stem, and the pons and midbrain raphe nuclei project to the thalamus, limbic system, and cortex.

Question: Which of the following is the origin of both the mesolimbic and mesocortical dopaminergic pathways in the brain?
Explanation:
• The mesolimbic and mesocortical pathways both originate in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), but the mesolimbic pathway transmits to the limbic system (via the nucleus accumbens) and the mesocortical pathway transmits to the frontal cortex.
  • The nigrostriatal pathway transmits from the substantia nigra to the striatum.
  • The tuberoinfundibular pathway transmits from the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland.

Question: Which of the following does NOT indicate Down's Syndrome?
Explanation:
Inhibin A would be elevated in a Down's pregnancy. 

There would also be decreased levels of PAPP-A.

Question: When is the first trimester combined screening carried out?
OptionE: As early in the pregnancy as possible
Explanation:
often combined with the dating scan. 

Source: Fetal anomaly screening lecture

Question: People who experience their breathing to regularly stop when they are sleeping, are said to have sleep apnoea. Obstructive sleep apnoea is more common than central sleep apnoea. What is the main difference?
OptionA:
Central sleep apnoea is when the brain's respiratory centres does not send signal to muscles that control breathing. 

Obstructive sleep apnoea is when there is upper airway obstruction
OptionB:
Central sleep apnoea is when you have daytime tiredness

Obstructive sleep apnoea is when you don't
OptionC:
Central sleep apnoea occurs once in an hour

Obstructive sleep apnoea occurs more frequently
OptionD:
Central sleep apnoea occurs in larger individuals

Obstructive sleep apnoea can happen to anyone
OptionE:
Central sleep apnoea can cause heart failure

Obstructive sleep apnoea can't
Explanation:
A) TRUE : 

central sleep apnoea: Central sleep apnea results when the brain temporarily stops sending signals to the muscles that control breathing.

The condition often occurs in people who have certain medical problems. For example, it can develop in someone who has a problem with the brainstem, which controls breathing.

Conditions that can cause or lead to central sleep apnea include:

Problems that affect the brainstem (the brainstem controls breathing) including brain infection, stroke, or conditions of the cervical spine (neck)
Parkinson disease
Obesity
Certain medicines, such as narcotic painkillers
Heart failure
If the apnea is not associated with another disease, it is called idiopathic central sleep apnea.

A condition called Cheyne-Stokes respiration can mimic central sleep apnea. This involves breathing to a variable depth, usually while sleeping.

Central sleep apnea is not the same as obstructive sleep apnea. With obstructive sleep apnea, breathing stops and starts because the airway is narrowed or blocked. But a person can have both conditions, such as with a medical problem called obesity hypoventilation syndrome.

obstructive sleep apnoea : a clinical condition in which there is intermittent and repeated upper airway collapse during sleep. This results in irregular breathing at night and excessive sleepiness during the day.

Complete apnoea is defined as a ten-second pause in breathing activity.
Partial apnoea, also known as hypopnoea, is characterised by a ten-second period in which ventilation is reduced by at least 50%.

 

B) FALSE: you can have tiredness from both

 

C) FALSE: I made this up :) 

 

D) FALSE: OSA is more common in larger individuals - obesity is a strong risk factor for OSA. It can increase pharyngeal collapsibility through mechanical effects on pharyngeal soft tissues and lung volume, and through central nervous system–acting signaling proteins (adipokines) that may affect airway neuromuscular control.

(: http://www.atsjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1513/pats.200708-137MG#.VV9QhE9Viko)

 

E) The connection between sleep apnea and heart disease is evolving very rapidly. People with cardiovascular problems such as high blood pressure, heart failure, and stroke have a high prevalence of sleep apnea. Whether sleep apnea actually causes heart disease is still unclear, but we do know that if you have sleep apnea today, the chance that you will develop hypertension in the future increases significantly.

One of the problems in defining the relationship between sleep apnea and heart disease is that people with sleep apnea often have other co-existing diseases as well.

If you treat people with high blood pressure and sleep apnea, or heart failure and sleep apnea, the measures of blood pressure or heart failure are significantly improved. There is good evidence to think there is a cause-and-effect relationship between hypertension and sleep apnea.

Question: Which of the following is the most commonly used screening test for down's in the UK?
Explanation:
In the First trimester combined screen, hCG levels, PAPP-A levels and nuchal translucency are all measured. 

 

It is the most sensitive test for down's but should be performed before 13 weeks + 6 days. 

After this time, PAPP-A levels become innaccurate. 

 

If people present later on in the pregnancy, they are offered the quadruple screen which measures: hCG, uE3, AFP and inhibin A  in the serum.

Question: Which of the following waveforms will predominate on an EEG in deep sleep (sleep stage 4)?
Explanation:
• Whilst awake and alert, beta waves predominate on an EEG.
  • When you are relaxing and not being particularly alert, alpha waves predominate.
  • In sleep stage 1, a time of drowsiness and transition ('dropping off'), a mixture of alpha and theta waves are seen.
  • In sleep stage 2, as sleep sets in properly, theta waves predominate. Short periods of fast rhythmic waves called sleep spindles may be seen, with occasional large K complexes that appear to look like the beginnings of delta waves.
  • In sleep stage 3 a mixture of theta and delta waves are seen.
  • In sleep stage 4, deep sleep, delta waves predominate. 
  • There will be 4-6 20min periods of REM sleep in a night, where fast, active beta-like waves are seen on EEG. 

NB: I don't know if we need to know this or not, I have done a question on it because it is in my learning outcomes from CBL. Please don't give me hate if you think this isn't something we'll be examined on - I'm not trying to be annoying I'm trying to help! :)

Question: Which of the following screening test results is indicative of Edward's Syndrome?
OptionA:
elevated: hCG and inhibin A

decreased: AFP, uE3 and PAPP-A

 

Increased nuchal translucency
OptionB:
Decreases: AFP, uE3 and hCG

 

Increased nuchal translucency
Explanation:
A = results for downs. Note: free hCG and PAPP-A are tested in the first trimester combined screen, whereas all hCG, uE3, inhibin A and AFP are all measure in the second trimester quadruple test. 

B = Correct

C = Neural Tube Defect

D = made it up

E = Patau's? - although both of these are found in patau's, it is not enough to make a diagnosis.

Question: Dave, a 53 year old HGV driver, has attended your GP practice today. He has come to speak with you, as being a type 1 diabetic he is unsure if he needs to inform the DVLA of his condition at the moment. Over the past year he has been finding his diabetes more difficult to control. Although he has had no severe hypos, he is becoming less aware of when he is becoming hypo, so much so that his son, Derek, now is a passenger for all of his journeys. On examination, Dave appears well with a visual acuity of 6/12 in both eyes. What would you advise Dave to do ?
OptionA: Dave's visual acuity is below the standard for driving. He must inform the DVLA.
OptionB: Dave is healthy and has experienced no severe hypos. He is safe to drive. Do not inform the DVLA.
OptionC: Dave is showing impaired awareness of becoming hypo. Inform the DVLA.
OptionD: As long as Dave has someone to recognise if he is becoming hypo and checks his blood sugar every 2 hours he is safe to drive. Do not inform the DVLA.
Explanation:
Dave is a HGV driver so falls into group 2 for drivers with type 1 diabetes by the DVLA guidance. Dave must inform the DVLA if any of the following occur:

 

- He experiences a severe hypo in the past 12 months (severe meaning that he requires assistance from another person)

- He develops impaired awareness of becoming hypo.

- He suffers severe hypoglycaemia whilst driving.

- He develops any other condition which is notifiable to the DVLA.

 

https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/313214/DIABINF.pdf

 

In this scenario, answer C is correct.

 

A visual acuity of 6/12 (without correction) is the minimum visual acuity for driving.

Question: What is the name for the type of joint that is formed between the articular processes of vertebrae?
Explanation:
The joint being referred to is the facet joints of the vertebrae which are known as zygopophyseal joints.

These joints are a form of synovial, plane joints so D is correct. Plane joints are also found between carpals (intercarpal) and tarsals (intertarsal)

A is incorrect, condyloid joints form the radiocarpal (wrist) joints, and metacarpophalangeal (knuckle) joints

B is incorrect, this type of joint is also known as a symphysis i.e. the pubic symphysis

C is incorrect, pivot joint examples include the radioulnar joints 

E is incorrect, the main joints between vertebral bodies can be described as fibrocartlilagenous joints

Question: Mick Wiltson, a 20 year old medical student has recently put on excessive weight, never feeling satisfied and is edging on obesity with his excessive eating. A lesion in what centre and location is responsible for his hyperphagia?
Explanation:
The feeding centre is located in the lateral hypothalamus.

Its stimulation causes the desire to eat.

Thus a lesion here would cause the opposite of these symptoms, and Mick would NOT experience the urge to eat, leading to rapid weight loss and starvation.

 

 

 

The satiety centre is located in the ventromedial hypothalamus.

Its stimulation causes the desire to stop eating.

Thus a lesion here would cause hyperphagia ie excessive eating, never feeling full or satisfied, leading to obesity.

Question: You are recording an ECG on Flora, a 46 year old female patient who is acutely unwell. You notice that her trace shows tall, "tented" T waves. This suggests that Flora is exhibiting which type of electrolyte imbalance?
Explanation: Hyperkalaemia causes tall "tented" T waves on an ECG.

Question: The posterior cord of the brachial plexus gives rise to two main nerves. What are they?
Furosemide exerts it's mechanism of action by binding to the NKCC membrane transporter at which part of the nephron?
Explanation: Furosemide is a loop diuretic which binds to the NKCC (Na+/K+/2Cl-) cell membrane transporter in the loop of Henle.

Question: What is the principal function of the nephron in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT)?
Explanation: In the PCT, most of the solutes initially filtered out of the blood into the filtrate in the Bowman's capsule are now selectively reabsorbed.

Question: Eric ,a 40 year old male, has come to see you at the GP surgery to talk about his results after having an ambulatory blood pressure monitor (ABPM). You tell Eric that the results show he has hypertension and that in addition to lifestyle changes you would recommend prescribing him some medication. What would be the most appropriate first line therapy for Eric?
Explanation:
According to the NICE guidelines, anyone with hypertension under the age of 55 should be offered an ACE Inhibitor (ACEI) e.g. Ramipril or an Angiotensin II Receptor Blocker (ARB) e.g. losartan unless they are of Afro-Caribbean descent where a calcium channel blocker would be more appropriate. This is also the case if they were over 55 years of age.

 

http://pathways.nice.org.uk/pathways/hypertension#path=view%3A/pathways/hypertension/antihypertensive-drug-treatment.xml&content=view-index

Question:
You are on placement taking a history from Mr King, a 65 year old male, at the GP surgery. He mentions that last week he had to go into A and E as he was experiencing palpitations and severe shortness of breath. From his notes you can see that a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation was made. He has been asked to see you as "the doctors said that I might have to go on some tablets or something." Looking at his notes you see the latest entry.

 

15/05/2015

 

PC - Severe SOB and Palpitations

 

PMH - Hypertension, Mitral Stenosis.

 

SH - Lives at home with his wife, Laura.

 

FH - None

 

DH - Ramipril

 

Based on this information, calculate Mr King's CHADSVASC score.
Explanation:
Mr King has a score of 2 due to:

 

Hypertension - indicated in his PMH and suggested by the fact that he is on Ramipril. (1)

Age = 65 (1)

 

 

Total = 2

Question: Mick Wiltson, a 20 year old medical student, went abroad during his summer of first year since he was not able to go on a "gap yah". He returned with a tattoo and is now experiencing right upper quadrant abdominal pain, loss of appetite and jaundice. Like all good medical students he received all his appropriate health care vaccinations. What is Micks most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
A - Hep A is spread via the feacal-oral route. ssRNA virus

 

B - Hep B is spread via unprotected sex, needles and blood transfusions. This could have been a possibility, however he had previously received the vaccination against Hep B as this is a vaccination provided to health care workers. ds/ssDNA

 

C - Hep C is the correct answer. Since this can be spread via infected blood and needles and is not one of the standard health care workers vaccines. ssRNA

 

D - Hep E is spread via contaminated water. ssRNA

 

E - There are no indications from his history that he is an alcoholic (yet). While this could be a possibility, his tattoo points towards Hep B or Hep C.
Tags: Abdomen, Vaccinations, Year 1 Revision, Public Health, Jaundice

Question: Mr Huang is sitting in Bangor on placement, dreaming about treatment next week. Suddenly, his consultant, shouts at him asking him to open his eyes and pay attention to the class. He then asks "Mr Huang, which of the following is a not a common side effect of iron supplements?
Explanation: correct, vomiting is not a common side effect. Case 8.

Question: "We are never ever getting back together" - (Swift, 2012). This statement refers to the inhibition of phospholamban which stops phospholamban from binding to which other cellular structure?
Explanation:
Phospholamban in its monomeric form inhibits SERCA preventing calcium reuptake from the sarcoplasm which slows the relaxation of the heart. However PKA causes phosphorylation of phospholamban forming a pentamer which can not inhibit SERCA hence allowing calcium reuptake.

Taylor Swift was therefore referring to phospholamban and SERCA.

Question: 'Cause, baby, now we got bad blood' - Swift, 2014. This statement refers to the presence of normocytic, normochromic anaemia which is most likely to be caused by which of the following?
Explanation:
Normocytic, normochromic anemia is where MCV and the colour of RBCs is normal. It is often seen in patients with chronic inflammatory conditions such as RA. E is therefore correct

A is incorrect as iron deficiency would cause microcytic and hypochromic 

B and C both cause macrocytic anaemias, specifically megaloblastic anaemias.

D is incorrect as thalassaemia causes a microcytic anaemia similar to iron-deficiency.

Question: During glycolysis, which of the following steps does the enzyme aldolase catalyse?
Explanation:
The answer is D - Aldolase catalyses Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate ---> Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate + dihyrdoxyacetone phosphate. Dihydroxyacetone phosphate is then converted to another glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate molecule.

Step A is catalysed by hexokinase.

Step B is catalysed by phosphohexose isomerase.

Step C is catalysed by phosphofructokinase-1.

Step E is catalysed by enolase.

Question: What does this histological image show?
Explanation:
This histological image shows glomerulosclerosis. It is characterized by diffuse thickening of glomerular capillary basement membranes and increased amount of mesangial matrix with mild mesangial cell proliferation (mesangial enlargement). This occurs as a microvascular complication of diabetes and can occur in both type 1 and type 2. 

 

I got the image from this link if anyone would like to have a look :) http://missinglink.ucsf.edu/lm/ids_106_dm_complications/

Question: Which of the following is least likely to be prescribed in a patient suffering from chronic back pain
Explanation:
The following is taken from the NICE guidelines which can be found here

B is correct as amitryptyline, a TCA, can be used to treat back pain unresponsive to conventional analgesia

C is correct as whilst it is not likely in most cases, if pain is severe then strong opiates could be given especially after assessment by a specialist

D is correct, weak opiates are used if paracetemol is ineffective

E is correct as NSAIDs are often the first thing prescribed if paracetemol alone is not working. If over 45 then patient should be given a PPI to reduce gastric ulcer risk.

A is incorrect as sertraline is an SSRI which NICE says explicitly should not be used to treat pain.

Question: Asmaf has been wishing for snow and it has finally come however, at a cost. Whilst running on the pavement he has slipped, tripped, and bus'up his lip! Furthermore, he has suffered some sort of diffuse axonal injury shown by the presence of antibodies to which of the following:
Explanation:
➢ Damaged axons can be seen using antibodies to beta amyloid precursor protein after head impact as a result of DAI – seen 2-3 hours post injury

 

Taken from Case 16 Plenary 1 - Functional neuroanatomy and nerve cell response to brain injury

Question: this question shows an ECG from a patient with a congenital structural heart problem. What part of the wave formation is the arrow pointing to?
Explanation: this shows Wolff parkinson white syndrome and the delta wave represents the pre-excitation of the ventricle as the impulse bypasses the AV node and uses the accessory pathway which is most often the Bundle of Kent

Question: Which of the following would you consider to not to be a cause of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy?
Explanation:
When you suspect an individual may have HCM, you need to come up with some differential diagnoses as so what else might be the cause of this HCM as it has many different causes. 

- 40-60% have a familial / genetic cause (one of which is the presence of the MYBPC3 gene and the MYH7 gene. This is autosomal dominance inheritance pattern and causes a sarcomeric protein change. You would need to take a detailed family history to form a family tree of 2/3 generations.

- 5-10% caused by syndromes, such as haemochromotosis or glycogen storage disease. This also includes obesity.

- 25-30% have unknown causes.

 

 

Digoxin would NOT be a cause of an enlarged heart, although it is a positive inotrope (makes the heart contract more strongly)

 

 

See Cardiomyopathy lecture, Case 15

Question: Many physiological changes happen to the breast during pregnancy. In this context, what are Montgomery's tubercles
Explanation: Sebaceous glands of the nipple become hypertrophied. They keep the nipple and areola moist and healthy

Question: Which method of insulin administration is has the highest risk of sepsis?
Explanation:
Intravenous administration: Insulin given intravenously has the highest risk of infection and only lasts a few mintues

 

Subcutaneous administration: Safest for long-term use and slower to act

 

Intramuscular administration: Difficult to self administer but works quickly

Question: A patient in their 5th month of pregnancy came into the emergency last night with vaginal bleeding. This event turned out to be a miscarriage. To reduce the emotional distress caused you prescribe what?
Explanation:
By 4 months of pregnancy the mother is able to make milk. The high levels of oestrogen, progesterone and hPL prevent full milk secretion. 

Having miscarried, the levels of these hormones will drop and so now the mother can lactate.

To prevent this, you need to prescribe something that would decrease the action of prolactin

Prolactin inhibiting hormone is dopamine and therefore you can give a dopamine agonist

Question: Garfield has just finished eating his favourite meal of lasagne, causing some incretins to be release from his gut. Assuming cats work in much the same way as humans, which of the following is true of GLP-1 (an incretin)?
OptionA: It is released from D cells in the small intestine
OptionB: It will increase beta-cell response by enhancing glucose-dependent insulin secretion
OptionC: It will act on the CNS, resulting in decreased satiety (sensation of satisfaction with food intake)
OptionD: It increases the rate of gastric emptying into the duodenum
OptionE: It increases postprandial secretion of glucagon from pancreatic alpha-cells
Explanation:
Correct answer is B! GLP-1 will increase beta-cell response by enhancing glucose-dependent insulin secretion

 

A: GLP-1 is actually secreted from L cells in the small intestine

C: It will act on the CNS, but increases satiety and hence reduces the intake of food

D: It decreases the rate of gastric emptying into the duodenum, so that products of food digestion enter more slowly and smoothy and hence there is less of a peak demand for insulin. This is one of the ways incretins help to reduce to beta-cell workload

E: It will decrease postprandial secretion of glucagon, which helps to maintain the counterregulatory balance between insulin and glucagon (also decreases beta-cell workload)

 

Case 10 - Slide 12 of lecture: Insulin therapy in type 1 diabetes mellitus

Question: Deficiency in which of these pituitary hormones results in decreased pigmentation?
Explanation:
Answer is D! 

 

ACTH deficiency causes decreased pigmentation. Precursor of ACTH gives rise to MSH which inhibits appetite and stimulates melanocytes causing skin pigmentation.

 

GH deficiency in childhood results in short stature, whilst in adulthood will result in abnormal body composition, reduced muscle mass, reduced well-being and reduced performance

 

FSH deficiency will result in infertility

 

TSH deficiency will result in hypothyroidism

 

Vasopressin (ADH) deficiency results in diabetes insipidus 

 

Case 10 - Lecture: Key principles in the anatomy and physiology of the endocrine system

Question: Which transporters are used to transport fructose into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen?
Explanation:
SGLT1 and GLUT2 are used in combination when there is a high glucose concentration in the intestinal lumen. 

GLUT 2 is usually on the basal membrane of enterocytes.

GLUT5 is rather specific to fructose

Question:
A 45 year old woman  comes to the GP surgery complaining of excessive sweating, palpitations, weight loss and fatigue. You decide that she probably has some form of thyroid disorder so you send her away to have some thyroid blood tests. The results come back as:

  • Serum TSH: Low
  • Serum free T4: Normal
  • Serum T3: High

What is the most likely diagnosis
Explanation:
Correct answer is D!

 

A: Hypothyroidism secondary to pituitary disease: TSH low/normal, T4 low, T3 low/normal

B: Primary hyperthyroidism: TSH low, T4 high, T3 high

C: Euthyroid sick syndrome: TSH normal/low, T4 normal, T3 low

D: CORRECT, Hyperthyroidism with T3 toxicosis: TSH low, T4 normal, T3 high

E: Primary hypothyroidism: TSH high, T4 low, T3 low/normal
Tags: Endocrine, Thyroid Gland, Case 10, Pituitary Gland, Hormones

Question: A 25-year old female patient was diagnosed with Crohn's disease 1 month ago; it is active and classed as mild to moderate. What drug has she most likely been prescribed?
Explanation:
Anti TNF drugs- prescribed for severe Crohn's/ severe UC

Azathioprine- more likely used in the maintenance of remission of Crohn's and UC 

Budesonide- used in the treatment of mild/moderate Crohn's 

Ciclosporin- used in the treatment of UC 

Mesalazine- used in the treatment of mild to moderate UC 

 

Reference: IBD lecture Case 11

Question: Brenda's heart is beating healthily in sinus rhythm. Action potentials in her ventricular cardiomyocytes occur in a number of phases. In which of these phases do the L-type calcium channels close, whilst the potassium channels do not, meaning that K+ efflux continues?
Explanation:
To begin with there is high K+ intracellularly (150mM) and high Na+ extracellularly (145mM). 

  • Phase 0 - There is a rapid influx of Na+ into the cell, causing depolarization to about +52mV.
  • Phase 1 - K+ channels open and there is some efflux of potassium out of the cell, so there is a slight drop in membrane potential. Na+ channels have deactivated.
  • Phase 2 - L-type calcium channels open and there is some influx of Ca2+ into the cell, balancing the efflux of K+ and causing a plateau.
  • Phase 3 - L-type calcium channels close but the potassium channels do not, so efflux of K+ continues and repolarization occurs.
  • Phase 4 - Inward rectifying K+ channels stabilize the resting membrane potential at -90mV.

Question: Brian's heart is beating in healthy sinus rhythm. There are some times when his ventricular cardiacmyocytes are in their effective refractory periods. Over which phases of the ventricular cardiomyocte action potential does this occur?
Explanation:
• The effective refractory period (ERP) occurs across phases 0, 1, and 2.
  • During the ERP a new action potential cannot be initiated, and the cell cannot fire again.
  • In phase 3, the cell can activate again if the stimulus is great enough.

http://www.pathophys.org/physiology-of-cardiac-conduction-and-contractility/actionpotential/  Good diagram of the ventricular cardiac action potential for anyone wanted a refresher :)

Question: You are driving along the M4 eager to start your 3rd FY2 rotation at Newport. Suddenly you witness a multi-car pile up occur in front of you. After a mini fist pump because the BMA have negotiated that the first doctor at an RTC has the right to charge £21 per casualty treated, you asses the danger. After concluding it is safe for you to approach the scene on foot you scan for casualties. Which of these casualties would you attend first?
OptionA: 19 year old woman sitting in a car weeping
OptionB: 30 year old man lying on the floor with an obvious compound fracture
OptionC: 16 year old girl with a puncture wound in the thigh and bleeding perfusly
OptionD: 87 year old man in a car unconscious
OptionE: 26 year old woman screaming in hysterics at the side of the road
Explanation:
Obviously there is a moral dilemma between the young girl and older man. 

Our first aid training states that the order of treatment is 

 

Breathing

Bleeding

Bones

and then any other injuries 

 

Therefore you must go and asses the unconscious casualty for breathing. 

It is common for young people to be placed in a higher triage catagory than necessary and older patients to placed to low.

Question: During glycolysis, what is the net gain of NADH and ATP from a single molecule of glucose?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C - 2 x NADH and 2 x ATP.

The inputs into glycolysis are 1xglucose, 2xNAD+, 2xATP and 4xADP.

The outputs are 2xpyruvate, 2xNADH, 2xADP and 4xATP.

Because 2 ATP molecules are put in and 4 ATP molecules are produced, the net gain is 2 ATP.

Question:
A 16 year old boy is admitted to A&E with a suspected overdose of Theophylline (they normally take this for their asthma). On admission, their serum Theophylline is 30mg/L. 

 

On checking the BNF, you find that Theophylline has a clearance of 0.045L/kg/hour. 

 

The patient weighs 70kg. How much Theophylline will be removed in 24 hours?
Explanation:
Clearance in 24 hours = 0.045 (rate of clearance) x 24 (hours) x 70 (kg) = 75.6 litres would be cleared in 24 hours for this patient. 

 

If 75.6 L is cleared in 24 hours, the amount of drug cleared = 75.6 x 30mg = 2268mg

 

Alternatively, may be quicker to just calculate:

Amount removed = (0.045 x 24 x 70 x 30)

Question:
A patient is being given Pilocarpine eye drops 0.5% for their glaucoma. 

How much drug is contained in 1 drop if each 1mL contains 20 drops?
Explanation:
0.5% = 0.5g per 100mL = 500mg in 100mL or 5mg in 1mL (just remember that 1% = 1g/100mL)

1mL contains 20 drops, and so 20 drops contains 5mg.

 

Therefore, (5/20)mg in 1 drop = 0.25mg = 250μg

Question: which of the following arteries supplies the brainstem?

You are an FY2 on duty in UHW A&E. Brenda O'Brian, aged 36, has come in complaining of palpitations and pre-syncope, following severe diarrhea and vomiting. Brenda rarely comes to A&E or sees her GP. You carry out an ECG and see a prolonged QT interval and a notched T wave and admit her, worried that she may have a repolarization abnormality. Give her history, what is the most likely cause of her repolarization abnormality?
Explanation:
• Given her history of severe diarrhea and vomiting, hypokalaemia would be at the forefront of your mind in terms of causing her repolarisation abnormality. 
  • VW class III drugs are K+ channel blockers, so can cause repolarisation abnormalities via acquired long QT syndrome, and idopathic long QT syndrome could also explain her situation. However, these would be likely to be further down your list given her history, and also given the fact that she rarely visits her GP so the chances of her having a long term heart condition requiring K+ channel blocker treatment or constant monitoring like long QT syndrome are lower. 
  • Torsade de Pointes is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, and patients with repolarisation abnormalities can degenerate into TDP. TDP can lead to v fib, cardiac arrest, and death, so is what you'd be worried about preventing in Brenda's case.
  • Research has shown that old MIs can precipitate repolarisation abnormalities, but this is not one of factors mentioned in the lecture as a key point. Also, as she's only 36 the chances of her having a previous MI are lower.

Question:
Kanye West is getting a bit too hyped on a rant about world domination and tears his sternocleidomastoid in the process.

 

What nerves will transmit his pain? ( even though Kanye does not feel pain)
Explanation:
spinal accessory is motor innervation for SCM and C2 and C3 nerve fibres transmit proprioception and pain for the SCM.

 

Sources are from essential clinical  and case 16 anatomy practical.

Question:
Lets say that brown fur colouring is dominant to grey fur colouring in mice. If you have 168 brown mice in a population of 200 mice.

What is the predicted frequency of heterozygotes?

(To 2 significant figures throughout the question if needed).
Explanation:
Full disclosure, completely stole this question from this website because it caught be out: http://www.indiana.edu/~l111/handouts/hardy.htm (Q3).

 

Start with what you know -- if 168 out of 200 are brown, that means 32 mice must be grey. There are only two phenotypes (three genotypes). So the first step is to determine q2.

 

Why don't you start with p2 since I given you the frequency of the dominant phenotype?

Think about it -- you have two different genotypes that can give you the dominant phenotype. Homozygous dominant and heterozygotes.

 

So the frequency of the dominant phenotype would be:

frequency of dominant phenotype = p2 + 2pq

You can't solve for p, if both p and q are unknown. So solve for q first -

q2 = (32/200) = 0.16

q = 0.4

p = 1 - (0.4) = 0.6

What is the predicted frequency of heterozygotes?

2pq = 2 (0.6)(0.4) = 0.48

 

A good way of checking you've worked it out correctly is by putting your figures for p and q back into the good ol' Hardy Weinberg equation and checking that it equals 1. 

 

(Also, sorry for it not making the numbers about medicine, I didn't want to pick a dominant disease and have someone comment with actual facts about it).

Question:
You are asked to give a baby an antibiotic suspension for a chest infection. 

She weighs 15kg and has been prescribed a dose of 7.5mg/kg/day for 7 days. It is given as 3 injections a day, and the strength of the suspension is 250mg in 5mL.

What dosage should you put on the medicine label?
Explanation:
The individual dose needed is (15 x 7.5)mg / 3 = 37.5mg 

 

The strength is 250mg in 5mL, which could also be thought of as 25mg in 0.5mL (simply divided by 10) 

 

37.5mg can be divided into 25mg and 12.5mg to make it easier to 'split up' the solutions, i.e. the dose is 0.5mL (containing 25mg) and 0.25mL (containing 12.5mg):

0.5mL + 0.25mL = 7.5mL 

 

Alternatively, once you have worked out the strength and individual dose, you could use:

(5 x 37.5) / 250 = 0.75 

I've done this by cross multiplying (250/5) = (37.5/X)

Question: The carnitine shuttle is responsible for transferring Acyl-CoA molecules through the mitochondrial membrane to be used in beta-oxidation. Which of the following enzymes is responsible for combining an Acyl-CoA molecule with a carnitine molecule, so that it can be transferred across the mitochondrial membrane?
Explanation:
The answer is C - Carnitine acyltransferase I combines a carnitine molecule and an Acyl-CoA molecule so that they can be shuttled across the mitochondrial membrane.

Enolase is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, that is not involved in beta-oxidation.

Acyl-CoA synthetase is involved in converting fatty acids into Acyl-CoA molecules.

Carnitine acyltransferase II breaks down Acyl-carnitine into Acyl-CoA and carnitine, once it has been transferred across the mitochondrial membrane.

Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in the beat-oxidation cycle, but it doesn't have a role in the carnitine shuttle.

 

Found this video really helpful in explaining the carnitine shuttle and beta-oxidation cycle - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f8x0VlziGm4

Question: Which of these muscles of the larynx are involved in opening of the airway ( rima glottidis)? ohh rima
Explanation:
Posterior circo-atytenoid, abducts vocal cords

 

B- D Adduct vocal cords - innervated by internal recurrent laryngeal

 

Vocalis - relaxes the posterior ligament

 

Page 613 Essential clinical anatomy, Question is from Case 16 anatomy practical

Question: The ginger bearded medical student is on placement.  His consultant gets him to take a history of a patient who has IBD and is in remission - therefore is on drugs to maintain this remission.  What drug is used to maintain remission in both forms of IBD?
Explanation:
The correct answer is azathioprine - an immunosuppressant.

A - is a 'new biology' involving the suppression of cytokine TNF.

C - is a local corticosteroid that is used for mild to mod Crohns.

D - used in severe UC and Crohn's.

E - a 5-aminosalicylic acid used for mild to mod UC.

Question: Brian comes to see you in clinic. He has recently been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. His episodes of AF last for around 24 hours at a time, and his ventricular rate during episodes is approximately 70bpm. What type of AF does Brian have?
Explanation:
AF can be divided into three categories;

  1. Paroxysmal - episodes last <48 hours
  2. Persistent - episodes last >48 hours but <1 week
  3. Permanent - the patient is constantly in AF all the time

Within these categories AF can further be described as;

  • Fast - ventricular rate is approximately 140bpm
  • Rate controlled - ventricular rate is approximately 70bpm
  • Slow - ventricular rate is <60bpm

Question: A patient on a ward complains of muscle cramping which is becoming so bad they're fingers and wrists are constantly contracting. Upon examination they appear to have hyperexcitability of the nerves and their wrists are locked in a flexed position. Blood tests are ordered as a low level of which ion is suspected?
Explanation:
This patient is exhibiting the classic signs of tetany which is essentially maintained muscular contractions with hyperexcitability of nerves. The primary cause of tetany is hypocalcaemia i.e. Ca2+ less than 2.2mmol/L. This is mentioned in the calcium homeostasis and bone lecture of Case 14. 

 

Wikipedia explains why tetany occurs in hypocalcaemia

 

"Low calcium levels in the extracellular fluid increase the permeability of neuronal membranes to sodium ions, causing a progressive depolarization, which increases the possibility of action potentials. This occurs because calcium ions interact with the exterior surface of sodium channels in the plasma membrane of nerve cells. When calcium ions are absent the voltage level required to open voltage gated sodium channels is significantly altered (less excitation is required). If the plasma Ca2+ decreases to less than 50% of the normal value of 9.4 mg/dl, action potentials may be spontaneously generated, causing contraction of peripheral skeletal muscles"

Question: Which of the following statements concerning MRI is correct?
OptionA:
T1: fat is bright, water is dark

T2: fat is dark, water is bright
OptionB:
T1: fat is bright, water is bright

T2: fat is bright, water is dark
OptionC:
T1: fat is dark, water is dark

T2: fat is bright, water is bright
OptionD:
T1: fat is bright, water is dark

T2: fat is bright, water is bright
OptionE:
T1: fat is dark, water is bright

T2: fat is bright, water is dark
Explanation:
T1: fat is bright, water is dark, good for anatomy

T2: fat is bright, water is bright, good for pathology

 

See Case 11, Small + Large Bowel Imaging

Question: Buscopan...
OptionA: Is a laxative; used for bowel preparation
OptionB: Is an antispasmodic; stops peristalsis, preventing blurred images
OptionC: Is an oral bulking agent; distends the small bowel and acts as a contrast
OptionD: Is an anti-inflammatory drug; used to treat Crohn's disease
OptionE: Is an anti-diarrhoeal drug; used to prevent diarrhoea
Explanation: C describes Kleanprep

Question: B7 Biotin deficiency is very rare in the human body.  This is because a specific part of the body produces an excess of the body's requirement.  Which part of the body does this?
Explanation:
This was in the Fundamentals of Nutrition lecture in case 11.

Biotin is needed as a coenzyme for fatty acid and leucine metabolism, and is needed for gluconeogenesis and cell growth.

Its deficiency (very rare) causes hair loss, red rashes, depression, lethargy, hallucinations.

Question:
A man presents at A&E after a car accident. The paramedic tells you that he has suffered from a contrecoup injury, but is GCS 15 and his pain is being managed. 

 

You immediately notice that the patient has tilted their head down and towards the left. When you ask the patient, he tells you that he has double vision, but when he tilts his head the double vision seems to subside. 

 

Upon neurological examination, his right eye is unable to look downwards when asked, and struggles to abduct. 

 

What nerve has he damaged?
Explanation:
This is trochlear nerve palsy. 

 

It causes weakness/paralysis of the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for intorsion, depression and abduction of the eyeball (explaining his inability to perform those extraocular movements). 

 

It often causes vertical double vision as the weakened muscle prevents the eyes from moving simultaneously. To compensate for the double-vision, patients characteristically tilt their head down and to the side opposite the affected muscle:

(http://www.residencynotes.com/2011/10/trochlear-nerve/ - picture)

 

Because the trochlear nerve is thin and has the longest intracranial course of the cranial nerves, it is particularly vulnerable to trauma. It can also be a congenital problem. 

 

Sources - https://meded.ucsd.edu/clinicalmed/neuro2.htm 

http://www.neuroanatomy.wisc.edu/cn/cntable.htm
Tags: Anatomy, Cranial nerves, Trauma, Eye, Case 16

Question:
Asmaf retires from professional football and ends up eating pies and chewits all day whilst lying in bed. His BMI balloons up to 37.2 and he becomes barely recognisable, looking somewhat similar to Israel Kamakawiwoʻole. 

 

Compared to his housemate Mike Chang, whose BMI is 22.5, how many more times is Asmaf likely to develop Type II diabetes?
Explanation:
 Four major determinants are:
1. Increasing age
2. Obesity
• Increases risk 80-100 fold
• BMI > 35 is 93.2 times greater chance than BMI < 22.5
• Western diet high in saturated fats, sugar and red meat
3. Ethnicity
• 2-4x more prevalent in South Asian, African and Caribbean people living in the UK
• High risk in middle eastern/Latin/Hispanic Americans
4. Genetics
• If one identical twin has diabetes, chance of the other developing type II diabetes is > 90%.
• Risk to non-identical twins in 25%-50%
• Polygenic disorder; most of genes involved are linked to beta-cell function. TCF7L2 allele ↑ risk of type II diabetes by 1.5times

Question: in the lungs the mucous layer provides a sticky surface for participants. The serous glands secretion the watering component are under parasympathetic control. Which receptor does the ACh released stimulate?
Explanation:
M3 receptors are stimulated. This brings about an increase in intracellular Ca2+ , followed by Cl- leaving. water follows the Cl- thus creating the mucous. This net movement of Cl- from the interstitium to the lumen is the prime regulating factor promoting fluid secretion

 

(Cl- enters the epithelial cells via a co transporter also carrying Na and K. Cl- then enter then lumen through a regulated Cl- channel activating a second messagener system--> get cAMP activity switching on kinase which phosphorylates the Cl- channel so that it opens)

Question: Which part of the intestine is most likely to be affected by ulcerative colitis?
Explanation: Ulcerative colitis is a diffuse mucosal inflammation limited to the colon. It almost always affects the rectum, and it may extend proximally in a symmetrical, uninterrupted pattern to involve all or part of the large intestine.

Question: Brenda suffers from a re-entrant tachycardia, and has been taking a VW class I drug as part of her treatment for this. She is experiencing some unpleasant side effects, particularly drowsiness, disorientation, and convulsions. Which subtype of VW class I drug must she be taking to experience these side effects?
OptionD: All of the above - these are general VW class 1 side effects
OptionE: None of the above - these are not side effects you would commonly see with any VW class I drug no matter the subtype
Explanation:
• VW class Ia drugs can cause blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation, and urinary retention.
  • VW class Ib drugs can cause drowsiness, disorientation, and convulsions because they can act on the CNS.
  • VW class Ic drugs have been associated with ventricular fibrillation if given after an MI, which can often lead to sudden death.
  • Some general VW class I drug side effects include; diarrhea, nausea, headache, and dizziness.

Question:
Afferents in neural reflexes to the mucous layer of the lungs are stimulated by irritating stimuli or inflammation. Reflexes may go through the CNS or only in airway walls.

Which description best fits the sympathetic regulation of serous glands in the respiratory tract?
OptionA:
alpha-1 adrenergic stimulates secretion

Beta-2 adrenergic inhibits secretion
OptionB:
Alpha 1 adrenergic stimulates secretion

beta 1 adrenergic stimulates secretion
OptionC:
alpha 1 adrenergic inhibits secretion

beta 2 adrenergic inhibits secretion
OptionD:
alpha 1 adrenergic inhibits secretion 

beta 2 adrenergic stimulates secretion
OptionE:
Alpha 1 adrenergic stimulates secretion
beta 2 adrenergic stimulates secretion
Explanation:
sympathetic regulation is very weak but has these actions. The sympathetic pathway is mainly there to moderate PNS

 

 

M1-Rs increase preganglionic transmission

M2-Rs reduce further ACh release from nerve endings

M3 -Rs stimulate airway smooth muscle contraction

Question: Frusemide acts on which part of the nephron to achieve it's diuretic effect?
Explanation: Inhibits NaCl reabsorption in the loop of Henle and causes more potent diuresis than other diuretics and can be used in patients with reduced renal function. Loop diuretics are used in moderate to severe heart failure. Side effects include deafness at high doses as well as those of thiazide diuretics being hypokalaemia, hyperuricaemia, hypercholesterolaemia and hyperglycaemia

Question:
A 68 year old female presents with thoracic back pain which started about 3 weeks ago. It is now so severe that she cannot attend her job, where she works in an office. 

She has a 20 pack year smoking history.

No history of malignancy or neurological symptoms. 

This is her X-ray:

 

What do you suspect is wrong with her?
Explanation:
Risk factors which indicated this woman for an X-ray: >50yrs with new onset pain and thoracic pain. 

The X-ray shows a winking pedicle at the left L1 level (See: http://radiopaedia.org/cases/winking-owl-sign) which is almost always a sign of a bony metastasis. 

Possibility that this woman's primary tumour is in her lung due to her smoking history as the most common sites are breast and lung however this cannot be decided without further investigation obviously. 

B - Osteosaroma is the most common primary bone tumour in the spine (in bony tissue as opposed to in the bone marrow). 

C - She could have postural back pain due to her office job however this is more likely to be lumbar rather than thoracic.

D - There is nothing in the history which would indicate an infection. 

E - symptomatic thoracic disc prolapses are less common than those related to the lumbar region and it would be likely to come on very rapidly due to trauma rather than over 3 weeks.

Question: You are on the wards and hear staff discussing a patients ecg tracing, whole listening in you just catch the words ‘irregularly irregular’, given this what is your initial thought at the most likely rhythm the ecg shows?
Explanation: Atrial fibrillation I characterised by a lack of coordinated atrial activity resulting in the atria rippling and not contributing towards ventricular filling. This effects ventricular activity producing the characteristically irregularly irregular pulse (irregular rhythm with no detectable pattern to the irregularity)

Question: What is the difference between ARTERIOSCLEROSIS and ATHEROSCLEROSIS
OptionA: Arteriosclerosis describes the widening lumen of the arteries, atherosclerosis involves the formation of an atheroma
OptionB: Arteriosclerosis describes the hardening and thickening of the arteries, atherosclerosis involves the formation of an atheroma
OptionC: Arteriosclerosis describes the hardening and thickening of the arteries, atherosclerosis involves the formation of an increased vessel luminal diameter due to chronic hypertension
OptionD: Arteriosclerosis describes the hardening and thickening of the arteries, atherosclerosis involves the formation of a thrombotic infarct in a major vessel
OptionE: Arteriosclerosis describes the torsion of the spiral arteries occurring before menstruation while atherosclerosis refers to the formation of a thrombotic infarct in a major vessel
Explanation: Arteriosclerosis involves the hardening and thickening of the arterial walls resulting in a loss of their elastic properties. Atherosclerosis is one of the processes that contributes to arteriosclerosis and involves the formation of an atheroma which is an accumulation of lipid plaques within the vessel wall. Although this process predisposes to a thrombotic event it itself refers to the plaque formation. Arteriosclerosis of the small arteries and arterioles is termed arteriolosclerosis and is mainly due to hypertension. Arteriosclerosis results in a reduced arterial lumen resulting is decreased tissue perfusion in addition to this due to the loss of elasticity rupture is increasingly likely to occur and there is a predisposition to thrombus formation.

Question: Which of the following is a function of parasympathetic innervation of the lung?
Explanation:
The three functions of Parasympathetic innervation of the lung are:

  1. bronchoconstriction
  2. vasodilation
  3. mucous gland and goblet cell secretion

Question:
A patient presents to their GP with a cough with sputum. 

They are a smoker.

With this information, what colour would the sputum have to be for you to be pretty certain they had bronchitis
Explanation:
Cigaret smoke decreases ciliary motley, directly damaging the epithelium causing inflammation. You get hypertrophy of mucous glands with an increased number of goblet cells. So basically your body makes more mucous and is unable to get rid of that mucous. Therefore increasing the chance of infection, increasing inflammation, blocking airways and causing a cough.

The Green colour is due to a protein in neutrophils

Question:
Yellow flag symptoms of back pain are the psycho-social factors which affect how someone deals with their pain. 

Which of the following is NOT a yellow flag symptom in back pain?
OptionA: A negative attitude that back pain is harmful.
OptionC: A belief that treatment will be passive.
Explanation:
These are from the Spinal Trauma lecture from Spine Dragon yellow flag symptoms are:

Of course, recent unemployment could cause some of these factors, for example financial problems or low morale but unemployment is not a yellow flag in itself.

Question: Which cytokine is released due to the effects of smoking. It is involved in the damaged epithelia and is released by macrophages, CD4 and NK cells as well as some others
Explanation:
In Emphysema for example;

  • TNF alpha is released, negatively effecting epithelia.
  • This causes an increase in monocytes.
  • neutrophils release elastase.
  • elastase degrades elastic tissue and alveolar sacs
  • this reduces recoil which is needed to keep the small air tubes open

this leads to:

  • hyperinflation of the alveoli
  • destruction of alveolar walls
  • destruction of alveolar capillary walls
  • loss of lung elasticity

Question: DHA is an omega-3 fatty acid. DHA deficiency can occur in pregnancy- how will DHA deficiency most likely affect the baby?
OptionD: Development of cardiovascular disease in the future
Explanation:
Bigger babies associated with gestational diabetes 

Decreased lower limb blood flow, vasoconstriction, fatty liver, reduced size of pancreas and B-cells, GH resistance, decreased renal blood flow and impaired ketogenesis are all associated with IUGR 

Development of cardiovascular disease and growth restriction are associated with large consumption of trans fats in pregnancy
