Question: What is the name of the mineral which makes up the majority of the bone (approximately 70%) at a cellular level?
Explanation: Hydroxyapatite is the main component of the inorganic material making up the composition of bone at a cellular level. Hydroxyapatite is largely made up of calcium, but also phosphorus and oxygen.

Question: You are in a musculoskeletal clinic where you get talking to Mr Harris, a 34 year old male. He has come in with a rotator cuff injury where he has injured one of the muscles. Which muscle listed below could he have injured?
Explanation:
Rotator Cuff Muscles - SITS

 

Supraspinatus
Infraspinatus
Teres Minor
Subscapularis

Question: You are performing a lower limb neurological examination on a patient in clinic. You place a wisp of cotton wool just inside the patients knee to assess their sensory distirbution for soft touch. What dermatome are you testing?
Explanation: L3 is inside the knee.

Question: You've been asked to examine Mr Gregory's hands. You notice pronounced muscle wasting in the hypothenar eminence with reduced sensation over the medial one and a half digits in his right hand. What nerve is most likely affected?
Explanation: Ulnar Nerve - innervates all muscles in hand (except the LOAF muscles), innervates hypothenar eminence, sensory distribution = medial one and a half digits.

Question: the positive symptoms of schizophrenia are caused by:
OptionA: an increase in dopamine in the mesocortical pathway
OptionB: an increase in dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway
OptionC: a decrease in dopamine in the mesocortical pathway
OptionD: a decrease in dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway
Explanation:
positive Sx are caused by an increase in the mesolimbic pathway

negative Sx are caused by a decrease in the mesocortical pathway

Question: You have been working with a suicidal patient with schizophrenia for a while now and have found that you need to prescribe them an antipsychotic. Which one would you give them?
Explanation: Clozapine is the only drug recommended for suicidal patients. It is also commonly thought to work best, though has lots of side effects like rare but fatal bone marrow suppression and it has also been linked to metabolic syndome

Question: You are on the neuro ward where you're introduced to Mr Phillips, a 23 year old male. You've been asked to test his ankle jerk reflex. What nerve roots does this reflex test ?
Explanation:
Reflexes - Count from 1-7

 

Ankle - S1, S2

Knee - L3, L4

Biceps - C5

Brachioradialis - C6

Triceps - C7

Question: The primary gatekeepers to the sick role in modern society are:
Explanation:
Question taken from Chronic Illness 1 sociology workbook 

 

I'm not 100% sure what the definition of a gate keeper is but I think it is this:

A health care professional, usually a primary care physician or a physician extender, who is the patient's first contact with the health care system and triages the patient's further access to the system.

Question: Mrs Tibbles, and 87 year old lady suddenly develops severe hypertension and progressive deterioration of renal function. You are concerned she may have renal artery stenosis. Which of these imaging methods is the 'gold standard' in imaging renal arteries?
Explanation:
Digital subtraction angiography = Intra-arterial method provides gold standard; intravenous approach lacks adequate resolution. This method requires contrast agents (may reduce GFR). (See table in Tims Fluid and electrolyte balance in HF lecture, also quick google search reports this method as gold standard but also most invasive.)

 

Spiral CT angiography = good 3D images, uses IV contrast (often high volumes needed)

 

Magnetic resonance angiography = avoids contrast agent, accurate only for main (proximal) vessels, expensive, limited availability 

 

Renal artery Doppler - ultrasound scan = operator dependent; variable sensitivity/specificity 

 

Radionuclide renography with captopril = poor anatomical resolution but sensitive detection of functional stenosis via GFR effects

 

 

 

Case 15 - Tim's Fluid and electrolyte balance in HF lecture
Tags: Investigations, Cardiology, Case 15, Heart, Heart failure

Question:
You are a GP in a surgery in Cardiff. Your next appointment has been booked in advance by Mrs Mears. Mrs Mears is a 35-year-old primigravida, in early pregnancy.

 

Mrs Mears is very health-conscious. She has never smoked, doesn't drink, eats a diet of mainly green vegetables and exercises regularly. As this is her first pregnancy, and she only plans to have one, she is very keen for nothing to go wrong.

 

Mrs Mears enters your office and drops onto your desk a rather formidable set of papers. She explains that she has recently had a private work-up of various blood tests and other diagnostic procedures, and wants to discuss the results with you. She is otherwise fit and well.

 

Of the various tests, these are the results that you take a close look at:

 

Fasting blood glucose      4.2 mmol/L

HbA1c                      27 mmol/mol

Haemoglobin                105                (Normal > 105)

Mean cell volume           90 fl              (Normal 80 - 100)

Serum ferritin             16 mg/L            (Normal > 15)

B12                        195 pg/mL          (Normal 200 - 900)

Blood type (of mother)     A -

Blood type (of father)     O +

Nuchal Translucency        1.3 mm

 

Based on these results (and the limited time you have), what should you be most concerned about?
Explanation:
Mrs Mears' mean cell volume is normal for women who are not pregnant, but in pregnancy a score of less than 105 is considered anaemic, and may need iron supplementation, or diet modification.

 

B12 levels are lower than normal, but this is common in pregnancy, where detectable levels fall. It might be worth to keep monitoring her B12, but a more iron-rich diet such as fish will probably increase it anyway.

 

Her rhesus type is negative, and her husband's is positive, so there is a chance that her baby is also positive. This could carry a risk of rhesus incompatibility if there were a triggering event. But no such event has occurred yet, and she does not plan to have a second baby.

 

Her blood glucose and HbA1c are within normal ranges (fasting glucose 3.9-5.5, HbA1c 20-41), so there is no indication of gestational diabetes.

 

The nuchal translucency test was below 3.5 mm. She is also relatively young, so has a low risk of a child with Down Syndrome.

Question: which dopamine receptor activates Adenylyl cyclase?
Explanation:
D1 and 5 are Gs coupled and therefore activate AC. this causes mainly post-synaptic inhibition

 

D2,3 and 4 are all Gi/Go coupled and therefore inhibit AC. they activate K+ channels and inhibit Ca2+ channels. this causes pre and post synaptic inhibition.

Question:
You've been asked to take a wound swab from Miss Evans a 22 year old patient. After figuring out how to twist the cap off of the sterile container you take the swab and send it to the lab. The following results are sent back to you:

 

Gram Stain - Positive

Catalase Test - Positive

Coagulase Test - Positive

 

Which of the following is the most likely organism detected by the wound swab ?
Explanation:
Staphylococcus aureus is a common organism present as part of the natural skin flora. It can be determined as the cause from the results given as:

 

Gram Stain - Gram positive organisms include Staphylococcus and Streptococcus. Gram negative organisms include: E-coli and Pseudomonas. This rules out A and B

 

Catalase Test (differentiates between staphylococcus and streptococcus) - Positive - staphylcoccus. Negative - streptococcus. This rules out E.

 

Coagulase Test (differentiates between staph aureus and epidermidis) - Positive - staph aureus. Negative - staph epidermidis

 

I realise this is quite a specific question but we did cover microbiology and the tests used in case 2. These questions also seem to come up in progress tests too. Hope this helps :)
Tags: Year 1 Revision, Case 2, Progress tests, ISCE

Question: What is the greatest factor which influences the likelihood of developing degenerative disc disease?
Explanation:
Degenerative Disc Disease has a strong genetic predisposition however is a multifactorial disease with other factors influencing the likelihood of developing it including:

 

Lifestyle factors - diet, exercise and smoking history.

Age

Previous injury e.g. trauma with mechanical loading

 

Case 14

Question:
Mrs Ross is a 28 year old pregnant woman who has been involved in a car crash. She has lost a lot of blood and is in need of transfusion. There is little detailed information available about her past medical history, but her husband explains that she has been healthy since they met and that her blood type is B-.

 

He knows this for certain as they have both been tested by their doctor to determine risk of rhesus incompatibility. The baby's blood type is unknown, but the husband points out that his own blood type is A+.

 

Which blood is suitable for transfusion? And what, if any, treatment should she be given for rhesus incompatibility?
OptionB:
Methylene blue B- blood. 

 

No treatment for rhesus incompatibility required.
OptionE:
Normal B- blood.

 

No treatment for rhesus incompatibility required.
Explanation:
As the patient is pregnant and her CMV status is unknown, CMV-negative blood should be given. She isn't immunodeficient, so doesn't require irradiated stock. And methylene blue stock is frozen plasma, so wouldn't replace any cells.

 

As the mother is rhesus negative and father is positive, there is above 50% chance that the baby is positive, and there is definite risk of rhesus incompatibility after a sensitising event such as a car crash. Anti-D antibodies are given pretty commonly, so are definitely a good idea here.
Tags: Blood Groups, Case 12, Haematology, blood supply, Pregnancy

Question: In the bone remodeling cycle, which of the following works to break down and reabsorb bone following strain or fracture?
Explanation:
• Osteoclasts are involved in bone breakdown and absorption
  • Osteoblasts are involved with bone formation and synthesis
  • Osteocytes are cells derived from osteoblasts, and are involved in the initiation of bone remodeling
Tags: Spine, Case 14, Year 1 Revision, year 1, Bone

Question: Jenny, an 83 year old grandmother has a fall in her home and is admitted to A and E with a suspected neck of femur fracture. An x-ray is taken and it is also noted that Jenny has reduced bone mineral density suggesting an underlying diagnosis of osteoporosis. Which subsequent test would confirm this diagnosis?
Explanation:
The first presentation of osteoporosis is typically after a fracture has been sustained. It is typically seen in post-menopausal women and is where there is a reduced bone mineral density. Jenny's diagnosis of osteoporosis would be confirmed by a DEXA (dual energy x-ray absorpitometry) scan where a T score could be calculated. 

 

A CT scan and X-rays are able to show osteopenia (reduced mineral density) but will not diagnose osteoporosis.

Serum blood levels may be able to indicate whether calcium is being resorbed into the blood showing an imbalance in bone metabolism and turnover but do not give and indication of bone quality.

 

Case 14 Wrap Up - Formative SBA Question

Question: Emily comes to see you following a recent fracture. You X ray the fracture site. Her X ray when she first presented is A, and her X ray from today is B. Looking at B, her X ray from today, which phase of bone healing would you say her and her fracture are now in?
Explanation:
Emily's fracture is in the 'repair' phase, as her X ray shows a callus. The phases of remodeling are as follows;

  1. Inflammation phase - characterized by a haematoma forming, and increased capillary permeability at the site of the fracture.
  2. Repair phase - characterized by the formation of a callus, which subsequently undergoes ossification and becomes hard.
  3. Remodeling - the return to normal structure.

Question:
A 25 year old woman is thrown from her horse at a local festival. On the way to hospital she becomes increasingly drowsy. Paramedics have inserted an oropharyngeal airway and have given high flow oxygen (at 40%) via a face mask because of her obstructed airway. An arterial blood gas sample is taken. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals

 

Patients ABG values:                    Normal ranges:

 

PaO2- 18.8 kPa                             >10 kPa (75 mmHg) on air
pH- 7.19                                          7.35 – 7.45
PaCO2- 10.2 kPa                            4.7 – 6.0 kPa
Bicarbonate- 23.6 mmol l-1             22 – 26 mmol l-1

You try to determine what acid-base disturbance this woman has in order to manage and treat her appropriately. What acid-base disturbance is suggested by her ABG results?
Explanation:
C- The reduced level of consciousness and obstructed airway will impair oxygenation and ventilation, causing an increase in PaCO2, a respiratory acidosis. There's unlikely to be much compensation (change in HCO3- because of the acuteness of the situation. However, we would expect too see more compensation in chronic respiratory acidosis.

 

There are 5 steps to remember when faced with ABG results. (1) How is the patient? (2) Asess oxygenation (3) Determine PH (4) Assess PCO2 (5) Assess HCO3- or base excess.

 

E- mixed acidosis/alkalosis- If both respiratory and metabolic components are driving PH towards the same side of 7.4 (both acidic or both alkalotic) then this is classed as a mixed picture.

 

NB- the PaCO2 should be about 10KPa less than the % inspired O2 concentration. More than 10 signifies an issue with oxygenation.

 

See Case 10 plenary and http://www.resus.org.uk/pages/alsabgGd.pdf but try to answer the questions first because the answers are on this link.
Tags: Kidney, Arterial Blood Gas, Biochemistry, Case 10, endocrinology

Question: 81 year old Brenda come to see you. She is not happy because she has had three fractures in the last year as a result of her osteoporosis. You decide to prescribe her Alendronate, a bisphosphonate. Which of the following most accurately describes the mechanism of action of a bisphosphonate like Alendronate?
OptionC: Inhibits osteoclast function and increases osteoblast acitivity
OptionD: Inhibits osteoclast function and induces apoptosis of osteoclasts
Explanation:
• Bisphosphonates (e.g. Alendronate, Risedronate and Ibandronate) inhibit osteoclast function and induce apoptosis of osteoclasts, stopping the breakdown of bone.
  • PTH analogues (e.g. Teriparatide) are a newer therapy which increase the activity of osteoblasts, thus increase the formation of new bone.

Question:
You are on placement on the orthopaedic ward. An x-ray is present in one of the patient's notes: 

You remember taking a history from the patient a few days ago. You recall that he complained of bone and joint pain. He also mentioned that some of his bones had "changed shape". It's also noted on the notes that serum alkaline phosphate is high. After taking a good look at this x ray, and consider the blood results you realise that the diagnosis was...
Explanation:
Usually asymptomatic 

Alkaline phosphate is high 

Thought to be over activity of osteoclasts, with the compensatory osteoblast activity forming weaker than normal bone.

Usually begins in pelvis.

Bone and joint pain being the primary complaints.

 

Case 14 - recommended reading "disease of bone" section from Kumar and Clark.

Question: Which Herpes virus is associated with developing nasopharynx carcinomas?
Explanation:
Case 16: Infections of CNS lecture 

 

herpes virus 4 aka Epstein barr virus can cause infectious mononucleosis, nasopharynx carcinomas, Burkitt lumphoma

Question: Mrs Williams, your elderly neighbour, decided to give you some help in your revision and proceeded to describe her extravagant list of medications. Hours passed and you thought you'd never again see daylight but one drug caught your attention!!! It was the mysterious concoction that was to help her with her "bad chest". She explained how she sometimes gets intense central burning pain when she goes to her salsa classes but this drug is "just marvellous at instant relief". Which of these drugs is she most likely to be describing?
Explanation:
A. Salbutamol is a ß2 adrenergic receptor agonist used to treat bronchospasm

B. Verapamil is a VW class IV Ca2+ channel blocker

C. Adenosine binds to A1 receptors which inhibits adenylyl cyclase, reduces cAMP which then stimulates K+ efflux and cell hyperpolarisation resulting in transient heart block at the AV node

D. Isosorbide mononitrate is used as a preventative treatment of angina but cannot be used to treat an "angina attack". It's metabolised to NO which acts as a vasodilator to increase coronary blood flow.

E. CORRECT Nitroglycerine  (aka Glyceryl trinitrate or GTN) is also metabolised to NO resulting in vasodilatation but can be used to treat an angina attack.

Question: Which of these types of mesoderm contributes to the formation of the somites in an embryo?
Explanation:
At the end of the third week, intraembryonic mesoderm differentiates into:

  • paraxial mesoderm- which forms somitomeres and somites
  • intermediate mesoderm- which contributes to the urogenital system
  • lateral mesoderm- which is involved in forming the body cavity
  • The last two options are made up!
  • From Langman's Embryology.

Question: Which of these is not a risk factor for developing PID?
Explanation:
Risk factors for developing pelvic inflammatory disease include:
Factors related to sexual behaviour, for example:

  • Young age (younger than 25 years).
  • Early age of first coitus.
  • Multiple sexual partners.
  • Recent new partner (within the previous 3 months).
  • History of sexually transmitted infection in the woman or her partner.

Recent instrumentation of the uterus or interruption of the cervical barrier, such as due to:
Termination of pregnancy.

  • Insertion of an intrauterine device (within the past 6 weeks).
  • Hysterosalpingography.
  • In vitro fertilization and intrauterine insemination.

The COCP is not a causes, but the POP may increase risk slightly. 

Source- NICE CKS

Question: You see Brian in clinic, who has been having problems with his left leg. Following examination of the leg, you suspect an upper motor neuron lesion. Which of the following is not a sign of an upper motor neuron lesion?
Explanation:
Upper motor neurons signs:

  • Increased muscle tone (spasticity).
  • Weakness (Pyramidal pattern of weakness - flexors weaker than extensors in the legs, opposite in the arms).
  • Hyperreflexia (increased reflexes).
  • Positive Babinski reflex (dorsiflexion of the big toe).
  • Sustained clonus.

Lower motor neuron signs:

  • Decreased muscle tone.
  • Atrophy of the muscles supplied by the particular nerve in question.
  • Arreflexia (absence of reflexes).
  • Muscle fasciculations (twitching).

Question: It's another fine day, and Carol decides to take the advice given to her on board and does a Park Run with Rob. During the run, Rob overtakes her. Carol gets off the scale angry and tries to overtake him. She doesn't notice a big tree branch on the path, trips and falls down. She is currently undergoing Excitotoxicity due to traumatic brain injury. Which receptors are involved in Excitotoxicity?
OptionA: AMPA and NMDA (which at rest is blocked by Ca2+ ion)
OptionB: AMPA and NDMA (which at rest is blocked by Ca2+ ion)
OptionC: NDMA and AMPA (which at rest is blocked by Ca2+ ion)
OptionD: NMDA and AMPA (which at rest is blocked by Mg2+ ion)
OptionE: AMPA and NMDA (which at rest is blocked by Mg2+ ion)
Explanation: AMPA and NMDA (which at rest is blocked by Mg2+ ion) - refer to cellular response to brain injury lecture (case 16)

Question:
Ms Mcgonagall has smoked all her life and is referred to you for a chest xray after becoming breathless. She is no longer able to go for her evening runs so has been dieting strictly so is still managing to lose a bit of weight before the Yule Ball. This is her erect chest xray

Which of these is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
How to examine a chest xray

On a chest x-ray lung abnormalities will either present as areas of increased density or as areas of decreased density.

Lung abnormalities with an increased density - also called opacities - are the most common.
A practical approach is to divide these into four patterns:

  1. Consolidation - any pathologic process that fills the alveoli with fluid, pus, blood, cells (including tumor cells) or other substances resulting in lobar, diffuse or multifocal ill-defined opacities.
  2. Interstitial - involvement of the supporting tissue of the lung parenchyma resulting in fine or coarse reticular opacities or small nodules.
  3. Nodule or mass - any space occupying lesion either solitary or multiple.
  4. Atelectasis - collapse of a part of the lung due to a decrease in the amount of air in the alveoli resulting in volume loss and increased density.

 

 

Pleural effusions
A pleural effusion is a collection of fluid in the pleural space. Fluid gathers in the lowest part of the chest, according to the patient's position. If the patient is upright when the x-ray is taken, a pleural effusion will obscure the costophrenic angle and hemidiaphragm. If a patient is supine a pleural effusion layers along the posterior aspect of the chest cavity and becomes difficult to see on a chest x-ray. Some features:

  • The left lower zone is uniformly white
  • At the top of this white area there is a concave surface - meniscus sign
  • The left heart border, costophrenic angle and hemidiaphragm are obscured
  • Slight blunting of the right costophrenic angle indicates a pleural effusion on that side
  • With large volume effusions, mediastinal shift occurs away from the effusion (note: if coexistent collapse dominates then mediastinal shift may occur towards the effusion)

The weight loss was just a red-herring here.

 

Symptoms of pleural effusion:

  • A small amount of fluid is completely asymptomatic. In fact, depending on the respiratory reserve of the patient, even large amounts of fluid can accumulate within the pleural space before any symptoms are recognised.
  • Eventually as the amount of fluid increases, with resulting elastic/compressive atelectasis of the adjacent lung, the patient will experience reduced exercise tolerance and breathlessness.

I cannot stress enough how good this website is, it has the images for all the differential answers listed here!

http://radiologymasterclass.co.uk/tutorials/chest/chest_pathology/chest_pathology_start.html

 

Congestive heart failure likely to cause symmetrical pattern, cancer likely to have sharpening of costophrenic angle rather than blunting. Pneumothorax and pneumonia just look very different, see link above or google some images!

Question: You are reviewing Brian in clinical, who 3 months ago was diagnosed with a partial spinal cord tear following a RTA. On examination today, he has no motor function below the level of injury, but has sensory function below the level of injury. Where would you grade Brian on the Frankel Scale?
Explanation:
• A - Complete paralysis
  • B - No motor function, sensory function preserved
  • C - Useless motor function preserved
  • D - Some useful motor function preserved
  • E - Normal function

Question: Stimulation of which of the following receptors results in activation of adenylate cyclase?
Explanation:
The correct answer is E - Beta-1 adrenergic receptors are Gs protein coupled receptors that work by activating adenylate cyclase, increasing the concentration of cAMP.

Alpha-1 adrenergic and M-3 muscarinic are Gq protein coupled receptors that act by activating phospholiapse-C, increasing intracellular Ca levels.

Alpha-2 adrenergic and M-2 muscarinic are Gi protein coupled receptors that act by deactivating adenylate cyclase, decreasing the concentration of cAMP.

Question: In Holdsworth's 2-column theory of mechanical stability, which of the following is 'key' to maintaining mechanical stability?
Explanation:
• In Holdsworth's 2-column theory of mechanical stability, the PLC (posterior ligament complex) is key to mechanical stabiltiy. The PLC is made up of the posterior longitudinal ligament, the ligamentum flavum, and the ligamentum nuchae.
  • In Denis' 3-column theory of mechanical stability, the middle column (the posterior half of the vertebral body) is key to mechanical stability.

Question: Which of the following theories about the existence of families agrees with the idea that families have both positive and negative effects as a result of providing and caring for family members?
Explanation:
Plenary 1, Case 8

 

Functionalist = nuclear families have positive social functions (e.g. economic support, reproduction)

 

Marxist = families have a relationship to the labour market as producers and consumers, and are therefore affected by changes in the labour market, welfare policies and employment

 

Feminist = families have negative social consequences by increasing gender divisions and promoting gender norms

 

Psychosocial = CORRECT, families have both positive and negative effects due to caring and providing for other family members

 

I don't care = non a sociological theory, but a valid option. Unfortunately in this case it is not the single best answer

Question: Which of the following is correct regarding the anatomy of the ear?
OptionA: The middle ear is a fluid filled cavity.
OptionB: The stapes inserts onto the round window.
OptionC: The organ of Corti is found in the middle ear.
OptionD: The Eustachian tube is found in the middle ear.
OptionE: The cochlea is responsible for maintaining balance.
Explanation:
D is correct.

 

A - The external and middle ear are air filled cavities. The inner ear is fluid filled.

 

B - The stapes inserts onto the oval window, not the round window. The oval window is important for impedance matching - the oval window is much smaller than the stapes so amplifies hearing sesnsitivity by a factor of 1000. The round window bulges outwards into the middle ear to allow for sound transmission in the fluid filled inner ear.

 

C - The organ of Corti is found within the cochlea in the inner ear.

 

D - correct. The Eustachian tube connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx. Fluid may accumulate in this region in addition to infection causing a conductive hearing loss characteristic of otitis media.

 

E - The semi-circular canals are important for balance whilst the cochlea is important for hearing.

Question:
Two stressed second year medical students were reminiscing about year 1 exams they had to get through to get to second year. To calm themselves down about upcoming exams, they started thinking of ridiculous questions that came up (and therefore how hard Peerwise was compared to the actual paper)

  

One particular question that they both remembered was:

 

What is the value of 105?

 

 

Note: Feel free to use a calculator
Explanation:
105 is 10 x 10 x 10 x 10 x 10 = 100,000. Hence is the right answer.

 

Hope this little teaser lessens a bit of the revision stress!

Question: Which of the following muscles belongs to the medial compartment of the thigh?
Explanation:
Anterior Compartment of Thigh - Iliopsoas, sartorius, pectineus and quadriceps femoris (vastus lateralis, medialis, intermedius and rectus femoris).

Medial Compartment of Thigh - Obturator Externus, Gracilis, and the adductors (magnus, brevis and longus).

Posterior Compartment of Thigh - Semimembranosus, Semitendonosus and Biceps Femoris

 

Piriformis is a deep gluteal muscle.

Question:
Michael 'swag' Winterberry has just ordered a cheeky nandos. As he waits for his order impatiently, he mindlessly ponders the meaning of life, but more importantly the types of cardiomyopathies.

 

One particular cardiomyopathy comes to mind; one which is mostly genetic in nature, most common in young people and is associated with left ventricular blood flow obstruction. Which type is he thinking about?
Explanation:
Hypertrophic myopathy is the correct answer :)

 

In this type there is a characteristic Left ventricular blood flow obstruction caused by the mitral valve pressing on the septum.

There is also: ASH ( asymmetric septal hypertrophy) in most cases and chamber stiffness. 

 

 

Other key myopathies:

Dilated - cardiac enlargement with reduced systolic function 

AVRC - mainly affecting right ventricle; fatty infiltrations and hypertrabeculation

RCM - reduced systolic function usually due to myocardial infiltration (e.g. amyloid deposits)

Question: Which of the following structures all pass through the cavernous sinus?
OptionA:
Cranial nerves III, IV, V1, V2, V3, VI and VII

 

External jugular vein
OptionB:
Cranial nerves III, IV, V1, V2 and VI

 

External jugular vein
OptionD:

Internal carotid artery

Internal carotid artery

Question: You are asked to perform a lumbar puncture on Brenda. Whilst performing the procedure you feel a first 'give' then a second 'give'. What do these two 'gives' indicate?
OptionB: First give=Posterior longitudinal ligament, Second give=Dura mater
OptionD: First give=Ligamentum flavum, Second give=Posterior longitudinal ligament
Explanation:
The first give is the ligamentum flavum, and the second is the dura mater. As the dura and arachnoid mater are flush against each other due to pressure from the CSF in the subarachnoid space, the needle is now in the subarachnoid space - you have reached your destination! 

NB: You wouldn't ever want to pierce the posterior longitudinal ligament, as this would mean you'd gone all the way through the spinal cord!! You can see that from this image;

Question: Which of these drugs is most likely cause or exacerbate peripheral oedema?
Explanation:
Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that is can cause peripheral oedema (more so than non-dihydropyridines). This is thought to be due to their more selective arteriolar vasodilation (as opposed to venous). 

Amlodipine inhibits calcium ions into vascular smooth muscle cells and cardiac muscle cells. The contractile processes of cardiac muscle and vascular smooth muscle are dependent upon the movement of extracellular calcium ions into these cells through specific ion channels. Amlodipine inhibits calcium ion influx across cell membranes selectively, with a greater effect on vascular smooth muscle cells. Amlodipine is a peripheral arterial vasodilator that acts directly on vascular smooth muscle to cause a reduction in peripheral vascular resistance and reduction in blood pressure.

Side effects include:
Common: peripheral edema and fatigue
Uncommon: blood disorders, development of breasts in men (gynecomastia), impotence, depression, insomnia, tachycardia, or gingival enlargement
Rarely: erratic behavior, hepatitis, jaundice

 

 

Direct (arteriolar) vasodilator drugs also cause oedema by enhancing renal sodium reabsorption through their blood pressure effect and activation of RAAS. Class 1c Na channel blockers can cause heart failure and thus lead to or worsen peripheral oedema. 

 

Amiodarone: is a member of a class of antiarrhythmic drugs with predominantly Class III (K channel blocker), prolongs phase 3 of the cardiac action potential, the repolarization phase where there is normally decreased calcium permeability and increased potassium permeability. Very common side effects (More than 1 in 10 people): abnormal laboratory test results, corneal deposits, eye or eyesight problems, nausea, photosensitivity skin reactions with redness, tingling, burning or blistering of the skin, taste changes, vomiting

 

Bisoprolol:

A beta-blocker which is used to decrease myocardial infarction mortality and prevent recurrence of tachyarrhythmias. It selectively and competitively blocks catecholamine (adrenalin) stimulation of β1 adrenergic receptors (adrenoreceptors), which are mainly found in the heart muscle cells and heart conduction tissue (cardiospecific), but also found in juxtaglomerular cells in the kidney. It decreases the adrenergic tone/stimulation of the heart muscle and pacemaker cells. Decreased adrenergic tone shows less contractility of heart muscle and lowered heart rate of pacemakers. 
Side effects include: Overdose of bisoprolol leading to fatigue, hypotension, low blood sugar, bronchospasms, and bradycardia. 

 

Digoxin

Digoxin is occasionally used in the treatment of various heart conditions, namely atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter and sometimes heart failure that cannot be controlled by other medication. Digoxin’s primary mechanism of action involves inhibition of the Na+/K+ ATPase, mainly in the myocardium. This inhibition causes an increase in intracellular sodium levels, resulting in a reversal of the action of the sodium-calcium exchanger, which normally imports three extracellular sodium ions into the cell and transports one intracellular calcium ion out of the cell. The reversal of this exchange causes an increase in the intracellular calcium concentration that is available to the contractile proteins. Increased intracellular calcium lengthens phase 4 and phase 0 of the cardiac action potential, which leads to a decrease in heart rate. Increased amounts of Ca2+ also leads to increased storage of calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, causing a corresponding increase in the release of calcium during each action potential. This leads to increased contractility (the force of contraction) of the heart without increasing heart energy expenditure.

Common adverse effects (≥1% of patients) include loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea as gastrointestinal motility increases. Other common effects are blurred vision, visual disturbances (yellow-green halos and problems with color perception), confusion, drowsiness, dizziness, insomnia, nightmares, agitation, and depression, as well as a higher acute sense of sensual activities

 

Spironolactone:

Belongs to a class of pharmaceutical drugs known as potassium-sparing diuretics, and is used primarily as a diuretic and antihypertensive in the treatment of heart failure and hypertension. Spironolactone is used primarily to treat heart failure, edematous conditions such as nephrotic syndrome or ascites in patients with liver disease, essential hypertension, hypokalemia, secondary hyperaldosteronism (such as occurs with hepatic cirrhosis), and Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism). Along with many other MOAs, the relevant one here is Spironolactone inhibiting the effects of mineralocorticoids, namely, aldosterone, by displacing them from mineralocorticoid receptors (MR) in the cortical collecting duct of renal nephrons. This decreases the reabsorption of sodium and water, while limiting the excretion of potassium (A K+ sparing diuretic). The drug has a slightly delayed onset of action, and so it takes several days for diuresis to occur.

The most common side effect of spironolactone is urinary frequency. Other general side effects include ataxia, drowsiness, dry skin, and rashes. Because it reduces androgen levels and blocks androgen receptors, spironolactone can, in males, cause breast tenderness, gynecomastia, and physical feminization in general, as well as testicular atrophy, reversible infertility, and sexual dysfunction, including loss of libido and erectile dysfunction. In females, spironolactone can cause menstrual irregularities and breast tenderness and enlargement, likely due to a combination of its progestogenic and indirect estrogenic actions. The most important potential side effect of spironolactone is hyperkalemia, which can be life-threatening
Tags: Cardiology, Case 13, Case 15, Pharmacology, Heart failure

Question: The brain stem exits the skull via which foramen?
Which of these is part of the axial skeleton?
Explanation:
Axial is in blue/green

Appendicular skeleton in standard bone colour

Question: Janet, a 59 year old female has had a terrible accident at work that wasn't her fault. Before claiming compensation, she intends to get herself better. She is told that she has completely severed her common fibular nerve. What is the best term to describe this injury?
Explanation:
Neuropraxia - a functional deficit in the nerve but with no associated structural/histological change e.g. Saturday Night Palsy.

 

Axonotmesis - Several axons are damaged due to severing of the endoneurium and perineurium. Epineurium remains in tact.

 

Neurotmesis - Whole nerve is severed affecting the nerve axon and encapsulating connective tissue.

 

Chromatolysis - the process following nerve injury which causes the nerve cell body to swell and involves the dissolution of Nissly granules within the cell.

 

Neurotropism - Where proximal nerve fibre stumps change direction to unite to thier distal portion in order to rejoin and repair the nerve.

Question: Which of these statements regarding curvatures of the spine is true?
OptionA: Cervical curvature is a primary curvature present that develops in foetal period and is retained through life
OptionB: Lumbar curvature is generally more pronounced in males
OptionC: Lumbar curvature becomes prominent when infant begins holding their head erect
OptionE: Thoracic curvature become apparent when infant begins to walk/assume upright posture
Explanation:
• T and S curvatures are primary curvatures that develop during the foetal period and are retained through life. These are a consequence of differences in height between anterior and posterior parts of vertebrae
  • C and L curvatures are secondary curvatures that begin to appear in the foetal period but not obvious until infancy. These are a consequence of differences in thickness between anterior and posterior parts of IV discs
  • C curvature becomes prominent when infant begins to hold their head erect
  • L curvature becomes apparent when infant begins to walk/ assume upright position
  • L curvature generally more pronounced in females, it ends at the lumbosacral junction of L5 with the sacrum
  • S curvature is reduced in females so coccyx protrudes less into pelvic outlet (birth canal)

Question: Osteoporosis is a pathological process involving the vertebral bodies of all vertebrae, especially in post-menopausal women. Which area is most affected?
Explanation:
Thoracic vertebrae are most commonly affected which can lead to excessive thoracic kyphosis 'humpback' due to abnormal increase in thoracic curvature causing the vertebrae to curve posteriorly. This may be due to erosion of anterior part of one or more vertebrae.

Dowager's hump: colloquial name for this excessive curvature in older women from osteoporosis 

Progressive erosion and collapse of vertebrae leads to an overall loss in height which can occur in geriatric men and women.

Question: Above the arrow coming from the yellow star is pointing to the epiphyseal rim, which of these best describes the composition of this structure?
Explanation:
• Most superior and inferior surfaces of vertebral bodies are covered with hyaline cartilage which are a remnant of the cartilainous model from which bone develops, except for the periphery where there is a ring of smooth bone called the epiphyseal rim, derived from the anular epiphysis. 
  • Spongy (cancellous) bone - which is found at the ends of long bones (in the epiphysis). This makes up 20% of all bone. This type of bone contains red bone marrow and a network of bony trabeculae.
  • Dense regular connective tissue is found in tendons and ligaments

Question:
A 17 year old boy named Tommen comes into A&E with his mother Cersei, he complains that his neck feels very stiff and you can see that he is looking away from bright hospital lights, however you cannot find any rash; because you weren't born yesterday you immediately think that he might have meningitis. You quickly bang out a lumbar puncture and send the CSF off to the lab. 

 

The results come back

 

- purulent CSF

- some mononuclear

- high polymorph cells

- high proteins

 

Which type of meningitis does this make you suspect and how would you manage it?
OptionC: Bacterial - probably nothing bacterial meningitis is normally self-limiting within 10 days
OptionD: Viral - probably nothing viral meningitis is normally self-limiting within 10 days
Explanation:
The broad three types of meningitis are bacterial (pyogenic), viral and chronic/TB.

 

The CSF can usually be used to distinguish between the three as follows 

 

 In Viral meningitis – clear CSF, some mononuclear and no polymorph cells
 In bacterial – purulent CSF, some mononuclear and high polymorph cells, high proteins
 In TB meningitis – purulent CSF, high mononuclear, some polymorph cells

 

If there was a rash and nisseria meningitidis was suspected then prophylactic antibiotics would be started before the lab results came back. 

 

Most cases of viral meningitis do not require treatment, are limiting within 10 days and have no long lasting effects.

 

Most cases of bacterial meningitis are treated with antibiotics - there are a wide range that might be used depending on the organism. 

 

Learning outcome for Case 16 - Outline the microbiology of central nervous system infections

 

You can sort of work this out if you remember the immunology behind it.
Tags: Immunology, Infectious Disease, Brain, Virology, Case 16

Question: What type of joint is the sacro-iliac joint?
Explanation:
The sacroiliac joints are part syndesmosis and part synovial joints. The synovial part of the joint is C-shaped with the convex iliac surface of the C facing anteriorly and inferiorly.

Consists of anterior synovial joint (between auricular surfaces of sacrum and ilium covered with articular cartilage) and a posterior syndesmosis (between tuberosities of sacrum and ilium)

a) L3 spinous process tip and L3/4 IV disc

b) Just below this spinous process so between L3/4 spinous processes

a) L3 spinous process tip and L3/4 IV disc
b) Just above this spinous process so between L2/3 spinous processes

Question:
Miss Walker is a 24 year old anatomy student, pregnant for the first time. She has been studying the foetal blood flow, and is keen to discuss it with you, a GP who hasn't thought about any of this in 30 years. You realise you're about to look pretty foolish, unless... Something from your med school days is coming back to you...

 

What best describes the foetal blood flow?
OptionA:
• There are two umbilical veins which take blood from the placenta
  • The foramen ovale allows blood to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium
  • The ductus arteriosus allows blood to pass from the pulmonary trunk to the descending aorta
  • The ductus venosus allows blood to pass from the descending aorta to the umbilical artery
OptionB:
• The ductus venosus allows blood to pass from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava
  • The ductus arteriosus allows blood to pass from the left atrium to the right atrium
  • The foramen ovale allows blood to pass from the pulmonary trunk to the descending aorta
  • There is one umbilical artery which takes blood back to the placenta
OptionC:
• The ductus venosus allows blood to pass from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava
  • The foramen ovale allows blood to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium
  • The ductus arteriosus allows blood to pass from the pulmonary trunk to the descending aorta
  • There are two umbilical arteries which take blood back to the placenta
OptionD:
• The ductus venosus allows blood to pass from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava
  • The foramen ovale allows blood to pass from the left atrium to the right atrium
  • The ductus arteriosus allows blood to pass from the descending aorta to the pulmonary trunk
  • There are two umbilical arteries which take blood back to the placenta
OptionE:
• There are two umbilical veins which take blood from the placenta
  • The foramen ovale allows blood to pass from the right atrium to the left atrium
  • The ductus arteriosus allows blood to pass from the descending aorta to the pulmonary trunk
  • The ductus venosus allows blood to pass from the descending aorta to the two umbilical arteries
Explanation:
Here is the foetal blood flow:

 

  1. Blood flows from the placenta through the umbilical vein, through the ductus venosus and into the inferior vena cava.
  2. Blood enters the right atrium.
  3. Some blood flows via the foramen ovale into the left atrium. From here it continues to the left ventricle and around the body as in post-birth, eventually returning to the right atrium.
  4. Some blood enters the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk. It bypasses the lungs by flowing through the ductus arteriosus into the descending aorta.
  5. Blood is collected by the two umbilical arteries and taken back to the placenta.

Question:
This diagram shows T7 and T8 vertebrae (hypothetically, this is a diagram of T vertebrae but not at a specific level)

 

What would be the most inferior spinal nerve root visible on this diagram (labelled with green line)?
Explanation:
In the cervical spine, the nerve root exits above the vertebral body of the corresponding number e.g. C3 spinal nerve root, then C3 vertebra below, C4 spinal nerve root below that etc. This continues until C7 vertebrae which then has the C8 nerve root exiting below it (an extra C nerve compared to only 7 C vertebrae)

After this point the subsequent nerve roots exit below their corresponding vertebra for example the T7 vertebral body, T7 spinal nerve below, T8 vertebra below that with the T8 spinal nerve exiting below this (as in this diagram)

Question:
Whilst on placement, you see a patient who has a drug administered to his left eye. 

 

When you test his corneal reflex with cotton wool, you find that it is absent. His pupil is also moderately dilated and you observe that his sclera is very white compared with his right eye.

 

What drug has he been administered?
Explanation:
The answer is cocaine, which is a Na+ voltage gated channel blocker and a sympathicomimetic. It causes:

  • loss of the corneal reflex
  • pupil dilation (although not as effectively as tropicamide which is why I used the wording 'moderately')
  • a white sclera, as it is a peripheral vasoconstrictor 

The other drugs can also be given to the eye, and can cause some of the effects seen in this patient; however as an SBA question, cocaine is the drug that causes all 3 of his effects. 

 

  • Tropicamide is a mAChR antagonist, and causes pupil dilation
  • Tetracaine is a Na+ voltage gated channel blocker and causes loss of the corneal reflex
  • Phenylephrine is an alpha adrenoceptor agonist and causes pupil dilation and a white sclera
  • Antihistamines can be given topically on the eye to treat allergic conjunctivitis, allergic rhinitits. They are H1 antagonists.

Question: You are reviewing Brian in clinic, who has recently been in an RTA and incurred damage to one of the nerves in his left leg.There is axonal injury and Wallerian degeneration in the distal segment, but the endoneurium is intact. Tinnel's sign is present. What degree of nerve injury does Brian have in this particular nerve?
Explanation:
• 1st degree (neurapraxia) - localised conduction block that results in some degree of demyelination, but the axons are not damaged and Wallerian degeneration doesn't occur. No Tinnel's sign.
  • 2nd degree (axonotmesis) - Axonal injury has occurred and the distal segment undergoes Wallerian degeneration, but the endoneurium is intact. Advancing Tinnel's sign may be seen.
  • 3rd degree (scarring) - Wallerian degeneration is combined with scarring of the endoneurium.
  • 4th degree (complete scar block) - The nerve is in continuity but there is complete scar block resulting from the injury to the nerve. Regeneration will not occur unless the block is removed.
  • 5th degree (neurotmesis) - The nerve is completely divided and must be repaired before any regeneration can occur.
  • 6th degree (mixed pattern) - Represents a combination of any of the previous five types of injury, often seen in crushing injuries as different degrees of injury are seen in different areas along the crush site.

Question:
In this image of the lumbar plexus there are two major nerves highlighted in yellow

Which of there statements is correct?
OptionA:
The more superior yellow nerve is the Genitofemoral nerve (L2-3)
The inferior, larger yellow nerve is the Femoral nerve (L2, 3, 4)
The Femoral nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the anterior compartment of the thigh.
OptionB:
The more superior yellow nerve is the Genitofemoral of the thigh (L2-3)
The inferior, larger yellow nerve is the Obturator nerve (L2, 3, 4)
The Obturator nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the medial compartment of the thigh.
OptionC:
The more superior yellow nerve is the Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (L2-3)

The inferior, larger yellow nerve is the Femoral nerve (L2, 3, 4)
The Femoral nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the medial compartment of the thigh.
OptionD:
The more superior yellow nerve is the Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (L2-3)
The inferior, larger yellow nerve is the Femoral nerve (L2, 3, 4)
The Femoral nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the anterior compartment of the thigh.
OptionE:
The more superior yellow nerve is the Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (L2-3)
The inferior, larger yellow nerve is the Obturator nerve (L2, 3, 4)
This Obturator nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the medial compartment of the thigh.
Explanation:
A mneumoic to remember the lumbar plexus:

Sexy Indecent Ian Gets Laid On Fridays Luckily

S: Subcostal (T12)

I: iliohypogastric nerve (L1)
I: ilioinguinal nerve (L1-2) - Remember H comes becomes before I in alphabet/these nerves spell HI to get order of the two ilio nerve
G: genitofemoral nerve (L1-2)
L: lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (L2-3)
O: obturator nerve (L2, 3, 4)
F: femoral nerve (L2, 3, 4)
L: lumbosacral trunk (L4-S4)
Note, some texts do not include the subcostal nerve and lumbosacral trunk as part of the lumbar plexus.

 

If you are struggling to remember which way round obturator and femoral nerves are as they have the same roots, just remember the Femoral nerve is FAT. It is the largest of the lumbar plexus. 

 

Obturator nerve

Nerve roots: L2-L4

Motor: Innervates the medial (adductor) compartment of the thigh.

Sensory: Cutaneous branch innervates the skin of the medial thigh.

 

Femoral nerve

Roots: L2, L3, L4.

Motor Functions: Innervates the muscles: Illiacus, pectineus, sartorius, all the muscles of quadriceps femoris.

Sensory Functions: Innervates the skin on the anterior thigh and the medial leg.

 

 

 

This website is really helpful for a summary of each of these nerves and general anatomy 

http://teachmeanatomy.info/lower-limb/nerves/lumbar-plexus/

Question: You are in clinic testing Brenda's reflexes. You test her biceps reflex and her triceps reflex, and both are normal. Which spinal nerve roots are you testing with each reflex?
OptionA: Biceps: C5 and C6, Triceps: C7 and C8.
OptionB: Biceps: C5 and C6, Triceps: C6 and C7.
OptionC: Biceps: C4 and C5, Triceps: C5 and C6.
OptionD: Biceps: C6 and C7, Triceps: C7 and C8
Explanation:
• Biceps are supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve, which originates from C5 and C6.
  • Triceps are supplied by the radial nerve, which originates from C7 and C8.

Question:
Whilst on placement in A&E you are asked to dress a wound. 

 

You see that the wound is contaminated with flecks of dirt, looks to be red and inflamed with an odd smell. After irrigating and taking a swab to be sent off, you decide to dress the wound. 

 

How is the wound going to heal?
OptionA: First intention, which involves leaving the wound open to heal by granulation
OptionB: Second intention, which involves bringing the wound edges together
OptionC: First intention, which involves bringing the wound edges together
OptionD: Second intention, which involves leaving the wound open to heal by granulation
Explanation:
This would be a case of healing by second intention. 

 

Healing by first intention:

  • Wound is closed and the edges are brought together
  • Used for clean, fresh wounds in well-vascularised areas 
  • Fastest and most cosmetically pleasing method

Healing by second intention:

  • Wound is left open, edges kept separate 
  • Used for contaminated, infected wounds with extensive loss of tissue
  • Healing occurs by granulation (risk of infection)
  • Broader scar formation

Question: Which of the following is not a red flag for serious/sinister spinal pathology?
OptionA: Younger than 50 years old with new onset back pain.
OptionD: History of significant spinal trauma or injury
Explanation: These are all red flags except being younger than 50 years old with new onset back pain. The age-related red flags are <16 years old or >50 years old with new onset back pain.

Question:
You see a young boy with an abrasion on his eyelid. 

 

The consultant tells you that this is thin skin, and wants you to tell him the layers of thin skin. 

 

Which one of the following is only found in thick skin, and therefore would not be included in your list?
Explanation:
Stratum lucidum is found in thick skin only (soles of feet, fingertips etc.)

 

  • Stratum basale is the bottom layer of keratinocytes and is responsible for renewing epidermal cells; contains a row of undifferentiated columnar stem cells that divide frequently 
  • Stratum spinosum is the next layer up and is also called the prickle cell layer; cells that move into this layer begin to synthesise keratin. Appearance comes from the cells being tightly bound by desmosomes 
  • Stratum granulosum sees the cells losing their nuclei and is characterised by dark clumps of cytoplasmic material; kertain proteins and water-proofing lipids are produced
  • This is where the stratum lucidum would fit in 
  • Stratum corneum is a later of dead cells, reduced to flattened scaled, filled with dense keratin

This is thick skin (so you can see all of the layers):

Question: Which of these muscles is in the deep layer of intrinsic back muscles?
Explanation:
Extrinsic back muscles:

 

  • Superficial: trapezius, latissimus dorsi, levator scapulae and rhomboids
  • Intermediate: serratus posterior superior and inferior 

Intrinsic back muscles:

  • superficial: splenius muscles (capitis and cervicis)
  • intermediate: erecotor spinae including from lateral to medial: iliocostalis, longissimus, spinalis (each with their of regional divisions into lumborum, thoracis and  cervicis part)
  • Good way to remember to order of erector spinae from lateral to medial is I Love Sex
  • Deep: transversospinales muscle group (including semispinalis, multifidus and rotatores muscles), interspinales, intertransversarii and levatores costarum  are also in this compartment and are the smallest of the deep back muscles

Question:
Kanye has a song called 'I Am A God'. www.youtube.com/watch?v=ViGNBLQpGWE

 

What delusional symptom is he showing?
Ben, a 10 year old boy has recently been diagnosed with asthma. On his drug chart he has been prescribed Salbutamol. What is the mechanism of action of Salbutamol ?
Explanation:
Salbutamol - B2 Agonist - stimulates B2 receptors in the lungs which promotes bronchodilation via activation of the Gs GPCR intracellular cascade.

Ipratropium - Muscarinic Antagonist - reduces vagal tone which usually causes bronchoconstriction.

Theophylline (Methylxanthines) -  inhibit phosphodiesterase activity preventing bronchoconstriction.

Question: The oesophagus passes through the diaphragm at which vertebral level ?
Explanation:
Voice - Inferior Vena Cava (T8)

Of - Oesophagus (T10)

Africa - Aorta (T12)

Question: I am a nerve formed from the anterior rami of spinal nerves S2-S4. I leave through the greater sciatic foramen between piriformis and coccygeus, and then hook around the ischial spine and sacrospinous ligament and exit via the lesser sciatic foramen. Which nerve am I?
Explanation:
• Sciatic nerve (L4-S3) - Passes through greater sciatic foramen inferior to piriformis, and enters the gluteal region.
  • Pudendal nerve (S2-S4) - Leaves through the greater sciatic foramen between piriformis and coccygeus, and then hooks around the ischial spine and sacrospinous ligament and exits into the perineum via the lesser sciatic foramen.
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1) - Leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic formen inferior to piriformis and supplies gluteus minimus, gluteus medius, and tensor fascia lata.
  • Inferior gluteal nerve (L5-S2) - Leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic formen inferior to piriformis and superior to the sciatic nerve, and supplies gluteus maximus.

Question: Miss Adams a 24 year old female attends the sexual health clinic where she discusses the options of using a long acting reversible contraceptive (LARC). Which of the following methods is an example of a LARC?
Explanation: LARC's include the IUCD, implant and the contraceptive injection. These methods of contraception are long lasting so can be beneficial for some women as they don't need to take a pill at the same time each day. They are easily reversible as once removed/stopped fertility will return to normal.

Question: Which of the following nerves does not contain fibres from the L4 nerve root?
Explanation:
The inferior gluteal nerve has roots L5-S2

The superior gluteal nerve has roots L4-S1 

The sciatic nerve has roots L4-S3

The femoral and obturator both have nerve roots L2-L4

Question: Miss Williams has been prescribed the combined oral contraceptive pill. It contains the synthetic hormone Ethinyloestradiol. Which reproductive hormone in the body does this mimic?
Explanation:
The combined oral contraceptive pill contains both synthetic oestrogen (Ethinyloestradiol) and progesterone (Levornogestrel).

Question: Amy, a 17 year old female, has been referred to the endocrinology clinic as she as not yet gone through puberty and has a suspected hormonal problem. On examination you notice that Amy has underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics for her age, but breast buds and sparse pubic hair is present. What Tanner Stage is Amy ?
Explanation:
For assessing the tanner stage in females, examination of breast development and presence of pubic hair is used.

 

1 - Breast tissue absent, no pubic hair

2 - Breast buds and sparse growth of pubic hair

3 - Breast tissue development and darker, coarser pubic hair.

4 - Further enlargement of breast tissue and hair in adult type but covering a smaller area

5 - Adult appearance

 

 

http://www.childgrowthfoundation.org/CMS/FILES/Puberty_and_the_Tanner_Stages.pdf

Question: Calcitonin is released by which of the following structures?
Explanation:
Calcitonin is the hormone which opposes the effects of PTH (i.e. it responds to high calcium by inhibiting osteoclasts and generally causing a decrease in serum Calcium) is primarily released by the parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland. 

 

The parathyroid gland releases PTH, the Liver produces calcifediol from cholecalciferol (D3), the kidney converts calcifediol to calcitriol (active vitamin D), the skin converts a cholesterol precursor to D3 in presence of UV light.

Question:
Kendrick Lamar, having spent a long day dropping sick rhymes, decides to go on Peerwise. However he is shocked to see people actually think Kanye is the best rapper. He then uses his far superior creativity to make a Peerwise question.
It reads:

"Within the network of dural venous sinuses, the transverse sinuses drain the blood from the confluence of sinuses. What do the transverse sinuses directly drain into?"

 

What is the answer to Kendrick's question?
Explanation:
The transverse sinuses drain blood from the confluence of sinuses, which itself receives blood from the straight sinus (and indirectly the inferior saggital sinus (B)) and superior saggital sinus (A).

The correct answer is (D) as the transverse
sinus drains directly into the sigmoid sinuses. These then recieve blood from the petrosal sinuses and after passing through the jugular foramen become the internal jugular veins (C). The external jugular veins (E) are not involved in this system.

Question:
A 35 year old man presents following a series of lung infections. He has a very productive cough, producing lots of sputum with a small amount of blood. He has smoke 10 a day since he was 20, and has recently unintentionally lost some weight but has no other serious medical or family history. On examination you find that he has course crackles, particularly in the lower lung fields early during inspiration. He has some wheeze and large airway ronchi. 

 

On an x-ray you notice tram-lining.
Explanation:
Bronchiectasis is an abnormal dilation of the bronchial tree that can present at any age.

75% of patients have a very producing cough and 50% suffer from haemoptysis. There are treatments which may slow development, but it is largely irreversible.

Smoking is unlinked to the pathogenesis and a bit of a red herring.

Question: Degenerative lesions in which part of the brain can give rise to severe pain of central origin in the absence of painful stimuli?
Explanation:
• Thalamus is the gatekeeper for sensory information running to areas of the sensory cortex from ascending sensory pathways (Spino-thalamic tract is responsible for pain, temperature and crude touch)
  • electrical stimuli of the thalamus (posterior nuclei) can elicit pain
  • Degenerative lesions here can lead to severe pain of central origin = thalamic pain
  • Nociceptive signals first perceived as pain in sensory area of cortex
  • CNC contains no sensory neurones and brain surgery can be carried out on a conscious patient (although removing other structure would be painful!!)

Question:
A 48 year old woman is admitted to A&E with severe right upper quadrant pain. She tells you that her pain started after eating out last night and got worse throughout the night. She describes how it comes and goes in waves, and that she feels sick. 

 

You decide to run some LFTs (reference ranges in brackets):

  • Albumin - 43 g/L (3.5 - 5)
  • Bilirubin - 26 μmol/L (0.1 - 1.0)
  • ALT - 11 iu/L (7 - 55)
  • ALP - 247 iu/L (45 - 115) 

What do you think she has, combining the history and LFTs?
Explanation:
The overall pattern of the LFT and history indicates cholestatic disease because:

  • In hepatic disease you would see higher transaminases (AST/ALT), along with a much higher bilirubin
  • In haemolytic disease (i.e. pre-hepatic) you would expected a raised bilirubin, predominantly unconjugated. This is quite hard to diagnose without a FBC, but isn't likely given the history 
  • In cholestatic disease there is raised ALP and bilirubin, but a normal ALT. 

The answer here is billiary colic, which is caused by a gallstone obstructing the gallbladder neck and therefore bile flow. The pain is due to the contractions of the gallbladder pushing against the stone, which explains why it is is colicky in nature. The stone can fall back into the gallbladder or passed into the common bile duct (- this would potentially lead to cholecystitis or ascending cholangitis if the bile becomes infected). 

 

I've quickly included why it isn't the other options:

  • Although it could ultimately lead to cholecystitis, there is no evidence of inflammation/infection of the gallbladder in the information provided 
  • It isn't viral hepatits because the history is not typical of it and the LFTs show don't show a hepatic pattern 
  • Ascending cholangitis is caused when gut bacteria infect an obstructed bilary tree; normally patients would have systemic symptoms such as fever, and raised inflammatory markers
  • Primary billiary cirrhosis is an auto-immune disorder with granulomatous destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. Although the LFTs could match early PBC, the history is wrong as this is an acute presentation; patients with early PBC normally present to a primary care setting with milder symptoms such as tiredness.

 

I realise this is a hard question! - I think as long as you recognise that it is cholestatic in nature and that colic pain comes in waves, should be ok :)
Tags: Investigations, Jaundice, Liver Tests, Case 11, Case 3

Question: Which of the following muscles is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X)?
Explanation:
A to D are the extrinsic muscles of the tongue
A-C are innervated by the hypoglossal nerve, D is the only one of the four innervated by the vagus nerve.
E is a muscle of mastication and is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (V3).

Question:
A 28 year old man presents to his GP with right upper quadrant pain. As soon as he walks in, you can see that is jaundiced. 

When asked, he tells you that he has recently been travelling through Asia. He had an episode of diarrhoea and vomiting whilst out there, but it settled within 24 hours and he has been fine since. 

You also ask about tattoos, unprotected sex and IV drug use. He admits to having tried heroin about 6 years ago, and isn't sure whether the needle was sterile. He hasn't used IV drugs since. 

 

His LFTs come back as follows (reference ranges in brackets):

  • Albumin - 33 g/L (3.5 - 5)
  • Bilirubin - 104 μmol/L (0.1 - 1.0)
  • ALP - 200 iu/L (45 - 115)
  • AST - 1860 iu/L (8 - 48)
  • ALT - 2453 iu/L (7 - 55) 

Given his history and LFT results, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Hepatitis A is most likely given the history of recent travel and an episode of diarrhoea and vomiting several weeks before the jaundice. 

 

  • Previous use of IV drugs does put him at risk of Hep B, but it seems unlikely given the acute presentation and the fact that the drug use was 6 years ago
  • Hepatitis C is a chronic condition and is often asymptomatic during the acute phase, so it seems unlikely that he would have presented this jaundiced with Hepatitis C. However the use of a needle for IV drugs does mean that he should be screened for this, as it is often called the 'silent killer' and may not be noticed until there has been significant liver damage 
  • EBV can affect the liver and cause hepatitis, but with the history as well, this seems unlikely 
  • Auto-immune hepatitis normally presents in an insidious way with tiredness, nausea and anorexia
Tags: Investigations, Liver Tests, Case 11, Year 1 Revision, Case 3

Question: In a dystopian world where the essential fatty acid Linoleic acid doesn't exist, what previously non-essential fatty acid would become essential?
Explanation:
Alpha linoleic acid is already an essential fatty acid but Arachidonic acid, whilst not normally essential is able to replace linoleic acid in a deficiency.
Thankfully this linoleic acid deficient dystopia is fictional.

Question: A subserosal uterine fibroid would be found in which area of the uterus?
Explanation:
A is the location of subserosal fibroids (perimetrium is essentially peritoneum so these fibroids grow outwards from the uterus into the abdominal cavity)
B is the location of intramural fibroids
C is the location of submucosal fibroids

Question:
Hermione has been very stressed all year about her upcoming OWL exams, in the last few months she has also developed low back pain which has made the stress worse and she can't think of how she might have hurt her back. She has had a thorough examination and every investigation under the sun and no organic cause for her pain has been found.

What is the most likely condition Hermione is suffering from?
Explanation:
Allodynia = light touch sensitive sensory neurones (low threshold mechano-receptors) start to generate pain responses innappropriately after chronic stimulation of nociceptors

 

Central pain sensitisation = prolonged stimulation of nociceptors causes an accumulation of peptides (e.g. Substance P) in the dorsal horn, this is accompanied by increase (wind up) in activity of nociceptive pathways

 

Primary hyperalgesia = within an injured area histamine, prostaglandins and bradykinin increase nociceptor sensitivity to pain which may persist for days. 

 

Secondary hyperalgesia = in region outside of the area of tissue damage there is also an increased sensitivity to pain which may last for some hours

 

Somatization (also know as somatoform or somatic symptom disorder) = pain as a manifestation of stress in absence of organic cause/ injury. Pain experienced is often chronic but is real and plays a significant role in conditions such as low back pain and can lead to anxiety and stress. Be careful to avoid inappropriate interventions in these patients

 

Somatic syndrome: this is a sub-class used in diagnosis of depression (with or without somatic syndrome). It is a collection of symptoms, is the threshold (4) is met then patient is classed as having somatic syndrome. 

ICD-10 defines somatic syndrome as:
Some depressive symptoms are widely regarded as having special clinical significance and are here called "somatic". (Terms such as biological, vital, melancholic, or endogenomorphic are used for this syndrome in other classification)

To qualify for the somatic syndrome, four of the following symptoms should be present:
(1) marked loss of interest or pleasure in activities that are normally pleasurable;
(2) lack of emotional reactions to events or activities that normally produce an emotional response;
(3) waking in the morning 2 hours or more before the usual time;
(4) depression worse in the morning;
(5) objective evidence of marked psychomotor retardation or agitation (remarked on or reported by other
people);
(6) marked loss of appetite;
(7) weight loss (5% or more of body weight in the past month);
(8) marked loss of libido.

The presence or absence of the somatic syndrome is not specified for severe depressive episode, since it is presumed to be present in most cases

Question: Mrs Jones presents to you with ptosis, dilated (unilateral - right) pupil, double vision and it is looking down and out. Which cranial nerve has been affected and what is the underlying pathology?
Explanation: Ischaemic nerve damage is less likely to affect the pupil while an aneurysm is more likely to cause pupillary dilation.

Question: Stannis Baratheon, the one true king of Westeros, eats his enemies for breakfast. When doing this he uses his muscles of mastication, which are innervated by which nerve?
Explanation: The four muscles of mastication; temporalis, masseter and medial and lateral pterygoids, are innervated by the third of the main branches of the Trigeminal nerve, the mandibular nerve (V3)

Question: Which of these is the correct action of cyclo-oxygenase?
OptionA: Cleaves fatty acids from cell membrane phospholipids to form arachidonic acid
OptionB: Coverts arachidonic acid to eicosanoids which are further modified into leukotrienes
OptionC: Coverts arachidonic acid to endoperoxides and cell-specific prostanoids
OptionE: Joins O2 and arachidonic acid to make PGG2
Explanation:
PLA2 = Cleaves fatty acids from cell membrane phospholipids

 

Lipoxygenases  (LOX) = Coverts arachidonic acid to eicosanoids which are further modified into leukotrienes which have roles in chemotaxis, broncho-constriction and vascular permeability 

 

Prostaglandin-H synthase (PGHS) = Coverts arachidonic acid to endoperoxides ( e.g. PGG2) by oxygenation then modifies these into cell specific prostanoids. COX is one of the two catalytic domains of this enzyme

 

COX = Joins O2 and arachidonic acid to make PGG2

 

Critical Haem iron = Converts PGG2 to PGH2 in peroxidase domain 

 

Prostanoids = these are endoperoxides (describes their chemical structure) and includes both prostaglandins and prostacyclins. 

Most important prostanoid made by PGHS is PGH2 from which all other prostaglandins are derived

 

Prostaglandins =  involved in inflammation and pain

 

Prostacyclins =  help resolve inflammation and oppose prostaglandin effects

 

NSAIDS such as ibuprofen: reversibly, competitive inhibiter of COX domain activity in PGHS

 

Aspirin: irreversible inhibitos of PGHS1 and 2 COX domains by acetylation of key serine residue

Question:
Mr. Jones has suffered a stroke which has caused hemiplegia in his arm; he is really struggling to perform simple tasks such as getting dressed and is getting increasingly frustrated.

 

To explain what has happened, you produce a diagram to explain where the occlusion has taken place.

What number represents the most likely site of Mr. Jones' stroke?
Explanation:
The answer is 7, the middle cerebral artery - this artery supplies the motor cortex and an occlusion here would cause contralateral hemiplagia.

4. Superior cerebellar artery
5. Posterior cerebral artery
6. Posterior communicating artery
7. Middle cerebral artery
8. Internal carotid artery
9. Ophthalmic artery
10. Anterior cerebral artery
11. Anterior communicating artery
12. Hypothalamic artery
13. Anterior choroidal artery

Question: It's a cold friday evening in an A&E department, you're the only doctor in the hospital and you're finishing a 250 hour shift. A patient comes in with a suspected occlusion of a cerebral artery. They present with a numbness and paralysis in their left leg and foot. Which cerebral artery is likely to be occluded?
Explanation:
It is the anterior artery as it supplies the medial aspects of the parietal and frontal lobes which includes the leg motor area of the cerebral cortex. It is the right sided artery as the motor areas act contralaterally i.e. the right area controls the left leg.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anterior_cerebral_artery

Question: Why should aspirin not be given to patients who are under the age of 16?
OptionD: Associated with increased sex drive in pubertal teenagers, increases chance of underage sex
Explanation:
Didn't want this question to be a spelling test question but recently got Rett's and Reye's muddled up so thought I'd make a question!

 

Reye's syndrome: potentially fatal effects of brain and liver, classified into the following stages:

 

Rett syndrome: is a rare condition that affects the development of the brain. It can cause severe physical and mental disability that begins in early childhood. Most cases of Rett syndrome are caused by a mutation (change in the DNA) in the MECP2 gene, which is found on the X chromosome (so almost always seen in girls), although mutations in other genes have been found in some cases where the symptoms don't quite follow the classic pattern described above.
The MECP2 gene contains instructions to make a particular protein (MeCP2) that is vital for brain development. The gene abnormality prevents nerve cells in the brain from developing properly.
Although Rett syndrome is caused by a genetic mutation, almost all cases are sporadic and occur without any family history of the condition. This is known as a 'de novo' mutation.

 

Conn's syndrome: a disease of the adrenal glands involving excess production of a hormone, called aldosterone. Another name for the condition is primary hyperaldosteronism. Can cause potentially curable high blood pressure (hypertension). Often it produces few symptoms but most people have high blood pressure which may cause poor vision or headaches. Primary hyperaldosteronism has a number of causes. About 66% of cases are due to enlargement of both adrenal glands and 33% of cases are due to an adrenal adenoma that produces aldosterone. Other uncommon causes include adrenal cancer and an inherited disorder called familial hyperaldosteronism

 

D: No idea whether it increases sex drive in under 16s but I highly doubt it, just couldn't think of another potential option and thought this might amuse people. If it did increase sex drive in under 16s would unlikely be a reason not to prescribe it as likely the benefit would outweigh this risk. 

 

E: NSAIDs in general can compromise renal function in all patients by altering renal haemodynamics. Inhibits production of prostaglandins that would usually dilate afferent arteriole of glomeruli so leads to unopposed constriction of afferent arteriole and reduced renal perfusion pressure. 

 

NSAIDs are also contra-indicated in pregnancy

Question: Kanye is watching the beautiful natural miracle of Kim breast feeding Nori. He ponders about the regulation of what is occurring in front of him. Which one is true?
OptionA: Suckling stimulates mechanoreceptors in nipple causing an increase in dopamine and an increase in oxytocin causing formation and ejection of milk
OptionB: Suckling stimulates mechanoreceptors in nipple causing an increase in dopamine and a decrease in oxytocin causing formation and ejection of milk
OptionC: Suckling stimulates mechanoreceptors in nipple causing an decrease in dopamine and an increase in oxytocin causing formation and ejection of milk
OptionD: Suckling stimulates mechanoreceptors in nipple causing decrease in prolactin and an increase in oxytocin causing formation and ejection of milk
OptionE: Suckling stimulates mechanoreceptors in nipple causing increase in prolactin and an decrease in oxytocin causing formation and ejection of milk
Explanation: Suckling stimulates mechanoreceptors in nipple causing a decrease in dopamine which inhibits prolactin production. Prolactin therefore increases in production, with its increase stimulating milk secretion. Oxytocin increases also from stimulation of mechanoreceptors causing the contraction of myoepithelial cells surrounding the alveoli causing milk ejection

Question: Julie, a 19 year old arts student, visits the GP complaining of non-specific gastrointestinal problems. However, she mentions some rectal bleeding and so you consider the possibility that she may have an inflammatory bowel disease. Which of these is correct concerning the risk factors and protective factors for inflammatory bowel disease?
OptionA: Oral contraception decreases the risk of ulcerative colitis
OptionB: Smoking decreases the risk of Crohn's disease
OptionC: Breast feeding increases the risk of developing ulcerative colitis
OptionD: Having an appendectomy decreases the risk of ulcerative colitis
OptionE: Eating lots of refined carbohydrate decreases your risk of Crohn's disease
Explanation:
D is correct. Having an appendectomy before the age of 20 is a protective factor in the development of UC (but not Crohn's)

 

The oral contraceptive increases the risk of UC

Smoking increases the risk of Crohn's and decreases the risk of UC

Breast feeding decreases your risk of developing UC (and Crohn's)

Eating refined carbohydrates increases your risk of Crohn's disease

 

This information came directly from Case 11, Plenary 4

Question: Which dermatome supplies the skin overlying the medial malleolus?
Explanation:
Some commonly examined/questioned dermatome landmarks

 

C3 = Level of a high turtle/polar neck jumper 

C6 =  (radial nerve) 1st digit (thumb) and second digit

C7 = Middle Finger (median nerve)

C8 = (ulnar nerve) 4th and 5th digit, also the funny bone
T4 = Nipples
T10 = Belly But'ten' (Umbilicus)

L2 = On the anterior medial thigh (imagine putting your hands your pockets and this covers this area in that direction)

L3 = knee, the medial epicondyle of the femur.

L4 = medial malleolus and big toe (medial side, L4 to the floor), some diagrams have this covering the knee as well so test medial knee for L3 and medial malleolus for L4 as those are safe!

L5 = most of sole of foot

S2/3 = genitalia 

S5 = anus
