Question: When answering impossible questions and reading mean comments on peerwise, a medical student questions why there are so many arseholes using the site. Because it is the run up to the exam and her brain is fried, she suddenly panics that she has forgotten the dermatome that supplies the arsehole, which is it?

A patient needs to receive some potassium intravenously.  They will receive 100mg KCl in total, and this should be infused at 0.05 mmol/min, delivered with saline.

 

Due to his impaired haemodynamic status, the patient's drip rate must be kept at 50ml/min.  What volume of saline should the KCl be dissolved in, given that Mr of KCl = 74.5?
Explanation:
I think this situation is very unlikely to start with, just so you know :P

 

Firstly, find the number of moles of KCl that you want to infuse: 100mg=0.1g, 0.1g / 74.5g/mol = 0.00134mol or 1.34mmol.

 

Next, you know that the potassium needs to go in at 0.05mmol/min, so you can work out over what time period this dose should go in: 1.34mmol / 0.05mmol/min = 26.85 mins.

 

Then you just need to work out how much saline will have gone in in that time given the set drip rate: 26.85mins x 50ml/min = 1342ml, or 1.34L

Question: Mr Weasley has been complaining of back pain for the last 2 months that keeps him awake at night. You decide to carry some blood tests to exclude sinister causes. The results show a normal ESR and CRP as well as a normal ALP.  Which of these types of condition is most likely given these results?
Explanation:
• White count, ESR and CRP likely to be elevated in infection such as discitis
  • ESR and CRP elevated and anaemia seen in malignancy
  • Patients with metastatic disease and unknown primary cancer need thorough investigation
  • Normal ESR and CRP can distinguish mechanical back pain from rheumatic
  • ALP is elevated in Paget's disease

Question: Which of the following is NOT a cause of supratentorial and infratentorial lesions?
Explanation:
Metabolic causes such as hypoglycemia, hepatic failure, renal failure, hypoxia etc are seen in diffuse and multi focal encephalopathy

 

source: case 16, how to access an unconscious patient lecture

Question: Which of these conditions is strongly suggested by the following xray?
Explanation:
The xray shows a winking owl sign/ winking pedicle which is due to destruction of the vertebral body and indicates malignancy 

The image below is a similar xray but with two blue owl signs on the vertebra below and an arrow pointing to the winking pedicle

 

  • Spinal infection may destruction of the IV disc on xray which is indicative of infection (good prognostic sign as infections generally treatable)
  • Xray is normal in simple low back pain, prolapsed disc but can also be normal in infection or malignancy too
  • There is no clear fracture on this xray
  • Other metasteses may also be seen on spinal xray e.g. lung
  • Spondylesthesis and spondylosis unlikely to be seen on xray especially at this angle
  • Spondylosis refers to degeneration of the spine, most often, the term spondylosis is used to describe osteoarthritis of the spine, but it is also commonly used to describe any manner of spinal degeneration.
  • As with many other terms to describe spinal problems, spondylosis is more of a descriptive term than it is a diagnosis.
  • The most common cause of low back pain in adolescent athletes that can be seen on X-ray is a stress fracture in one of the bones (vertebrae) that make up the spinal column. Technically, this condition is called spondylolysis (spon-dee-low-lye-sis). It usually affects the fifth lumbar vertebra in the lower back and, much less commonly, the fourth lumbar vertebra.
  • If the stress fracture weakens the bone so much that it is unable to maintain its proper position, the vertebra can start to shift out of place. This condition is called spondylolisthesis (spon-dee-low-lis-thee-sis). If too much slippage occurs, the bones may begin to press on nerves and surgery may be necessary to correct the condition.
  • X-rays of the lower back (lumbar) spine from the side (not AP) will show the position of the vertebra e.g. lateral X-ray of the lumbrosacral spine demonstrating the forward shift in the fifth lumbar vertebra on the sacrum (L5-S1 spondylolisthesis).

Xray below shows spondylolysis

 

The xray below shows spongdylolisthesis

Question:
You are on placement in the cardiology department at UHW, the consultant calls you over to listen to a child with a systolic ejection murmur that increases with valsalva. When you remove your stethoscope she asks you:

a) which imaging technique you think she will now use to look at this child's heart and

b) what is at the top of her differential diagnoses list. (bonus points for the measurements she'd use to confirm the diagnosis)
Explanation:
Cardiomyopathies are myocardial disorders in which heart muscle is structurally and functionally abnormal without CAD, hypertension, valvular or congenital heart disease

There are 5 types: hypertrophic, dilated, arrythmogenic, restrictive, unclassified

It is a significant cause of death in the young

 

This patient has Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

The systolic ejection murmur that increases with valsalva is heard because of turbulent flow

By performing the valsalva manoeuvre, less blood is returned to the heart so the chamber is smaller, there is greater obstruction therefore increased turbulence so the murmur is heard louder.

XR and ECG could appear normal so are less reliable than an Echo.

 

Therefore the next step would be to perform an ECHO looking at the septum:LV wall thickness. 

***here come the bonus points***

hypertrophy if the septum: LV wall thickness ration is >1.3. Or septum  >~15

You would also perform genetic tests to confirm (you could also perform a cardiac muscle biopsy where you would find myofibril disarray

Question: Bathilda is told she has neuropathic pain, which of the following definitions best fits neuropathic pain?
OptionA: Chronic pain initiated by nervous system lesions or dysfunction
OptionC: Pain resulting from activity in neural pathways secondary to actual tissue damage or potentially damaging stimuli
OptionD: Pain spontaneously generated from a peripheral nerve
OptionE: Pain that has persisted for over 3 months and is increasing in severity
Explanation:
B= neurogenic pain = Pain generated by a nerve

 

C = Nociceptive pain = Pain resulting from activity in neural pathways secondary to actual tissue damage or potentially damaging stimuli

 

D = Pain spontaneously generated from a peripheral nerve = this is also describing neurogenic pain but peripheral subtype

 

E = Chronic regressive pain = Pain that has persisted for over 3 months and is increasing in severity

 

  • Neurogenic pain is often considered a type of neurpathic pain but is a more specific term as pain is arising from the nerve itself due to an injured or diseased nerve that spontaneously generates pain
  • nerve may be spontaneously generating pain e.g. in diabetic neuropathy or carpel tunnel or emanating from nerve plexus such as brachial plexus.
  • Usually feels like an electric shock

Question:
Albus has suffered a lumbar disc herniation causing unilateral weakness in ankle dorsiflexion, hyporeflexia of the knee jerk reflex and loss of sensation over the medial malleolus. 

At what level is the disc herniation most likely?
Explanation:
Albus is showing unilateral signs of nerve compression/injury which makes makes you think is a posterior-lateral herniation of a spinal nerve root

The signs are indicative of compression of the L4 nerve root

Because the nerve root from a specific level will pass through the superior bony half of the IV foramen from which they exit they are above and protected from a herniation at the level from which they exit.

However, nerve roots passing into the IV foramen immediately (those originating at the level of the herniation) pass directly across the area of herniation i.e. in this diagram the L5 nerve root which originates from the L5 vertebral level will pass into the IV foramen and be protected from the L5-S1 herniation but the S1 nerve that originates at the S1 level will be compressed before it enters the IV foramen

 

From this we can work out that is the L4 nerve root has been compressed there must be a disc herniation at the IV disc above the segment from which is arises so must be at the L3-L4 IV disc

Question: What might a short PR interval most likely be indicative of?
Explanation:
Short PR interval (due to the impulse taking a 'short cut' down the Bundle of Kent) and a characteristic delta wave is seen in WPW.

Long PR interval is associated with heart block.

Question: What is the layer immediately deep to the skin of the anterior abdominal wall?
Explanation:
camper fascia = superficial fatty layer of subcutaneous tissue

Question: A 28 year old lady comes into A&E and is diagnosed with a fracture to her right humeral shaft. She is complaining of loss of sensation over the dorsum of her right hand and clinically appears to have a right wrist drop. What nerve do you suspect has been damaged?
Explanation: Clinically radial nerve injury can be caused by a fracture of the mid shaft of the humerus as the radial nerve runs in the radial groove. This often presents clinically with a wrist drop due to denervation of the extensor muscles and sensory changes over the dorsum of the hand.

Question: Which of a following muscles are innervated by the ulnar nerve in the anterior compartment of the forearm?
OptionA: Flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor carpi radialis
OptionB: Medial half of flexor digitorum profundus and flexor carpi ulnaris
OptionC: Lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus and flexor carpi ulnaris
OptionD: Medial half of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor carpi ulnaris
Explanation:
The anterior compartment of the forearm is innervated by the median nerve except for the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus and flexor carpi ulnaris. 

 

Source - Gray's Anatomy

Question: Which nerve supplies sensation to the lateral 3 1/2 fingers of the palmar aspect of the hand?
Explanation:
The sensation of the hand is provided by the radial, ulnar and median nerves. The dorsum of the hand is supplied by the radial nerve; the lateral 3 1/2 fingers on the palmar aspect are supplied by the median (it can help to remember that this skin includes the skin over the thenar eminence, the muscles of which the median nerve also supplies) and the ulnar nerve provides sensation to the medial 1 1/2 fingers on the palmar aspect.

 

Source: Gray's anatomy

Question: Where is the common origin of the posterior compartment of the forearm muscles and what is inflammation of this known as?
Explanation: The common extensor origin is the lateral epicondyle and this is known as tennis elbow. Inflammation of the common flexor origin of the anterior compartment forearm muscles is the medial epicondyle and inflammation of this is known as golfer's elbow.

Question: Which of the following thyroid function test results would most likely indicate primary hypothyroidism?
Explanation:
The answer is C - In primary hypothyroidism, there is a decreased production of T3 and T4 from the thyroid gland. This means that there is less negative feedback on the anterior pituitary gland, so it releases more TSH leading to high TSH levels.

A would indicate primary hyperthyroidism.

B would indicate secondary hyperthyroidism.

D would indicate secondary hypothyroidism.

E probably indicates something, but i don't know what...

Question: What is released from the zona fasciculata in the adrenal glands?
Explanation:
The answer is B - The zona fasciculata is in the adrenal cortex and releases cortisol.

The zona glomerulosa is in the adrenal cortex and releases aldosterone.

The zona reticularis is in the adrenal cortex and releases DHEA.

The adrenal medulla releases adrenaline and noradrenaline.

Strongbow is a cider-like beverage akin to urine, so it may well be produced by the kidneys, but sadly not the zona fasciculata.

Question:
I am a DNA virus with no envelope. 

I am trasmitted via direct contact, and can lie latent. 

 

I cause genital herpes. 

What virus am I?
Explanation:
The answer is herpes simplex virus 2. 

All of the above viruses are DNA viruses without an envelope, and can display latency (so the first part of the question isn't massively important!)

  • HSV 1 - cold sores
  • HSV 2 - genital herpes
  • HSV 4 - Epstein-Barr i.e. glandular fever
  • HPV (human papilloma virus) - both 6 and 11 cause genital warts

Question:
A mother brings her child to the GP, concerned about a rash on her cheek, as seen below:

 

The GP tells the mother than her child has 'fifth disease'. He cannot remember the causative virus ("it's been 30 years since I studied this!"), and looks to you for help. 

You recall that the virus is part of the II group in the Baltimore classification. What is the virus?
Explanation:
Fifth disease is also known as erythema infectiosum, and is known colloquially as 'slapped cheek syndrome'.

 

It is group II of the Baltimore scheme i.e. it is a SS +ve sense DNA virus. It is caused by parvovirus B19, and is extremely common in childhood (it's called fifth disease because it's one of the common diseases seen in children). 

 

The other viruses are wrong because:

  • Poxviruses - this family contains variola (smallpox), monkeypox and cowpox. Smallpox has been eradicated so it is unlikely to be that; monkeypox causes a more generalised vesicular rash and is very rare; cowpox causes large vesicles on the hands
  • Picornaviruses - this is an RNA virus so isn't the answer given the Baltimore classification! - contains poliovirus, coxsackievirus etc. 
  • Adenoviruses - usually present with acute pharyngitis and most children show signs of previous infection by school age 
  • Papovirus - namely human papilloma virus, which has multiple presentations including warts and cancer

Large 'a' waves are indicative of A) Pulmonary hypertension and also E) Complete heart block. However, the canon 'a' waves are specific for complete heart block.

D) Tricuspid regurgitation has large 'v' waves

The patient was diagnosed with heart failure a few months ago, and would feel tired and breathless even after walking short distances (around 50m). 

 

Which class of heart failure did this patient fit in to?
Explanation:

Class I - No significant limitation, breathless only on marked exercise

Class II - Mild symptoms, slight limitation during ordinary activity - can be broken down into further classes:

(2b) - Breathless on mild exercise

 

Class III - Breathless on minimal exercise (short distances for example, like 20-100m)

 

Class IV - Breathless at rest

Question: Which of these drugs will constrict the pupil and redden the sclera?
Explanation:
Cocaine = local anaesthetic and sympathomimetic. It is a stimulant, an appetite suppressant, and a nonspecific voltage gated sodium channel blocker, which in turn causes it to produce anaesthesia at low doses. Causes pupil dilation (mydriasis), whitening of the sclera and loss of corneal reflex. Cocaine was historically useful as a topical anesthetic in eye and nasal surgery, although it is now predominantly used for nasal and lacrimal duct surgery as has been largely replaced in Western medicine by synthetic local anesthetics such as benzocaine, proparacaine, lignocaine-xylocaine-lidocaine, and tetracaine. 

 

Phenylephrine = selective α1-adrenergic receptor agonist, acts on SNS causing mydriasis (pupil dilation) and peripheral vasoconstriction therefore whitening of the sclera. Used primarily as a decongestant, as an agent to dilate the pupil, and to increase blood pressure. When used as eye drops is often used in combination with tropicamide as a synergist when tropicamide alone is not sufficient

 

Pilocarpine = non-selective mACh receptor agonist (in ParaNS) which acts therapeutically at the muscarinic acetylcholine receptor M3 due to its topical application. Causes pupil constriction (miosis) and pulls open the canal of Schlemm to reduce pressure in the eye and reddens the sclera. Used to treat dry mouth and glaucoma.

  • It acts on a subtype of muscarinic receptor (M3) found on the iris sphincter muscle, causing the muscle to contract -resulting in pupil contraction (miosis).
  • Pilocarpine also acts on the ciliary muscle and causes it to contract.
  • When the ciliary muscle contracts, it opens the trabecular meshwork through increased tension on the scleral spur. This action facilitates the rate that aqueous humor leaves the eye to decrease intraocular pressure.

Tetracaine = a potent local anesthetic mainly used topically in ophthalmology and as an antipruritic, and it has been used in spinal anesthesia. All local anesthetics are membrane stabilizing drugs; they reversibly decrease the rate of depolarization and repolarization of excitable membranes (like nociceptors) acting mainly by inhibiting sodium influx through sodium-specific ion channels in the neuronal cell membrane, in particular voltage-gated sodium channels (Class Ib drugs, also include lidocaine). Reduce choline reuptake and result in loss of corneal (blink) reflex

 

Tropicamide = antimuscarinic drug (mACh receptor antagonist) blocks the ParaNS so produces short acting mydriasis (dilation of the pupil) and cycloplegia (paralysis of the ciliary muscle of the eye, resulting in a loss of accommodation).Because of short action it is typically used during eye examinations such as the dilated fundus examination, but it may also be used before or after eye surgery

Question: Matthew is a 48 year old Caucasian man who was recently started on ramipril for his hypertension. He has come to see you, the GP, today since he has developed a dry cough for the last month. What would you change his medication to and what is a common side effect of this medication?
Explanation:
For hypertension, people aged under 55 years should be put on antihypertensive treatment with an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.

 

 

However ACE inhibitors have a common side effect of a chronic cough. 

 

Therefore second line treatment are angiotensin II receptor blocker such as losartan. Side effects of ARBs are hyperkalaemia, dizziness and headaches. 

 

If the person still had hypertension you could combine ARBs with calcium channel blockers such as amlodipine. 

 

A - Calcium Channel Blockers

B & C - Beta Adrenoreceptor blocker

D - Loop diuretic

E - ARB

 

All the side effects are actual side effects of the drugs taken from Case 15 Coffey lecture and the BNF.

Hypertension treatment guidelines are from the NICE guidelines. https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg127/chapter/1-Guidance#initiating-and-monitoring-antihypertensive-drug-treatment-including-blood-pressure-targets-2

Question: Fenrir undergoes a CT scan which shows an occlusion of one of the major arteries in the brain. He tells you in confidence that he noticed while urinating he had lost all sensation in his genitals and reported urinary incontinence. He has no other sensory deficits. From this information, which artery do you suspect may be occluded?
Explanation:
The image below shows which areas of the brain are supplied by which arteries

Symptoms of anterior cerebral artery syndrome e.g. occlusion: 

  • Hemiparesis or hemiplegia contralaterally, involving primarily the lower limbs and pelvic floor musculature - did not mention whether he had any motor symptoms or not but likely he would have
  • Sensory deficits contralaterally, involving primarily the leg and perineum - although he didn't have and sensory leg deficits he the only symptom he did have was linked to the ACA
  • Apraxia (due to branches to the supplementary motor area and corpus callosum)
  • Disconnection syndrome (due to callosal branches)
  • Anosmia (due to branches of the olfactory bulb and olfactory tract)
  • Urinary incontinence
  • Grasp reflex and or sucking reflex contralaterally (if circle of Willis compromised)

 

 

Signs and symptoms of MCA syndrome:

  • Hemiparesis or hemiplegia of the lower half of the contralateral face
  • Hemiparesis or hemiplegia of the contralateral upper and lower extremities*
  • Sensory loss of the contralateral face, arm and leg*
  • Ataxia of contralateral extremities*
  • Speech impairments/aphasia: Broca's, Wernicke's or Global aphasia as a result of a dominant hemisphere lesion (usually the left brain)
  • Perceptual deficits: hemispatial neglect, anosognosia, apraxia, and spatial disorganization as a result of a non-dominant hemisphere lesion (usually the right brain)
  • Visual disorders: déviation conjuguée, a gaze preference towards the side of the lesion; contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
  • *faciobrachial deficits greater than that of the lower limb

Signs and symptoms of PCA syndrome:

Peripheral Territory Lesions

  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
  • cortical blindness with bilateral involvement of the occipital lobe branches
  • visual agnosia
  • prosopagnosia
  • dyslexia, Anomic aphasia, color naming and discrimination problems
  • memory defect
  • topographic disorientation

Central Territory Lesions

  • central post-stroke (thalamic) pain: spontaneous pain, dysesthesias and sensory impairments
  • involuntary movements: chorea, intention tremor, hemiballismus
  • contralateral hemiplegia
  • Weber’s syndrome: occulomotor nerve palsy
  • Bálint's syndrome: loss of voluntary eye movements optic ataxia, asimultagnosia (inability to understand visual objects)

Internal carotid artery occlusion

  • The internal carotid artery provides blood supply to most of the brain's cortex on one side, including the frontal, parietal and temporal lobes. Only the posterior parts of the brain are supplied by different arteries. The internal carotid divides into two large branches, the middle and anterior cerebral arteries, and symptoms arise from disruption of blood flow to the areas they supply. If this was occluded the symptoms would likely be far more wide spread as both ACA and MCA affected
  • Though occlusion of this major artery can have devastating effects, no part of the brain is dependent solely on the internal carotid from one side so it may be asymptomatic. Each person is born with a different degree of communication between the large blood vessels. Symptoms, therefore, vary widely between different people. 
  • In addition, if occlusion develops gradually, the communicating arteries have more time to grow and to provide more blood to the other side, should it become occluded.
  • Occlusion of the internal carotid can lead to paralysis of the entire opposite half to the face and body. This is mainly due to disruption of blood flow in the middle cerebral artery, one of its two main branches, which leads to a stroke in the main motor area of the cortex.
  • The other large branch, the anterior cerebral artery, supplies blood to the areas that control the feet and lower limbs.
  • Paralysis may be complete or partial, may affect only an leg, or the leg and arm on the opposite side.
  • Occlusion of the carotid is often preceded by temporary blindness in one eye, a condition known as amaurosis fugax
  • Completed stroke can cause loss of half of the visual field or a smaller portion of it.
  • Sensation may be lost on the other side of the body, since the sensory part of the cortex is also supplied by the middle cerebral artery. As with motor symptoms, sensory disturbances can vary from mild to severe.
  • The patient might become completely mute. He might be able to produce speech but it will be unintelligible. His understanding of language might be intact or might be completely lost
  • Personality changes, including passivity and inability to plan ahead, may occur

Basilar artery occlusion

Arises the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (supplying the superior and inferior aspects of the cerebellum)

Acute occlusion of the basilar artery may cause brainstem or thalamic ischaemia or infarction. It is a true neuro-interventional emergency and, if not treated early, brainstem infarction results in rapid deterioration in level of consciousness and ultimately death.

Patients with acute occlusion of the basilar artery will present with sudden and dramatic neurological impairment, the exact characteristics of which will depend on the site of occlusion:

  • sudden death/loss of consciousness

top of the basilar syndrome:

  • visual and oculomotor deficits
  • behavioural abnormalities
  • somnolence, hallucinations and dreamlike behaviour
  • motor dysfunction is often absent

proximal and mid portions of the basilar artery (pons) can result in patients being 'locked in' 

  • complete loss of movement (quadriparesis and lower cranial dysfunction)
  • preserved consciousness
  • preserved ocular movements (often only vertical gaze)

Question: Which of the following is not a function of aldosterone?
Explanation:
Angiotensin II stimulates the release of aldosterone from the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. Aldosterone acts on the distal tubules and causes;

  • Increased sodium reabsorption
  • Increased potassium secretion
  • Increased water retention

Thus, blood pressure and volume are increased. Aldosterone also stimulates the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which has vasoconstrictive properties and increases fluid retention by the kidneys.

Question: A pregnant 40-year-old lady comes in to review her Quadruple screening test. Based on her results, you explain to her that her baby possibly has an open neural tube defect. What result(s) from the Quadruple screening test that show this?

Question: Which of these best describes the mechanism and location of ADH secretion?
OptionA: ADH is made and secreted by hypothalamus directly into the blood
OptionB: ADH is made by the hypothalamus, travels via portal vessles into the pituitary gland where is is released into the blood
OptionC: The hypothalamus produces and packages ADH into vesicles, relays it via neural pathways to anterior pituitary where it is released into the blood
OptionD: The hypothalamus produces and packages ADH into vesicles, relays it via neural pathways to posterior pituitary where it is released into the blood
OptionE: The hypothalamus stimulates neural pathways acting on the anterior pituitary to produce and release ADH into the blood
Explanation:
The anterior pituitary is the the glandular, anterior lobe that communicates with the hypothalamus via neural and vascular pathways, hypothalamus excretes releasing/stimulating hormones which regulate hormone secretion from the anterior pituitary. Neuroendocrine cells in the hypothalamus project axons to the median eminence, at the base of the brain. At this site, these cells can release substances into small blood vessels that travel directly to the anterior pituitary gland (the hypothalamo-hypophysial portal vessels) that will act on the anterior pituitary to release various hormones. 

The posterior pituitary is not glandular as is the anterior pituitary. Instead, it is largely a collection of axonal projections from the hypothalamus that terminate behind the anterior pituitary, and is also a store for the later release of neurohypophysial (oxytocin and vasopressin/ADH) hormones. These hormones are released from neurohypohyseal capillaries, from there they get into the systemic circulation.
The posterior lobe develops as an extension of the hypothalamus. The magnocellular neurosecretory cells of the posterior side possess cell bodies located in the hypothalamus that project axons down the infundibulum to terminals in the posterior pituitary. This simple arrangement differs sharply from that of the adjacent anterior pituitary, which does not develop from the hypothalamus.

 

 

 

I feel the best way to show this is with some nice diagrams.
Tags: Endocrine, Year 1 Revision, Pituitary Gland, Hormones, Hypothalamus

Question: Which of these is made by the kidney?
Explanation:
Aldosterone: secreted by adrenal cortex (zona glomerulosa) and actions lead to increase blood volume by reabsorption of sodium in kidneys (primarily). Also causes Potassium and H+ secretion in kidney.

 

Angiotensinogen: secreted by the liver, causes vasoconstriction and release of aldosterone from adrenal cortex dipsogen.

 

ADH: (Antidiuretic hormone or vasopressin), secreted by posterior pituitary (but made by hypothalamus). Causes retention of water in kidneys, moderate vasoconstriction and release ACTH in anterior pituitary

 

Erythropoietin: secreted by the kidney, stimulates erythrocyte production

 

Glucagon-like peptide-1: secreted by L cells in the ileum, stimulates the adenylyl cyclase pathway, resulting in increased synthesis and release of insulin

Question:
Belinda the Bacterium is gram negative. She is spread faecal-orally, and there is a vaccine available against her, but it is not given as part of the UK vaccination schedule.

 

What species is Belinda?
Explanation:
Belinda is a cholera bacterium. V. cholerae is gram negative, usually spread through water contaminated by faeces and has a (very unpleasant) oral vaccine available if you travel to a high-risk area.

 

C. difficile is gram positive and doesn't have an approved vaccine on the market yet.

H. influenzae is spread by aerosol and is part of the childhood vaccination schedule.

P. aeruginosa is often associated with bronchiectasis, otitis external and UTIs. It is spread by aerosol. There are a few potential vaccines being trialled.

H. pylori has no vaccine available.
Tags: Microbiology, Vaccination, Case 11, Case 9, Public Health

Question: What amino acids are the majority of amine hormones synthesised from?
Explanation:
• Arginine and tyrosine are conditionally essential amino acids, the other three options were are essential amino acids, meaning they cannot be synthesized de novo (from scratch) and therefore must be supplied in its diet.
  • The nine essential amino acids humans cannot synthesize are phenylalanine, valine, threonine, tryptophan, methionine, leucine, isoleucine, lysine, and histidine.
  • Six amino acids are considered conditionally essential in the human diet, meaning their synthesis can be limited under special pathophysiological conditions, such as prematurity in the infant or individuals in severe catabolic distress. These six are arginine, cysteine, glycine, glutamine, proline and tyrosine.
  • Five amino acids are dispensable in humans, meaning they can be synthesized in the body. These five are alanine, aspartic acid, asparagine, glutamic acid and serine
  • The majority of amine hormones are derived from tyrosine but lots are also from tryptophan (e.g. Melatonin)

Question: Which zone of a liver acinus is most prone to damage?
Explanation: Zone 3 cells are furthest away from the hepatic arteries and so are less well oxygenated and more prone to toxin damage and ischaemia.

Question: Having consumed a whole tube of Pringles during a stress-induced binge eating session, a medical student wonders about the various types of papillae found on the tongue. He remembers that the commonest type of papilla does not have any taste buds on its surface. What type of papilla is he thinking about?
Explanation:
The correct answer is A - Filiform papillae are the commonest type and are mainly found on the anterior 2/3 of the tongue. They do not have any taste buds on their surface. Their main function is to act as an abrasive coating, giving the tongue a cleaning and rasping action.

Fungiform papillae are dispersed among the filiform papillae and have taste buds on their surface.

Foliate papillae are also involved in taste and are distributed at the posterior sides of the tongue.

Circumvallate papillae are also involved in taste and are distributed in a V shaped pattern at the back of the tongue.

I made up kiliform...sorry.

Question:
Balthazar the Bacterium is gram negative. He is spread sexually or trans-placentally, and can cause neurological complications.

 

What species is Balthazar?
Explanation:
Balthazar is a syphilis bacterium. T. pallidum is usually transmitted sexually, but can be congenital. Like all bacterial STIs, it is gram negative. As well as rashes, syphilis can cause gummas on various organs, as well as cardiovascular and neurological complications (neurosyphilis).

 

C. trachomatis can be transmitted sexually or during childbirth, and does not cause neuro complications.

Herpesvirus 2 is not a bacterium.

N. gonorrhoeae can be transmitted sexually or during childbirth, and does not cause neuro complications.

H. ducreyi can only be transmitted sexually, and does not cause neuro complications.
Tags: Sexual Health, Microbiology, Neuropathy, Year 1 Revision, Public Health

Question: Which of these hormones exerts negative feedback inhibition on the anterior pituitary following release of GHRH?
Explanation:
Anti-GH I made up

 

Cortisol: is a glucocorticoid steroid hormone, released from the adrenal cortex (zona fasciculata and zona reticularis cells)  and results in stimulation of gluconeogenesis, inhibition of glucose uptake in muscle and adipose tissue, mobilization of amino acids from extrahepatic tissues AND stimulation of fat breakdown in adipose tissue anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive

 

DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone): is an androgen steroid hormone, made/released by testes, ovary and kidney (theca cells of ovary
Leydig cellss of testes). Causes virilization (biological development of sex differences) and is anabolic

 

Secretin: made/released by S cells of the duodenum. Causes secretion of bicarbonate from liver, pancreas and duodenal Brunner's glands, enhances effects of cholecystokinin AND stops production of gastric juice

 

Somatostatin: is made/released by hypothalamus, islets of Langerhans, gastrointestinal system (in this case would be released from hypothalamus). Has many actions including:

  • Inhibit release of GH and TRH from anterior pituitary
  • Suppress release of gastrin, cholecystokinin (CCK), secretin, motilin, vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP), enteroglucagon in gastrointestinal system
  • Lowers rate of gastric emptying
  • Reduces smooth muscle contractions and blood flow within the intestine
  • Inhibit release of insulin from beta cells
  • Inhibit release of glucagon from alpha cells
  • Suppress the exocrine secretory action of pancreas.

Question: You are a GP in rural Wales. The last patient of the day is 62 year old Harry who has not been to the practice for over 20 years. You immediately notice he is jaundiced. He tells you that he has not been feeling well recently and although he has been busy on the farm, he has not been working any harder than usual and has lost over a stone in weight in the last month. You question him further and reluctantly he admits to you that he has had pale, offensive smelling stools. You are concerned and so do some bloods. Harry returns next week and his bloods show an markedly increased ALP. Given the history and bloods, what are you concerned may be wrong with Harry?
Explanation: Post hepatic jaundice is caused by something blocking the flow of bile after it has been conjugated in the liver and causes pale stools as less bile reaches the intestines so less urobilinogen can be produced by the intestinal bacteria and as urobilinogen gives faeces its colour, they are pale. Post hepatic jaundice can be commonly caused by gallstones, pancreatic cancer obstructing the biliary duct or anything causing an obstruction in flow.

Question:
Vicky the Virus contains double-stranded DNA and is enveloped. She can be spread sexually or blood-borne. There is a vaccine available, although it isn't given as part of the standard UK vaccination schedule (Americans get it from birth).

 

What is Vicky?
Explanation:
Vicky is a Hep B virus. It is an enveloped DNA virus. It is transmitted sexually or by contaminated needle. The vaccine is given to at-risk groups in the UK, but apparently American babies receive it at birth.

 

 

Herpes 2 has no vaccine available.

 

Polio is a single-stranded RNA virus and is non-enveloped. It is spread faecal-orally. UK children are vaccinated fully against it, as part of the 5-in-1 at ages 2, 3 and 4 months, the 4-in-1 at preschool age and the 3-in-1 at secondary school age. Hopefully not for much longer...

 

Epstein-Barr virus is spread through saliva, and there is no vaccine available yet.

 

Rabies Virus is a single-stranded RNA virus and is enveloped. It is spread through saliva, usually via an animal bite. There is a vaccine available, which must be given asap after a suspected infection.

 

 

I've given up trying to learn every virus' genome type and envelope-ness, but I have noticed that the only DNA viruses we've come across are the 5 herpesviruses, HPV and Hep B. I hope this helps narrow it down.
Tags: Microbiology, Vaccination, Virology, Case 9, Infectious Disease

Question: Brenda is out for a walk in the snow in her shorts and t-shirt. Because she is cold, she notices her skin turns paler as her blood vessels vasoconstrict to conserve heat. In the process of vasoconstriction in vascular smooth muscle cells, which of the following stimulates phosphorylation of the myosin light chain?
OptionA: Calcium binding to ryanodine receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum
OptionB: IP3 binding to IP3 receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum
OptionC: The binding of calcium to calmodulin, creating calcium-calmodulin complexes
OptionD: Calcium binding to troponin, causing the movement of tropomyosin away from myosin binding sites
Explanation:
In vascular smooth muscle cells, vasoconstriction occurs as follows;

  1. Ligand binds to a G protein-coupled receptor.
  2. A chemical cascade occurs, culminating in the formation of IP3.
  3. IP3 binds to IP3 receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  4. Calcium is released from the SR, and binds to calmodulin creating calcium-calmodulin complexes.
  5. This binding activates MLCK, which phosphorylates the myosin chain.
  6. This will enable myosin crossbridges to bind to actin and contraction to occur, bringing about vasoconstriction.

Options A and D occur in cardiomyocytes, not in vascular smooth muscle. Smooth muscle doesn't contain a troponin complex.

 

Source: MC (the king daddy) lecture in case 15 'drugs used to treat cardiac failure'
Tags: Case 15, Year 1 Revision, Heart, Heart failure, year 1

Question: You go to see your best friend and her daughter. Her daughter Millie is able to pull herself up to standing using the nearby table and waves at you when you come in. You give her a present you bought for her and she transfers it from one hand to the other. How old is Millie?
Explanation:
At 9 months old a normally developing infant should:

 

  • be able to crawl 
  • Pull to standing with support
  • Transfer objects from hand to hand 
  • Wave/clap

Source - development lecture

Question:
Voldemort the Virus is a single-stranded, positive sense, enveloped RNA virus. He is spread by aerosol and can cause nasty complications to a baby if its mother contracts the virus while pregnant. There is a vaccine available, and it forms part of the regular UK childhood vaccination schedule.

 

What is Voldemort?
Explanation:
Voldemort is a rubella virus. It is a SS +ve RNA enveloped virus. It is spread by aerosol, and can cause congenital rubella syndrome if the mother contracts it while pregnant - often resulting in deafness and other disabilities. The MMR vaccine is given at 1 year and preschool ages.

 

 

Rotavirus is a double-stranded and non-enveloped RNA virus. It is transmitted faecal-orally, and you'll almost certainly be immune by childbearing age. Babies are vaccinated at 2 and 3 months.

 

VZV is a DNA virus. It is transmitted by aerosol, and can cause problems when contracted in utero, but the vaccine is not given as part of the UK childhood vaccination schedule (it is however offered to non-immune pregnant women).

 

CMV is a DNA virus. It is transmitted sexually and in saliva, and can also cause problems to foetuses. There is no vaccine available.

 

Hepatitis C is a single-stranded positive sense enveloped RNA virus. But, it is transmitted through contaminated needles and has no vaccine available.
Tags: Microbiology, Vaccination, Virology, Case 9, Infectious Disease

Question:
Hagrid, a 24 year old bushy-bearded man, comes to see you concerned about his size, he is at least 8 feat tall and has a large face, hands and feet. He says as long as he can remember he has always been big for his size, towering over his average height father in his early teens.

He had always just put it down to being 'big boned' but is now concerned it might be preventing it him from getting a girlfriend and affected his career as a teacher. What do you suspect may be the reason for Hagrid's size?
Explanation:
What is gigantism?

  • A condition characterized by excessive growth and height significantly above average. In humans, this condition is caused by over-production of growth hormone in childhood resulting in persons between 2.13 m (7 feet or 84 inches) and 2.74 m (9 feet or 108 inches) in height.
  • If there is hypersecretion of GH  causing increased growth of soft tissues and bone before the fusion of the epiphyses this is called gigantism (often in children)
  • If there is hypersecretion of GH causing increased growth after the fusion of the epiphyses in adults, this is acromegaly and has more associated symptoms
  • Complete fusion in females occurs as early as 12 years and is usually complete by 16 years in girls. Complete fusion in males can occur as early as 14 years and is usually complete by age 19. Therefore, Hagrid was already excessively tall before this fusion took place so he has gigantism not acromegaly
  • It causes growth of the hands, face, and feet.

What Causes Gigantism?
A pituitary gland tumor is almost always the cause of gigantism. The pea-sized pituitary gland—located at the base of your brain—makes hormones that control many functions in your body. Some tasks managed by the gland include temperature control, sexual development, growth metabolism, and urine production. When a tumor grows on the pituitary gland, the gland makes more growth hormone than the body needs. Other less common causes of gigantism may include:

  • McCune-Albright syndrome: a disease that causes abnormal growth in bone tissue, patches of light-brown skin, and gland abnormalities
  • Carney complex: an inherited condition that causes non-cancerous tumors on the connective tissue, cancerous or non-cancerous endocrine tumors, and spots of darker skin
  • multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1: an inherited disorder that causes tumors in the pituitary gland, pancreas, or parathyroid glands
  • neurofibromatosis: an inherited disorder that causes tumors in the nervous system

Acromegaly: is a syndrome that results when the anterior pituitary gland produces excess growth hormone (GH) after epiphyseal plate closure at puberty. A number of disorders may increase the pituitary's GH output, although most commonly it involves a tumor called pituitary adenoma, derived from a distinct type of cell (somatotrophs). Acromegaly most commonly affects adults in middle age, and can result in severe disfigurement, complicating conditions, and premature death if unchecked. Because of its pathogenesis and slow progression, the disease is hard to diagnose in the early stages and is frequently missed for years until changes in external features, especially of the face, become noticeable. Some of the feature include:

  • Soft tissue swelling visibly resulting in enlargement of the hands, feet, nose, lips and ears, and a general thickening of the skin.
  • Soft tissue swelling of internal organs, notably the heart with attendant weakening of its muscularity, and the kidneys, also the vocal cords resulting in a characteristic thick, deep voice and slowing of speech
  • Generalized expansion of the skull at the fontanelle
  • Pronounced brow protrusion, often with ocular distension (frontal bossing)
  • Pronounced lower jaw protrusion (prognathism) with attendant macroglossia (enlargement of the tongue) and teeth spacing
  • Hypertrichosis, hyperpigmentation, and hyperhidrosis may occur in these patients
  • Acrochordon (skin tags)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome

 

Klinefelter syndrome also known as 47,XXY or XXY, is the set of symptoms that result from two or more X chromosome in males. The primary feature is sterility. Often symptoms may be subtle and many people do not realize they are affected. Sometimes symptoms are more prominent and may include weaker muscles, greater height, poor coordination, less body hair, smaller genitals, breast growth, and less interest in sex. - although Hagrid is tall he also has a large beard and big hands/face/feet which wouldn't be expected in Klinefleter's

 

Precocious puberty: is puberty occurring at an unusually early age. In most cases, the process is normal in every respect except the unusually early age, and simply represents a variation of normal development. In a minority of children, the early development is triggered by a disease such as a tumor or injury of the brain. Even when there is no disease, unusually early puberty can have adverse effects on social behavior and psychological development, can reduce adult height potential, and may shift some lifelong health risks. - this is unlikely as although he did grow very large very early this would likely reduce his maximum height reached rather than increase it

 

WAIT! Why isn't he just a giant?!

  • A giant is a very large humanoid which can potentially grow to approximately twenty five feet tall and appear to be a large human. (this Hagrid wouldn't be tall enough to qualify!)
  • Some may appear as large and hairy humanoids, while others resemble humongous-sized people, and some may even have bestial features (i.e. protuding sharp molars). None of the others features were reported
  • A powerful and nearly unstoppable race, giants generally aggregate themselves in tribes since their numbers have greatly dwindled in recent centuries. You wouldn't be able to have a sensible conversation with a giant and they wouldn't be able to hold down a teaching job
  • Half-giants are beings with some, but not a total, amount of giant heritage or blood, as well as part human blood. For instance, a human might have a Giant mother and a wizard father or vice versa. However, the logistics of a normal-sized witch bearing a half-giant baby are difficult if not impossible to imagine, let alone the logistics of this sort of conception.
  • The real Hagrid was at least 11ft and 6inches, vastly taller than the tallest ever human even as a half giant so this can likely be ruled out too!
Tags: Superheroes with issues, Endocrine, Year 1 Revision, Hormones, year 1

Question: Brian comes to see you, livid. He is on Ramipril for his heart failure, but says his life is being made a misery by a never-ending dry cough. He's had enough, and before things get to aggressive you decide to put him on Candesartan. You think Candesartan is great, not only because is an angiotensin II receptor antagonist, but because of another reason too. However, with all Brian's shenanigans you've forgotten the other reason - which of the following is it?
OptionA: Forces angiotensin II to bind to AT1R receptors, which causes vasodilation
OptionB: Forces angiotensin II to bind to AT2R receptors, which causes vasodilation
OptionC: Forces angiotensin II to bind to AT3R receptors, which causes vasodilation
OptionD: Forces angiotensin II to bind to AT2R receptors, which causes vasoconstriction
OptionE: Forces angiotensin II to bind to AT3R receptors, which causes vasoconstriction
Explanation: Angiotensin II receptor blockers are highly selective for AT1R, so ARBs can shift the balance of which receptors angiotensin II binds to. If all the AT1R receptors are occupied by ARBs then angiotensin II has to bind to AT2R instead. Activation of AT2R tends to cause opposing effects to the activation of AT1R receptors, including vasodilation.

Question: When does blood flow through the right coronary artery?
Explanation:
The right ventricle is thinner walled so wall tension is not usually high enough to prevent flow generated by LV contraction. This means that right coronary flow is biphasic occurring in systole AND diastole

 

LCA flow is a predominantly diastolic phenomenon. This is because the thick wall of the LV creates systolic tension that myocardial blood flow is inhibited by.

 

(this was taken from one of our small groups in year 1 - i can remember specifically which one, maybe poiseuilles law featured?)

Question: In the alternative pathway, which complement protein acts as C3 convertase?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C - C3bBb acts as C3 convertase it the alternative pathway.It has two main functions:

It cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b.

It can also be combined with C3b to form C3bBb3b (C5 convertase). C5 convertase then cleaves C5 into C5a and C5b, which goes on to form the membrane attack complex.

• There is no head of the corpus callosum but the other four parts do exist and should be identifiable in saggital plane
  • The visual cortex lies in the occipital cortex therefore there are many axons in the posterior swelling of the corpus callosum (the splenium) connecting right and left visual inputs
  • Rostrum mean front/birds beak and this is what this part looks like
  • Genu = knee
  • Splenium = swollen 
  • On the diagram below they have labelled what we were taught as the body as the trunk but these are the same thing!

Question:
Arnold has come to your surgery because he has pain and hypersensitivity in a patch of skin on his right leg. He describes the pain as a 'burning sensation', which is aggravated when he has a bath.

 

You diagnose Arnold with meralgia paraesthetica. Where is the area of pain on Arnold's leg?
Explanation:
The symptoms described above are the typical symptoms of meralgia paraesthetica, which is the compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve where it passes through the inguinal ligament.

 

     

 

Source: Lower Limb Anatomy Practical from Case 17

Question: Dominique Hamton is fasting, in hopes of losing some of her baby fat and getting that summer body she's always dreamed of. Her body is a great working machine and has processes in places to keep gut motility working despite the lack of mechanical stimuli. There is an increase in the sensitivity of smooth muscle in the small intestine, due to intrinsic nervous activity, as a response to fasting resulting in what reflex?
OptionA: the shortening and elongating of individual villi
Explanation:
the migrating motility complex occurs during fasting and when there is no mechanical stimuli, to flush out the gut and prevent stasis. This happens every 1/2 an hour and takes two hours. They are all part of the normal post prandial movement in the small intestine and the whole transit time is 4 hours. 

Source: TJ's plenary case 10

Question: Which of the following is NOT true about ADH?
OptionB: Increases water resorption from the distal tubule
OptionC: Increases sodium resorption from the loop of henle.
Explanation:
Functions of ADH include (but are not limited to)

  • water resorption in the distal tubule
  • vasoconstriction
  • sodium resportion for the loop of henle. 

Functions of Aldosterone 

  • water and sodium resorption in the distal tubule
  • increased potassium excretion
  • hypertension.

Question: An ECG has just been shoved in your face by the consultant you are following, they ask you to summarise the ECG back to them. In the panic you feel your heart beat and it seems irregularly irregular. You reckon if they'd handed you a print out of your ECG at that very moment it would also have no p waves. What are you experiencing?
Explanation:
AF is known for being irregularly irregular

 

ECG of atrial flutter would show saw toothed shapes

 

If R is far from P then you have a first degree

 

torsades de pointes is all over the place

 

for bundle branch block you would look at V1 and V6: 

  • RBBB: late activation of right ventricle therefore deep S waves in I,V6...tall R wave in V1
  • LBBB: deep S waves in V1......tall R waves in I and V6

A good way to remember is ACE:

  • Cough

Hypotension is obvious. 

 

The dry cough is caused by increased bradykinin. Bradykinin is usually broken down by Angiotensin II.

Carotid sinus baroreceptors are innervated by which cranial nerve that synapses in the Nucleus tractus solitarius?
Explanation:
Carotid BRs are innervated by the sinus nerve of Hering which is a branch of the GLOSSOPHARYNGEAL

 

aortic BRs are innervated by the aortic nerve which combines with vagus on its way up to the NTS. these are less sensitive than the carotids as they have a higher threshold

Question: Rabies and vCJD are examples of "diseases and infections which are transmitted naturally between vertebrate animals and man." What is the term more commonly given to these diseases?
Explanation:
Zoonoses are "diseases and infections which are transmitted naturally between vertebrate animals and man" - WHO

Vector borne diseases require an animal host to transmit the disease /infection e.g. the mosquito in malaria.

Vehicle borne diseases require an object to carry the disease causing organism e.g. fomites, air droplets etc.

A man was diagnosed with heart failure a year and a half ago. 

 

He comes in to your GP clinic describing gynaecomastia. 

 

What medication is likely to have caused this?
Explanation:
Spironolactone acts as an Androgen Receptor Antagonist causing:

Gynaecomastia and sexual dysfunction in men

Menstrual irregularities and breast enlargement and tenderness in women. 

 

Ramipril is an ACE-i

Losartan is an ARB

Furosemide is a loop diuretic

Question: Which of the following is not a function of Angiotensin II
Explanation:
Bradykinin break down is facilitated by ACE itself. 

Excess bradykinin causes the dry cough seen with ACE inhibitors

It is not present with ARBs because ACE continues to function normally. 

 

Other functions of Angiotensin II include:

  • H+ secretion (with the sodium retention)
  • release of ADH from the posterior pituitary gland
Tags: Case 15, Pharmacology, Physiology, Heart, Heart failure

Question: Which ribs can be classed as 'false' ribs?
Explanation:
The answer is B - The 'false' ribs are ribs 8, 9 and 10 as they are not directly connected to the sternum.

Ribs 11 and 12 are classed as 'floating' ribs as they only articulate anteriorly.

1-7 are 'true' ribs.

1, 2 and 10-12 are atypical ribs.

Question: This is a histological image of a late Primary Follicle. To which of these structures is the black arrow pointing?
Explanation:
antrum - The open space or chamber, filled with a clear watery fluid, which develops as the primary ovarian follicle continues to grow by mitotic divisions of the granulosa, i.e., follicular, cells; the presence of an antrum which occupies less than half of the volume of the follicle (a somewhat arbitrary distinction) defines the attainment of the stage of secondary follicle; a larger antrum defines the mature follicle = vesicular follicle = Graafian follicle.

corona radiata - The single layer of low columnar granulosa, i.e., follicular, cells of the secondary and vesicular ovarian follicles which surround and anchor the the diploid primary oocyte to the inner follicular wall.

corpus albicans - The pale shrunken remnant of a corpus luteum in the cortex of the ovary, consisting primarily of dense fibrous connective tissue which develops at the end of a menstrual cycle or a pregnancy.

granulosa cells - The lining cells of all ovarian follicles except the primordial follicle, and of the corpus luteum; the granularity of the cytoplasm of these follicular cells is due to the increase in the production and secretion of estrogens and progesterone; their endocrine activity is regulated by FSH from the anterior pituitary.

zona pellucida - The thick, solid, transparent outer membrane of glycoproteins. immediately external to the oocyte's cell membrane, separating the developing oocyte from the granulosa, i.e., follicular, cells of the primary, secondary, and vesicular follicles (the cells which will form the corona radiata); after ovulation, it forms a physical barrier through which sperm must penetrate in order to achieve fertilization; the acrosomal proteolytic enzymes of the sperm head can digest the glycoproteins of the zona pellucida.

 

 

See this link - http://apbrwww5.apsu.edu/thompsonj/Anatomy%20&%20Physiology/2020/2020%20Exam%20Reviews/Exam%205/CH27%20Ovarian%20Follicles.htm

Question: Which of these statements about central nervous system cells is true?
OptionA: Grey matter consists of mainly neuronal axons
OptionB: Grey matter contains axons the are always non-myelinated
OptionC: Most of the neurones in the CNS are myelinated
OptionD: White matter mainly contains glial cells and non-myelinated neuronal axons
OptionE: White matter looks dark than grey matter using Weigert stain
Explanation:
• Most neurones in the CNS are un-myelinated
  • Grey matter is a major component of the CNS and consists of neuronal cells bodies, neurophil (dendrites, myelinated and non-mylinated axons), glial cells (astroglia and oligodendrocytes) and capillaries
  • Grey matter contains numerous cell bodies and relatively few myelinated axons (but there are some!) 
  • White matter contains mostly glial cells and myelinated axons that transmit signals from one region of the cerebrum to another and between cerebrum and lower brain centres
  • Using weigert stain white matter looks dark/black and grey matter looks much paler (brownish-yellow) as this stains lipid so will mainly stain the myeline sheaths in the white matter so this takes up much more stain that grey matter

Question: Which two structures does the internal capsule separate/pass between if you are looking at a midline coronal section?
Explanation:
• Depending on exactly where the coronal section has been taken may have an influence over which structures are being separated by the internal capsule, however I tried to make sure there was not two answers that could be correct in either of the positions above (as caudate and thalamus would both be on same side of internal capsule)
  • There are two major areas of white matter in the brain, one being the corpus callosum connecting the two cerebral hemispheres and the other being the internal capsule containing many tracts and connecting the cortical tracts of the cortex to other parts of the brain e.g. brainstem and spinal cord. 
  • Internal capsule carries info past basal ganglia (caudate nucleus and putamen, the globus pallidus, the substantia nigra, the nucleus accumbens, and the subthalamic nucleus), separating the caudate (and thalamus) from the lentiform nucleus
  • There are various groupings used by different books etc the striatum = caudate nucleus and putamen
  • The lentiform nucleus = the putamen and globus pallidus (these may be shown individually as in second diagram above)
  • The internal capsule contains both ascending and descending axons including those of the corticospinal tract

Question: Mr Riddle comes to see you after having been diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS) after having new onset blurred vision with no pathologies of the actual eye itself. He is asking you about the details of his condition and wants to know which cells are causing his disease. What will you tell him?
Explanation:
• While it may be seem like the neurones that cause this disease they are actually the victims of this de-myelinating disease
  • MS is caused by oligodendrocytes becoming damaged and no longer myelinating and maintain the myelination of the neurones in the nervous system so action potentials and conduction is interrupted 
  • One of the first signs is often blurred vision but when investigated eyesight is not the problem but the problem is with the pathways/coordination between eyes
Tags: Nerves, Neurology, Neuroscience, Year 1 Revision, Case 6

Question:
Amiodarone is a potassium channel blocker used to treat certain arrhythmias.

Which Vaughn Williams Class is it?
Explanation:
I = Sodium channel blocker: flecainide 

II = Beta Blocker

III - correct! 

IV - Calcium channel blocker: Diltiazem 

V - others, in particular Adenosine
Tags: Case 13, Pharmacology, Case 17, Heart, Heart Arrhythmias

Question: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of Flecainide?
OptionA: Increases the refractory period. Slows repolarisation by blocking voltage-gated potassium channels.
OptionB: Reduces the slope of phase 4 by preventing the actions of catecholeamines in the heart.
OptionC: Prevents depolarisation from bypassing the AVN down alternative pathways, by blocking sodium channels.
OptionD: Reduces the speed and strength of contraction as well as the conduction speed of cardiac myocytes. This is by blocking slow calcium channels.
OptionE:
Slows heart rate by causing transient AVN block. 

Activates A1 receptors causing hyperpolarisation by potassium efflux.
Explanation:
A, Class III, potassium channel blockers, amiodarone 

B Class II, beta blockers

C Correct, Class I, sodium channel blockers

D Class IV, calcium channel blockers, diltaizem

E class V, adenosine

Question: Your patient has been diagnosed with Crigler Najjar syndrome a form of hepatic jaundice with  mild deficiency of conjugating enzyme. Which of these best describes their Liver function test results?

increased urine conjugated bilirubin

increased AST and ALT
OptionB:
Increased plasma unconjugated bilirubin

increased urine conjugated bilirubin

increased AST and ALT

Normal GGP
OptionC:
Increased plasma unconjugated bilirubin

normal plasma conjugated bilirubin

urinary urinobilinogen present

decreased haemoglobin
OptionD:
increased plasma conjugated bilirubin

increased urine conjugated bilirubin

disproportionately increased ALP

disproportionately increased GGT
OptionE:
Increased plasma unconjugated bilirubin

no urine conjugated bilirubin

increased AST and ALT

slightly increased GGT
Explanation:
E- CORRRECT. this syndrome is a form of hepatic unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia

 

A- describes hepatic conjugated hyperbilirubineamia. Causes include viral hepatitis, cirrhosis and Dubin-johnson disease

B- made this up. Don't know what it would mean!

C- this is pre hepatic unconjugated bilirubineamia. causes include haemolysis (Rh incompatibility, autoimmune or drug induced haemolytic anaemia, thalaessemia, sickle cell diseae)

D-this is post hepatic conjugated hyperbilirubinaemia which occurs when the exit route is blocked causes include gall stones, biliary stricture, cancer, primary biliary cirrhosis, all of which lead to obstructive jaundice. bilirubin in urine  causes it to be dark whilst stools may be pale due to lack of conjugated bilirubin.

Question: A lesion to the left optic tract would lead to which of the following pathologies?
OptionB: Complete loss of vision in the left eye
Explanation:
• Lesions of the retina or partial lesion of optic nerve before the optic chiasm will lead to areas of no vision on the ipsilateral side (a central/paracentral scotoma)
  • Lesions spanning the whole optic nerve, before the optic chiasm, will lead to complete loss of vision in one (the ipsilateral) eye = monoocular field loss
  • Lesions in the optic chiasm itself which overlies the pituitary gland and is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery so lesion can be caused by a pituitary tumour or occlusion of the ACA. These lesions lead to compression of the chiasm preventing crossing of fibres that would usually occur here, resulting in bilateral loss of temporal vision = bitemporal hemianopia (meaning half without vision). If not irreversibly damaged surgery to remove a tumour may largely restore vision 
  • If there is a lesion in the optic tract or optic radiation (posterior to the optic chiasm) will affect/lose same half of vision in both eyes = homonymous hemianopia but because the lesion is on the left the loss of vision in the back of the eye is the left of both eyes but because the visual fields cross over (as you can see from colour coding in second diagram) the back left of the eye is responsible for vision of the right visual field. Therefore you get contralateral homonymous hemianopia to the side of the lesion. This may be an entire hemifield (half of vision) or smaller segment (describe the quadrant e.g superior) depending on how much of the tract/radiation is damaged
  • Can get macular sparing with the homonymous hemianopia (explained above) due to blockage/haemorrhage in the middle cerebral artery supplying all but the inner edge of the optic radiation (this is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery as are very medial, see diagram below)
  • Blow to the back of the head onto a hard surface may damage exposed visual cortex which gets information from central (macular) region of vision. One or both visual fields may be affected = foveal scotoma. The primary visual cortex here is also supplied by the posterior cerebral artery so occlusion of this artery may have similar effects

Question: Which drug used to treat type 2 diabetes works by DIRECTLY inhibiting potassium channels in the beta islet cells?
Explanation:
A) metformin is a biguanide. These work by increasing insulin senstivity, downregulating hepatic gluconeogenesis and glycolysis and reduce digestion and absorption speed of glucose. It does this by inhibiting PEPCK. 

 

B) Correct! Normally, at a high glucose concentration, glucose diffuses into Beta islet cells through GLUT 2 transporters. It is then converted to Glucose 6 phosophate by glucose kinase and enters the kreb's cycle within the mitochondria. The ATP produced goes to CLOSE potassium channels. The increased concentration of potassium in the cells causes depolarisation and calcium entry which causes insulin secretion by exocytosis of vesicles.

Glicazide binds to these potassium channels and closes them.

 

 

C) Gliptins work by inhibiting the DDP4 enzyme which breaks down incretins. Incretins such as GLP1 and GIP block the potassium channels mentioned above which causes insulin secretion by the same mechanism. 

 

D) Glitazones bind to PPAR gamma. They form a complex which acts as a transcription factor for GLUT4 which is upregulated. This allows for faster uptake of glucose, particularly in adipocytes where lipogenesis and fatty acid uptake also occurs. 

 

E) Acarbose is a man-made oligosaccharide which competitively inhibits alpha-glycosidase enzymes. This slows and even prevents the breakdown of disaccharides so fewer glucose molecules are produced and absorbed.

Question:
Scenario
A 24 year old woman gives birth to a boy who is diagnosed with Down syndrome immediately after birth. She had blood screening tests during the 2nd trimester of pregnancy and had been advised that she was at low risk of having a child with Down syndrome. Her husband, who is aged 52, is very upset.  What is the likely explanation?
OptionA: An error in the laboratory measurements for the screening test
OptionC: The fathers age leads to a significantly greater risk of Down syndrome
OptionD: Screening tests have a recognised false negative rate
OptionE: The antenatal team made a clinical error and should have carried out an amniocentesis
Explanation:
Answer D is correct

In this screening test for Down syndrome low risk is usually defined as less than 1 in 150 so this does not exclude the possibility of Down syndrome.

Other diagnostic tests have a lower false negative rate (ie do not miss a case) such as amniocentesis with foetal DNA testing but carry risks of miscarriage and are much more expensive so are not justified in all pregnancies.

Question: A fasting plasma glucose of 6.5 mmol/L in a 57 year old is most likely an indication of what?
Explanation:
The fasting blood glucose level required for the diagnosis of diabetes is >7mmol/l, however 6.5mmol/l is higher than is expected in a person who is not insulin resistant and has normal glucose tolerance.

Diabetes insipidus does not cause hyperglycaemia.

Question:
A 22 year old women presents to her GP with palpitations and reports feeling unusually tired for the past few weeks. 

On examination she looks pale, and you note pallor in the lower palpebral conductiva. 

 

A blood test reveals:

Hb: 97  g/l         (nr 115-145 g/l)

Mean Corpuscular Volume: 60 fl  (nr 80-99fl)

Ferritin: 5        (nr 18-160ng/l)

B12: 171          (nr 150-400x9/l)

Folate: 4.7        (nr 4.5-11 ng/ml)

 

What type of anaemia is she likely to have?
Explanation:
Microcytic: Low MVC

Normocytic: normal MVC

Macrocytic: high MVC

 

Low ferritin--> iron stores are low. Iron deficiency anaemia is microcytic,

Macrocytic--> B12 or Folate deficiency 

Normocytic: low Hb with normal MVC may indicate anaemia of chronic disease.

Question: 18 year old gymnast accompanied by her rugby lad of a boyfriend previously diagnosed with a pars defect attends clinic complaining of severe back pain after a risky back-flip. The doctor suspects that she has a forward displacement of the L5 vertebra. What is she diagnosed with?
Explanation:
She has been diagnosed previously with spondylolysis (pars defect) which is common in young athletes and hyperextension activities. This can predispose to spondylolisthesis where the defect leads to forward displacement of the vertebra.

She has no symptoms of ankylosing spondylitis. 

She is too young to have degenerative spondylolisthesis.

There is nothing to suggest she has TB so can't infer Pott's disease from the info provided.

Question: During pregnancy, what is the drug syntocinon most commonly used for?
Explanation: Syntocinon or syntometrine is injected into the upper thigh of the mother. Because the umbilical cord is clamped, the drug doesn't affect the baby's circulation. It contains oxytocin, which helps pull the placenta away from the uterine wall. The delivery of the placenta can take between 5 minutes to an hour.
